site_title: John Kerry cuts short Europe trip after breaking leg in bike crash
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry broke his right femur in a cycling accident in France's French Alps and will return to the US for treatment, cutting short a European trip. Kerry, 71, had been holding talks in Switzerland on the Iran nuclear crisis when the accident occurred near Chamonix. He will seek treatment at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

images.alt_text: KEEN CYCLIST: During breaks from negotiations, Mr Kerry has often headed out of his hotel to ride his bike - which he usually brings along on his foreign missions.

site_title: Understanding the table
summary: A table illustrates the correlation between various investment indices, with a high correlation indicating assets move together, a low correlation implying they move in tandem but not equally, and a negative correlation indicating opposite movements. Investors prefer diversified portfolios with low or negative correlations to minimize losses when one asset class declines. The table includes the S&P 500, MSCI World, and bond indices, with other indices serving as benchmarks for alternative assets.

images.alt_text: THE ALTERNATIVE ROUTE: Other than the S&P 500, the MSCI World and the two bond indices, the remaining indices are considered benchmarks to measure the performance of alternative assets.

site_title: Faster than China? India's road, rail drive could lay doubts to rest
summary: India's government has increased spending on roads and rail infrastructure, aiming to boost economic growth and potentially surpass China. Prime Minister Narendra Modi's reformist government has doubled spending allocations for roads and bridges and raised the rail budget by a third. Analysts expect the infrastructure spending to have a positive impact on the economy, with growth potentially increasing by over one percentage point this year. However, the government faces challenges in securing private sector funding and implementing a clear policy on tolls to attract investors.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's reformist, but hard-up government has begun a splurge on road and rail building that analysts say could remove doubts over whether economic growth in India really is overtaking China.

site_title: German business lobby groups call for Russia's inclusion in G-7 meeting
summary: German business lobby groups are calling for Russia's inclusion in the G-7 summit, citing the potential for Russia's presence to contribute to solving crises. The G-7 leaders held a summit without Russian President Vladimir Putin last year due to Russia's annexation of Ukraine's Crimea region. With ongoing fighting in eastern Ukraine, the exclusion has continued for a second year.

site_title: Indonesia manufacturing activity contracts for 8th month in May: survey
summary: Indonesia's manufacturing activity contracted for the 8th straight month in May, according to a private survey, with output, new orders, and employment all weak. The HSBC Markit PMI edged up to 47.1, still below 50, as producers trimmed purchases and shed workers due to deteriorating economic conditions. The contraction raises pressure on policymakers to stimulate growth, with May's new export orders index contracting to 40.2, its lowest figure since 2011.

site_title: Australia manufacturing activity expands in May
summary: Australian manufacturing activity expanded in May for the first time in six months, according to the Australian Industry Group's performance of manufacturing index (PMI). The index rose 4.3 points to 52.3, surpassing the 50 threshold. Exports, production, new orders, and employment all grew, with exports reaching a 17-year high. The expansion is seen as a positive sign for the sector, which has been in recession for almost five years.

site_title: Japan May final manufacturing PMI 50.9, back in expansion after rocky April
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded in May for the first time in two months, with the Markit/JMMA final PMI rising to 50.9, above the 50 threshold separating contraction from expansion. New orders and output rose, suggesting domestic demand is strengthening. This positive sign is crucial for the economy, as an expanding manufacturing sector could lead to higher growth and support the Bank of Japan's 2% inflation target. The development comes after Japan's economy faltered in April, with household spending slumping and consumer inflation remaining flat.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.58% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.58% lower on Monday, marking the end of an 11-day winning streak. The Nikkei 225 index fell 118.61 points to 20,444.54. This follows modest drops on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.64% and the S&P 500 shed 0.63%. The market was cautious ahead of Greece's bailout talks, with the dollar strengthening to 124.17 yen. The weak yen benefits Japanese exporters, but the euro slipped to $1.0965.

site_title: China new home prices increase in May: survey
summary: China's new home prices increased 0.5% month-over-month in May, the first rise in four months, according to a survey by the China Index Academy. The average price rose to 10,569 yuan (S$2,293) per square meter. This marks a stronger increase than a 0.21% gain in January. Authorities have been supporting the property market to boost the economy, which has been in the doldrums for over a year. The central bank has cut interest rates and eased mortgage policies to stimulate the industry.

images.alt_text: Sales representatives talk to potential buyers in front of a model of a residential complex at a real estate exhibition in Wuhan, Hubei province. China's new home prices increased in May for the first time in four months, a survey showed Monday, as effects of Beijing's loosening policies to boost the market kick in.

site_title: Proposal to modify plants revives GMO debate
summary: A group of scientists at the University of Copenhagen proposes "rewilding" as a process to give back to plants genes that were bred out of them, using modern molecular biology techniques. This method, which involves precision breeding, aims to promote drought resistance and other desirable traits in plants. However, the proposal has sparked debate, with some experts arguing that rewilding is not a viable concept, as proponents of GMO-free foods may not accept it. The researchers suggest that rewilding could be labelled as non-GMO in the US, but not in Europe, where GMO is defined by the process, not the product.

site_title: Eyeing outbound Asian real estate capital
summary: Asian investors are increasingly eyeing European real estate, with gateway cities such as France, Germany, and Italy becoming popular due to their transparent and regulated markets. According to ING Real Estate Finance, Asian capital made up 6.1% of European commercial real estate investments in 2013, growing to 6.5% in 2014. Investors are seeking high-grade assets with stable yields, and ING manages a book of €25 billion in real estate finance in Europe and Asia-Pacific. German cities like Berlin and Frankfurt are favored due to their stable returns, and ING is working to improve its platforms to cater to the growing demand.

site_title: Man shot dead by police near Shangri-La hotel
summary: A 34-year-old Singaporean driver was shot dead by police after speeding through barricades at a police checkpoint near the Shangri-La hotel. The incident occurred on Sunday morning when the driver accelerated despite warnings to stop, causing a red Subaru Impreza to crash through barricades. Two other men, aged 26 and 31, were detained and found to have controlled drugs and a drug-taking utensil in the vehicle. Preliminary investigations indicate the incident was isolated and related to drugs, with security measures increased in the area.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
A 34-year-old Singaporean driver was shot dead while two other men have been detained after an incident in the vicinity of the Shangri-La hotel on Sunday morning.

site_title: Shangri-la Hotel incident: Police identify man shot dead and two arrested
summary: The Singapore Police Force identified a 34-year-old Singaporean, Mohamed Taufik Bin Zahar, as the driver shot dead in a car crash near the Shangri-la Hotel during a high-level security summit. Two individuals were arrested in connection with the incident. The crash occurred early on May 31, and the investigation is ongoing.

site_title: Fed's meetings getting more complicated, says new research
summary: The Federal Reserve's FOMC meetings have become more uncertain and complicated since the financial crisis, according to new research. FOMC minutes have increased in length, with a rise in the number of "counting words" and a decrease in consensual statements. This suggests a greater diversity of viewpoints among participants. Fed board economists attribute this to the use of non-traditional monetary policies post-crisis, which were less familiar and led to more debate among policymakers.

site_title: Solar Impulse takes off for six-day, six-night Pacific flight
summary: The Solar Impulse 2 aircraft took off from Nanjing, China, on a six-day, six-night flight over the Pacific Ocean, marking the most ambitious leg of its quest to circumnavigate the globe powered only by the sun. Pilot Andre Borschberg, 62, is on a 8,500 km flight to Hawaii, aiming to set a record for duration by a single pilot. The flight is part of a 12-leg journey, scheduled for 25 days, and aims to promote green energy. The aircraft has faced extended delays due to weather concerns, but Borschberg is confident in the weather window.

site_title: Indian govt again issues land acquisition order
summary: The Indian government has issued an executive order to facilitate the acquisition of farmland for large projects, replacing an existing ordinance pending parliamentary approval. This is the third attempt by the Modi government to ease land acquisition rules, which have been blocked by lawmakers in the upper house of parliament. The move aims to build consensus and address conflicts between farmers and companies, with billions of dollars in investment tied up due to land disputes. The ordinance will need the president's signature to take effect.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise on Monday opening
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.12 points to 1,749.64 points on Monday, with a gain of 151 to 88 gainers versus losers. The market saw RM40.4 million in trading volume.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rally
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rallied on Monday, following a week of losses, driven by official data showing a pick-up in Chinese manufacturing activity in May. The Hang Seng Index rose 181.42 points to 27,605.61, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.77% to 4,739.33, and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 3.54% to 2,892.03.

site_title: Ready to tear the house down, WWE-style
summary: Dolph Ziggler, a WWE superstar, is set to perform in Singapore on July 2 as part of WWE Live, a three-hour show at the Singapore Indoor Stadium. Ziggler, a two-time world heavyweight champion, has a personal connection to the city-state, having visited as a child and trying local food. He trains hard to maintain his physique, often working out on an empty stomach, and is excited to put on a great show for fans. This marks the WWE's first show in Singapore since 2007, featuring other big stars such as John Cena and Paige.

site_title: Soaring tanker rates show oil supply glut persists
summary: Oil supply glut persists, with a surge in demand for supertankers driving benchmark charter rates 57% higher. Opec is pumping record amounts of oil, and spare tanker capacity in the Middle East is at its tightest. Analysts say the surplus will take at least another quarter to dissipate, despite recent drops in US oil inventories. The world is still pumping 1.9 million barrels a day more crude than needed, with 485 million barrels of oil in transit to buyers in the coming weeks.

site_title: 'Little spaces' make big difference in megacity Lagos
summary: The Lagos state government has installed over 80 parks since 1999, despite a shortage of space, to provide green spaces for its 20 million residents. These small parks, often tucked away in congested areas, offer a respite from the city's noise and pollution. They have also been shown to help combat childhood obesity, with a 2012 study finding that many children have access to playgrounds but rarely use them due to negative lifestyle trends. The government's efforts to recreate the city's original green spaces, like Ikoyi Park, are hindered by high land values and developers' focus on high-rise construction.

site_title: Blackstone plans Oakland apartment project as tech boom spreads
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest real estate private equity firm, plans a $150 million residential and retail project in Oakland, California, as the city's real estate market benefits from the Bay Area technology boom. The project, in partnership with CityView, will feature 435 rental apartments and 2,230 square meters of retail space. Oakland's housing market is attracting investors due to rising housing costs in nearby San Francisco, with the city ranking fourth in US apartment-rent growth in the first quarter. Construction is expected to begin by the end of the year.

site_title: Directors' share purchases rebound
summary:

site_title: Fed researchers propose another policy tool
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York's research chief proposes a segregated balance account (SBA) as an additional policy tool to raise interest rates. The SBA would allow banks to deposit excess reserves at the Fed, earning the overnight rate, reducing the Fed's need to transact directly with shadow lenders. This would shift the role of banks in monetary policy transmission and ease the burden of the Fed's reverse repo facility. The proposal aims to increase the Fed's ability to guide short-term rates higher and reduce reliance on the reverse repo facility.

site_title: Credit Suisse hiring equities bankers on Saudi market opening
summary: Credit Suisse plans to expand its equities sales and research team in Saudi Arabia as the country's largest bourse opens to direct foreign investment on June 15. The move is expected to attract US$40 billion in foreign inflows over the next five years. Credit Suisse may also hire additional investment bankers if international banks win more IPO mandates. The bank has shifted its regional equities team from Dubai to Riyadh in 2012.

site_title: North Korea seen able to avoid food crisis
summary: North Korea has updated its farming methods and switched crops to mitigate the effects of drought, potentially averting a food crisis. The country has seen improved food supplies and production, with the lowest shortfall since the mid-2000s, according to independent studies. The new farm management system allows smaller groups of farmers to keep a greater share of their crops, improving distribution. Experts attribute the success to diversifying crops and increased allocation of resources in agriculture, with the possibility of meeting any shortfall through imports.

site_title: G-7 holds off criticising Japan over yen's drop
summary: The G-7 held off criticizing Japan over the yen's sharp drop against other currencies, potentially emboldening the Bank of Japan to loosen monetary policy further. This could lead to the yen's value dropping even lower. The OECD's upcoming Economic Outlook on Japan on Wednesday may also influence the BOJ's actions.

site_title: SilkAir launches direct flight to adventure capital Cairns
summary: SilkAir launched its first direct flight to Cairns, marking Singapore Airlines' return to the Australian city after 14 years. The thrice weekly flights, operated with Boeing 737-800 aircraft, will feature Business and Economy classes. SilkAir's CEO Leslie Thng stated that Cairns' inclusion will help develop tourism, business, and cultural exchanges. This new service is the airline's most operationally expensive yet, but aims to capitalize on Cairns' growing popularity as the "adventure capital."

site_title: IMF mission gives upbeat assessment of Ukraine
summary: The head of an IMF team visiting Ukraine gave a positive assessment of progress on reform, saying "good implementation" of the reform programme had been achieved by Kiev. The team reached "understandings" on most issues and discussed further discussion on a US$17.5 billion four-year bailout programme. The second tranche of US$2.5 billion depends on the outcome of the visit, which is expected to give recommendations to the IMF board in June.

site_title: US newspapers struggle to find path in digital age
summary: US newspapers continue to struggle in the digital age, with weekday circulation falling 17% and ad revenue declining over 50% in the past decade. Despite efforts to shift to digital subscriptions and mobile apps, the industry faces significant challenges, including dwindling valuations and limited investment opportunities. Analysts suggest that newspapers must adopt a startup mindset to innovate and compete, but the industry's failure to increase revenue since 2008 makes it difficult to invest in digital. Exceptions, such as the Washington Post under new owner Jeff Bezos, show promise, but overall, the industry's future remains uncertain.

site_title: FSB's too-big-to-fail plan flawed: Vanguard
summary: Vanguard Group, the world's second-largest money manager, has joined Fidelity in opposing the Financial Stability Board's (FSB) plan to identify too-big-to-fail investment funds. The FSB's proposal, which aims to require funds with over $100 billion in assets to be assessed for systemic risk, could lead to higher capital requirements and costs for investors. Vanguard argues that the plan is "deeply flawed" and threatens to disrupt the capital markets. The regulator's approach is instead urged to focus on activities that increase risk, rather than individual fund size.

site_title: Australia home prices fall 0.9% in May
summary: Australia's home prices fell 0.9% in May, marking the first decline in six months, according to CoreLogic RP Data. This drop was largely due to decreases in Sydney (0.7%) and Melbourne (1.7%). The decrease is seen as a welcome development for policy makers aiming to calm the inner-city markets in Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: Jetset with the right card
summary: A credit card for travelers was recently introduced, aiming to simplify the selection process. The new card is designed to provide the best options for different travel needs. Meanwhile, China urged Southeast Asian countries to support openness amidst US tariffs. Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, owned by Ambani, delayed its India IPO beyond this year. US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly, and China unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.19% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.19% lower on June 1, 2015, following losses on Wall Street and a disappointing Chinese manufacturing gauge. The Hang Seng Index dropped 51.13 points to 27,373.06. This decline was part of a broader market trend, with other Asian markets also experiencing losses.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.19 per cent lower Monday following more losses on Wall Street at the end of last week, while an official gauge of Chinese manufacturing came in below expectations.

site_title: China May manufacturing PMI edges up to 50.2, meets forecasts
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed slight growth in May, with the official PMI index rising to 50.2, meeting forecasts. This indicates growth on a monthly basis, but overall economic growth is expected to slow to a 25-year low of around 7% this year due to factors such as a property downturn and high local debt. The central bank has already delivered interest rate cuts to spur growth and reduce borrowing costs.

site_title: Call for shift in mindset to raise productivity in Singapore
summary: Singaporean economists are calling for a shift in mindset to boost productivity, focusing on enhancing skillsets and driving entrepreneurship at higher management levels, not just among workers. This view was shared at the 23rd Singapore Economic Roundtable. The roundtable aims to address the country's low growth and productivity issues, which go beyond foreign labor.

site_title: Industrial hub Ulsan a warning signal for cooling South Korea
summary: South Korea's industrial hub, Ulsan, is facing a crisis as major companies, including Hyundai Motor and SK Innovation, have suffered significant losses. The port city, once the cradle of the country's industrialization, now risks becoming a "rust belt." Policymakers have called for a shift towards developing domestic demand and services, as the country struggles to shake its dependence on manufacturing and exports. This move is seen as a warning signal for the nation, which has the world's fastest-ageing society and an economy in need of diversification.

site_title: Apple mulls 1st yen bond in near future, Goldman Sachs says
summary: Apple may sell its first yen-denominated bond "in the near future" after hiring Goldman Sachs and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group to arrange investor calls. The company aims to boost its capital return program by $70 billion through March 2017 by accessing international debt markets. The yen bond sale would be Apple's first in the Japanese currency and is expected to be priced at around zero to three basis points more than yen swaps. The exact timing of the sale is not specified, but it may occur as early as June 4.

site_title: Esquina rolls out the crowdpleasers
summary: Chef Robert Daniels has taken over at Esquina, a restaurant owned by Loh Lik Peng, with a straightforward and confident menu. The restaurant, located at 16 Jiak Chuan Road, offers dishes such as thyme scented bread, truffled ham and cheese toastie, and roasted Coral trout. The menu has become more down-to-earth, which may run counter to its hipster leanings. In contrast, The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill has launched a "raw" bar concept, featuring cooked seafood on ice, but critics find it hard to accept the pricing and limited offerings.

site_title: Brookfield said to be in talks to buy Blackstone's Center Parcs
summary: Brookfield Asset Management Inc is in talks to acquire UK holiday-resort operator Center Parcs UK Group from Blackstone Group LP for approximately £2.4 billion. The acquisition would be made through Brookfield's publicly traded subsidiary and funds managed by the parent. If talks fail, Blackstone may proceed with an initial public offering of Center Parcs instead. Center Parcs operates five resorts in the UK with revenue of £314.6 million in the year to April 2014. This deal would be Brookfield's latest addition to its portfolio of resort properties, which already includes the Atlantis Paradise Island Resort in the Bahamas.

site_title: US Vice-President Biden's son Beau dies of cancer
summary: US Vice-President Joe Biden's son Beau Biden, 46, has died of brain cancer at the Walter Reed Medical Center. Beau Biden was a two-time attorney general for Delaware and a military lawyer who deployed to Iraq in 2008. His family described him as having "integrity, courage and strength" and said his spirit will live on through his wife and children. The Biden family, including President Barack Obama, has paid tribute to Beau's commitment to his family and his service to the country.

summary: Singapore's Minister for Defence Ng Eng Hen emphasizes the importance of a rules-based system in maintaining trust and stability in the region. He calls for cooperation among all parties in the South China Sea dispute to provide clarity and build mutual confidence and trust. Ng notes that the current rules and institutions must adapt to accommodate new powers and rising aspirations, and that established powers and rising nations alike have a vested interest in maintaining a stable security architecture.

summary: Moscow international airports delayed or cancelled over 100 flights due to stormy weather, with 73 flights delayed and 8 cancelled at Domodedovo airport. A weather warning predicted storms and strong winds that could topple trees and bring down power lines.

site_title: Merkel calls for support for US trade pact
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel urged support for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) ahead of the G7 summit, calling for a deal by 2017 to avoid a disruption when US President Barack Obama leaves office. Merkel emphasized the importance of the US-German relationship, with the US being one of Germany's most significant partners.

site_title: Defiant Blatter wins Fifa vote amid corruption storm
summary: Sepp Blatter won a fifth term as FIFA president, defeating challenger Prince Ali bin al Hussein after the latter withdrew from the race. Blatter, who defied calls to resign, promised to guide FIFA out of the corruption turmoil. His win came after a dramatic campaign amidst corruption allegations, with Blatter maintaining his position despite opposition.

site_title: Britain's private sector growing at fastest pace in a year: CBI
summary: Britain's private sector experienced its strongest economic growth in a year, with a +33 growth indicator in May, according to the Confederation of British Industry. This surpassed weak official data for the first quarter of 2015. The services sector showed the most robust growth, with output rising at its fastest pace since early 2006.

site_title: All eyes on Kaisa's Kwok for turnaround after Sunac exit
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd. CEO Kwok Ying Shing faces a turnaround challenge after a corruption probe, bond default, and failed takeover attempt. Citigroup expects Kwok to sell assets to raise cash, while DBS Group Holdings suggests seeking another partner due to the company's significant mess. Kwok's leadership is crucial in stabilizing the company.

site_title: Update: S'porean man shot dead by police, 2 others detained
summary: A 34-year-old Singaporean man was shot dead by police in an incident near the Shangri-La Hotel, where a high-level security summit was taking place. Two other Singaporean men, aged 26 and 31, were detained. The incident occurred at 4:36 am on Sunday.

site_title: New Zealand's sheep vanish, overtaken by more profitable dairy cows
summary: New Zealand's sheep population has significantly decreased due to the increasing demand for dairy products and the conversion of sheep farming land to dairy pastures. The global price for butter and cheese increased, while demand for sheep meat and wool waned, leading to a shift in agricultural priorities. As a result, the ratio of sheep to New Zealanders has decreased from 20 to 7.

site_title: Aussie startups luring Silicon Valley money
summary: US venture capital firms are increasingly investing in Australian startups due to the country's favorable legal and regulatory environment. In 2013, Accel Partners' team members visited Erina, a coastal town in Australia, to explore investment opportunities. This trend is expected to continue, with US firms attracted to Australia's business-friendly climate and skilled workforce.

site_title: Airbus sees 'several hundred' orders at Paris Airshow
summary: Airbus is expected to announce "several hundred" airplane orders at the June 15-21 Paris Airshow, according to Fabrice Bregier, chief executive of the company. This comes after a surge in demand for medium-haul jets like the A320, but the company is struggling to find buyers for its largest model, the 544-seat A380 superjumbo.

site_title: Adding alternative investments to your portfolio
summary: A financial adviser suggests adding alternative investments, such as private equity, real estate, and commodities, to a portfolio to diversify it. These investments can move independently from the rest of the portfolio, reducing correlation. However, costs associated with these investments should be considered. Adding alternative investments can provide a way to reduce reliance on traditional investments, but it's essential to weigh the costs and benefits before making a decision.

site_title: Greek government faces internal backlash over pick for IMF representative
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras faced opposition from his Syriza party lawmakers over the appointment of Elena Panaritis as Greece's representative to the International Monetary Fund, citing conflicting views with the party's anti-bailout stance. Around 40 deputies opposed the appointment and requested it be withdrawn. The move deepens divisions within the ruling party, which has been plagued by internal conflicts since Tsipras took office.

site_title: Mansions replace old homes in upscale makeover for US suburbs
summary: Homeowners in the US suburbs are opting for mansions instead of tearing down their old homes. MERION Homes, a US construction company, has purchased 24 old rambler-style houses in Northern Virginia for $450,000 each, only to demolish them and sell custom-built, three-story residences for over $1 million. The decision is due to the limited size and outdated features of the original homes.

site_title: Police did the right thing in Shangri-La incident: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen
summary: Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen stated that the police handled the Shangri-La incident effectively, doing the right thing by considering it could be a terrorist plot. The incident, later revealed to be drug-related, occurred near the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore.

site_title: Port workers lift strike threat in Argentina export hub: port chamber
summary: Port workers in Argentina's Rosario grains export hub lifted a strike threat after a pay deal was reached with employers, allowing further negotiations. The workers, members of the CGT labour federation, announced their decision after the grains crushers' union ended a three-week strike. The port chamber reported the development, citing the workers' decision to continue negotiations.

site_title: Legal case likely for passengers on SQ836
summary: An American lawyer, Floyd Wisner, is planning to mount a legal case for passengers on Singapore Airlines Flight 836, citing "remarkable similarities" to a 2008 Qantas flight that fell 2,000 meters. The case claims many passengers would have suffered severe emotional and physical trauma. Wisner's firm represents passengers on the ill-fated AirAsia Flight 8501.

site_title: Greece, economy, bond purchases top agenda of ECB meeting
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to keep its bond purchase program in place despite downside risks to economic growth, according to analysts. The ECB's governing council is unlikely to announce any new policy moves during its meeting on Wednesday, following the success of the program. The decision is seen as a pledge to maintain support for the struggling Greek economy and stabilize the eurozone.

site_title: US tried Stuxnet-style virus operation against North Korea but failed
summary: The US attempted to deploy a Stuxnet-style virus to sabotage North Korea's nuclear programme in 2010, but the operation was unsuccessful due to the country's secrecy. The campaign was reportedly led by the NSA and aimed to disrupt centrifuges enriching uranium. The failure was attributed to Pyongyang's ability to maintain secrecy, similar to the Iran operation where Stuxnet was first deployed in 2009 and 2010.

site_title: US: Stocks sag as consumer confidence slips
summary: US stocks fell modestly on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 115.44 points (0.64%) to 18,010.68. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declined, shedding 13.40 and 27.95 points, respectively. A key consumer confidence measure came in lower, contributing to the market's downturn. The economy contracted in the first quarter, as confirmed by the government.

site_title: China deployed artillery in South China Sea: US officials
summary: China has deployed two artillery pieces on one of its artificial islands in the South China Sea, raising concerns among US officials about Beijing's military expansion in the region. The heavy artillery, since removed, were spotted in the Spratly Islands, within range of territory claimed by Vietnam. This move is part of China's massive island-building project, which US officials believe is aimed at extending its military reach in the contested waters.

site_title: RBI set for third interest rate cut of the year
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is set to cut interest rates for a third time this year, confident that inflation remains stable enough to withstand the summer monsoon. The benchmark repo rate has already been lowered by 50 basis points to 7.5% this year. The move aims to support the economy amid a challenging summer season.

site_title: Greece looms large at a time when 'bad news is bad news'
summary: US stocks may rebound this week if employment data alleviates fears of an economic slowdown, Greece averts disaster, or more multi-billion dollar deals are struck in the healthcare sector. Markets have been volatile over the past 18 months due to repeated false alarms from the Federal Reserve and Greece's repeated close calls with default and a euro exit. Investors may be drawn to the healthcare sector amid current M&A mania, despite the ongoing uncertainty.

site_title: Credit card selection made easy for travellers
summary: A Singaporean startup, GET.com, has created a list of the best credit cards for travelers based on individual priorities. The comparison site analyzed 130 cards and identified the top two cards for nine key types of travelers, taking into account factors such as travel patterns and lifestyle goals. The list aims to help travelers make informed decisions about which card to use abroad.

site_title: Kerry returns to US after breaking thigh bone in bicycle fall
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry returned to Boston after breaking his right thigh bone in a bicycling accident in eastern France. Kerry, 71, was transported by medical helicopter to a hospital in Geneva for evaluation before being sent to Massachusetts General Hospital for treatment. His injury is not life-threatening, and he is expected to make a full recovery. Kerry's trip was cut short, and he will seek treatment with his doctor who performed his prior hip surgery.

site_title: Google puts virtual reality in reach with cardboard
summary: Google has released a new, affordable version of its virtual reality headgear, Google Cardboard, priced at $4. The device, which debuted at the 2014 developers conference, has become a huge hit. The new version offers improved features and is available for consumers to buy. This move brings virtual reality to a wider audience, making it more accessible to people who may not have been able to afford more expensive VR headsets.

site_title: Get a tax break plus lobster & beef in Japan
summary: In Japan's rural towns, dwindling populations are attracting outside donors with tax breaks and gifts, dubbed "hometown taxation." Since 2008, over 36,000 donors have supported towns like Hirado, which received 1.46 billion yen in donations last year. The gifts range from seafood to luxury items, but critics say the system has become unsustainable, with less funding for civic projects and a widening wealth gap between cities and countryside.

site_title: Murky future for NSA data sweep as 'sunset' looms
summary: The US Patriot Act, a key law supporting bulk surveillance, is set to expire at midnight, potentially shutting down most bulk collection efforts by the National Security Agency. The law's expiration will be enforced at 4:00 pm EST, with any collection after midnight deemed illegal. The move follows the revelation of Edward Snowden's data sweep, which sparked outrage. The future of NSA data sweep remains unclear as Congress may not pass a new law to replace the expired one.

site_title: New wave of smart tech on show at Taiwan's Computex
summary: Computex, Asia's largest tech trade show, will feature 1,700 exhibitors showcasing smart living and wearable technology, including gadgets that analyze state of mind and identify burglars. The event, now in its 35th year, is expected to attract 130,000 visitors from Taiwan and around the world. Mature products will be on display, according to David Liu of the Taipei Computer Association, highlighting the focus on smart living and wearable technology.

site_title: New Malaysia Airlines CEO impresses with micromanaging ways
summary: Malaysia Airlines' new CEO Christoph Mueller is implementing a restructuring plan with a new brand, smaller fleet, and one-third fewer staff, aiming for a fresh start. Mueller, a 52-year-old German, has successfully restructured Ireland's Aer Lingus and Lufthansa, and is impressing with his micromanaging approach. His plans are seen as a promising blueprint for the ailing carrier, with one long-time executive describing his leadership style as a key asset.

site_title: Opec supply, US shale output seen keeping oil prices weak
summary: Opec supply and US shale output are expected to keep oil prices weak in 2015, with a Reuters survey predicting a global oil benchmark average of $61.60 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is likely to maintain its joint production target of 30 million barrels per day, protecting its market share. Analysts predict oil prices will rise to $70.90 in 2016 and $75.90 in 2017, driven by healthy global demand and a more balanced market. US shale production is also expected to contribute to weak prices.

site_title: Buck to stop with bankers as G-7 seeks conduct code for lenders
summary: Global regulators are developing a new global code of conduct for lenders, with the goal of making individuals accountable for banking misbehavior. The move comes after a series of scandals, including foreign-exchange manipulation, that have damaged the industry's image. The Financial Stability Board will oversee the development of the code, which aims to encourage better conduct from the outset and reduce reliance on penalties that weaken banks' capital health. The code is seen as a response to the fallout from the financial crisis and a way to restore trust in the banking industry.

site_title: Greece, EU partners pressed to resolve debt crisis at G-7 finance meeting
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jack Lew urged Greece and its European partners to resolve the debt crisis, warning that time is running out to unlock 7.2 billion euros in bailout cash. The issue dominated G7 finance ministers' talks in Dresden, with the US and Japan pressing for a resolution. Despite Greece not being on the official agenda, the crisis was a key topic, with Lew stating that "all parties need to move" to avoid rattling the eurozone and global economy.

site_title: Greece's Tsipras attacks creditors over 'absurd' reforms
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras criticized creditors for pushing "absurd" reforms that hinder negotiations for a debt deal. Tsipras argued that the lack of an agreement is due to creditors' insistence on unreasonable proposals, not Greece's stance. He emphasized the need for a compromise based on the country's democratic choice. The comments come as Greece continues to navigate debt crisis negotiations.

images.alt_text: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras on Sunday attacked its creditors for insisting on what he described as absurd reforms which have only held up progress in negotiations for a deal aimed at preventing his country from defaulting.

site_title: Indian factory growth accelerates in May, strong domestic demand-PMI
summary: India's manufacturing activity accelerated in May, reaching its fastest pace in four months, driven by strong domestic demand. The HSBC Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 52.6, surpassing economists' predictions of 51.2. The growth is expected to be further boosted by a possible Reserve Bank of India interest rate cut.

site_title: South Korea's exports slump by the most in almost six years
summary: South Korea's exports fell 10.9% in May, the largest decline in almost six years, as overseas sales continued to slump. The decline is the fifth straight monthly drop, underscoring concerns about the impact on the country's economy. Economists predict a potential rate cut by the Bank of Korea due to the weak exports, which are also influenced by the Korean won's strength against the yen and euro.

images.alt_text: South Korea's exports fell the most in almost six years in May, underscoring concern that the slump in overseas sales is harming a recovery in Asia's fourth-biggest economy.

site_title: Feeling yippy?
summary: A golf swing technique involving a left arm stop and right hand flip is highlighted, but no further details about its significance or implications are provided.

site_title: The Brits are back
summary: A British culinary invasion is coming to Singapore with three new restaurants set to open. MEATliquor Singapore is one of the establishments, with a soft opening this weekend and a planned opening at the end of June. The third location is expanding with a second site soon. This marks a significant increase in British dining options in the city-state.

site_title: South Africa sports ministers says Fifa probe attack on sovereignty
summary: South African Sports Minister Fikile Mbalula has responded to US Justice Department allegations that the country paid bribes to secure the 2010 World Cup hosting rights. Mbalula described the claims as an "attack on our sovereignty" and stated that South Africa would not allow its reputation to be tarnished without a response. The US Justice Department alleges that a South African bid committee official paid bribes to Concacaf president Jack Warner, who diverted the funds for personal use. South Africa's local organising committee for the 2010 World Cup has denied the allegations, stating that the $10 million payment was for a soccer development fund.

site_title: US hits out at China on sea reclamation at security summit
summary: The US has condemned China's intensifying reclamation activities in the South China Sea, calling for an immediate halt to land reclamation by all claimants. US Defense Secretary Ashton Carter stated that Beijing's actions are "out of step" with international norms, and the US will continue to send military aircraft and ships to disputed areas. The US is seeking a peaceful resolution to the disputes and wants Beijing to respect international norms.

site_title: Greece, growth worries keep cap on Wall Street
summary: US markets experienced a volatile week due to concerns over US growth and Greece's debt talks. Despite tech stocks reaching new highs, investors remained cautious, citing mixed economic data and a potential economic contraction. The Nasdaq Composite scored a fresh record on Wednesday, but overall, the market failed to reach recent record highs.

images.alt_text: Another volatile week marked by distrust over the US growth rebound and Greece's debt talks prevented US markets from locking in recent record highs.

site_title: Edox gears up, expands reach of sports range
summary: Swiss watchmaker Edox is shifting its focus to the higher end of the mass segment with its precision performance sports watches. The brand aims to drive brand awareness with a new marketing strategy, targeting consumers with a range of timepieces from S$1,450 to S$5,800. Edox's senior brand manager, Pamela Tan, sees this as a continuation of the brand's revolution since 2006.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Oil slides on strong dollar, supply glut worries
summary: Oil prices dropped to one-month lows due to a strong dollar and concerns over a global supply glut. The rising dollar makes dollar-denominated commodities more expensive, reducing demand and prices. Opec, which produces 30% of global crude, meets June 5 for a production gathering in Vienna, fueling supply glut worries.

site_title: Fifa probe: US official says more indictments likely
summary: A US federal investigator, Richard Weber, says he is "fairly confident" another round of indictments will be filed in the FIFA corruption scandal. Weber did not disclose remaining targets, including Sepp Blatter, FIFA's newly re-elected president. Weber's statement comes after previous indictments were made, indicating ongoing investigations and potential future charges.

site_title: One man shot dead, two others detained near Shangri-La hotel
summary: A car crashed past police barricades near the Shangri-La Hotel in Singapore, where a high-level regional security meeting was taking place. One person was shot dead and two others were detained after the driver refused to open the rear of the car for checks. US Defence Secretary Ash Carter was present at the meeting. The incident occurred early Sunday morning, near the hotel where the meeting was being held.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Opec output rises and is seen to stay high
summary: Crude oil prices fell in early Asian trading on Monday as Opec output rose and is expected to stay high, contributing to a market that remains over supplied. Despite a 5% jump on Friday due to US rig cuts, prices dropped as near-record production in major oil-producing regions persisted. The market's over-supply sentiment was reinforced by expectations of sustained Opec production levels.

images.alt_text: Crude oil prices dipped in early Asian trading on Monday as rising Opec output and an expectation that the group would keep production high added to sentiment that the market remained over supplied despite ongoing falls in US rig operations.

site_title: Jet fuel tankers from Asia arriving in Los Angeles in June
summary: A wave of jet fuel tankers from Asia is expected to arrive in Los Angeles in early June, providing supplies that should keep wholesale prices stable after a recent surge. The Neptun D, a 60,000-tonne tanker, is set to dock on June 3, followed by FPMC 18 on June 11. The shipments are expected to alleviate pressure on the market, which saw prices jump earlier this month.

site_title: Sweden readies infrastructure boom to help lower unemployment
summary: Sweden's government plans to boost infrastructure investments to reduce unemployment, reversing a 30-year stagnation. Finance Minister Magdalena Andersson aims to increase spending on roads, railways, and high-speed networks. The government will also encourage state-run pension funds to invest in projects and consider debt-financed initiatives. This move is expected to improve the economy and help meet the government's pledge to lower unemployment.

site_title: China import tax cuts no remedy for retail slowdown
summary: China has slashed import tariffs on select goods, including sneakers and skincare, in an attempt to boost consumer spending and stimulate economic growth. However, many Chinese shoppers, like 28-year-old Chen Xuejun, say the move won't change their purchasing habits, as they prioritize quality and design over price. China's private consumption accounts for over half of its GDP growth, but lags behind other markets, and the tariff cuts are seen as a potential remedy, but its effectiveness remains uncertain.

site_title: In India, 'the vision thing' proves challenge for Modi aides
summary: India's Modi administration is struggling to balance its pro-business and pro-poor policies, sparking concerns among both groups. The administration's communication has been marred by mistakes, including Finance Minister Arun Jaitley's overstated tax demands, which triggered a stock selloff. In response, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has introduced policies aimed at helping the poor, including a revised land bill and changes to labor rules. The move is seen as an attempt to counter opposition claims of a "suit-boot government" and gain support from farmers.

site_title: India douses century-old coal fires as Modi seeks output boost
summary: India is working to extinguish century-old coal fires near coalfields in eastern India, aiming to boost coal output and reduce reliance on imports. Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks to relocate over 100,000 residents near the coalfields to new homes, allowing for increased coal production. The move aims to secure power for all and reduce a US$15 billion annual coal import bill. The Jharia coalfield, prized for its high-quality steelmaking coal, is a key target for this initiative.

site_title: Google working with Levi Strauss to make smart clothes
summary: Google is collaborating with Levi Strauss to develop smart clothing through a project called Project Jacquard, which utilizes touch-screen control capabilities. The project is being led by Google's Advanced Technology and Projects team and is the company's first partnership with Levi Strauss. The goal of Project Jacquard is to integrate technology into clothing, allowing for seamless interactions between the wearer and the digital world.

site_title: BOJ sovereign bond paper profit tops Zuckerberg wealth
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has generated a record profit of 4.81 trillion yen ($39 billion) from its bond holdings, surpassing Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg's net worth of $35 billion. The valuation gain is a result of the central bank's efforts to combat deflation by buying bonds, which has led to a significant increase in its holdings. As the BOJ continues to accelerate bond purchases, it may face challenges in selling the holdings without incurring losses.

site_title: More of the world's elderly are staging heists and robbing banks
summary: A recent heist in London's Hatton Garden diamond district, where thieves stole over £10 million in cash and gems, has raised concerns about the involvement of elderly individuals in crime. The suspects, aged between 42 and 74, were arrested after police cracked the case, with most being older and experiencing physical limitations. The heist has been linked to rising poverty rates and isolation among the elderly in some countries, sparking debate about the factors contributing to this trend.

site_title: Airbus sees "several hundred" orders at Paris Airshow
summary: Airbus is expected to announce "several hundred" orders for its aircraft at the June 15-21 Paris Airshow, according to Fabrice Bregier, Airbus' chief executive. This comes as the company sees a surge in demand for its medium-haul A320 jets. However, Airbus is struggling to find buyers for its largest model, the 544-seat A380 superjumbo, with a potential revamp of the aircraft's engines not currently on the agenda.

site_title: Micromanaging new CEO impresses at Malaysia Airlines
summary: Malaysia Airlines' new CEO Christoph Mueller has impressed with his micromanaging style, aiming to revamp the airline with a new brand, smaller fleet, and reduced staff. Mueller, a 52-year-old German, has successfully restructured Ireland's Aer Lingus and Lufthansa. However, analysts worry about the airline's long history of mismanagement and damaged brand after two plane disasters, making it challenging for Mueller to turn the carrier around.

site_title: State commodity traders proliferate to take on Glencore, Cargill
summary: State-owned enterprises from Azerbaijan, Saudi Arabia, China, Oman, Thailand, and Russia are expanding or establishing trading arms to directly buy and sell natural resources, bypassing traditional traders like Glencore and Cargill. This trend aims to secure the offtake of production or supplies, according to Socar Trading CEO Arzu Azimov. The move is driven by countries' desire to reduce dependence on external traders and maintain control over their resources.

site_title: Indian govt again issues land acquisition order
summary: The Indian government has issued an executive order for the third time to ease land acquisition rules for large projects, aiming to facilitate investments and maintain continuity despite a failed parliamentary vote on a contentious land bill. The ordinance replaces an existing one pending presidential approval and aims to ensure farmers receive fair compensation. This move is part of the Modi government's reform efforts to make it easier for investors to acquire land.

site_title: South Korea to ban private cab services in blow to Uber
summary: South Korea's lawmakers passed a bill to ban private taxi services, effectively outlawing Uber's low-cost uberX service. The ban, set to take effect by the end of the year, is the first nationwide legislation targeting Uber. This marks the latest setback for the US company, following similar restrictions in other countries. The move is seen as a significant blow to Uber's expansion plans in the region.

site_title: Indonesian inflation accelerates on higher food prices
summary: Indonesia's inflation accelerated to 7.15% in May, its highest level in five months, due to increased food prices. The country's consumer price index rose faster than expected, surpassing the 6.79% increase in April. This surge in inflation is attributed to higher fuel costs, following the government's decision to almost completely abolish huge subsidies and let petrol prices float with the market.

site_title: Rate hike will remove uncertainty & distortion, says JP Morgan chairman
summary: JP Morgan chairman Jacob Frenkel says there's too little debate about the cost of staying in a zero interest rate policy and too much debate about exiting it. He warns that prolonged ultra-low interest rates distort resource allocation and encourage asset price bubbles. Frenkel advises balancing the fear of normalizing monetary policy with the fear of not normalizing it, suggesting that a rate hike would remove uncertainty and distortion.

site_title: Europe should weigh World Cup boycott to oust Fifa's Blatter: UK
summary: The UK has called for a World Cup boycott if FIFA President Sepp Blatter doesn't quit amid a corruption scandal. Blatter, who was re-elected last week, was shown "zero respect" by Swiss authorities, who denied questioning him. The European governing body's head advised Blatter to quit, but he rejected the advice. The UK's stance is seen as a possible response to Blatter's recent complaints, but no further action has been taken.

site_title: Pfizer merger chatter awakens Glaxo bulls
summary: Options traders are showing increased interest in GlaxoSmithKline Plc, with the highest volume in contracts since 2007 in May. This surge is attributed to Pfizer merger chatter, which has sparked bullish sentiment. Traders are paying record prices for bullish options over bearish ones, indicating a potential shift in investor sentiment.

site_title: Thousands gather for opening of World Trade Centre deck
summary: Thousands of people gathered in New York to witness the opening of the World Trade Centre's observation deck, a symbol of the city's resilience after the 9/11 attacks. The 104-story tower, the tallest in the Western hemisphere, offers breathtaking views of the city from its 100th, 101st, and 102nd floors. The event marked a significant milestone in the city's recovery, allowing visitors to experience the stunning skyline from a new vantage point.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says it offered at least 14,000 employees jobs
summary: Malaysia Airlines has invited approximately 14,000 employees to join the new company formed as part of a corporate revamp. The airline aims to return to profitability after two disastrous accidents last year, with plans to break even in 2018. Turnaround plans include capacity rightsizing, eliminating losses, and renegotiating contracts. The old structure, Malaysian Airline System Bhd, will cease operations in August, and the new company will start growing again in 2017-2018.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines Bhd invited at least 14,000 employees to join the new company formed as part of a corporate revamp as the carrier seeks to return to profitability after two disastrous accidents last year.

site_title: Singapore's exports to recover over next five years: HSBC
summary: HSBC predicts Singapore's exports will rebound over the next five years, driven by the recovery of Asian economies and completion of trade agreements. Exports are forecasted to grow 3.9% globally and 5% within Asia (excluding Japan) per annum from 2015-2020, significantly higher than the 1.1% growth from 2013-2014. This growth is expected to be boosted by the economic rejuvenation of emerging markets in Asia.

site_title: Singapore golf's uncertain future
summary: Singapore golf's uncertain future, a golf course has been facing financial struggles and potential closure after its owner, the Singapore Turf Club, reported significant losses. The club cited declining attendance and increasing costs as reasons for its financial struggles. The course's uncertain future has sparked concerns among golf enthusiasts and the local community, with some calling for alternative uses for the land. The exact fate of the course remains uncertain, with no clear solution in sight.

site_title: Merkel appeals to Germans to back trade pact ahead of G-7 meeting
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel urged Germans to support the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) ahead of the G-7 summit she is hosting in June. She hopes the agreement will be finalized by 2017, as talks between the EU and US could be disrupted if an agreement isn't reached before US President Barack Obama leaves office in January 2017. Merkel emphasized the importance of maintaining transatlantic free trade, comparing it to the advanced stage of talks between the US and Asia on a free trade agreement.

site_title: SEA Games to be a spectacle - and within budget: sponsorship chief
summary: Singapore's sponsorship chief, Richard Seow, praises the "unprecedented level" of support from firms for the 28th South East Asia (SEA) Games, which will be held in Singapore from June 5 to 16. The event has attracted S$80 million in sponsorship from over 100 firms, exceeding its target of S$50 million. Seow ensured the Games will be within the S$324.5 million budget, with most events offering free admission and stadiums packed with spectators. He hopes Singaporeans will support the host country's athletes in their quest for medals.

site_title: D is key
summary: A recent article highlights the challenges of obtaining natural vitamin D during winter due to the limited penetration of sun's UV rays. This issue has been exacerbated by recent news in the region, including a delayed India IPO by Reliance Jio, a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, and China's efforts to aid employment amid trade tensions. US weekly jobless claims have also fallen unexpectedly. Amid these economic developments, China urges South-east Asian countries to support openness amidst looming US tariffs.

site_title: Corporate sukuk still stymied by pricing, design
summary: Corporate sukuk issuance is hindered by legal, design, and pricing issues, deterring companies from issuing sukuk compared to conventional bonds. Governments' sukuk issuance is expanding, bringing Islamic finance into the mainstream. Companies face heavy tax burdens and complex product designs, making it more expensive for them to issue sukuk. Special legislation is needed to alleviate these issues and encourage corporate sukuk sales.

site_title: S'pore market cap inches down to S$994b from all-time high
summary: The Singapore stock market's market capitalization dropped to S$994 billion in May, down from an all-time high of S$998 billion in April. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 95 points or 2.7% to 3,392.11, mainly due to declines in banks, Singtel, and Singapore Airlines. Weak first-quarter earnings and a shaky Wall Street contributed to the market's soft showing, with year-to-date gains of only 0.8%. Despite this, brokers remain optimistic, citing the STI's relatively low valuation and attractive dividend yield.

site_title: China reforms head down path littered with crisis casualties
summary: China's leaders are implementing the country's next major economic reform, focusing on interest rates, currency moves, and international money flows. This move could lead to a more efficient economy, but history shows that premature liberalization can result in disastrous consequences, such as crises in Latin America and Europe. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. Experts warn that the country must get the reform right to avoid a trail of crises.

site_title: Wealthy Chinese heading abroad to buy diamonds without scrutiny
summary: Wealthy Chinese individuals are bypassing China's strict regulations on luxury purchases by buying diamonds abroad, resulting in a slowdown in diamond sales in China. Major jewellery outlets, such as Tiffany & Co. and De Beers, have reported a decline in sales in the country. Revenue from luxury jewellery is forecast to grow by 8% annually through 2018, according to an analyst. This trend is attributed to China's growing disdain for ostentatious displays of wealth, which is becoming increasingly frowned upon at home.

site_title: Sharp fall in lending in April casts doubt on S'pore banks' loan target
summary: Singapore bank lending experienced a sharp decline in April, falling for the fifth consecutive month, and dipping further than the previous month. This marks the first time since 2006 that consumer loans have decreased. Business lending also contracted sharply, with a level of contraction last seen during the global financial crisis. This dismal performance may cast doubt on the banks' loan target of a 5% rise this year, potentially leading to a skim or miss of their expectations.

site_title: BT Luxe Night brings whisky to the mix
summary: About 70 senior executives attended a whisky-tasting event at The Business Times Luxe Night, marking a first for the event. Spirits and wine specialist Lam Chi Mun dispelled misconceptions about whisky, stating it comes in various styles and ages, and can be enjoyed in different ways. He showcased several types of whisky, including single malts, blended whiskies, and Japanese whiskies, and encouraged attendees to sample them in their preferred manner. The event also featured a lucky draw and showcased LG's new 4K OLED television set.

site_title: SMRT beefs up rail engineering capability
summary: SMRT Corporation has introduced a comprehensive career development roadmap for its rail engineers, called the SMRT Train Engineer Professionalisation (STEP), to improve train service reliability and attract engineering talent. The scheme provides structured career tracks, job rotation, management training, and new accreditation, moving away from a seniority-based approach. This move aims to enhance the attractiveness of SMRT's engineering jobs and support the growth of its engineering staff.

site_title: India vegetarians hit by high lentil prices as Canada crop shrinks
summary: India is facing a shortage of lentils due to Canada's reduced crop, which has led to higher prices. Canadian lentil stockpiles are down by half from last year, while shipments to India, the top buyer, are at an all-time high. This has boosted prices for lentils, chickpeas, and dried beans, affecting millions of vegetarians in India who rely on these legumes as a food staple. Prices are expected to remain high until the Canadian harvest starts in August, with some farmers already pre-selling their output at record prices.

site_title: Proactive stance against strokes
summary: A proactive stance against strokes is crucial, especially with an ageing population, as they cause major disabilities and social burdens. Understanding stroke mechanisms and causes can help prevent them. Strokes can be divided into three categories: blood clots, high blood pressure, and blood vessel damage. Taking preventive measures, such as managing blood pressure and cholesterol levels, quitting smoking, and maintaining a healthy diet, can significantly reduce the risk of stroke. By being aware of the causes and mechanisms of stroke, individuals can take proactive steps to protect themselves and their loved ones.

site_title: Life lessons
summary: A Singaporean golf course, Jurong Country Club, is set to be taken away in November 2026, sparking discussion among golfers. Meanwhile, in international news, the Asean region has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, with Malaysia expressing its stance. In the US, weekly jobless claims have fallen unexpectedly. China is urging Southeast Asian countries to support openness as US tariffs loom, while Chinese property shares surge on reports of a meeting to revive the sector.

site_title: The emotional side of family businesses
summary: Family businesses successfully navigate complex and dilemma-filled environments by balancing emotional and hard business considerations. A recent KPMG survey found that while emotional dimensions are respected, they are secondary to hardcore business considerations in decision-making. Family businesses cope with ambiguity by finding ways to balance the forces of family and business, rather than relying solely on mathematical optimization. This "both/and" strategy enables them to deliver in uncertain markets, making emotional values a key differentiator in their success.

site_title: For all intents and purposes
summary: NUS School of Design and Environment students showcased innovative projects at the NUS Industrial Design Show 2015, including Flati bags that transform into accessories, SoundCARE ambient monitoring system for ICU patients, HeatStik portable kitchen appliance, Tabao-ware smart storage solution, uNit desk organizer, STAK stand for elderly luggage, Itadakimasu tableware for food awareness, Snuggle laptop case and pillow, and more, highlighting the students' creativity and problem-solving skills.

site_title: Chinese stock funds attract most cash since April '08 in week: BofA
summary: Investors worldwide poured US$4.5 billion into Chinese stock funds in the week ended May 27, marking the largest weekly inflows since April 2008. This surge in funds, combined with a US$600 million inflow in the prior week, brings the total to US$4.6 billion. In contrast, US share funds experienced US$3.9 billion in withdrawals and bond funds posted US$400 million in outflows, following a US$1.4 billion inflow the previous week.

images.alt_text: Investors worldwide poured US$4.5 billion into funds that specialize in Chinese stocks in the week ended May 27, marking the biggest weekly inflows into the funds since April 2008, data from a Bank of America Merrill Lynch Global Research report showed on Friday.

site_title: MND appeals against court ruling on AHPETC issue
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) filed an appeal against a High Court judgment that rejected its application to appoint independent accountants to Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). The Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) advised MND to file the appeal to allow the government to disburse grants to AHPETC while safeguarding public funds. The move comes after the court's ruling was met with concerns over the handling of public funds by the opposition-led town council.

site_title: Political football: Why the US - and not Europe - took action on Fifa corruption
summary: The US took action against FIFA corruption, arresting seven top officials and indicting 14 on charges, after years of research exposing corrupt practices dating back to the 1990s. Unlike Europe, where football dominates, the US's emergence as a major player in the sport led to increased scrutiny and intervention. The US's unique blend of laws protecting corporate interests and toughening punishments for corrupt business practices played a significant role in the FIFA crackdown.

site_title: Briefing
summary: India reported economic growth of 7.3% for 2014-15, surpassing the previous year's 6.8% but falling short of the government's forecast of 7.4%. The US economy contracted in the first quarter at a 0.7% annual rate, while dealmaking in the US rose 52% year-on-year to $746.9 billion. Meanwhile, Malaysia's 1MDB secured $1 billion in funding from Abu Dhabi to ease debt worries. Global economic trends, including China's potential slowdown and the UK economy's contraction, are also being closely watched.

site_title: Avago's US$37b buy points to bigger deals
summary: Avago's $37 billion acquisition of Broadcom Corp is the largest tech deal in history, surpassing the previous record of $30 billion. The transaction reflects the growing trend of consolidation in the chip industry, driven by low interest rates, swelling cash piles, and rising stock valuations. Industry experts predict more super-sized tech mergers, including in enterprise hardware, software, and the Internet, as companies seek growth and diversification. Other potential targets include Salesforce.com, Intel Corp, and Twitter.

images.alt_text: Avago Technologies' purchase of Broadcom Corp represents the biggest technology deal of all time.

site_title: Silk Road to boost yuan
summary: China plans to use its New Silk Road project to boost the use of its currency, the yuan, in trade totaling $2.5 trillion by 2025. The One Road, One Belt plan connects China to Asia, Africa, and Europe, promoting the use of the yuan and increasing trade. Countries along the route have abundant resources, while China faces environmental pressure and dependence on foreign supplies. This move aims to expand trade and reduce the country's reliance on foreign supplies.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US decreased in may to a six-month low
summary: US consumer confidence fell to a six-month low in May, decreasing to 90.7 from 95.9 in April, according to the University of Michigan. This marked the biggest decline since 2012. Household concerns about the economy and wages, combined with rising gas prices, contributed to the decline. Despite a strong labor market, pay gains are needed to encourage spending and propel growth. The decline in confidence is consistent with sluggish consumer spending, which has been slow to accelerate despite lower gasoline costs.

site_title: Nurturing the spirit of enterprise
summary: Successful entrepreneurs are grooming their children to take over startups, often starting at a young age. The Zietz family in Florida is a prime example, with parents Sam and Rachel already running a successful business and their children, Rachel, 14, Jordan, 13, and Morgan, 9, showing entrepreneurial spirit. The family's approach is to treat the kids like adults, sharing knowledge and encouraging them to apply it. Other parents, like Joanna Strober, are also teaching their children the value of entrepreneurship, with some already starting their own businesses.

site_title: Asia wants positive US-China ties: PM Lee
summary: Asian countries, including Singapore, hope for positive US-China ties, avoiding a zero-sum game. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that competition between major powers is unavoidable, but it should be managed through strengthening international rules and norms. The US and China have differing initiatives, such as the AIIB and TPP, which could impact regional stability. Lee urged China and ASEAN to draw up a South China Sea Code of Conduct to prevent tensions and promote cooperation.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: A tough, fascinating challenge on the horizon
summary: A global challenge of finding a ball on a golf course is on the horizon, with varying levels of difficulty depending on the tee used. Key events include a low-profile property trust's data center gambit, US weekly jobless claims falling unexpectedly, and Chinese property shares surging on reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Additionally, China has unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions and Asean has agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority. Reliance Jio has also delayed its India IPO beyond this year.

site_title: Google unveils Android Pay in fresh challenge to Apple
summary: Google unveils Android Pay, a mobile payment system for Android devices, at its developers conference in San Francisco. Android Pay allows users to store credit card information on their handsets and make contactless payments in over 700,000 US retail outlets. The system generates a one-time virtual account number for security and can be downloaded from Google Play. The move is seen as a challenge to Apple's Apple Pay system. Android Pay will also support fingerprint-checking, gesture controls, and smartwatches, although it's unclear if it will extend to Apple Watch.

site_title: New rules put spotlight on Jardine stocks
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) will revise its benchmark starting from September, requiring constituents to have a minimum trading volume of 0.1% of issued shares. This change, which doubles the current requirement, aims to increase liquidity among index stocks. The Jardine group's companies, currently on the STI, may be at risk of being dropped if their trading volumes do not meet the new standard. The STI will remain the blue-chip market benchmark, but the large-cap portion will be combined with the Mid-Cap Index to create a new FTSE ST Large & Mid Cap Index.

site_title: Merkel says will work constructively with Britain on EU reform
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she will work constructively with British Prime Minister David Cameron on reforming the European Union, reaffirming her desire to keep Britain within the bloc. Merkel stated, "Where there's a will, there's a way," while Cameron emphasized the importance of the "substance" of reforms over a timeline. The two leaders did not comment on whether changes to the EU treaty could be achieved before Britain's membership referendum.

site_title: Chicago PMI falls more than expected in May
summary: The Chicago PMI fell to 46.2 in May, reversing the previous month's rise to 52.3. This marked a significant decline, beating analysts' expectations of a 53.0 reading. The drop indicates a weakening in the US manufacturing sector, contrary to recent trends.

site_title: A numbers game
summary: A recent article explores the concept of corporate purpose, which is the reason a company exists beyond making a profit. It involves creating value for stakeholders beyond shareholders, including employees, customers, and the community. Companies are encouraged to define their purpose and align it with their values and goals. This shift in focus aims to drive long-term sustainability and social responsibility. As a result, various organizations are partnering to promote financial literacy, reduce waste, and engage volunteers, ultimately redefining the role of businesses in society. This new approach is expected to drive positive change.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: IHH Healthcare's results were below expectations due to lower inpatient volume growth and higher operating costs. The company is trading at 48.2 times its 2015 forecast price-earnings ratio, making valuations relatively unattractive. In contrast, Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is recommended as a "buy" due to its strong fund-management platform strategy and potential for US dollar-Singapore dollar appreciation. Keppel DC Reit is also upgraded to a "buy" after acquiring Intellicentre 2 for A$43.3 million, which is expected to bring its earnings profile closer to estimates.

site_title: Football: Fifa votes for new president
summary: FIFA's congress voted for a new president, with incumbent Sepp Blatter expected to win despite a corruption scandal. Blatter, 79, is seeking a fifth term, while challenger Prince Ali bin al Hussein of Jordan, 39, campaigned on reform. Blatter vowed to lead FIFA out of the scandal, promising to establish transparency. The vote started with Blatter as the favourite, requiring a two-thirds majority to win in the first round. A simple majority would suffice if the battle goes to the second round, with voting expected to take at least one hour.

site_title: Far from the madding crowd: China's rich seek own islands
summary: China's wealthy individuals, like entrepreneur Lin Dong, are buying private islands in the South China Sea, with over 600 island owners, mostly corporations and individuals for tourism and pleasure. However, uncertainty over bureaucratic land ownership restrictions blights their paradise, with Lin estimating he could be evicted if he builds on his island. China claims 14,500 km of coastline and 7,300 islands, but only allows the sale of island land use rights, valid for 50 years, to companies rather than individuals.

site_title: SE Asia vows to rescue "boat people"
summary: Southeast Asian nations agreed to intensify search and rescue efforts for stranded migrants, with over 4,000 migrants already landed in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Myanmar, and Bangladesh since a crackdown on people-smuggling gangs began. A meeting in Bangkok established an anti-trafficking task force and approved recommendations to address the crisis's root causes, with Myanmar participating despite denying it is the source of the problem. The agreement includes provisions for promoting human rights and economic development in migrant-sending countries, but the Rohingya minority in Myanmar remains a contentious issue.

site_title: Singapore Post to enhance dividend policy
summary: Singapore Post Limited has announced plans to enhance its dividend policy, aiming for a total annual dividend payout of 7 cents per share to be paid on a quarterly basis starting from the financial year ending March 31, 2016. This represents an increase from the proposed total annual dividend of 6.25 cents per share. The company's board has also recommended a special dividend of 0.75 cents per share for the financial year ended March 31, 2015.

site_title: Asia-Northern Europe freight rates at lowest since 2009
summary: Shipping freight rates for containers from Asia to Northern Europe have fallen 23% to $342 per 20-foot container, the lowest level since 2009. The drop is attributed to overcapacity of vessels and sluggish trade. This marks a significant decrease, halving the rate from its previous level. The decline is expected to continue due to the ongoing trade imbalance between Asia and Northern Europe.

site_title: US dealmaking at record year-to-date high
summary: Dealmaking in the US has reached a record high, with US$746.9 billion in mergers and acquisitions from January 1 to May 28, a 52% increase from the same period in 2014. Notable deals include Charter Communications' acquisition of Time Warner Cable for $56 billion and Avago Technologies' purchase of Broadcom Corp for $37 billion. Global M&A activity is up 35% year-over-year, with US$1.7 trillion of deals struck.

site_title: Retail refresh
summary: Singapore's malls are revamping to attract shoppers with fresh brands, new extensions, and innovative concepts. Several malls, including Takashimaya SC, Orchard Road, and VivoCity, have introduced new levels, expanded existing space, and infused their line-ups with new-to-market brands. These revamps aim to fill the gap between mass-market and high-end luxury brands, offering affordable luxury options. Malls are also focusing on creating a seamless shopping experience, with features like direct access to MRT stations and high foot traffic. The goal is to make malls unique destinations, rather than just another run-of-the-mill shopping center.
