Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Fifa suspects face quick extradition to US, Swiss experts say
summary: Swiss authorities expect extradition of seven senior FIFA officials arrested on corruption charges to the US to occur within months, with a possible timeline of two months to a few months. The men, from Latin America and the Caribbean, have contested extradition, but Swiss law allows for a relatively straightforward process, with the US having 40 days to make a formal request. Switzerland has a history of efficiently handling extraditions, as seen in cases involving Roman Polanski and Adnan Khashoggi.

images.alt_text: It will probably be a matter of just months before seven senior FIFA officials arrested in Switzerland can be extradited to the United States to face corruption charges, Swiss legal experts said on Friday.

site_title: Opec officials celebrate better market ahead of key meeting
summary: Opec officials expect a calmer market ahead of their June 5 meeting, citing rising global demand and reduced supply. This is despite the global oil glut, with prices improving as a result. Opec officials indicated that production policies will likely remain unchanged, following the decision not to cut output in November 2014. The market has adjusted itself since then, and demand is expected to continue improving.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower, closing at 1,747.52 after 2.23 billion lots valued at RM3.69 billion were traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 370-424.

site_title: Teeing up for good times again
summary: The 2015 BT Corporate Golf League kicked off with a networking night at Singapore Pools' Livewire. The event, now in its sixth edition, brings together top business executives and decision makers for golf, camaraderie, and networking. Returning teams include Audi Singapore, Bank of Singapore, and KPMG, while new teams include Abeo Electra and Consistel. The League, presented by Audi Singapore, has delivered great golf and entertainment over the past five years.

site_title: New putters from Scotty Cameron
summary: Scotty Cameron, a renowned golf putter craftsman, has introduced two new putter models: Roundback and GoLo. These additions expand his existing range, offering golfers new options for improved performance.

site_title: Opec supply, resurgent shale seen keeping oil prices weak
summary: Oil prices are expected to remain relatively weak for the rest of 2015 due to ample global supply from traditional Middle East producers and the resurgence of US shale production. A Reuters survey of 28 analysts predicts the global oil benchmark North Sea Brent crude will average $61.60 a barrel in 2015, close to current levels. Opec is likely to maintain its joint production target of 30 million barrels per day and keep output above that level, further supporting weak prices.

site_title: Father & son
summary: A father-son duo, Dru Davis and his father, Davis Davis, made headlines. Dru, a sophomore at Alabama, won his first college golf tournament, the Puerto Rico Classic, on February 24, 2015, hours before his father was named US Ryder Cup captain for 2016.

site_title: China sets higher standards for new petrochemical projects
summary: China has raised standards for new petrochemical projects to boost efficiency and alleviate public concerns. The National Development and Reform Commission set new requirements for crude distillation units, ethylene units, and refining units, including higher processing capacities and stricter emission standards. New petrochemical complexes must be built on islands or abandoned land, with a minimum capacity of 40 million tonnes per year. The goal is to increase sector efficiency and address public opposition to projects perceived as hazardous.

site_title: Efficient performer
summary: The Volvo S80 T5 Drive-E is a fuel-efficient and powerful sedan, boasting a 2.0-litre turbocharged engine producing 245 hp and 350 Newton-metres of torque. With an 8-speed automatic transmission, it achieves a fuel consumption of 6.2 litres per 100 km under the combined cycle, a 25% improvement over its predecessor. The S80 is also responsive and smooth on the road, with a 0-100 kmh time of 6.5 seconds. Its large cabin, boot, and comfortable ride make it a cost-effective option in its class.

site_title: Govt accepts proposals on moneylending regulation
summary: The Singapore government has accepted 12 recommendations from the Advisory Committee On Moneylending to strengthen the country's moneylending regulatory regime. The recommendations aim to protect borrowers while allowing the industry to remain commercially viable. Key changes include capping interest rates at 4% per month, limiting upfront administrative fees to 10% of the loan principal, and capping late fees at $60 per month. The government's goal is to create a more robust and efficient marketplace for moneylending.

site_title: BOJ inflation gauge at zero as cheap oil offsets efforts to reflate economy
summary: The Bank of Japan's main inflation gauge slowed to zero in April, as cheaper oil prices offset efforts to reflate the economy. Core consumer prices rose 0.3% from a year earlier, exceeding economists' forecasts. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is betting on stronger growth driven by cheaper oil to eventually spur inflation, despite warning of temporary price drops. The BOJ is expected to expand policy again, with 21 of 36 economists predicting a stimulus boost by the end of October.

site_title: All parties need to move on Greece: US Treasury Secretary Lew
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew stated that Greece and its creditors must move towards a deal to keep the country in the European single currency. Lew emphasized the need for flexibility from the European Central Bank, International Monetary Fund, and European Commission in exchange for bailout funds. He noted that Greece needs to make tough economic reforms, but insisted that a resolution is possible without a crisis, beneficial for everyone and the global economy.

site_title: NTUC fully supports NWC's recommendations
summary: Singapore's National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) fully supports the National Wages Council's (NWC) 2015-2016 wage guidelines, recognizing the need for sustainable wage increases in a tight labor market. The guidelines consider company performance and prospects, focusing on productivity growth. NTUC will continue to engage companies to implement the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) for all workers in every sector. The guidelines aim to grant a fair wage increase to employees.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: MND appeals court judgment which turned down application to appoint accountants at WP-run town council
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has appealed a High Court judgment dismissing its application to appoint independent accountants to the Workers' Party-run Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East Town Council (AHPETC). The MND claims the government cannot disburse public funds to AHPETC due to serious findings by the Auditor-General's Office and the High Court. The appeal was filed on the advice of the Attorney-General's Chambers, following a judgment that turned down the MND's application.

site_title: Fifa congress resumes after bomb threat in Zurich
summary: Swiss police investigated an anonymous bomb threat at the Fifa congress in Zurich, prompting a 45-minute pause and initial denial of re-entry to the auditorium. The threat was made by telephone to a Zurich newsroom, but no one was evacuated. A search was conducted, and the premises were cleared by authorities. Congress participants and media representatives were later allowed back into the auditorium with no additional security measures. The congress resumed after the search, with Fifa Secretary General Jerome Valcke stating that the premises had been cleared.

site_title: Watchdog suggests EU take less rigid view of foreign derivatives rules
summary: The European Union's top markets regulator, Steven Maijoor, suggests the EU should take a less rigid view of foreign derivatives rules to avoid disputes with other countries. The EU and US have been at odds over whether US rules for derivatives are equivalent to EU rules, which could impact European banks' use of US clearing houses. Maijoor proposes a more granular assessment of equivalence decisions and calls for global-level rules to avoid future differences. The EU Commission is expected to push back its decision deadline on US rules by six months to December.

site_title: Indian economy grows 7.5% y/y in March quarter; by 7.3% in 2014/15
summary: India's economic growth accelerated to 7.5% in the March quarter, exceeding forecasted 7.3% annual growth. This marks the first time the country has surpassed 7.5% growth since 2011. For the fiscal year 2014/15, growth was 7.3%, down from an earlier official estimate of 7.4%. The revised growth rates indicate a strong economic performance, but analysts note that the Indian economy still faces challenges such as high inflation and a large fiscal deficit.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's National Wages Council released guidelines for 2015/2016, focusing on skills to boost productivity growth. Despite weak productivity, Singapore's exports are expected to rebound in the next five years due to emerging markets' economic and trade rejuvenation. Moneylenders in Singapore will face stricter rules, including a monthly interest cap of 4% and a late fee cap of $60. Bank lending in Singapore declined 1.1% in April, with business lending contracting sharply. The STI dropped 1.7% over the week, amid global market volatility.

site_title: Tat Hong reports net loss of S$17.08m for Q4 FY2015
summary: Tat Hong Holdings reported a net loss of S$17.08 million for Q4 FY2015, down from a net profit of S$4.2 million in the same quarter of 2014. Revenue fell 12% year-on-year to S$136.64 million, with all divisions experiencing weaker performances. The group's net profit for FY2015 plummeted 85% to S$4.87 million, significantly lower than the previous year's S$32.81 million.

site_title: Economy in US shrank 0.7% in first quarter as trade gap jumped
summary: The US economy shrank 0.7% in the first quarter due to harsh winter weather, a strong dollar, and port delays. This revised estimate is higher than the initial 0.2% gain and contradicts the median forecast of 84 economists. The trade gap jumped, with exports declining due to a strong dollar and imports increasing after labor disputes at West Coast ports were resolved. Federal Reserve officials expect this setback to be temporary, leading to consideration of interest rate hikes this year.

images.alt_text: The world's largest economy hit a bigger ditch in the first quarter than initially estimated, held back by harsh winter weather, a strong dollar and delays at ports.

site_title: Oil fund's biggest outflow in 6 years shows rally may stall
summary: The US Oil Fund, the largest US exchange-traded fund tracking oil, is experiencing its largest two-month outflow in six years, with $1 billion withdrawn in April and May. This follows a 30% rally in oil prices, which may be stalling. Oil prices have rebounded from a six-year low due to speculation that reduced drilling will decrease output, but investors are now pulling out, citing concerns about another price drop. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is expected to maintain its production target, and analysts predict a supply surplus will push oil prices down to $55.

site_title: Oil industry group slams US EPA's renewable fuels proposal
summary: The American Petroleum Institute (API) has strongly opposed the US EPA's proposal for renewable fuels use from 2014 to 2016, calling for a program overhaul. API President Jack Gerard stated that US ethanol use has reached a saturation point without significant infrastructure changes, and consumers do not want biofuels. The EPA proposed 17.4 billion gallons of renewable fuels for 2016, prompting the API to urge Congress to repeal or reform the biofuels program.

site_title: Oil prices firm on mixed US stockpiles report
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday after a mixed US report showed a decline in crude and gasoline reserves, but a rise in output that could exacerbate the global supply glut. US oil prices jumped 71 cents to $58.39 per barrel, while Brent North Sea crude rose 85 cents to $63.16 per barrel. The report showed a 2.8 million-barrel decline in US commercial crude inventories, but a 304,000-barrel-per-day increase in production. The market is awaiting the release of the US GDP report for further clues on demand.

site_title: Golden Agri-linked Widjajas tap S'pore investors for acquisitions
summary: Indonesian billionaire Eka Tjipta Widjaja's family is seeking control of London-listed mining company Asia Resource Minerals plc (ARMS) through a reverse takeover bid. The move aims to expand the family's coal mining empire and become one of Indonesia's top four producers. Golden Agri-Resources Ltd, another family-owned company, has received S$4.3 billion in loans and bonds to fund its expansion. The family's plans coincide with Indonesian President Joko Widodo's plan to build 35,000 megawatts of electricity over the next five years.

site_title: New chartered accreditation for rail engineers
summary: Singapore has introduced a new chartered accreditation for rail engineers, expanding the Institution of Engineers, Singapore's (IES) Chartered Engineer (CEng) programme. The move aims to address the growing demand for railway professionals as Singapore's rail network expands to 360km by 2030. The IES CEng qualification provides accreditation to engineers in fields that don't require Professional Engineer registration, based on independent peer review. Rail engineers can apply from end-2015, and the accreditation will support the SkillsFuture movement and raise industry standards.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Europe: Shares tread water on Greek uncertainty; Syngenta rises
summary: European shares remained unchanged at the open on Friday, stuck within their recent range as investors awaited Greek debt talks updates. The FTSEurofirst 300 index was flat at 1,615.96 points. Syngenta shares rose 2.3% after building defenses for a possible higher bid from Monsanto. Greece's government aims to reach a cash-for-reforms deal by Sunday, but euro zone officials and IMF head express concerns about the country's potential exit from the euro zone.

site_title: China central bank wants "healthy" stock market, warns of debt risk
summary: China's central bank has expressed a desire for a "healthy" stock market, despite a recent 6% slump in Chinese shares. The People's Bank of China warned of a slowing economy and rising debt levels, citing risks from heavily-indebted local governments and a slowing real estate market. The bank vowed to deepen China's financial market through reforms, but did not address concerns about the stock market's volatility, with Chinese stocks rising 140% in the last 12 months.

site_title: Singapore: Not a good week for stocks as STI drops 1.7% in wake of HK, China selloff
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 1.7% to 3,392.11, following a selloff in Hong Kong and China. The market has been under pressure due to comparisons with its regional peers. Despite improved volume, the decline was attributed to the collapse of the Hong Kong-Shanghai connect. The STI lost 58 points over the week, with Friday's session seeing a 25.66-point drop.

site_title: Sweden-Canada group picked for LaGuardia terminal work
summary: A consortium led by Swedish construction company Skanska AB and Vancouver airport operator Vantage Airport Group Ltd has been selected to finance, build, and manage a $3.6 billion replacement for LaGuardia Airport's 50-year-old central terminal. The new 35-gate terminal will feature improved amenities, security, and screening. Construction is set to start in 2016 and is expected to be completed five to six months sooner than a traditional public project, with the consortium responsible for cost overruns. The project is part of a broader redevelopment of the airport, guided by a master plan.

site_title: Chinese teapots provide edge over US for world's top oil buyer
summary: China is poised to further expand its lead as the world's largest buyer of crude oil, thanks in part to "teapot" refineries that account for a third of the country's processing capacity. New rules will nearly double the amount of crude these small refineries can import, boosting China's appetite for foreign oil. China's record purchases in April, 7.4 million barrels a day, surpass the US, which imported 7.3 million barrels a day, and are expected to continue through the year, creating a global supply deficit by the end of the year.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB secures US$1b from Abu Dhabi fund ahead of loan deadline
summary: Malaysia's state fund 1MDB has secured $1 billion in funding from Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Company (IPIC) ahead of a loan deadline, easing debt worries. The deal, finalized on June 4, allows 1MDB to repay a $975 million loan to a global banking syndicate. This move brings short-term respite to the fund, which has amassed $11.6 billion in borrowings and faces controversy over its management. The deal is a significant step towards reducing 1MDB's debt levels and is part of a restructuring plan aimed at rationalizing the fund by early next year.

site_title: Macquarie sees ticking bomb for India as restructured loans fail
summary: India's state-run banks face a growing crisis as restructured loans sour at a record pace, threatening their appetite for new lending. The outstanding restructured loans, valued at 570 billion rupees, almost doubled in the year ended March 31. Macquarie Group has warned that this debt is a "ticking time bomb," and Standard & Poor's predicts a record portion will fail in 2016. The industry's iron and steel sector is particularly vulnerable, with 40% of standard restructured loans to infrastructure and steel companies expected to slip into nonperforming assets in the coming quarters.

site_title: Government accepts National Wages Council's recommendations
summary: The Singapore government has accepted the National Wages Council's (NWC) recommendations for 2015/2016, which include real wage increases in line with productivity growth over the long term. The NWC recommended employers to share productivity gains fairly with workers and to grant a built-in wage increase of at least S$60 for workers earning up to S$1,100. The government also supports restructuring employer medical benefits to portable medical benefits to improve cost-effectiveness. The CPF salary ceiling will increase to S$6,000 from January 2016, and further increases will be made to older workers' CPF contribution rates.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China securities regulator says to keep contact with global index companies
summary: China's securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission, will maintain contact with global index companies to facilitate yuan-denominated A shares' inclusion in global indexes. This move aims to bring long-term capital into China's stock market. The regulator's statement comes ahead of a June 9 decision on China A share inclusion by MSCI Inc.

site_title: SNEF calls for focus on productivity to sustain wage hikes
summary: Singapore's National Employers Federation (SNEF) has urged the focus on productivity to sustain wage hikes as employment growth slows. The economy is expected to grow 2-4% annually over the next five years, with employment growth slowing from 66,000 to 20,000 per year. SNEF endorses the National Wages Council's 2015/2016 guidelines to raise productivity, ensuring real wage growth is in line with productivity growth. This will enhance competitiveness and ensure sustainable real wage increases.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: German retail sales rebound in April
summary: German retail sales rebounded 1.7% in April, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 0.8% increase. This marks a positive sign for private consumption driving growth in Europe's largest economy, despite weakness in the first quarter. Year-over-year retail sales increased 1.0%, boosted by spending on shoes, clothes, and other items. The solid 3.1% increase in retail sales for the first four months of the year suggests continued household spending will support economic growth.

site_title: Euro zone lending slows to standstill in April
summary: Euro zone lending to households and firms has stalled at 0.0% for the first time in two months, according to European Central Bank data. This follows a rise in March and comes despite a massive stimulus scheme launched by the ECB. The M3 measure of money circulating in the euro zone grew 5.3% in April, higher than the previous month's 4.6%. The slow lending growth has raised concerns about the struggling euro zone economy, which is recovering despite policy efforts.

site_title: CPIB arrests Singaporean, several others suspected of football match fixing
summary: The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) in Singapore arrested a Singaporean suspect of football match fixing and several others of different nationalities. The operation, carried out on May 28-29, was based on information received and resulted in the arrests. The CPIB is investigating potential match-fixing involving football matches, but no further details on the suspects or the scope of the investigation have been released.

site_title: National Wages Council issues guidelines for 2015/2016
summary: The National Wages Council released guidelines for 2015/2016, focusing on skills to ignite productivity growth. The council recommends built-in wage increases for employers based on business performance and workers' contributions. For low-wage workers, the threshold increases from S$1,000 to S$1,100, with a minimum S$60 increase. The guidelines also encourage restructuring of employer medical benefits to portable medical benefits.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: We need to fix Fifa right now, Blatter tells congress
summary: Sepp Blatter, FIFA president, urged members to "fix FIFA right now" amid corruption allegations, calling for calmness and a return to stability. Seven high-ranking officials were arrested in Zurich in a Swiss police operation at US request, further rocking the organization. Blatter's call to action comes as FIFA faces intense scrutiny and pressure to reform its governance structure.

images.alt_text: Sepp Blatter told members of world football's governing body on Friday that they must help "fix Fifa right now" amidst allegations of corruption.

site_title: New career roadmap for SMRT engineers
summary: SMRT Corporation has introduced the SMRT Train Engineer Professionalisation (STEP) scheme to improve the reliability of its train services and increase the attractiveness of its engineering jobs. The structured career roadmap offers three career tracks, rail engineering courses, leadership training, job rotation, and mentorship. STEP aims to prepare SMRT engineers for the new Chartered Engineer (Singapore) accreditation and support the company's expansion to meet Singapore's future rail network growth. The initiative is part of SMRT's measures to prepare for a doubling of its rail capacity by 2030.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

To improve the reliability of its train services and increase the attractiveness of its engineering jobs, public transport operator SMRT Corporation has introduced on Friday a structured career roadmap for its rail engineers.

site_title: Equinix to buy Telecity for US$3.6 billion, ending Dutch deal
summary: Equinix Inc agreed to buy Telecity Group Plc for £2.35 billion (S$4.8 billion), ending Telecity's planned merger with Interxion Holding NV. The deal, recommended by Telecity's board, includes a mixture of cash and stock worth 1,145 pence per share, 5% more than the latest closing price. The acquisition aims to create a trans-Atlantic data-centre operator, as data centres explore mergers due to increased remote data storage and access.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.11% down, Shanghai sinks further
summary: Hong Kong shares ended 0.11% down, while Shanghai shares finished slightly down after a volatile session. The Hang Seng Index fell 30.12 points to 27,424.19, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.18% to 4,611.74. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 1.32% to 2,793.25. The losses followed a painful sell-off in the previous session, with the Shanghai Composite Index plummeting 6.50% on Thursday.

site_title: Blatter expected to win re-election despite soccer corruption scandal
summary: Sepp Blatter is expected to win re-election as FIFA president despite a corruption scandal engulfing the sport's governing body. Blatter promised more transparency and urged unity, but critics argue he has not done enough to combat corruption. Prince Ali bin Al Hussein is the only challenger, but his chances appear slim given the support of the Asian and African confederations and many Latin American states. The scandal has led to calls for a boycott of the 2018 World Cup and criticism from major sponsors, but the numbers appear to be in Blatter's favor.

images.alt_text: World soccer boss Sepp Blatter was expected to be re-elected on Friday, defying growing calls for him to step down in the face of corruption scandals engulfing the sport's governing body.

site_title: Four senior executives receive national awards for contributions to Singapore
summary: Four senior executives, Dominic Barton, Michael R Splinter, Paul Graham, and Gautam Banerjee, have received national awards for their contributions to Singapore. They received the Public Service Star (Distinguished Friends of Singapore) and Public Service Medal (Friends of Singapore) for their outstanding economic contributions to the country. The awards were initiated by the Economic Development Board in 1998 to recognize senior executives who have made significant contributions to Singapore's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Chinese developer Evergrande shares down after share placement
summary: Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd shares plummeted 16% on May 29, 2015, after offering new shares at a 17.95% discount, resulting in HK$4.6 billion in net proceeds. The share placement followed a suspension of trading on Thursday.

site_title: Nike says Fifa indictment does not allege criminal conduct by company
summary: Nike Inc stated that charging documents in the Fifa bribery scandal do not allege the company's involvement in criminal conduct. The US authorities charged nine soccer officials and five sports media executives with over $150 million in bribes. Nike said it cooperated with authorities and that no employee was aware of or participated in any bribery or kickback scheme. The company is not a Fifa partner and is trying to challenge Adidas' dominance in soccer by sponsoring top players and teams.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.20% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.20% lower on Friday, marking a third consecutive day of losses, following a sell-off on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index fell 56.03 points to 27,398.28.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks squeak out gain in 11-day rally
summary: Tokyo stocks rose for an 11th consecutive day, extending their longest winning streak since 1988. The Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.06% to 20,563.15, while the Topix index rose 0.05% to 1,673.65. The rally marks the longest in over 25 years, with investors seemingly brushing off US President Trump's latest threats to stocks.

site_title: Buhari to be sworn in as Nigerian president
summary: Nigerian President-elect Muhammadu Buhari will be sworn in on May 29, 2015, after a historic democratic transfer of power. Buhari, a former military ruler, has vowed to tackle corruption and defeat the Islamist Boko Haram militants. His election victory has inspired hope for a new direction in Africa's most populous nation, which has struggled with economic growth and a raging insurgency. About 30 countries, including South Africa and the US, will attend his swearing-in ceremony.

site_title: Swiss economy contracts in first quarter after franc cap dropped
summary: Switzerland's economy contracted 0.2% in the first quarter, reversing a 0.5% growth in the previous quarter, according to data released by the State Secretariat for Economic Affairs. The contraction was attributed to a weakening trade balance, particularly in goods and services. This marks the first GDP data release following the Swiss National Bank's decision in January to remove the 1.20 euro cap on the franc, allowing it to float freely against the euro. Analysts had forecast a 0.1% drop in GDP.

site_title: China confirms first MERS case: state media
summary: China has confirmed its first case of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), a viral respiratory illness. The case was reported by China's state television, China Central Television. Authorities had been investigating a suspected victim from South Korea who skipped home quarantine to visit China. This development comes as the Asian garment industry prepares for higher US tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from President Trump targeting Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: China: Stocks cap wild week with two-day drop as PetroChina falls
summary: China's stock market ended a wild week with a two-day drop, with the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.2% to 4,611.75. PetroChina fell 2.3%, Evergrande Real Estate Group Ltd dropped 27%, and the CSI 300 Index rose 0.1%. The market's volatility has raised concerns that China's world-beating rally may have gone too far, too fast. Industry groups saw mixed results, with energy companies dropping 1.5% and healthcare and technology shares rising 2.4%.

site_title: Japan household spending logs surprise 1.3% drop in April: govt
summary: Japan's household spending dropped 1.3% in April, extending a 13-month decline. This defies market expectations that it would rise for the first time since the sales tax hike in 2014. The drop is attributed to the prolonged economic stagnation in the country.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls, posts the worst monthly loss in 6 months
summary: The South Korean won fell 3.2% against the dollar on a monthly basis, posting its worst monthly loss in six months. The currency ended local trade down 0.2% at 1,108.2 per dollar, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) falling 0.6% during the month. Investors fear the weaker yen will weigh on exports, raising concerns about smoothing operations by foreign exchange authorities. This marks the sharpest monthly losses since November, with the KOSPI also experiencing its fourth consecutive monthly losing streak.

site_title: Rupiah slump sends Indonesian borrowers back home
summary: Indonesian borrowers are shifting away from overseas financings due to a slumping rupiah and rising hedging costs. Telecom operator Indosat recently refinanced its US dollar debt in the local rupiah market, citing cheaper funding options. The government is pressuring companies to reduce foreign currency liabilities, leading to a trend of local companies tapping the local market. Hedging costs have risen due to the rupiah's volatility, making it more expensive for borrowers to hedge their US dollar exposure, with costs now around 4% of the hedged amount.

site_title: Shell, Sembcorp among 4 short-listed in second stage to import LNG into Singapore
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore has short-listed four companies - BG Singapore Gas Marketing, Pavilion Gas, Sembcorp Industries, and Shell Eastern Petroleum - to participate in stage two of its Request-for-Proposal (RFP) to import liquefied natural gas (LNG) into Singapore. The short-listed companies will negotiate with potential LNG buyers and submit proposals to EMA for evaluation. Up to two companies will be appointed to import LNG, with exclusive franchises valid for three years or until they sell 1 million tonnes of LNG.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly higher, Nikkei rises for 11th day
summary: Asian markets rose Friday, with Japan's Nikkei up for an 11th straight session, while Shanghai fell for a second day. The yen sat near 12-year lows against the dollar due to expected interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The euro edged up but remains under pressure due to concerns over Greece's bailout. Tokyo rose 0.11%, Sydney added 1.45%, and Seoul gained 0.36%. Shanghai recovered slightly after a 6.5% fall on Thursday.

site_title: Gold holds above 2-1/2-week low but set for second weekly drop
summary: Gold prices hovered above a 2-1/2-week low on Friday, recovering slightly after a decline, as the dollar weakened following recent gains. The metal is still expected to fall for a second straight week due to higher US interest rates. Spot gold was at $1,188.35 an ounce, down 1.4% for the week. The US Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike is seen as a key factor, as it would boost the dollar and decrease gold's appeal.

site_title: Oil gains 1 per cent after US stocks drop for 4th week
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Friday after US crude inventories fell for the fourth consecutive week, despite a stronger dollar. July Brent crude rose 51 cents to $63.09 a barrel, while US crude was up 65 cents at $58.33 a barrel. Wildfires in Canada also supported prices. The fall in US crude stocks contradicted forecasts and came ahead of the Memorial Day holiday, which marks the start of peak summer driving season. Oil prices are set to post losses for a second straight week due to a stronger dollar.

site_title: Myanmar says don't 'single us out' at migrant crisis talks
summary: Myanmar rebuked the UN for singling out the country for criticism on the Rohingya migrant crisis, saying it's being unfairly targeted. The UN called on Myanmar to address the root causes of the crisis, which includes denying citizenship to the majority of its 1.3 million Rohingya Muslims. Myanmar's delegate said the issue is an internal matter, while the UN estimates there are 2,500 more migrants feared trapped at sea as the monsoon season approaches. The crisis has exposed gaping holes in the rule of law across several countries, with observers questioning the capacity of Southeast Asian neighbors to act on the issue.

images.alt_text: Myanmar's Foreign Ministry Director-General Htin Lynn speaks during an international meeting on migration in the Indian Ocean attended by delegates from 17 nations in Bangkok on May 29, 2015.

site_title: Blatter defiant as re-election vote looms
summary: FIFA President Sepp Blatter is set to face re-election despite a corruption scandal, with critics calling for his resignation. Governments, sponsors, and sports groups have joined forces to condemn the corruption, with British Prime Minister David Cameron and French President Francois Hollande calling for Blatter's resignation. However, Blatter has the support of African and Asian allies and is likely to win re-election, despite US and Swiss investigations into corruption involving FIFA officials.

site_title: Thailand hosts talks on Southeast Asia migrant crisis
summary: Thailand hosts a one-day meeting with 17 nations to discuss the Southeast Asia migrant crisis, which has seen thousands of migrants fleeing on boats across the Bay of Bengal. The talks aim to address the root causes of the crisis, but observers question the meeting's effectiveness. Over 3,500 migrants have arrived on Thai, Malaysian, and Indonesian soil, with 2,500 more feared trapped at sea. The meeting comes after Thailand's crackdown on people smuggling, which has thrown the industry into disarray and led to increased international pressure on countries to address the issue.

site_title: Japan April nationwide core CPI rises 0.3% y-o-y
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 0.3% in April from a year earlier, exceeding market forecasts. The increase is attributed to the sales tax hike in April last year, which inflated inflation by 2.0 percentage points. Excluding the tax hike's effect, the core CPI remained flat year-over-year. This keeps inflation distant from the Bank of Japan's 2% target.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday morning
summary: Malaysia's shares fell on Friday morning, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.30 points to 1,752.26 points. Volume reached 78.78 million lots worth RM25.9 million, with 105 gainers and 90 losers.

site_title: Japan April industrial output up 1.0% m-o-m
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 1.0% in April, its first gain in three months, exceeding the median estimate of 0.8%. Manufacturers predict a 0.5% increase in May and a 0.5% decline in June.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat; glass and ceramics shares fall
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Friday, with the main TAIEX index rising 4.47 points to 9,717.31. The glass and ceramics subindex fell 1%, limiting gains. The country's stocks trailed regional markets, with Singapore's STI rising 0.4% on Thursday. US stocks also edged to fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia new home sales highest in at least 5 years: HIA
summary: Australia saw its highest new home sales in at least 5 years in April, with a 0.6% increase, according to the Housing Industry Association. Sales of multi-unit homes rose 0.9%, while detached homes saw a 0.4% increase. The growth is attributed to falling mortgage rates and rising house values, with the eastern seaboard driving the growth. HIA chief economist Harley Dale expects the 'multi-unit' sector to continue driving the new home building cycle.

site_title: Australia: Shares strengthen on month-end settlements
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% to a three-week high on Friday, driven by a "buy on dips" strategy as investors awaited the end of the month. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit 5,803.0 points, with banks and mining sector stocks leading the gain. However, analysts remain pessimistic about the outlook due to the fading mining boom and expected monthly dip in May.

site_title: Visa's tough stance on Fifa augurs more sponsor demands
summary: Visa has publicly warned FIFA that it may end its sponsorship if the governing body does not address corruption issues, prompting other major sponsors like Coca-Cola and McDonald's to take a tough stance. Following US prosecutors' indictment of nine FIFA officials, Visa expressed "disappointment and concern" with FIFA's handling of the scandal, calling for swift and immediate action to address the issues within the organization. Other sponsors are likely to follow Visa's lead, putting pressure on FIFA to restore its reputation and rebuild a culture with strong ethical practices.

site_title: Moneylenders in Singapore to face more stringent rules: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's government has accepted 12 of 15 recommendations to strengthen its moneylending regulatory regime. The new rules include a maximum monthly interest rate of 4% and a late fee of S$60. The Advisory Committee on moneylending, set up by the Ministry of Law, was tasked with reviewing and strengthening the existing regime. The new rules are expected to provide better protection for consumers and help curb predatory lending practices.

site_title: Japan issues evacuation order after volcano erupts
summary: A violent volcanic eruption at Mount Shindake in southern Japan's Kuchinoerabu island on May 29, 2015, forced the evacuation of 137 inhabitants and shot a 9,000-meter ash column into the air. The eruption triggered a five-minute quake and a pyroclastic flow, with ash blanketing the breakwaters and discolored the sea. Japan's government and emergency services have been activated, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe mobilizing coastguard boats and military helicopters to ensure resident safety.

images.alt_text: Japan Meteorological Agency's Senior Coordinator for volcanic affairs Sadayuki Kitagawa holds an emergency news conference following the eruption of a volcano in southern Japan, as a screen shows a map of the volcano on Kuchinoerabujima, at the agency in Tokyo on May 29, 2015.

site_title: New Chartered Engineer accreditation for railway professionals
summary: Railway professionals in Singapore can now attain the Chartered Engineers (CEng) professional accreditation, introduced by the Institution of Engineers, Singapore (IES). A memorandum of understanding was signed with the Land Transport Authority, Singapore Workforce Development Agency, SBS Transit, and SMRT Corporation to support the accreditation process. SMRT and SBS Transit will sponsor fees, while a common set of industry standards for railway engineering competencies will be established. The move aims to address growing demand for rail engineers as Singapore's rail network is set to double by 2030.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Singapore: STI opens down 0.73% after Fed official's remarks on rate hikes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened down 0.73% on Friday, falling 24.9 points to 3,392.87, after US Federal Reserve President John Williams hinted at potential rate hikes later this year. Bank stocks and Singapore Airlines led the decline. The move follows a slightly lower US stock market on Thursday.

site_title: SIA rolls out special livery for SG50
summary: Singapore Airlines has unveiled special livery on two of its A380s to celebrate the nation's 50th birthday, SG50. The 10m-tall design featuring the Singapore flag will be on both sides of the fuselage until year-end. The airline will also operate a charity flight and offer promotions to encourage overseas Singaporeans and visitors to travel during the SG50 celebrations.

site_title: China April services trade deficit US$17.3b: fx regulator
summary: China reported a US$17.3 billion deficit in services trade in April and a total deficit of US$58.5 billion for the first four months of 2015, according to the State Administration of Foreign Exchange. This was despite a surplus of US$31.1 billion in services trade in April. China's trade surplus in goods was US$148.9 billion for the same period. The data suggests China's economy is experiencing a slowdown, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: South Korea to ban taxi services by private drivers in blow to Uber
summary: South Korean lawmakers passed a bill banning private drivers from providing taxi services, effectively outlawing Uber's low-cost uberX service. The ban, set to take effect by year-end, marks the latest setback for Uber, which has faced regulatory battles globally. Despite the ban, Uber still operates two services in South Korea: uberTaxi and UberBLACK. The company has been indicted in Korea and faces regulatory scrutiny in other countries, including an Italian court ban on its uberPOP service.

site_title: Fifa probe: US will vote against Blatter's re-election
summary: US Soccer Federation president Sunil Gulati joins the bid to oust FIFA president Sepp Blatter, voting for Prince Ali bin Al Hussein instead. This move risks the US chances of hosting another World Cup. The US authorities have accused FIFA of "rampant, systemic and deep-rooted corruption" and seven officials were arrested on bribery charges. Gulati believes better governance and integrity are more important than hosting a World Cup, prioritizing the bid for Prince Ali over potential US hosting chances.

site_title: Former Lehman chief blames crisis on 'perfect storm'
summary: Former Lehman Brothers CEO Richard Fuld blames the 2008 financial crisis on a "perfect storm" of factors, including government policies boosting home ownership and swelling home prices. He suggests that Lehman's demise was a "mandated bankruptcy" and that he also bears some responsibility. Fuld expresses concern over growing income inequality, slowing Chinese growth, and other global issues.

images.alt_text: Richard Fuld, former chief executive officer of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc., center, arrives at the Grand Hyatt Hotel to speak at the Marcum MicroCap Conference, in New York, U.S. on May 28, 2015.

site_title: Widjaja clan seeking acquisition support in Singapore
summary: Indonesian billionaire Eka Tjipta Widjaja is seeking acquisition support in Singapore to fund his expansion plans. His family's companies, including Golden Agri-Resources and Golden Energy & Resources, have received S$4.3 billion in loans and bonds from Singapore investors to build an empire worth US$7.5 billion. The family aims to gain control of Asia Resource Minerals Plc, a move that could make them one of Indonesia's top four coal producers. This comes after Widjaja's previous company, Asia Pulp & Paper, defaulted on US$13.9 billion in debt in 2001.

site_title: South Korea April factory output down for 2nd mth, below forecasts
summary: South Korea's industrial output declined by 1.2% in April, its second consecutive monthly drop, exceeding forecasted growth. This marks the fastest decline since January. On an annual basis, industrial output dropped 2.7%, while service-sector output rose 0.5% in April. The data raises concerns about the sector's strength and recovery.

images.alt_text: South Korea's industrial output fell in April for a second straight month on monthly terms, data showed on Friday, slipping at the fastest clip since January and raising concerns over the strength of improvements in the sector.

site_title: Fifa probe: Jack Warner's sons scrambled to deposit cash hoard at US banks, US court documents show
summary: US court documents show that Daryan and Daryll Warner, sons of former Fifa Vice President Jack Warner, deposited over $600,000 in cash at US banks in 2011, using tellers and ATMs to avoid detection. The brothers and their associates made deposits in amounts below the $10,000 threshold to avoid reporting requirements. This is part of a larger investigation into a Fifa bribery scandal that involves over $150 million in bribes.

site_title: IMF head says Greek exit a possibility: newspaper
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde stated that a Greek exit from the euro zone is possible but unlikely to signal the end of the euro currency. She believes a comprehensive solution to Greece's debt problems is "very unlikely" in the next few days. Greece's government hopes to reach a cash-for-reforms deal by Sunday, but negotiations have stalled. Lagarde ruled out granting further loans without a clear reform agreement, and said it's up to Europe to take precautions to avoid a potential bankruptcy.

site_title: Airbus admits 'assembly quality problem' after A400M crash
summary: Airbus has admitted to a "serious final assembly quality problem" following the May 9 crash of an A400M military cargo plane in Spain, which killed four people. Analysis of flight recorders revealed no structural faults, but poor installation of engine control units during assembly may have led to engine malfunction. The incident is the latest in a series of setbacks for the A400M program, which has been plagued by delays and costly overruns.

site_title: Singapore's exports expected to rebound in next five years: HSBC
summary: Singapore's exports are expected to rebound in the next five years, driven by emerging markets' economic rejuvenation, particularly in Asia. The country's exports are projected to grow 3.9% globally and 5% within Asia, with the ICT sector expected to grow 6% per annum. Despite a shift in trade balance, Singapore is well-positioned to remain a global ICT player, citing its high ranking in the World Economic Forum's Networked Readiness Index.

site_title: Advanced economies to drive global trade, emerging markets' growth patchy: HSBC
summary: HSBC's global overview report forecasts advanced economies to drive global trade growth this year, boosted by a stronger US dollar and eurozone recovery. Emerging markets are expected to experience patchy growth, with Japan's exports benefiting from the weaker yen at the expense of its trading partners. The report also notes a slowdown in China's GDP growth, which may put pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
HSBC expects machinery and transport to be the main driver of merchandise trade growth over the medium term.

site_title: As economies stumble, where is Southeast Asia's fiscal firepower?
summary: Southeast Asia's fiscal firepower is dwindling as economies stumble, with the Philippines experiencing its weakest economic growth in three years. Monetary policy is losing effectiveness due to high household debt, and governments are struggling to spend their budgeted funds. Despite falling oil prices, which were expected to boost growth, fiscal policy stimulus has failed to gain traction in several key economies, including Indonesia and Thailand. Governments are facing political stalemates and corruption probes, hindering investment and limiting room for further rate cuts.

images.alt_text: A slide in the Philippines' economic growth to its weakest in three years wraps up a slew of dismal data from Southeast Asia and adds pressure on governments to unleash some of their fiscal spending firepower given the limitation of monetary policy now.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.20% lower after 10-day rally
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.20% lower on Friday, snapping a 10-day rally, amid concerns about Japan's economy fueled by lackluster data. The Nikkei 225 index fell 41.19 points to 20,510.27. Household spending dropped 1.3% year-on-year, while core inflation was 0.3%, below the Bank of Japan's 2.0% target. The market was also influenced by worries about Greece's bailout and the potential for a Greek exit from the eurozone, with the dollar easing to 123.82 yen.

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore down 1.1% in April: MAS
summary: Bank lending in Singapore declined 1.1% in April, marking the fifth consecutive monthly drop, with business lending falling 1.8% and consumer loans dipping for the first time since 2006. This contraction was mainly due to weaker trade loans and no growth in construction lending. The Monetary Authority of Singapore reported a preliminary loan balance of S$594 billion, down from S$601 billion in March.

site_title: Qantas gives passengers access to 4,000 newspaper, magazine titles via app
summary: Qantas Airways has partnered with PressReader to offer passengers access to nearly 4,000 newspaper and magazine titles via its app. Passengers can download content in over 60 languages for unlimited access 12 hours prior to their flight. The new service aims to improve Qantas' environmental credentials and provides customers with a library of titles to choose from before takeoff. This addition complements the airline's new inflight entertainment program, which offers more regular and in-depth news coverage.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Cameron urges 'flexible and imaginative' EU reforms
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron urged the EU to adopt "flexible and imaginative" reforms, seeking changes to the bloc's policies and regulations. His government published a law paving the way for a vote on Britain's EU membership by the end of 2017, as Cameron aims to secure concessions before the referendum. The prime minister will meet with EU leaders to discuss proposed reforms, including tougher requirements for EU migrants and Britain's opt-out from the "ever closer union" commitment.

site_title: Aviation attorney may mount legal case for passengers on SQ836 which fell 4,000m
summary: Aviation attorney Floyd Wisner plans to consider a legal case for passengers on Singapore Airlines Flight 836, which plummeted 4,000m after losing power to both engines on May 23. The case bears similarities to a 2008 Qantas Flight 72 incident, where Wisner successfully negotiated a settlement for over 160 passengers. He believes many passengers on SQ836 may have suffered severe emotional and physical trauma, potentially qualifying for compensation. The law firm is currently representing passengers on another incident, Air Asia Flight 8501.

site_title: Nigeria's Akinwumi Adesina voted new Africa bank chief
summary: Nigeria's Akinwumi Adesina has been elected as the new president of the African Development Bank, winning 58.10% of the vote in six rounds of voting. He will succeed Rwandan Donald Kaberuka, who held the position for two terms, and represents a country considered Africa's new economic powerhouse. Adesina inherits a financially sound institution with a AAA rating from Fitch and will manage the continent's financial attractiveness while fighting poverty and developing infrastructure.

site_title: Canada recall of Takata airbags balloons to 1.5 million
summary: Canada's recall of defective Takata airbags has grown to an estimated 1.5 million vehicles, including models from Honda, Mazda, Toyota, and others, due to a potentially deadly chemical propellant that can cause airbags to deploy explosively. No reported "abnormal deployments" have been found in Canada, but the defect has been linked to six deaths and scores of injuries globally. This is part of a larger recall, which has affected nearly 34 million vehicles worldwide.

site_title: Oil market ticks higher after US petroleum report
summary: Oil prices rose modestly on Thursday after a US petroleum report showed declines in crude and gasoline inventories, with West Texas Intermediate (WTI) advancing 17 cents to $57.68 a barrel. Crude production also rose, offsetting some of the gains. Analysts attribute the market's recovery to the larger-than-expected decline in crude and gasoline stocks, despite a build-up in production.

site_title: China: Stocks open mixed after sharp selloff
summary: China's stock market opened mixed on Friday, with the CSI300 index rising 0.1% to 4,839.53 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.4% to 4,603.47 points. The previous day's sharp plunge of 6.7% and 6.5% for the two indexes, their worst day since January 19, 2008, was attributed to concerns over margin finance and liquidity. Despite a surge of 140% over the past 12 months, economists have warned that the rally was unjustified, citing cheap credit and record margin finance of 2 trillion yuan.

site_title: UK consumer confidence slips unexpectedly in May: GfK
summary: UK consumer confidence slipped unexpectedly in May, falling to +1 from +4 in April, according to a survey by GfK. Optimism about the economy over the next 12 months reached its lowest level since January, and Britons became less upbeat about their personal financial prospects. This drop in confidence contrasts with other surveys, which show a more upbeat picture of consumer morale. Economists expect economic growth to quicken after a slow start to the year, but the latest data casts doubt on the strength of Britain's recovery.

site_title: US: Stocks dip on worries about Greece
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, following a drop in eurozone markets due to concerns over a potential Greek exit from the eurozone. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 35.97 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also decreased. The International Monetary Fund's Christine Lagarde warned of a Greek exit's potential impact on the single currency area, further fueling market worries. Analysts also attributed a decline in the Shanghai Composite Index to tighter margin requirements in Chinese markets.

site_title: Google unveils Android Pay in fresh challenge to Apple
summary: Google has unveiled Android Pay, a mobile payment system for Android devices, in a fresh challenge to Apple's mobile payments. The system, in partnership with major credit card firms and payment processing firms, allows users to store credit card information and loyalty cards on their handsets. Android Pay will generate a one-time "token" for security and will be available for download on Google Play soon, with support from over 700,000 US retail outlets. The move aims to simplify and secure mobile payments, with Google focusing on simplicity, security, and choice.

site_title: Jawbone sues Fitbit over information 'plundering'
summary: Fitbit is sued by Jawbone, alleging "systematic plundering" of confidential information by poaching employees who downloaded sensitive materials before leaving. The lawsuit claims Fitbit recruited nearly a third of Jawbone's employees and had them download information like business plans and products. Jawbone seeks financial damages and relief to prevent the former employees from using the information. The lawsuit comes as Fitbit prepares for its initial public offering, which is expected to capitalize on the growing demand for wearable devices.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yuuzoo, Dukang, Metro, Keppel DC Reit, Neo Group
summary: Yuuzoo Corporation's stock price may see significant upside, according to an Edison Investment Research report. Dukang Distillers Holdings' sharp 20.9% rise in share price has raised concerns about potential corporate activity, prompting a "trade with caution" warning from the Singapore Exchange. Metro Holdings' net profit plummeted 83% to S$7.59 million in the fourth quarter, while Keppel DC Reit has entered into an agreement to buy a Sydney building for A$43.3 million (S$45.9 million). Neo Group's net profit rose 15.7% to S$7.4 million on a 47.8% revenue increase.

site_title: A clear corporate purpose is key to outperforming rivals
summary: A clear corporate purpose is crucial for outperforming rivals, according to research. 87% of companies believe that a purpose beyond profit leads to better results. Purpose-driven organisations have higher employee satisfaction, customer advocacy, and product quality. However, only 37% of companies believe their business model is aligned with their purpose. EY has launched a purpose-led transformation service to help businesses integrate their purpose into their operations, citing success in South-east Asia as evidence that transformations are more successful when connected to a purpose.

site_title: China's duty-free shopping habits spur bond sales in S Korea
summary: South Korean retailers Hotel Shilla Co and Shinsegae Co are tapping into China's duty-free shopping habits by issuing bonds. The surge in Chinese tourists has led to a 21.5% rise in duty-free sales, with visitors from China accounting for the largest share globally. To boost tourism, authorities plan to approve three more duty-free stores by July, while companies like Shinsegae aim to transform department store buildings into duty-free shops. The growth in duty-free spending is expected to continue, driven by rising Chinese tourism.

site_title: India tipped to overtake China in Modi's first year
summary: India is expected to surpass China as the fastest-growing major economy, according to GDP data released by the government, marking Prime Minister Narendra Modi's first year in office. However, economists question the accuracy of the data, citing weak industrial activity and sluggish corporate earnings. Despite a robust headline growth rate, the economy remains sluggish, with concerns over a persistent investment logjam and mounting bad debt.

images.alt_text: A massive increase in the government's planned spending on roads, railways and ports this year is expected to break a persistent investment logjam.

site_title: Japan's April retail sales rebound, easing pressure on BOJ
summary: Japan's retail sales rebounded 5.0% in April after three months of falls, easing pressure on the Bank of Japan to expand its stimulus program. The modest increase, slightly below forecast, suggests consumer spending is reviving but momentum remains weak. The BOJ has signaled no immediate expansion of stimulus, citing signs of a pick-up in private consumption. Household spending, a key driver of the central bank's program, faces uncertainty due to deflationary mindset and looming sales tax hikes.

site_title: Prvacki's unbearable lightness of being
summary: Milenko Prvacki's abstract paintings, on display at iPreciation gallery, reveal themselves through small, incremental details, requiring a patient viewer to fully appreciate. Born in Yugoslavia, Prvacki, a Cultural Medallion recipient, explores the notion of travel and identity through his works, often incorporating postcards and memories of his past. He uses abstract forms to disguise his memories, creating a personal lexicon that serves as a surrogate for the appearance of memory, offering a unique perspective on his experiences as a dislocated person.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Fiat Chrysler boss sure of a new merger in the auto industry
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) CEO Sergio Marchionne expects a new merger in the auto industry by 2018, although he did not confirm reports of a proposed tie-up with General Motors. Marchionne made the statement during a visit to FCA's Melfi factory in southern Italy, where the company is adding 1,550 jobs. FCA returned to profitability in the first quarter of this year, thanks in part to rising US sales. The company's merger with Chrysler was finalized in 2014, and Marchionne has a history of attempting to acquire GM's European unit Opel.

images.alt_text: Fiat Chrysler chief Sergio Marchionne said on Thursday he expects a new merger in the auto industry by 2018, without confirming reports he proposed a tie-up with General Motors.

site_title: The leader who made a career out of dodging scandals
summary: Sepp Blatter, FIFA president, has faced long-standing accusations of transparency and corruption. His career spanned 40 years, from 1975 as a technical director to president. Wednesday's Zurich arrests marked a turning point, potentially unraveling the governing body. Blatter has been accused of running FIFA like a Swiss bank, hiding billions of dollars in its coffers. The arrests may be a significant blow to his leadership, but the full extent of the scandal remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Mr Blatter has released a statement in support of the American and Swiss investigations into Fifa

site_title: Gucci giving discounts of up to 50% in China as it clears stock
summary: Gucci is offering discounts of up to 50% in China as part of its efforts to clear out merchandise designed by its former creative director. The sale, which began on Wednesday, aims to reposition the brand amid falling demand in Asia. The discounts coincide with China's decision to cut import tariffs for some luxury products and follow moves by other luxury companies to reduce prices in China due to a weakening euro. The sale is expected to last until next month, with Gucci looking to turn the page on its former creative director, Frida Giannini.

site_title: 10 financial advisory firms may have breached anti-competition law
summary: Ten financial advisory firms in Singapore have been provisionally found by the Competition Commission of Singapore to have breached anti-competition law by pressuring iFAST Financial to withdraw a 50% commission rebate on life insurance products. The firms, all members of the Association of Financial Advisers, allegedly agreed to restrict competition by withdrawing the offer, which was launched in 2013. The firms have six weeks to make representations before a final decision is made, with potential financial penalties if found guilty.

images.alt_text: Ten prominent financial advisory (FA) firms have been provisionally found by the Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) to have made an anti-competitive agreement against one of their own two years ago.

site_title: Disaster flick that's not all it's cracked up to be
summary: The movie "San Andreas" is a disaster film that depicts a massive earthquake that devastates California, with actor Dwayne Johnson playing a helicopter-rescue pilot trying to save his family. The film features extensive CGI-rendered destruction and a predicted second, more-destructive quake. While it has modest ambition, the movie falls short, with a rating of C, and prioritizes action over realistic portrayal of a real-world disaster. The film's large-scale destruction serves as a reminder of the possibility of such a tragedy occurring in the real world.

site_title: UN puts tie-ups with Fifa under scrutiny
summary: The United Nations is scrutinizing its partnerships with FIFA amid allegations of widespread corruption at the football governing body. The UN has ties with FIFA to promote health, gender equality, and child protection, including campaigns and programs since 1999. The investigation into FIFA's alleged bribery and graft is still in its early stages, and it's unclear whether UN agencies will reconsider their partnerships. The UN has had voluntary partnerships with FIFA, including initiatives during the World Cup, which have raised millions of dollars for development projects.

images.alt_text: The United Nations is taking a close look at its partnerships with Fifa following allegations of widespread corruption at football's world governing body, a UN spokesman said on Thursday.

site_title: Curious goings on at Chinese energy firm
summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power, a solar panel equipment company owned by China's richest man Li Hejun, saw its stock price plummet 47% last Wednesday. The company's business model appears to be a house of cards, reliant on borrowing money and a rising stock price. This mirrors the Enron scandal, where a company's stock price was artificially inflated through borrowing and speculation. The exact losses by Li Hejun are unknown, but it is clear that Hanergy's financial situation is precarious.

site_title: Sniffing out a new take on Singapore
summary: Singapore-based fragrance designer AllSense is organizing an 8-day series of scent walks through the city, led by researcher and artist Kate McLean. The walks, which take approximately an hour to complete, aim to map the city's scents and explore the subjective nature of smell. Participants are encouraged to record their thoughts on the aromas encountered, and the data collected will be compiled into a map to be presented in a gallery exhibition in August. The initiative coincides with SG50 celebrations and aims to elevate the importance of the sense of smell in understanding a city's ambiance.

site_title: Maybank Q1 profit up 6.3%
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender by assets, reported a 6.3% increase in Q1 profit to RM1.7 billion, driven by higher fee income and robust loan growth. Revenue rose 9.9% to RM9.18 billion, while loans expanded 14.3% year-over-year. However, the bank cautioned on a challenging environment due to economic slowdown and the implementation of a goods and services tax in Malaysia, which may impact private consumption growth. Shares ended 0.33% lower at RM9.11.

site_title: Innovation through the TPP
summary: Negotiators from 12 Asia-Pacific countries are nearing the completion of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a significant free trade agreement. The TPP aims to promote innovation and economic growth by setting a new standard for intellectual property (IP) protections. Strong IP protections are essential for investment in innovation, and Singapore, which chairs the IP negotiation, stands to gain from the agreement. Robust IP protections can stimulate domestic innovation, attract global investment, and create a knowledge-based economy, making Singapore a leader in IP protection in the region.

site_title: Sydney housing bubble seen surviving tepid speculator curbs
summary: Regulators in Australia are warning of a housing bubble in Sydney, with home prices surging 40% in three years. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) has asked lenders to limit investor mortgages to 10% annual growth, but this may not be enough to curb the market. Lending to investors is near a record high, and regulators are considering stricter measures, including requiring lenders to hold more capital against investor mortgages. Experts warn that Australia's high debt levels and stagnant wage growth are contributing to the housing bubble.

site_title: ECB flags risks from low interest rates, Greek situation
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has warned that record-low interest rates are putting insurance firms and banks under pressure, and a sell-off in stocks and bonds could damage the eurozone's recovery. The ECB also highlighted risks from Greece, including debt sustainability concerns and the potential for a Greek exit from the euro. However, ECB Vice-President Vitor Constancio expressed confidence that Greece will not leave the euro, but warned that a default could occur. The ECB's Financial Stability Review identified four main risks to eurozone financial stability, including a sharp market sell-off and debt sustainability concerns.

site_title: Neo Group posts 14-month earnings of S$7.4m
summary: Neo Group, a Singapore-based food and beverage caterer, posted 14-month earnings of S$7.4 million, a 15.7% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 47.8% to S$77.4 million, driven by growth in its food-catering business. The group has proposed a one-tier tax-exempt final cash dividend of 1.05 cents per share and is set to acquire a 55% stake in Thong Siek Holdings for S$7.35 million, expected to be completed by mid-June.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Rallying dollar powers to 12-1/2 year high versus yen
summary: The US dollar reached a 12-1/2 year high against the yen on May 28, 2015, amid expectations of a US interest rate hike and Japan's ultra-loose monetary policy. The Australian dollar fell 1.2% against the dollar after disappointing data, while commodity currencies like the Canadian and New Zealand dollars also dropped. Traders are wary of potential verbal intervention by Japanese officials to steady the yen, which has been under pressure since 2013. The dollar has gained over 4% against the yen since May 1.

site_title: Understanding the future of money and data
summary: The rise of the Internet of Things (IoT) and the increasing reliance on personal data raise concerns about the effectiveness of current data protection principles. As devices and wearables generate vast amounts of data, companies must balance convenience with user privacy. The emergence of e-money and digital payments has created regulatory challenges, with the potential for increased cybercrime and vulnerability. The lack of clear guidelines for regulating e-money and IoT devices threatens to hinder the development of a hyper-connected world, highlighting the need for fine-tuning existing laws or crafting new rules to address these emerging issues.

site_title: Sponsors start leaning on football governing body
summary: Sponsors of FIFA, including Visa, Emirates, and Sony, are expressing concern over the corruption scandal engulfing the world's governing body. The US indictment of nine officials and five sports media executives accused of bribes involving over $150 million has prompted several sponsors to reassess their relationships with FIFA. Some, like Visa, have threatened to end their sponsorship if FIFA fails to address the issues. Meanwhile, Adidas, Coca-Cola, and Nike have made statements calling for transparency and compliance, but have stopped short of cutting ties. A proposed boycott of a FIFA leadership vote has been ruled out, clearing the way for Sepp Blatter's likely re-election.

site_title: Prices of completed condos down 0.1% in April: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed non-landed private homes saw a 0.1% price decrease in April, according to the NUS flash estimate. Despite new completions intensifying leasing competition, resale property prices remained stable. Developer sales may have influenced resale buying sentiment, as buyers for resale properties need to occupy units immediately, while developer buyers can wait. The Central Region sub-index fell 0.1%, while Non-Central Region remained flat. Islandwide, small apartment and condo units rose 0.4%. Overall prices rose 0.3% from February.

images.alt_text: Prices of completed non-landed private homes in Singapore fell 0.1 per cent in April over March, according to the National University of Singapore (NUS) flash estimate released on Thursday.

site_title: Star funds beaten by rocky ride in yields, currencies
summary: Key investment funds, including Pimco's flagship Total Return Fund, have been negatively impacted by the recent rise in global yields and the euro's strength against the US dollar. The funds, which had taken long positions on German bunds and shorted euros, have struggled to keep up with market volatility. Top money managers, including Dan Fuss and Bill Gross, have warned of central bank actions and loose monetary policies that could trigger volatility, but many got caught flat-footed when interest rates rose at their fastest since 2013. As a result, several funds have underperformed their peer categories, with some posting negative returns for the year.

site_title: Private museum bridges past and future
summary: The Singapore Pinacotheque de Paris, a French private museum, has opened its doors with a "Museum of the Future" concept, featuring rare masterpieces by renowned artists alongside interactive technology platforms. The museum boasts touchscreen walls, a mobile app, and a website to engage visitors with art. The "transversality" concept, developed by founder Marc Restellini, juxtaposes artworks from different cultures and styles to highlight common ideas and aesthetics. The museum offers a unique blend of art, history, and technology, with three new restaurants and cafes set to open in the coming month.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Dukang Distillers slapped with 'trade with caution' after price surge
summary: Dukang Distillers Holdings, a Chinese spirits producer, saw its share price surge 20.9% the day before, prompting a "trade with caution" notice from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) due to unusual trading activity. The stock fell 6.8% on Thursday, a sharp decline. The company stated it was unaware of any other explanation for the trading activity. This unexpected move has raised concerns about the company's financial health and prompted the SGX to issue the warning.

site_title: Economists lend weight to G-7 meeting
summary: The world's top finance ministers and central-bank chiefs gathered in Dresden for a G-7 meeting, marked by a symposium led by economists such as Nouriel Roubini and Robert Shiller. The event aims to drive discussions on longer-term economic issues and encourage a more lively tone. Despite efforts to boost the relevance of the near four-decade-old G-7, its influence is threatened by emerging economic powers and the broader G-20. The meeting's agenda includes examining sustainable growth and the challenges of digitalization, with a focus on Greece's debt crisis and the need for reforms.

site_title: YuuZoo's latest disclosure opens a Pandora's box for SGX
summary: YuuZoo, an e-payments firm, released a positive research report about itself on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) website, which was commissioned by the company. The report, issued by Edison Investment Research, predicted a significant upside for YuuZoo's share price. However, the report did not disclose that YuuZoo paid for the research, and the SGX's website does not appear to have a clear policy on posting paid research reports. This has raised concerns about the line between paid and independent research, and whether such reports should be allowed on the SGX website.

images.alt_text: Maybe it's only me, but I'm not comfortable with e-payments firm YuuZoo posting a positive research report about itself as an official release on the Singapore Exchange's (SGX's) website, especially when YuuZoo paid for the research in the first place.

site_title: US rate hikes pose risks to emerging Asia but banks generally sound: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon stated that US interest rate hikes pose risks to emerging Asia's consumers and corporates, but the region's banks are generally sound. Despite this, the region's overall growth is expected to remain firm at 6% this year, benefiting banks. The MAS remains optimistic about the longer-term outlook for Asia, citing the rapid expansion of its middle class and regionalisation of Asian corporates as key drivers of growth.

site_title: English FA, UK government urge Fifa's Blatter to go
summary: The English Football Association and UK government have urged FIFA President Sepp Blatter to resign amid a corruption scandal. British investigative journalists, including The Sunday Times and BBC's Panorama, have exposed allegations of corruption, leading to seven officials being arrested and accused of taking bribes. The UK government, including Sports Minister John Whittingdale and Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond, support Blatter's resignation, with Prime Minister David Cameron's spokesman backing Blatter's rival for the presidency. FIFA officials, including FA vice-chairman David Gill and former England goalkeeper Peter Shilton, have called for a "clean sweep" and fresh faces at the top.

images.alt_text: England's Football Association and government urged Fifa president Sepp Blatter to resign on Thursday, as British investigative journalists were praised for helping to expose a major corruption scandal.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit acquiring Sydney data centre for A$43.3m
summary: Keppel DC Reit has agreed to acquire the shell and core building of Intellicentre 2 in Sydney from Macquarie Telecom for approximately A$43.3 million. The 8,169 sqm data centre is valued at A$47.3 million and sits on 20,000 sqm of freehold land. The deal is Keppel DC Reit's first acquisition after listing in December and is expected to be completed in Q3 2015. The acquisition is expected to be fully funded by debt and will increase the Reit's leverage from 26.7% to 29.9%.

site_title: Potent drama about deaf vs hearing
summary: A family drama, "Tribes," by playwright Nina Raine, revolves around the unspoken divide between the hearing and deaf worlds. Billy, a deaf young man, brings his hearing girlfriend Sylvia home to dinner, where she introduces the family to the world of signing. However, Billy's family's refusal to learn sign language sparks tension, leading Billy to become truculent and demanding. The play forces viewers to question their allegiances and see things from a deaf person's perspective, offering a provocative and humane exploration of the divide between the two worlds.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Indian billionaire's wealth grows along with Modi's political stature
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's wealth has quadrupled since Prime Minister Narendra Modi's election in 2014, with Adani Enterprises, Adani Power, and Adani Ports experiencing significant growth.
