While the food needs improvement, the restaurant's concept and ambiance, inspired by old-school gentlemen's clubs, have been well-received. The service is slow but attentive, and the restaurant's potential for growth is high, making it a welcome addition to the city's food scene.

site_title: OCBC staff attend 'speed networking' session
summary: OCBC held a "speed networking" session for 35 Gen Y employees, allowing them to mingle and learn from senior leaders in a non-traditional setting. This was the first time the bank held such an event, part of its Talkfest programme, which aims to facilitate dialogue between younger employees and senior leaders. The session was held at OCBC Campus, the bank's learning hub, and is part of its efforts to foster innovation and growth among its younger staff.

images.alt_text: Head of Treasury Research and Strategy Selena Ling (extreme right) sharing a light- hearted moment with her younger colleagues.

site_title: Even with rate hike on the horizon, stocks continue to defy gravity
summary: US stocks continue to defy gravity despite the Federal Reserve's promise of a rate hike this year. Traders are becoming increasingly inured to the threat of higher interest rates, with the yield on Treasury bonds remaining low. Economic data has been mixed, with a slight contraction in first-quarter GDP growth and disappointing retail sales. However, a strong core consumer price inflation report could force the Fed to act before the year is out. The stock market's record highs are also driven by a deal craze in the healthcare, telecoms, and technology sectors, sparking debate over the possibility of another bubble.

site_title: Banks bypass Fed rules to fund non-bank lending
summary: Regulators are concerned that banks' efforts to strengthen lending standards are shifting the market for high-yield credit to less-supervised loan funds, which are funded by Wall Street banks and leave systemically important institutions exposed to risks. Direct-lending funds and business development companies (BDCs) have surged, with loans by BDCs reaching $55 billion in 2022, up from $17 billion in 2010. Regulators warn that these non-bank funds may originate more risky loans, potentially leading to larger losses in stressed conditions, as they operate beyond bank supervision and lack depositors.

site_title: Aircraft makers banking on new LEAP engine
summary: CFM International's LEAP engine, used in the Airbus A320neo and Boeing B737 MAX, has successfully completed its first flight tests, promising 15-20% fuel savings compared to its predecessor, the CFM56. The engine, a joint venture between Safran and GE, is expected to power the next generation of planes, including the B737 MAX and A320neo, set to enter service in 2017 and next year, respectively. The engine's lightweight design and advanced materials are expected to contribute to the fuel savings, with Safran confident of meeting the promised performance levels.

site_title: Sweden pips Russia in Eurovision pop fest nail-biter
summary: Sweden won the 60th Eurovision Song Contest with 365 points, narrowly beating Russia's Polina Gagarina with 303 points. Mans Zelmerlow's upbeat song "Heroes" took the top spot, while Italy's Il Volo came third with 292 points. The contest, held in Vienna, was marked by a mix of politics and entertainment, with Armenia's song addressing the 1915 mass killings by Ottoman Turkey. Sweden's victory means the contest will be held in Sweden in 2016, and the event continues to attract a global audience of 200 million viewers.

images.alt_text: Sweden's Zelmerlow (above) takes first place with his up-tempo crowd-pleaser Heroes; Russia's Gagarina fails to take the title with her paean to world peace - A Million Voices.
Sweden's Zelmerlow takes first place with his up-tempo crowd-pleaser Heroes; Russia's Gagarina (above) fails to take the title with her paean to world peace - A Million Voices.

site_title: Rosberg in Monaco F1 hat-trick after Hamilton's pit-stop fiasco
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Monaco Grand Prix, becoming only the fourth driver to achieve a hat-trick of consecutive wins. The victory came after Lewis Hamilton's pit-stop was called in for an unnecessary stop, allowing Rosberg to take the lead. Hamilton's team apologized for the mistake, which deprived him of a fair sporting outcome. Rosberg's win enabled him to join a select group of drivers who have achieved the Monaco hat-trick, and rekindled his challenge for the drivers' championship.

site_title: FAA gives all clear for new data, e-mail system to relay changes in flight plans
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has approved a new data and e-mail system to replace traditional radio transmissions for flight plan changes, aiming to improve airport efficiency and reduce delays. The system, known as datalink, allows tower controllers and planes to relay requests and instructions quickly, potentially shaving time off delays. The FAA plans to roll out the system at over 50 US airports by next year, with estimated costs of $741 million for airport towers and $800 million for regional centers. The system is designed to reduce emissions and is expected to save airlines money.

site_title: Has Google peaked in dominance?
summary: Google's dominance in internet search and online advertising may be waning as the tech landscape shifts to mobile devices and social media. Analysts argue that Google's business model is narrow, relying heavily on search and advertising, which is being disrupted by rivals like Facebook and Alibaba. Google's shares have struggled since 2014, and its ventures in areas like self-driving cars and social media have failed to generate significant revenue. As mobile usage increases, Google's ability to deliver targeted ads is being eroded, and new mobile search startups are emerging to challenge its dominance.

site_title: Swedish policy impasse raises fears of runaway housing market
summary: A Swedish court has postponed a plan to cool the housing market by forcing homeowners to pay down mortgage principal, citing a lack of legal mandate. The move, aimed at preventing a housing bubble, is part of a broader policy impasse under a minority government. Sweden's central bank governor, Stefan Ingves, warns that the housing market is dysfunctional, with households borrowing excessively and prices surging. The government fears any moves to curb the market will anger voters, and the IMF has warned that prices are 15% too high, sparking fears of a potential housing market crash.

site_title: Kimchi losing its spice
summary: Korea's economy struggles with weak external demand, a slow domestic recovery, and low oil prices. The country's exports contracted 8.1% year-over-year in April, and the depreciation of the Japanese yen has reduced competitiveness. Low inflation, at 0.4% in April, has raised deflation fears. In response, the Bank of Korea has lowered interest rates to 1.75% to support economic growth. Downside risks include delayed economic recoveries in China and the US, and further yen depreciation. Investors can consider purchasing non-deliverable forwards on the Korean won against the US dollar.

site_title: Small food makers pave own way to big stores
summary: Small US food manufacturers are gaining traction in the market, with many privately-held companies now available in big stores such as Walmart and Whole Foods. Contract manufacturers and digital advertising have reduced barriers to entry, allowing small companies to produce goods inexpensively and target consumers without big marketing budgets. According to a report, small and mid-sized consumer goods companies have stolen $18 billion in US sales away from large players since 2009. Major food companies are responding by creating healthier products and acquiring natural or organic food brands.

site_title: S'pore investors still dumping US stocks
summary: Singaporean and Asian investors continued to sell US stocks in the first quarter of 2015, despite a strong US dollar making US assets less attractive. They sold a net $182 million in US corporate stocks, easing from a $2.08 billion sale in the previous quarter. Meanwhile, Asian investors sold a net $1.4 billion in US stocks, and US investors bought a net $39.07 billion in foreign stocks, with a focus on Asian equities. The strong dollar made US bonds unattractive, contributing to the decline in sales of US Treasury bonds.

site_title: Directors' sales up sharply, purchases down
summary: Directors of 15 Singapore companies made 24 purchases worth S$3.98 million in the third week of May, while four firms made seven disposals worth S$7.42 million. The buying activity fell from the previous week, but the buyback activity rose for the third straight week with 17 companies posting 52 repurchases worth S$17.6 million. Companies that repurchased shares include Hi-P International, Lian Beng Group, and TeleChoice International, following a decline in their share prices. Meanwhile, directors of CosmoSteel Holdings, GK Goh Holdings, MSM International, and Singapore Reinsurance Corporation made significant purchases or sales.

site_title: China's Apus app developer targets 300m users
summary: Beijing-based company Apus aims to double its user numbers to 300 million by the end of 2015, with a goal of reaching 1 billion users in three years. Apus, a popular app organizer, has raised $116 million in funding and holds $100 million in cash. The company has intentionally targeted regions with fastest smartphone user growth, with 32% of users in Southeast Asia and 17% in the Middle East. Apus' CEO, Li Tao, believes the additions of a browser and new search functions will help achieve its growth goals.

site_title: Greece urges creditors to compromise as IMF payment date nears
summary: Greece urged its creditors to compromise on demands to break an impasse over releasing funds for its cash-strapped economy, with a deadline looming for payments to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on June 5. Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis said Greece has made significant strides, but creditors must cover the remainder. The Greek government faces a cash crisis, with monthly salaries and pensions to be paid by May 29 and a repayment of 300 million euros to the IMF by June 12. A Greek exit from the euro is a possibility, with former Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan stating it wouldn't lead to the break-up of the monetary union.

site_title: ECB has done its part and now govts should do theirs: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank president Mario Draghi said the eurozone's economic recovery is an opportune time for governments to implement structural reforms to get their economies in order. Draghi stated that the economic outlook for the euro area is brighter than it has been in seven years. He emphasized that governments should take advantage of this recovery to address economic issues and ensure a sustainable growth path.

site_title: Ezion, GLP & YuuZoo steal the limelight
summary: Ezion, Global Logistics Properties (GLP), and YuuZoo dominated market attention in the week ending May 22, 2015. Genting Singapore's weak results and declining VIP traffic contributed to a forgettable trading week. The US Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting minutes released later in the year revealed no new information, yet Wall Street indices reached new all-time highs.

site_title: Bank of England admits to researching 'Brexit' risks
summary: The Bank of England has acknowledged researching the economic risks of a potential Brexit, following the release of confidential information to a newspaper. The central bank said it was working on the project, which could impact the UK's future within the EU, as Prime Minister David Cameron began negotiations on EU membership reforms ahead of a 2017 referendum. The bank's study, though initially confidential, could influence the debate on Britain's EU membership.

site_title: Top political official in China's southwest under investigation
summary: Top political official in China's southwest, Yu Yuanhui, has been placed under investigation for "severe disciplinary and law violation", a common euphemism for corruption. Yu, the Communist Party secretary of Nanning, is also a member of the standing committee of the regional government. This investigation comes as part of China's ongoing campaign against corruption, led by President Xi Jinping, following high-profile cases of bribery and abuse of power.

site_title: Bird flu spreads across US, causes egg shortage
summary: The US is experiencing its biggest outbreak of bird flu on record, with 40 million birds culled in 16 states and Canada. The highly infectious virus has led to a shortage of eggs, prompting companies to import eggs from overseas or use plant-based egg substitutes. With the US dollar bolstering import costs, companies are scouting for egg supplies abroad, including Europe and Canada. The shortage has led to a sharp increase in egg prices, with some companies facing 30% reduced egg supplies and a wholesale price rise of $1.83 per dozen.

site_title: 2 S'pore startups acquired by overseas firms
summary: Singaporean startups 3ree and Gushcloud have been acquired by Chinese and South Korean companies, respectively. 3ree, an integrated marketing agency, was acquired by Always Marketing Services for an undisclosed sum, while Gushcloud, a content and influencer marketing startup, was acquired by Yello Digital Marketing group for an eight-figure sum. The acquisitions are seen as a strategic move to expand the companies' presence in Asia, with Yello Digital Marketing planning to open a new headquarters in Singapore.

site_title: India minister vows to improve company tax regime
summary: Indian Finance Minister Arun Jaitley vowed to improve the company tax regime, promising competitive tax rates for corporate profits. He also announced a judicial resolution to address foreign portfolio investors' concerns over surprise tax claims. Jaitley emphasized the government's commitment to implementing a national sales tax on time.

images.alt_text: CONCILIATORY: Mr Jaitley promises to bring down the rate at which companies pay tax on profits, reiterating a budget pledge to cut the tax rate to 25 per cent from 30 per cent over four years.

site_title: Calls for more oversight in HK after routs
summary: Hong Kong-listed companies saw significant declines in market value, with US$35 billion erased in two days, amid concerns over regulator oversight. Goldin Financial Holdings and Goldin Properties plummeted over 40% and 41% respectively, while Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd tumbled 47% before its shares were suspended. The volatility highlights the need for regulators to keep pace with China's booming stock markets and prevent manipulation, with investors and analysts calling for increased oversight and timely action to curb price manipulation.

site_title: Detained Thai students "merely invited for talks": police
summary: Thai police claimed dozens of detained students were "merely invited for talks" after staging an anti-coup protest in Bangkok, despite angry scuffles and overnight detention. The students, who were among around 50 protesters, were later freed without charge. The detentions come as the military-controlled nation marks one year since the coup, with critics accusing the junta of silencing dissent.

images.alt_text: Dozens of Thai students who were dragged away and held overnight by police after they staged an anti-coup protest in Bangkok Friday evening were "merely invited for talks", a senior police officer said Saturday.

site_title: Shell CEO backs fossil fuels, climate change warnings: Guardian
summary: Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben van Beurden stated that the world's fossil fuel reserves can only be burned if carbon emissions are captured, and he forecasts a "zero carbon" energy mix by the end of the century. He rejected calls to divest from energy companies, citing the need for carbon capture and storage technology to meet the 2C climate scenario. Van Beurden also defended Shell's decision to drill in the Alaskan Arctic, citing rational grounds and assessed technical risks.

site_title: Munich Re embraces digitalisation as necessary to survive
summary: Munich Re, a global reinsurer, is embracing digitalization as a necessary step to survive in a changing market. Chairman Nikolaus von Bomhard believes the company must adapt to trends in Silicon Valley and other regions to stay ahead. Munich Re is investing in data analytics and big data to better understand risks and transform its business. Despite concerns over low yields and volatile markets, the company is on track to meet its net profit target. Von Bomhard also expressed concerns over being labeled "systemically relevant" by the Financial Stability Board, arguing that reinsurers are not interconnected and do not pose the same risks as banks.

images.alt_text: Dr von Bomhard notes that the reliance on the digital world is a double-edged sword. As much as it has exposed vulnerabilities, it has also fuelled the need to protect against cyber risks.

site_title: Indonesia believes most migrants at sea not Rohingya: Australia
summary: Indonesia disputes Australia's claim that Rohingya migrants are the majority at sea, stating that only 30-40% are Rohingya, while the rest are illegal laborers from Bangladesh seeking jobs in Malaysia. Indonesia estimates 7,000 people are stranded at sea, with Bangladeshis accounting for 400 of 600 on one vessel. Australia maintains its hardline policy on asylum-seekers, refusing to resettle stranded boat people and turning back vessels when possible.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has told Australia that most of the migrants stranded at sea in Southeast Asia are illegal labourers from Bangladesh, not oppressed Muslim Rohingya, Foreign Minister Julie Bishop said in comments published Saturday.

site_title: Ireland celebrates after huge 'Yes' to gay marriage
summary: Ireland celebrates a historic victory after 62% of voters approved gay marriage in a referendum, becoming the 19th country to legalize same-sex marriages. The "Yes" campaign, driven in part by young people and social media, marked a significant shift in the country's social landscape, with many hailing it as a major milestone for equality and human rights. The referendum's outcome was seen as a reflection of changing times and a decline in the influence of the Catholic Church in Irish society.

site_title: Yellen says Fed on course for 2015 rate rise even after slowdown
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that the Fed will proceed with raising interest rates this year, despite a slowdown in the economy, and will do so cautiously. She emphasized that the labor market is nearing full strength but not yet there, and that the pace of tightening will be gradual. Yellen assured investors that the cost of borrowing, including car loans and mortgages, will remain low for years to come. This move aims to avoid a shock to the fragile economy.

site_title: Keeping a family business going
summary: The article discusses the key to keeping a family business successful, as seen in the Glenfiddich whisky company. Peter Gordon, a member of the family, shares his experience of working at the distillery in the 1970s, where workers would drink day-old whisky to toughen calluses. This practice highlights the importance of internal quality controls and financial prudence in long-term family businesses.

site_title: Gold falls as Yellen points to rate hike, dollar jumps
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen signaled a possible interest rate hike this year, citing a recovering US economy. Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,204.72 an ounce, marking its first weekly decline in four weeks, as the dollar rose 1% against a basket of leading currencies. Investors expect higher US interest rates to increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, contributing to a bearish sentiment for gold.

site_title: BlackBerry cuts jobs worldwide in smartphone consolidation
summary: BlackBerry Ltd is cutting jobs worldwide as it consolidates its shrinking smartphone business. The company is aiming to make its device unit profitable again, focusing on financial professionals and government workers who demand security. Revenue continues to fall, but CEO John Chen has stemmed cash losses and BlackBerry began posting profits last year. The company has narrowed its target audience and is expanding in software, making applications that work on other manufacturers' mobile devices. The job cuts affect a number of employees worldwide, but the exact number is not disclosed.

site_title: OCBC holds speed networking session for Gen Y employees to meet senior leaders
summary: OCBC held a "speed networking" session on May 22 for 35 Gen Y employees, allowing them to mingle with senior leaders in a non-traditional setting. This was the first time the bank held such a session as part of its Talkfest program. The young employees met with eight senior leaders from various divisions, including corporate banking and technology. The session was inspired by the concept of "speed dating," where participants move between tables after brief interactions. The event aimed to facilitate dialogue and learning between employees and senior leaders.

site_title: Oil falls as dollar lifts on US inflation data
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday as the dollar strengthened following firm US inflation data, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping $1 to $59.72 a barrel. Brent North Sea crude also declined $1.17 to $65.37 a barrel. The Labor Department reported US consumer prices rose for a third straight month in April, supporting the dollar and weighing on oil prices. Analysts attributed the decline to profit-taking ahead of the long holiday weekend and the potential end of production cutbacks by oil companies as oil prices stabilize.

site_title: Sweden pips Russia in Eurovision pop fest nail-biter
summary: Sweden won the 60th Eurovision Song Contest, narrowly beating Russia with 365 points, compared to Russia's 303. Sweden's Mans Zelmerlow took the stage with his up-tempo song "Heroes," while Russia's Polina Gagarina performed her anthem "A Million Voices." The contest was marked by geopolitics, with Russia's annexation of Crimea and Ukraine's absence from the event. Despite this, the show remains a celebration of music and tolerance, watched by around 200 million people worldwide.

site_title: More investment in Australia's transport or risk gridlock: report
summary: Australia risks gridlock in its major cities if it doesn't invest more in transport systems, with costs estimated to reach A$53.3 billion a year by 2031. A report by Infrastructure Australia found that road congestion in Sydney alone costs A$13.7 billion in 2011, and could double by 2031. The government has pledged to fund infrastructure projects, with Prime Minister Tony Abbott stating that the economic toll of delay is "almost never counted." Australia's infrastructure investment lags behind countries with similar population densities and harsh weather conditions.

site_title: Time Warner deal talks pit Malone against protege Drahi
summary: Time Warner Cable merger talks are pitting French-Israeli tycoon Patrick Drahi against media mogul John Malone. Altice SA, a holding company led by Drahi, is making a bid for the US cable company, while Charter Communications Inc, led by Malone, is also pursuing the deal. The negotiations may lead to a transaction as early as this week, but no certainty exists. The move is part of a wave of consolidation in the US cable industry amid waning demand for traditional pay-TV packages and competition from online services.

site_title: Mercator loss balloons on exceptional items
summary: Mercator Lines, a Singapore-based dry bulk shipping company, reported a full-year loss of US$125.37 million, up from US$22.76 million a year ago, due to exceptional items including vessel impairment and an onerous contract. Revenue fell 25% year-over-year, and the company marked its third consecutive year of pre-tax losses. The decline in global trade and downward pressure on freight rates have been attributed to falling commodity prices, oversupply of new bulk carriers, and weakening international demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Streetside dentists still popular in India
summary: Streetside dentists in India, like Allah Baksh, continue to operate despite being unlicensed. They provide essential dental services to tens of millions of poor individuals who cannot afford clinic visits. Baksh charges $12 for services like fitting dentures. The unlicensed dentists are frowned upon by licensed counterparts but claim they fill a vital gap in healthcare.

site_title: For foreign lenders, Myanmar is no zero-sum game
summary: International banks entering Myanmar must partner with each other to set up club loans and share risk of borrower default. Foreign banks face challenges, including narrow onshore lending rates and limited collateral, and must work with domestic banks to expand their reach. A lack of an inter-bank lending system and high recovery rates for loans also pose significant risks. Despite these challenges, banks see opportunities for long-term development and economic transformation, with some predicting five decades of catch-up growth. Cooperation, not direct competition, is key to success in Myanmar's nascent financial market.

site_title: Brazil freezes US$22.6b in spending after raising taxes
summary: Brazil has frozen $30.2 billion in spending from its 2015 budget, with a focus on cutting current expenditures, discretionary spending, and infrastructure programs. The government has also raised taxes on banks, brokerages, and credit-card processors to 20% from 15%, boosting tax collection by $750 million in 2015. The measures aim to reduce the budget gap, which threatens Brazil's investment grade, but experts question whether the freeze will be enough to address the country's economic woes, including a deepening recession and high inflation.

images.alt_text: President Dilma Rousseff is trying to rein in the largest budget gap in 16 years that threatens Brazil's investment grade.

site_title: An EPL season to savour
summary: The English Premier League's 2014-2015 season concludes with all 20 clubs playing their final match. Chelsea was crowned champions a fortnight ago, and the other three Champions League qualifiers were confirmed last Saturday. The relegation battle reaches its climax, with Burnley and Queens Park Rangers already relegated, and either Hull City or Newcastle United joining them after Sunday's action. The focus shifts to the bottom of the table, where teams are fighting to avoid relegation.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: China Merchants enters into agreement for short-term revolving loan facility
summary: China Merchants Holdings (Pacific) has entered into a one-year, US$50 million revolving loan facility with DBS Bank for multi-currency borrowing. The loan can be used for toll road acquisitions, refinancing existing loans, general corporate purposes, or working capital requirements.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Bouncing off Tharman's trampoline
summary: Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam used a trampoline metaphor to describe Singapore's stance on social assistance, stating that the country provides support for individuals to take opportunities, but not a safety net for those who fall. He argued that this approach encourages personal responsibility and helps individuals bounce back from setbacks, rather than relying on a safety net that would provide a comfortable life. Tharman's comments were made during an interview at the St Gallen Symposium in Switzerland, where the theme was "Proudly Small".

site_title: IE Singapore gives pointers on tapping an integrated Asean market
summary: IE Singapore advises Singapore companies to focus on Asean economies like Thailand and Indonesia for long-term benefits from AEC integration. They should prioritize sectors like manufacturing and consumer goods, and partner with local firms in these economies. However, companies must weigh political and regulatory risks, taking a long-term view, as frameworks are still evolving in many Asean nations. A final tranche of commitments to the Asean framework agreement on services is expected this year, which should liberalize investment into 12 broad services sectors.

images.alt_text: Singapore companies should focus on Asean economies such as Thailand and Indonesia that are most ready to gain from integration, and zoom in on sectors that tap the region's manufacturing and consumer strengths, says International Enterprise (IE) Singapore.

site_title: Prices mixed on rebounding US$ and supply jitters
summary: Commodity markets experienced mixed prices last week, with oil prices rebounding despite a strong US dollar. Brent crude rose to $65.57 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude climbed to $59.60 a barrel. Cocoa prices surged to seven-month peaks due to supply concerns in Ghana, reaching $3,181 a tonne. Gold prices fell to a three-month peak, and base metals prices declined due to downbeat data in China and the strong US currency. The US Department of Energy reported a 2.7 million-barrel decline in US petroleum inventories and a 112,000-barrel drop in production, fueling hopes of an easing supply glut.

site_title: Getting connected
summary: The proposed Singapore-Kuala Lumpur high-speed rail is expected to have a significant economic and business impact. Travel time between the two cities will be reduced to 90 minutes, increasing the frequency and speed of trade between Singapore and KL. This will boost business ties, facilitate internationalization of local events, and create jobs in the construction and maintenance of the network. The rail link is also expected to ease congestion at the causeways, reduce travel stress, and increase access to transportation of goods and people. Economists predict a significant economic boost for both countries, with potential benefits including increased investments, job creation, and growth in the hospitality and airline sectors.

site_title: Return of the native
summary: Ikea, the affordable furniture giant, is shifting towards more authentic, better-crafted, and natural products. Design manager Marcus Engman foresees a trend towards natural materials, surface treatments, and honesty in materials. The company is launching new collections, including the Bjorknas line made from birch, and incorporating wireless charging technology into furniture. Ikea aims to make sustainable products, with 100% sustainable cotton textiles by 2015. The company is also collaborating with fashion designers to make its products more fashionable. Engman believes in embracing imperfections in mass production, promoting a "Democratic Design" approach.

site_title: The serial entrepreneur
summary: Serial entrepreneurs are expanding their reach beyond their main business ventures. Larry Page and Eric Schmidt, co-founders of Google, have diversified into various fields, including self-driving cars and asteroid mining. Similarly, Elon Musk has shifted his focus from PayPal to space exploration and electric cars. Young entrepreneurs, like Nelson Yap and Damien Tan, are following suit, starting new businesses after achieving success in their first ventures. Yap, a former barista and cook, opened a café and clothing store, while Tan, a designer and entrepreneur, launched a luxury spa. These individuals demonstrate that success can be achieved in multiple industries, and they are not afraid to take risks and pursue new opportunities.

site_title: Jakarta proposes to end tax-free debt
summary: Indonesia plans to ban companies from writing off interest costs against taxable income if their debt exceeds four times equity, aiming to curb private external debt that soared to over half of all foreign dues. The proposal, proposed by President Joko Widodo, would affect companies like PT Tower Bersama Infrastructure, which could take a hit due to its high debt levels. The move aims to balance reining in surging liabilities with encouraging investment to reverse the country's slowest economic growth in six years.

site_title: Bishopsgate GCB sets record per square foot price
summary: A record S$2,190 per square foot price has been set for a luxury Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Bishopsgate, Singapore. The S$33 million sale, which includes a basement and over 15,000 sq ft of land, surpasses the previous record of S$2,110 psf in Leedon Park in 2012. Separately, the Ridout site was sold for over S$90 million.

site_title: Banks on charm offensive in Myanmar
summary: Foreign lenders are venturing into Myanmar, investing in and advising the fledgling local financial market. Japanese banks have a headstart, with Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, and Mizuho Bank already established in the country. Singapore banks, including UOB and OCBC, have also opened branches and are providing trade finance and cash management services. To lift standards, foreign banks plan to hire staff, train them, and not poach local talent. However, concerns remain about the impact of politics, corruption, and the close ties between local lenders and the military junta on the country's banking sector.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: US will not meet ambitious goals for electric car use
summary: The US will not meet its ambitious goal of having one million plug-in vehicles on the road by 2015, as set by President Barack Obama in 2009. The original goal was scaled back in March due to slow technology and consumer interest. Despite efforts to meet lowered expectations, sales and government purchases have failed to meet the targets. The lack of progress has raised concerns about the feasibility of the US government's goal to have a fully fuel-efficient fleet.

site_title: China and Peru agree to study transcontinental rail link
summary: China and Peru have agreed to study the feasibility of a 5,300 km transcontinental railroad connecting Peru's Pacific coast with Brazil's Atlantic coast. The proposed railway would reduce shipping costs and upgrade infrastructure in both countries, benefiting China's export of industrial capacity and investment. This is part of China's $250 billion investment pledge in Latin America over the next 10 years, as announced by President Xi Jinping in January. The study is expected to be completed in the coming months, paving the way for a potential major infrastructure project in the region.

images.alt_text: China and Peru have agreed to study the feasibility of a controversial 5,300 km (3,300 miles) transcontinental railroad that will connect Peru's Pacific coast with Brazil's Atlantic coast, China's official Xinhua News Agency reported.

site_title: Germany, France usher Greece back to negotiating table
summary: European leaders, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Francois Hollande, urged Greece to return to the negotiating table for "intensive work" to wrap up a reform agreement, bypassing Athens' demand for a comprehensive solution. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras sought their help, but was told to focus on talks with the European Union, European Central Bank, and IMF creditors. The leaders offered support but emphasized the need for more work with the three institutions to resolve Greece's financial troubles, which risk default in as little as two weeks.

site_title: Moody's assigns Baa2 rating to GLP's proposed note issuance
summary: Moody's assigned a Baa2 rating with a stable outlook to Global Logistic Properties' proposed US$2 billion euro medium-term note issuance, citing stable income, good reputation, and prudent financial management. The rating is constrained by growing portfolio in emerging markets, revenue concentration in Japan and China, and ongoing capital needs. The notes are expected to fund business growth in China, and Moody's expects GLP to liquidate some of its investments to manage debt leverage. Fitch Ratings has also assigned a triple B plus (BBB+) expected rating to GLP notes.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Ireland turns out for historic vote on gay marriage
summary: Ireland held a historic referendum on gay marriage, with voters turning out in force after a campaign that exposed divisions in the traditionally Catholic nation. After 15 hours of voting, the referendum was deemed passed, allowing gay couples to wed. This change marks a significant shift in a country where homosexuality was illegal until 1993 and abortion remains restricted. The outcome is expected to have far-reaching social and cultural implications for Ireland.

site_title: Foreign buyers driving housing boom in Toronto
summary: Foreign buyers are driving the housing boom in Toronto, with the city attracting about a quarter of Canada's annual immigrant population. This influx of buyers is driving demand for new housing, including condos and rental properties, according to property developer Sam Mizrahi. The city's reputation as a safe country is luring international buyers, contributing to the city's growing housing market.

site_title: Corporate digest |
summary: CFM Holdings, a metal-stamping firm, has revealed that its Singapore subsidiary obtained a Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) for a factory building, but the permit was not issued by the proper authority. The company is working with authorities and contractors to determine the impact and risks. Meanwhile, the Singapore Exchange and Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange have signed a memorandum of understanding to collaborate on developing and expanding commodities markets in China and Singapore. Additionally, Hiap Seng Engineering has won a contract worth S$43 million for the Mogas-Cogen Project on Jurong Island.

site_title: Sodexo opens regional hub in Singapore
summary: Sodexo has opened its regional headquarters in Singapore's Fusionopolis, supporting operations in 15 countries and employing 60,000 people. The new office, located in a 20,000 sq. ft. facility, aims to develop new services with clients and promote innovation in services contributing to individual well-being and organizational performance. Sodexo targets a double-digit revenue increase in the Asia-Pacific region, driven by organic growth, and plans to partner with local research institutes and universities to better address Asian-centric taste preferences and health needs.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Taiwan lowers growth forecast in face of rival China
summary: Taiwan lowered its 2015 growth forecast to 3.28% due to increased competition from China in the tech industry, citing strong competition in the IT sector and a prolonged global economic slowdown. The country's stagnant economy has sparked public frustration, with stagnant growth rates and limited job and housing opportunities. Traditionally an export-driven technology hub, Taiwan's growth was boosted by the launch of Apple's iPhone 6, but China's growing tech industry has intensified competition, resulting in slower growth in demand for mobile devices.

site_title: Untapped US shale reserves face being erased from drillers' books
summary: The US shale oil industry is facing a potential loss of billions of barrels of untapped reserves due to low oil prices. Since the SEC changed the rules six years ago, allowing companies to claim proved reserves for wells that won't be drilled for years, more than half of the 9.7 billion barrels attributed to these wells are now considered unprofitable. The industry is now facing a five-year deadline to tap these reserves or erase them from their books, with oil prices having fallen 45% since June, making many of these wells unprofitable.

site_title: Accor to open first ibis Styles hotel in S'pore
summary: Accor will open its first ibis Styles hotel in Singapore at MacPherson and Aljunied Roads, with 298 refurbished rooms and amenities including a pool, gym, and restaurant. The hotel, owned by LVND Hotels, is set to open in the fourth quarter. The complex will also feature MacPherson Mall and a free shuttle service to nearby MRT stations. This marks the first Accor economy brand hotel in Singapore, chosen for its design appeal and affordability.

site_title: Forex rigging turns major banks into felons
summary: Five major global banks - Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, and UBS - have pleaded guilty to manipulating the world's currencies, agreeing to pay approximately $5.6 billion in penalties. The scheme, which unfolded over five years, involved traders colluding to pad their returns by manipulating currency prices and misleading clients about currency prices. The lack of oversight and pressure to squeeze profits from a relatively low-profit business created the perfect breeding ground for crime. The case highlights systemic issues within Wall Street, enabling banks to break the law despite regulatory black marks.

site_title: MapletreeLog acquiring 2 assets
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) is acquiring two properties in Vietnam and South Korea for S$42.2 million. The assets, a warehouse in Vietnam and a logistics centre in South Korea, offer a net property income yield of 10% and 8% respectively. The acquisitions will be fully funded by debt and will increase MLT's total portfolio to 119 properties with a book value of S$4.67 billion, while its leverage ratio will be approximately 34.9%.

site_title: Keep It Simple, Sweet
summary: Kiss 92FM DJ Maddy Barber shares her experience of decorating her marital home in Loyang Avenue, a 2,000 sq ft ground floor apartment. Initially, she prioritized natural materials like wood and stone, but her husband's dislike of certain decorative items led to a compromise. The couple now favors neutral colors and natural materials, which they find easier to agree on. The home features timber accents, a stone feature wall, and faux wood aromatherapy, creating a simple and comfortable atmosphere without any hints of country or bling.

site_title: S'pore-EU FTA expected to come into force after 2016
summary: The Singapore-EU Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) is expected to come into force after 2016 due to a European Court of Justice (ECJ) opinion request. The Investment Protection Chapter (IPC) was finalized and initialled by state counsels from Singapore and the EU, introducing new investment protection standards and arbitration rules. The EUSFTA aims to boost bilateral trade and investment relations between Singapore and the EU, replacing 12 existing bilateral investment treaties. The agreement is expected to enhance market access, intellectual property protection, and reduce technical barriers to trade between the two regions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 7 Heaven
summary: The new Audi Q7 is a luxuriously dynamic SUV with class-leading features and equipment. Weighing 210 kg less than its predecessor, the Q7 is shorter and lighter but roomier and better. It boasts a suite of innovations, including a new virtual cockpit, advanced driver assistance systems, and a responsive 3.0 TFSI quattro engine. The Q7's agility and handling capabilities make it a surprisingly enjoyable drive, with a new all-wheel steering system and adaptive air suspension. With its spacious interior and advanced safety features, the Audi Q7 sets a new standard for its class.

site_title: Singapore high-end homes back in vogue with foreigners
summary: Singapore's high-end homes have seen a resurgence in popularity among foreigners, with units costing over S$5m accounting for 19% of April purchases, up from 6% in Q1. This increase in luxury apartment sales is attributed to a bigger price drop in high-end homes compared to suburban properties and relatively attractive prices compared to Hong Kong. The revival in buying interest from mainland China buyers is also contributing to the surge in luxury home sales.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
PUTTING ON THE GLITZ: The family room in a show unit of a 4-bedroom Marina Bay Suites apartment.

site_title: Serum power
summary: Serums have become a staple in skincare routines, offering advanced technology to address various skin concerns. These concentrated potions are made with small molecules that hold active ingredients for better absorption and penetration. Unlike moisturizers, which provide surface-level hydration, serums target deeper skin issues and often contain potent anti-aging ingredients. Brands like Sulwhasoo and La Mer are leading the way with innovative serums, such as capsulated ginseng and marine plant stem cells, that deliver targeted results. Experts emphasize that a healthy lifestyle, including diet, sleep, and exercise, remains essential for achieving glowing skin.

site_title: Yoma's Q4 profit up 28% at S$8.16m
summary: Yoma Strategic reported a 28% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$8.16 million for Q4 2015, driven by higher fair-value and bargain-purchase gains on investment properties and acquisitions. The company also announced senior management changes, including the appointment of JR Ching as CFO and Melvyn Pun as CEO, replacing Andrew Rickards. Gross profit rose 2.2% to S$13 million, and the company's profit attributable to equity-holders grew 71.1% to S$28.05 million for FY2015.

site_title: Inflation heads towards Fed's 2% target as April CPI rises
summary: US inflation rose 0.3% in April, the largest gain since January 2013, driven by broad-based increases in prices for rents, used cars, and medical care. Core inflation, excluding food and fuel, also rose 0.3%, indicating the country is inching towards the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. Fuel expenses stabilized, and hourly wages adjusted for inflation increased 2.3% over the past 12 months. Fed officials are likely to raise interest rates in September, with many predicting the first rate increase since 2006.

site_title: IMF to Tokyo and its central bank: 'Take bolder policy actions'
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged the Bank of Japan to take bolder policy actions to combat deflation and achieve its 2% inflation target. The IMF's report comes after the BOJ's decision to maintain monetary easing at current levels, citing weak monetary transmission and a need for further easing to stabilize inflation. The IMF also warned that an over-reliance on monetary policy without stronger fiscal reforms could depress the value of the yen further. The report calls for the BOJ to stand ready for further easing and provide stronger guidance to markets.

site_title: AA Reit unveils S$41.7m warehouse redevelopment
summary: AA Reit is investing S$41.7 million to redevelop two industrial buildings into a five-storey ramp-up warehouse facility at Tuas West Road in Singapore. The redevelopment is expected to nearly double the gross floor area and increase plot ratio, valued at S$60.7 million upon completion. Annual rental income is projected to increase to S$4.15 million, with a net yield of around 7.2%. The project is expected to commence in Q3 FY2016 and complete in Q1 FY2018, coinciding with the Tuas West MRT Extension and a new container port in Tuas.

site_title: German business sentiment declines in May
summary: German business confidence declined in May for the first time in seven months, dropping to 108.5 from 108.6 in April, according to the Ifo institute. Despite this, the Bundesbank predicts continued economic expansion, citing a boost in capital investment and low borrowing costs. Risks remain due to uncertainty over Greece's eurozone status and geopolitical tensions. The economy is still expected to outperform the euro area, with a record-low unemployment rate and a weak euro benefiting exporters.

site_title: US: Wall St ends lower after Yellen comments fail to inspire
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen indicated the central bank is poised to raise interest rates this year, aligning with Wall Street's expectations. Yellen stated a rate hike would be warranted if the economy continues to improve, and it would take several years to return to normal interest rates. This move follows a week of slow trading activity, leaving investors uncertain about recent record-high levels.

site_title: China opens doors to 600b yuan of fund sales via HK
summary: China and Hong Kong will start cross-border sales of funds on July 1, allowing foreign asset managers to tap China's household savings of around $8 trillion. The initial quota is 600 billion yuan (S$130 billion), with 100 Hong Kong funds and 850 Chinese counterparts eligible. The mutual recognition programme will enable Chinese asset management firms to sell to offshore investors and give foreign counterparts access to the Chinese market, potentially increasing investment styles and mentality between the two markets.

site_title: The XE factor
summary: The Jaguar XE is a new compact sedan that combines handling and comfort, resulting from a £2 billion investment. With a lightweight aluminum body, the XE boasts a 50:50 front/rear weight distribution and aerodynamics, achieving a drag coefficient of 0.26. The car features modern luxury inside, including an eight-inch touchscreen and leather upholstery, and is powered by a 2.0-litre turbocharged petrol engine producing 240 hp. The XE's double wishbone front suspension and Integral Link rear suspension provide precise control and body stability, making it a fun yet composed drive.

site_title: German carmakers eye Nokia's map unit
summary: Germany's premium carmakers Mercedes, Audi, and BMW have teamed up with private equity firm General Atlantic to bid for Nokia's mapping unit Here, worth up to $4 billion. The bid comes after Nokia's strategic review of its maps business, with carmakers prepared to chip in up to $700 million each. Other players, including Uber and Baidu, are also bidding, but the carmakers believe their chances are high due to their reliance on Here's maps for vehicle navigation systems.

site_title: 'Grexit' poses medium-term risks to euro: Italy
summary: Italy's finance minister, Pier Carlo Padoan, says a Greek euro exit, or "Grexit," poses a medium-term risk to the eurozone, as it demonstrates the union's impermanence. The ECB's massive stimulus program calmed markets, but a possible exit could lead to a contagion effect, limiting a country's ability to borrow and potentially pushing it out unless the ECB intervenes. Padoan believes Greece's debt is sustainable with reasonable growth and public accounts, but the issue remains sensitive due to EU countries owning much of Greek debt.

site_title: Mercator posts bigger loss for FY ended March 31, 2015
summary: Mercator posted a wider loss of US$125.36 million for FY 2015, compared to US$22.75 million in the previous year, due to exceptional items including vessel impairment and onerous contract provisions. Revenue fell 25% year-over-year to US$56.35 million, resulting in a loss per share of US$0.092, up from US$0.017 in the prior year. The company attributed the decline to falling commodity prices, oversupply of new bulk carriers, and weakening international demand.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China margin trading balance hits 2t yuan
summary: China's margin trading balance has surpassed 2 trillion yuan, marking the first time it has reached this milestone. The growth of margin trading has fueled the Shanghai market's 40% year-to-date gain, despite warnings from regulators about the risks involved. The practice, which allows investors to borrow funds for trading with minimal collateral, has doubled in six months and surged above one trillion yuan for the first time since 2010. Experts warn that the market is "way too heated and risky," as investors face enormous losses if the market changes direction.

site_title: China, India likely to be biggest shareholders in AIIB
summary: China is likely to hold a 25-30% stake in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), with India expected to be the second-largest shareholder. The bank aims to be operational by the end of the year, but some delegates are sceptical about the timeline. Asian countries are expected to own 72-75% of the bank, while European and other nations will own the rest. The US and Japan have declined to join, citing concerns about transparency and governance.

site_title: Opec likely to maintain output
summary: Opec is likely to maintain its daily production target of 30 million barrels, favoring market share over prices, as rival producers buckle under the impact of shale and higher-cost suppliers. Analysts say the strategy is working, with prices rising 46% since mid-January. Opec's 12 members pumped 31.2 million barrels a day in April, exceeding the world's average demand. The decision is seen as a success, with several officials signaling continued production, despite opposition from some members.

site_title: New UK banks grow faster than 'Big Five' rivals
summary: Britain's new banks, known as "challenger banks," have surpassed the "Big Five" rivals in terms of growth, increasing lending by 16% last year compared to a 2.1% decline by larger banks. Smaller challenger banks, such as Metro Bank and OneSavings Bank, are growing at the fastest rate, while larger challengers like Virgin Money and TSB are showing slower growth. This trend is attributed to the new banks' ability to pick up customers shunned by bigger lenders since the 2007-9 financial crisis.

site_title: UBS tried to tap leniency programme but Justice Dept refused
summary: UBS Group escaped US criminal charges for currency market manipulation but its main unit pleaded guilty to manipulating interest rates. The bank's defense team, led by Gary Spratling, a former Justice Department prosecutor, sought leniency to avoid a guilty plea, but the Justice Department refused. A split decision reflected competing interests within the department. UBS agreed to pay over $5 billion to US authorities as part of a settlement. The case highlights the challenges of balancing policy considerations and the consequences of leniency programs in prosecuting corporate wrongdoing.

These events cater to a select audience of fewer than 100 people, often selling out quickly due to their exclusivity and adventurous nature. As a result, entrepreneurs like Crystal Chua and Janet Lim are starting their own private chef businesses and pop-up dinner events, catering to a demand for unique culinary experiences.

site_title: NSA had plans to hack Google app store: report
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) developed plans to hack into data links to Google and Samsung app stores to plant spyware on smartphones, a report by The Intercept said. The plan, called Irritant Horn, aimed to step up surveillance efforts on smartphones and was discussed in 2011 and 2012. The agencies could hijack data connections, implant malicious software, and send misinformation to targets. The plan targeted app store servers in various countries, including Africa, Europe, and Asia, and was motivated by concerns about the spread of popular movements.

site_title: Heat is on for PE funds to derive value in S-E Asia: Bain
summary: Private equity funds in South-east Asia are facing a challenge to derive value from their investments as exit value last year fell to $4.4 billion, the lowest level since 2006. Bain & Company's head of private equity practice in the Asia-Pacific, Suvir Varma, attributes the issue to the lack of IPOs in the region and the need for funds to engage in more "roll-up-your-sleeve deals". With 120 funds competing for deals in the $6 billion market, Varma calls for a "catch-up in the exit side" to balance with deal flow.

site_title: Hiap Seng Engineering lands contract worth S$43 million
summary: HIAP Seng Engineering has won a contract worth approximately S$43 million for mechanical works on the Mogas-Cogen Project on Jurong Island. Work is underway, with completion expected by September 2016. The contract is expected to contribute positively to earnings but is not expected to impact net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Walmart reduces goods sourcing from Li & Fung
summary: Walmart reduced its sourcing business from Hong Kong-based company Li & Fung Ltd, transferring certain functions in-house. This move raises concerns that other major retailers may follow suit, potentially impacting Li & Fung's business. The company's profit fell 18% last year due to increased competition, and its reliance on promotions to fend off online competitors. Analysts expect limited financial impact on Li & Fung, but warn of potential long-term sustainability concerns. The stock price dropped 3.2% following the announcement.

site_title: Strong US$ brings cheer to Americans on holiday in Europe
summary: The US dollar's 19% gain against the euro over the past year has made traveling in Europe more affordable for Americans, with visitor arrivals to Greece increasing 25% to 23,200 in January and February. The stronger dollar, coupled with the euro's devaluation, has led to cheaper wine, food, and accommodations, with tourists finding bargains in countries such as Greece, Italy, and France. Analysts predict the exchange rate will continue to favor Americans, with some forecasting a euro drop to US$1.07, further boosting tourism in Europe.

images.alt_text: MORE BANG FOR THE BUCK: The dollar has advanced against all of its 16 major counterparts since July, bolstered by a stronger economy.

site_title: Thai PTT says no plan to sell more refineries after Star Petroleum IPO
summary: PTT PCL, Thailand's largest energy firm, has no plans to sell more stakes in its oil refineries over the next few years after listing its 36% stake in Star Petroleum Refining Co (SPRC) in 2015. PTT will retain stakes in three refineries following the sale of its SPRC stake. This move comes after the company sold out its holdings in Bankchak Petroleum to reduce criticism about its monopoly in the domestic oil and gas business.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 7.54 points to 1,787.50. The index saw 1.58 billion lots valued at RM1.93 billion traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 498 to 296.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental JV buying Hotel Ritz Madrid
summary: Mandarin Oriental International is acquiring Hotel Ritz Madrid in a 50-50 joint venture with The Olayan Group for 130 million euros. The hotel, which opened in 1910, will undergo a 90 million euro renovation starting in 2017. Mandarin Oriental will manage the hotel under a long-term agreement and expects the acquisition to positively impact its future earnings. The 167-room hotel is located in a residential area near Madrid's financial and cultural district.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: iFAST Corporation has launched the distribution of bonds and Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) to add to its existing investment product offerings. The company received approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) for this new initiative in April. Analysts at DBS Group Research and UOB Kay Hian Research have given iFAST a buy rating, citing growth potential in its Asset Under Administration (AUA) with a forecast of 20% growth over FY15-17F. Meanwhile, Silverlake Axis's share price declined 8% due to allegations of accounting irregularities, which analysts consider unfounded.

site_title: US consumer prices soft, underlying inflation pushes up
summary: US consumer prices dropped 0.1% in April, the smallest decline since October 2009, due to weak gasoline prices. However, underlying inflation pressures, driven by rising shelter and medical care costs, remained strong. The core CPI, excluding food and energy costs, rose 0.3%, its largest gain since January 2013. This suggests the Federal Reserve is likely to raise interest rates later this year, despite sluggish economic growth in the first half of the year.

site_title: China Sky receives extension to release 1Q2015 results
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre Co has received a three-month extension to release its first-quarter 2015 results. The company is in the process of completing a follow-up procedure on its FY2014 results, which are pending completion. As a result, the management expects the 1Q2015 results to be released after the initial deadline of May 15. The review and verification work is expected to be completed within the extended three-month period.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Eiffel Tower shut as staff walk out over pickpockets
summary: The Eiffel Tower in Paris was closed to tourists on May 22, 2015, as staff walked out in protest over a surge in pickpockets targeting visitors, particularly Asian tourists. The closure comes ahead of a long weekend and is the latest in a series of strikes by staff at major tourist attractions in the city. Workers demand formal guarantees that measures will be taken to end the pickpocketing problem, which has led to threats and assaults against staff.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC are strengthening cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: China says to launch mutual fund recognition with Hong Kong on July 1
summary: China's securities regulator announced a mutual fund recognition scheme with Hong Kong to be launched on July 1, allowing funds in both markets to be sold to each other. This move is part of China's efforts to open up its capital market and internationalize its currency. The scheme is a key step after the Shanghai-Hong Kong stock connect, which was launched last November. The discussion on mutual recognition began in 2012, with a preliminary agreement reached in 2013.

site_title: Accor to open first ibis Styles hotel in Singapore
summary: Accor will open its first ibis Styles hotel in Singapore, ibis Styles Singapore, at MacPherson and Aljunied Roads, in Q4 2015. The 298-room hotel features a ship-like exterior, a pool, restaurant, gym, and refurbished interiors. It will be part of the MacPherson Mall complex, offering a range of amenities.

site_title: Poll: Singapore April consumer prices seen falling for sixth month
summary: Singapore's consumer price index likely fell 0.1% from a year earlier in April, marking the sixth consecutive month of decline, according to a Reuters poll. This follows a 0.3% drop in March. Core inflation, excluding housing costs, is forecast to reach a five-year low of 0.9% year-on-year, the lowest since March 2010. The decline in consumer prices is attributed to lower housing costs.

site_title: China margin trading balance balloons to record high
summary: Chinese investors' margin trading balance reached a record high of 2 trillion yuan, surpassing 2 trillion yuan for the first time, according to data from Shanghai and Shenzhen exchanges. This surge in borrowing for stock market trades highlights the risks in the rally, as investors only need to deposit a small proportion of the trade value, generating bigger profits but also bigger losses.

site_title: IMF urges Korea to cut rates to stave off deflation risk
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged South Korea's central bank to cut interest rates to prevent a protracted bout of deflation. The country's economy is slowing, and weak global demand is affecting its export-dependent economy. The IMF notes that the Korean won is undervalued and should be allowed to rise over time. With rates already at a historic low, the IMF suggests that pre-emptive rate cuts can help shift incentives towards consumption and investment, but longer-term cuts may be needed to break the dynamic of entrenched expectations.

site_title: Hong Kong watchdog chief warns investors on trading "miracle" stocks
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission warned investors to be cautious of "miracle" stocks with rapidly increasing values that don't match their underlying business fundamentals. A Thomson Reuters analysis found 35 Hong Kong-listed companies with market capitalizations over $1 billion that saw significant stock price increases despite low revenues. These stocks often have concentrated ownership, and their rapid gains can lead to quick collapses, as seen in the recent meltdowns of companies like Hanergy Thin Film Power Group and Goldin Financial Holdings.

site_title: Malaysia's Petronas posts 39% drop in Q1 profit on global oil slump
summary: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas reported a 39% drop in Q1 profit to 11.4 billion ringgit due to a 50% drop in benchmark crude prices. Revenue decreased to 66.2 billion ringgit, despite higher processed gas trading and LNG sales volume. Petronas maintains a projection for US$55 crude oil prices in 2015 and will pay a lower dividend of 26 billion ringgit to the Malaysian government. The company accounts for most of the government's oil and gas revenue.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.26% and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.07%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.42%. Mining and healthcare sectors boosted shares, while US-EU trade talks were in focus. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: China: Stock index hits 7-year high as more funds move in
summary: China's stock index reached a 7-year high, with the CSI300 index rising 2.3% to 4,951.33 and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 2.8% to 4,657.60 points. The four-day winning streak brought the weekly gain to 7.2% and 8.1% for the CSI300 and Shanghai Composite Index, respectively. Financial stocks led the sector rotation, while Shenzhen's start-up board ChiNext lost momentum.

images.alt_text: China stocks jumped to fresh seven-year highs on Friday, with a four-day winning streak bringing the weekly gain to the biggest since December as investors raised bets that a month-long consolidation period is ending.

site_title: Temporary Occupation Permit for CFM unit's factory building not issued by proper authority
summary: CFM Holdings announced that its subsidiary's Temporary Occupation Permit (TOP) for a new factory building was not issued by the proper authority. The company stated this after receiving an email from its architect claiming the permit was issued. CFM Holdings is working with relevant parties to assess the impact and regularize the permit issuance. The management is taking necessary actions to address the issue, but no further details were provided.

site_title: German economy reaches cruising altitude as business confidence stays high
summary: The German economy has reached a stable growth phase, with business confidence remaining high in May, according to the Ifo economic institute. The business climate index eased slightly to 108.5 points, but analysts viewed the data as positive, citing solid growth in the eurozone's largest economy. Domestic demand drove economic growth of 0.3% in the first quarter, while foreign trade acted as a drag. Experts expect the German economy to post solid growth in 2015, driven by private consumption, a robust labor market, and low inflation.

site_title: Hewlett-Packard's profit beats estimates on server demand
summary: Hewlett-Packard (HP) reported a fiscal second-quarter profit of 87 US cents a share, beating analyst estimates, driven by strong demand for corporate servers. Despite a 6.8% decline in sales, HP's enterprise business benefited from an 11% rise in industry-standard server sales. The company plans to split into two entities, with HP Inc focusing on PCs and printers, and Hewlett-Packard Enterprise supplying technology to businesses. HP shares rose 1.6% following the report, but the stock is still down 16% for the year.

site_title: China, India likely to be largest shareholders of AIIB: sources
summary: China is likely to hold a 25-30% stake in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), with India set to be the second-largest shareholder, holding between 10-15%. The shares were discussed during a meeting of the bank's founding members in Singapore.

site_title: SGX, Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange sign MOU to develop commodities markets in both countries
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Zhengzhou Commodity Exchange (ZCE) have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to jointly develop and expand the commodities markets in China and Singapore. The two exchanges will explore cooperation in product development, events, information sharing, and education programs. This move aims to leverage each other's strengths and promote the growth of commodities markets in the region, with SGX's chief Magnus Böcker noting that the partnership will support the exchange's commitment to the commodity industry in Asia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower, Richemont slips after update
summary: The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index edged lower in early trading on Friday, with Richemont leading the decline after reporting lower profits. Richemont shares fell 3.4% following an 8% drop in April sales and lower net profit. The index was down 0.1% at 1,618.50 points, but still on track for its best weekly gains in over a month.

site_title: Taper tantrum haunts Yellen as rate rise approaches
summary: The Federal Reserve is preparing for its first interest rate increase in nearly a decade, sparking concerns about a potential "taper tantrum" in the bond market. Fed officials fear that low bond yields near record lows could surge once rates are raised, leading to higher costs for mortgages and car loans. Janet Yellen has warned of a potential sharp jump in long-term rates after the rate hike, and the Fed is trying to prepare markets for the change while avoiding panic. Economists expect an interest rate increase in September, but the Fed's decision may be influenced by the risk of a market reaction.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly down; S&P 500 retreats from record
summary: US stocks declined on Friday ahead of a long holiday weekend, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 26.90 points (0.15%) to 18,258.84. The S&P 500 retreated from its record, dropping 3.74 (0.18%) to 2,127.08, while the Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.46 (0.01%) to 4,529.82. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on the US economic outlook, with a possible interest rate hike expected in September. Markets will be closed on Monday for the Memorial Day holiday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares jump as investors expect more money inflows
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.7% on Friday, driven by gains in mainland China markets and expectations of fresh money inflows from Chinese investors. The Hang Seng index rose to 27,992.83, posting a weekly gain of 0.6%. Strategist Lu Wenjie estimates Chinese investors could pump 200 billion yuan (S$43 billion) into Hong Kong stocks in the next two to three quarters, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Brazil to freeze US$23b in spending to meet target: source
summary: The Brazilian government will freeze around $31 billion in spending this year, in line with market expectations, to meet its target. The freeze affects executive, judicial, and legislative spending, totaling slightly more than 70 billion reais. This move signals greater commitment to austerity as President Dilma Rousseff battles to regain investor confidence in the economy. The decision is seen as a step towards reducing the country's fiscal deficit.

site_title: Singapore: Ezion, GLP & YuuZoo provide main features in soft week
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index had a forgettable week, with minimal notable events. The index fell on Monday to Wednesday, rose on Thursday, and then bounced 10.32 points to 3,450.18 on Friday. Weakness in Genting Singapore and accounting issues at Nobel Design were the only other notable news. The market's lack of significant movements was attributed to a lack of new information, with the US Federal Open Markets Committee meeting minutes revealing nothing new. The index ultimately ended the week 0.4% higher, above 3,450.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Friday
summary: Singapore's stock market experienced a lackluster week, with only a few notable transactions. Intercontinental Exchange Inc delayed the start date of its Singapore futures market for the third time, hindering the exchange's expansion into Asia. Yello Digital Marketing acquired a majority stake in Gushcloud, while Sodexo opened its regional headquarters in Singapore. Yoma Strategic reported a 28% year-on-year rise in net profit, driven by a fair value gain and currency translation. Meanwhile, the week's trading was largely dominated by the three stocks: Ezion, Global Logistics Properties, and YuuZoo.

site_title: Sodexo opens regional headquarters in Singapore at Fusionopolis
summary: Sodexo opened its regional headquarters in Singapore's Fusionopolis, serving clients in 15 countries with 4 million daily consumers. The new office aims to drive a double-digit revenue increase in Asia Pacific over the next three to five years. Currently, the 15 countries contribute about 1 billion euros to Sodexo's total revenues. The move marks the company's expansion plans in the region.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Negotiations for EU-Singapore FTA draw to close, implementation now pushed beyond 2016
summary: Negotiations for the EU-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (EUSFTA) have concluded, but implementation is now expected to be delayed beyond 2016 due to a European Court of Justice (ECJ) opinion request. The Investment Protection Chapter (IPC) will replace 12 existing Bilateral Investment Treaties, introducing precise investment protection standards and new arbitration rules. The EUSFTA aims to boost bilateral trade and investment between Singapore and the EU, enhancing market access and intellectual property protection. The agreement marks a step towards a potential EU-Asean Free Trade Agreement.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.73% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.73% in the first few minutes of trade on Friday, following a record close on Wall Street and a rally in Shanghai. The Hang Seng Index reached 27,723.67, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 1.23% and 1.58%, respectively.

site_title: Dutch government set to recommend ABN Amro privatisation
summary: The Dutch government is set to recommend ABN Amro's privatization through a stock market listing, seven years after nationalization during the 2008 financial crisis. Finance Minister Jeroen Dijsselbloem will discuss the plan at a cabinet meeting and send a letter to lawmakers for debate and approval. The bank's book value is 15.6 billion euros, potentially making its listing the largest in Amsterdam.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly up, early US rate hike unlikely
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, with Shanghai surging 1.23%, Hong Kong gaining 1.19%, and Seoul adding 0.27%. US interest rate hike expectations narrowed, easing the dollar, while oil prices fell. The S&P 500 closed at a record high, and shares in China's manufacturing sector showed signs of recovery, fueling hopes for further stimulus measures.

site_title: Nobel Design revises FY14 financial statements, following shareholders' concerns at AGM
summary: Nobel Design Holdings revised its FY14 financial statements following concerns raised by shareholders at its annual general meeting. The group reclassified "relevant entities" as "joint ventures" and reclassified a loan to an associated company from "cash flows from operating activities" to "cash flows from investing activities", with no impact on net cash flows. The changes were made after discussions with PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP and joint arrangement partners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.37 points to 1,796.4 points, driven by a 117-69 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 40.3 million lots worth RM 19.6 million.

site_title: The art of widening tastes
summary: Global art auction houses Christie's and Sotheby's are expanding their reach to attract Chinese bidders to Western art segments. Chinese collectors, fueled by a growing pool of ultra-high-net-worth individuals, have driven impressive sales of Western art, with Christie's and Sotheby's reporting significant growth in non-Chinese art sales. Notable transactions include Wang Jianlin's $28.2 million Picasso purchase and Wang Zhongjun's $62 million Van Gogh acquisition. To tap into this market, Christie's and Sotheby's employ "haute couture" outreach efforts, including exposure to Western artists, education, and VIP treatment. This strategy aims to broaden Chinese collectors' tastes and increase sales of non-Chinese art, which is seen as a growing opportunity for art market professionals.

images.alt_text: THE LURE OF THE WEST? Security guards stand at the doors as people take in Jia Aili's Nameless Days 2 during a media preview of Christie's Shanghai Spring Auction in Shanghai. Auction houses like Christies's and Sotheby's know that exposure, education and VIP treatment is the way to go to draw more Chinese collectors to Western art.

site_title: NZ consumer confidence eases in May
summary: New Zealand's consumer confidence index fell to 123.9 in May, down from 128.8 in April, indicating a decrease in optimism about personal and economic outlooks. Consumers feel less financially well off than last year and are less optimistic about the economy over the next 12 months. Expectations for consumer price inflation over the next two years rose to a four-month high of 3.6%.

site_title: Australia: Shares close flat, banks remain a drag
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Friday, ending the week down 1.2% as the big four banks continued to decline, with Commonwealth Bank falling 0.54%. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,664.7. The decline is attributed to concerns about the banks' earnings outlook, with the sector down more than 10% in the past few weeks.

site_title: Toshiba extends accounting probe to three more business units
summary: Toshiba extends its accounting probe to three more business units, including TV, computer, and chip businesses, after finding irregularities that led to profits being overstated by at least $415 million. The company will also mark down operating profit by at least 50 billion yen for the years 2012-2014 due to improper reporting of infrastructure project costs and construction work. Toshiba's internal investigation and a third-party committee, led by a former prosecutor, will conduct the inquiry.

site_title: Euro zone prospects improving but still muted: Draghi
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi stated that the euro zone's economic prospects are improving, but growth remains below pre-crisis levels and credible reforms are necessary. Draghi noted that monetary policy is working through the economy, with growth picking up and inflation expectations recovering.
