However, he emphasized that challenges persist, including debt overhangs and high structural unemployment, and that a cyclical recovery alone cannot solve all of Europe's problems.

site_title: Private equity exits in Southeast Asia last year lowest since 2006
summary: Private equity exits in Southeast Asia dropped to $4.4 billion in 2014, the lowest level since 2006, according to Bain & Company. Despite a slight increase in exit count to 30, half of those were valued below $50 million. The decline is attributed to a lack of IPO opportunities, with Suvir Varma, head of Bain's private equity practice, stating that the market needs to "open up" for private equity funds to exit successfully.

images.alt_text: Exit value by private equity funds in Southeast Asia last year slid to US$4.4 billion - the lowest level since 2006, a report by Bain & Company showed on Friday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares gain 1.9% on the week, best since April 17
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.9% on the week, the largest gain since April 17, after tepid US economic data reduced expectations of an early Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) ended 1.1% higher at 2,146.10 points, its sharpest daily gain in a month. The South Korean won also saw a 0.4% weekly decline.

site_title: Uber in talks with banks for US$1b credit facility
summary: Uber Technologies Inc is in talks with several large banks to secure a $1 billion credit line, known as a revolver, which is not needed to fund its day-to-day business. The cab-hailing company, valued at around $40 billion, is seeking the loan as it prepares to bid for Nokia Oyj's map business HERE. An initial public offering is not imminent, with one person stating it may not happen until next year at the earliest. About six to seven banks are expected to be part of the facility.

site_title: In China, firms flash green credentials as regulators loom
summary: China has introduced stricter regulations to combat pollution, requiring companies to significantly reduce emissions and environmental impact. Firms such as Apple, Mars, and Foxconn are investing in green initiatives, including reforestation, renewable energy, and energy-efficient equipment. The regulations, which have been likened to some of the strongest in the world, are expected to cost China's central bank an estimated 2 trillion yuan ($430.2 billion) annually over the next five years. Local and international firms are expected to bear the majority of the costs, with some viewing the regulations as a competitive advantage.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks stabilise; techs, banks up
summary: Taiwan's stocks rebounded 0.5% on Friday, tracking overnight US gains, with tech heavyweights TSMC and Touch panel maker TPK Holding leading the way. Banks also rose 0.5%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$30.490 to the US dollar. This rebound follows a 1.1% drop in the prior session.

site_title: Hong Kong routs that wiped out US$35 billion spur oversight calls
summary: A sudden sell-off in Hong Kong has wiped out $35 billion in market value from three listed companies, Goldin Financial Holdings, Goldin Properties Holdings, and Hanergy Thin Film Power Group. The sell-off, which saw the companies' shares plummet 40-47% in two days, has raised concerns about the need for greater oversight from Hong Kong's regulator. Investors are calling for the Securities and Futures Commission to step up its intervention to curb manipulation and protect individual investors, who are likely to bear the brunt of the volatility.

site_title: Exxon accelerates Iran sanctions lobbying as nuke accord looms
summary: ExxonMobil, the world's largest publicly traded crude producer, has hired a lobbying firm to discuss Iranian sanctions, marking the first time since 2010 that the company has enlisted outside lobbyists. Western energy companies are eager to tap Iran's vast oil reserves, which have been locked out to American firms due to sanctions. A nuclear deal between Iran and the US by June 30 could lead to sanctions relief and billions of dollars in investments by foreign oil companies, including Exxon.

site_title: Update: ABN Amro to be listed in stages, according to Dutch media reports
summary: Dutch bank ABN Amro is set to return to the market with a sale of up to 30% of its shares, with the first tranche expected to raise between 3 billion and 4.5 billion euros to pay down the national debt. The sale is likely to occur in October or November, with a potential delay to 2016. This marks a milestone in Europe's recovery from the 2008 financial crisis and one of the largest bank flotations in years, with a book value of 14.9 billion euros at the end of 2014.

images.alt_text: Dutch bank ABN Amro, nationalised after the financial crisis, should start its return to market this year with the sale of a first tranche of up to 30 per cent of its shares, the government decided on Friday, according to Dutch media.

site_title: Bank of Japan holds fire on stimulus after upbeat GDP data
summary: The Bank of Japan (BoJ) held its monetary easing program steady, despite upbeat GDP data showing Japan's economy grew 0.6% in the first quarter, beating expectations. The BoJ maintained its annual 80 trillion yen program, citing a moderate recovery trend and declining public investment. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda pushed back a timeline for hitting a 2.0% inflation target, but inflation remains below target at 0.2% in March. Analysts speculate that the BoJ may reconsider easing measures in the future.

site_title: HP sells US$2.3b China unit stake to forge partnership with Tsinghua Unigroup
summary: Hewlett-Packard Co sold a 51% stake in its China-based data-networking business, H3C Technologies, to Tsinghua Unigroup for at least $2.3 billion. The deal forms a partnership to create a Chinese technology powerhouse and allows HP to exit the business. The partnership will house H3C's networking operation alongside server, data-storage, and technology-services businesses. This move follows Western tech companies seeking local partners or selling off assets to Chinese buyers due to cybersecurity concerns in the region.

site_title: OPEC seen unyielding in battle with shale for oil-market share
summary: OPEC is expected to maintain its daily production target of 30 million barrels when it meets on June 5, despite pressure from rival producers. Analysts believe the strategy, which prioritizes market share over prices, is working, with prices rising 46% since mid-January. Global demand growth is expected to accelerate, and some analysts predict a $100 billion drop in global investment in oil production this year. OPEC's current strategy is seen as effective in reining in supply and stimulating demand, with some members opposing the decision but others supporting it.

site_title: Singapore: STI open 8.13 pts higher following Wall Street gains
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) opened 8.13 points higher, up 0.24%, to 3,447.99, following Wall Street's gains. The S&P 500 reached a new record due to strong earnings from Best Buy and CVS Health's acquisition of Omnicare. Gainers outnumbered losers 97 to 36, with notable movers including YuuZoo, Keppel Corporation, and CapitaLand.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental teams up with Saudi MNC to buy Hotel Ritz in Madrid
summary: Mandarin Oriental International, a subsidiary of Jardine Strategic Holdings, has partnered with Saudi Arabian multinational group The Olayan Group to acquire the Hotel Ritz in Madrid for 130 million euros. The 167-room hotel will undergo a 90 million-euro renovation, with Mandarin Oriental managing the property under a long-term agreement. The acquisition is expected to have a positive impact on the company's future earnings.

site_title: Aso to tell G-7 Japan is committed to fiscal consolidation
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso stated that Japan aims to balance its primary budget by fiscal 2020, aiming to maintain market trust in the country's debt management. This commitment to fiscal consolidation will be conveyed to the G-7 finance chiefs during their meeting in Dresden, Germany. The meeting is expected to discuss global issues such as Ukraine, Greece, and the Islamic State.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Friday he would tell Group of Seven finance chiefs next week that Japan aims to balance its primary budget by fiscal 2020.

site_title: Huatai said to plan top pricing for $4.5 billion Hong Kong offer
summary: Huatai Securities Co, China's fourth-largest listed brokerage by revenue, plans to raise $4.5 billion from a first-time share sale in Hong Kong. The company will sell shares at HK$24.80 apiece, a 35% discount to its Shanghai close. This follows a surge in China's stock market, with average daily turnover increasing 51% to $231 billion in April. Huatai joins other Chinese brokers in raising funds to expand, with two Internet entrepreneurs, including Tencent's chairman Ma Huateng, committing to buy shares. The company will set a final price on Friday.

site_title: Third time unlucky as ICE delays Singapore futures market again
summary: Intercontinental Exchange Inc (ICE) has delayed the start date of its Singapore futures market for a third time, pushing it to the second half of the year. The market was initially planned to open by the end of June, but will now not offer trading in Brent crude, gold, or yuan derivatives until then. The delay is attributed to customer preparations, as ICE aims to attract traders in the region and avoid regulations in their home countries. The market will initially offer oil, gold, and a Chinese currency product.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Yoma, Mandarin Oriental, AA Reit, CWT
summary: Singapore companies issued announcements on Friday that may affect trading. Yoma Strategic posted a 28% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$8.16 million, driven by a fair value gain of S$8.0 million due to revaluation of its investment properties. Mandarin Oriental International acquired the Hotel Ritz, Madrid, for S$192.9 million in a 50:50 joint venture. AIMS AMP Capital Industrial REIT will invest S$41.7 million to redevelop its industrial buildings into a five-storey warehouse facility. CWT Limited will have staggered master leases on the warehouse with varying lease terms and annual rent escalation.

site_title: Merkel sets tough line at EU summit with eastern partners
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel set a tough line at the EU summit with eastern partners, warning Russia not to expect special treatment and saying the Eastern Partnership is not an instrument for EU enlargement. Merkel also warned Russia it cannot return to the G7 club until it mends its ways over Ukraine. The EU will reaffirm its commitment to developing ties with Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova, and Ukraine, but all signs suggest Ukraine's EU membership is a long-term objective. The summit aims to build on the 2013 Vilnius summit and address domestic EU issues, including the UK's EU membership and Greece's debt crisis.

site_title: Peak gold seen this year as mining's 'weaklings' bite the dust
summary: Peak gold production is expected this year, with mine operators finally giving up hope of a recovery. Russia's Polymetal International Plc CEO Vitaly Nesis stated that a 2% decline in production is needed to support higher prices, but it will take four straight quarters of declines to improve market sentiment. Weaker output will start in the fourth quarter of 2015 or the first three months of 2016, according to Nesis. This is attributed to difficulty in closing mines, low energy prices, and too much hope among CEOs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fluctuate ahead of central bank policy decision
summary: Japanese stocks fluctuated ahead of a Bank of Japan policy decision, with the Topix falling 0.1% and the Nikkei 225 sliding 0.1%. Energy producers gained while insurers lost value. The yen strengthened to 121.06 per dollar. Economists expect the central bank to keep its asset-purchase plan unchanged, but some speculate a potential change could boost the economy. The yen may temporarily strengthen if policy remains unchanged, according to analysts.

site_title: China's next hot app: year-old Apus aims for 300 million users
summary: China's Apus, a year-old app launcher, aims to reach 300 million users by the end of 2015 and 1 billion in three years. The app, which helps users manage their home screens and apps, has raised $116 million from investors and is valued at $1 billion. Apus has drawn users from outside China, particularly in Southeast Asia and the Middle East, and has become the 7th most popular app on Google Play. Founder Li Tao believes the app's growth will help differentiate phone makers and increase its value.

site_title: AA Reit awards CWT's Indeco redevelopment project for warehouse
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial REIT (AA Reit) has awarded the redevelopment project of its two industrial buildings to CWT's Indeco Engineers. The project, valued at S$41.7 million, will transform the buildings into a five-storey ramp-up warehouse facility, increasing the gross floor area to 287,866 square feet. The redevelopment is expected to be completed in Q1 FY2018, with annual rental income projected to increase to S$4.15 million, resulting in a net yield of 7.2% per annum.

site_title: BOJ to stand pat on policy, may sound more upbeat on economy post-GDP
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to maintain its monetary stimulus and may offer a slightly more upbeat view of the economy despite mixed first-quarter GDP data. The economy expanded at 2.4% annualized, but growth was inflated by inventories and weak private consumption and exports. BOJ policymakers will likely cling to their view that the economy is recovering moderately, with some expecting a revision up in consumption and exports. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda is expected to repeat his inflation target of 2% by mid-2016 and defend the stimulus program.

site_title: Oil's whodunit moment coming with millions of barrels to vanish
summary: Millions of barrels of untapped oil discovered by US shale drillers during the 2008 oil boom are set to disappear from their inventories due to low crude prices. The Securities and Exchange Commission's (SEC) 2008 rule change allowed companies to claim proved reserves for wells that wouldn't be drilled for years, but with prices now at $60, many of these wells are considered money losers. Experts predict that up to 10-20 years may pass before some of these wells are drilled, with over 5.4 billion barrels of reserves attributed to undeveloped wells, up from 26% at the end of 2008.

site_title: Big Energy clashes with John Kerry on how to fix climate change
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry clashed with Europe's biggest energy companies, including Royal Dutch Shell and Statoil, over who should move first on climate change. Kerry argued that the energy industry, with its control of jobs and wealth, holds the tools needed to fix the environment. In contrast, the energy companies called for government policies that would give them incentives to act, such as a price on fossil fuel pollution. The companies cited the European Union Emissions Trading System as a model, but said it has not been effective in spurring businesses to act quickly.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher
summary: European stocks rose slightly higher at close on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.09% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 up 0.14%. The British pound hit two-month highs against the euro, driven by strong retail sales data. US stocks also edged up, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.07%. Analysts speculate on the timing of a potential US interest rate hike, with the Federal Reserve policymakers not expecting a rate increase in June.

site_title: Playboy puts clothes back on for new mobile app
summary: Playboy has launched a new mobile app, Playboy NOW, focusing on lifestyle and culture rather than nudity. The app features a daily briefing, original content, and curated content from the Playboy website. The move follows a successful digital strategy that has boosted website traffic by 258% in the past year. The app aims to cater to busy users seeking entertainment, information, and inspiration, while providing advertisers with opportunities to engage with loyal users. The "safe for work" approach reflects the brand's updated strategy, shifting away from its traditional emphasis on explicit content.

site_title: New kid on Asia's lending block spurs infrastructure-pledge boom
summary: China's Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has sparked a lending boom in Asia, with the World Bank and Japan's Asian Development Bank (ADB) increasing their commitments to infrastructure projects. The AIIB, backed by 56 nations, has pledged $100 billion, while the ADB has overhauled its development fund to boost lending by 50%. The move is seen as a response to China's growing influence, with some experts warning of potential environmental and corruption issues. The influx of new funding could lead to increased competition, but collaboration is also possible, with China's AIIB cooperating with existing institutions.

site_title: The rest is noise: three policy makers signal Greece's destiny
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, German Chancellor Angela Merkel, and European Central Bank President Mario Draghi are key players in determining the outcome of the Greek crisis. Despite conflicting statements from Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis, Tsipras is the decider, while Merkel's influence is crucial in deciding how to end the crisis, balancing voter support with the need to avoid a eurozone breakup. Draghi's actions have cushioned the impact of the crisis on non-Greek bond markets, while Merkel's past decisions have shown her ability to shape the currency union's direction. A deal is expected by the end of the month.

site_title: Indonesia sells US$2b global sukuk in largest-ever offering
summary: Indonesia sold US$2 billion of Islamic bonds at a yield of 4.325% in its largest-ever global sukuk sale. This rate is the lowest in three years, lower than the 4.35% paid for similar debt last year and the record-low 3.3% in 2012. The sale was made by the Finance Ministry, marking a significant step in the country's efforts to diversify its foreign currency reserves.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end 0.3% higher
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rose 0.3% to a 15-year high, marking a six-day rally. The benchmark index reached 20,264.41 points, with the Topix also increasing 0.06% to 1,647.85. The gains follow a strong performance in other markets, including Singapore, where the STI rose 0.4% on Thursday. Despite US trade tensions, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records, and the US dollar remained stable.

site_title: South Korea's Yello Digital Marketing buys majority stake in Gushcloud
summary: South Korea's Yello Digital Marketing acquired a majority stake in Singapore-based digital marketing startup Gushcloud in a multi-million dollar deal. Following the acquisition, YDM will shift its South-east Asian headquarters to Singapore and house up to 200 employees. Gushcloud co-founders Vincent Ha and Althea Lim will retain a significant minority shareholding and lead strategic roles within YDM. The deal aims to tap the huge potential in content and data to meet clients' needs in the digital world, with YDM's CEO Lee Sang Seok citing Singapore's strategic location and consumer markets.

site_title: Yoma's Q4 net profit gets boost from fair value gain and currency translation
summary: Yoma Strategic posted a 28% year-on-year rise in net profit to S$8.16 million for Q4 2015, driven by a fair value gain of S$8.0 million and a currency translation gain of S$6.08 million. For FY2015, net profit grew 71.1% to S$28.1 million, with revenue increasing 10.4% to S$110.9 million. Andrew Rickards will step down as CEO, replaced by Melvyn Pun, and JR Ching has been appointed as CFO.

site_title: Japan net external assets hit record US$3t as top creditor nation
summary: Japan's net external assets reached a record 366.86 trillion yen (S$4.04 trillion) at the end of 2014, making it the world's top creditor nation for 24 years. The weak yen boosted the value of overseas holdings, with Japan's gross external assets rising 18.5% to 945.27 trillion yen. External debt also grew 22.6% to 578.42 trillion yen, driven by increased acquisitions by foreign investors. The Bank of Japan's monetary stimulus contributed to the decline in the yen, benefiting exporters. Japan surpassed China as the world's largest creditor nation.

site_title: Guatemalan president sacks 3 ministers amid graft scandal
summary: Guatemala's President Otto Perez fired three ministers and his spy chief amid a deepening corruption scandal. The sacked ministers include interior minister Mauricio Lopez, environment minister Michelle Martinez, energy and mines minister Edwin Rodas, and intelligence chief Ulises Anzueto. Perez also fired his vice president, who was already facing corruption charges. The move aims to regain control over the government and address widespread corruption concerns.

site_title: HSBC wins reversal of US$2.46b Household judgment
summary: A US appeals court has reversed a $2.46 billion judgment against HSBC Holdings Plc in a securities class action stemming from a consumer finance business it bought over a decade ago. The 7th US Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that HSBC and three former Household International Inc executives are entitled to a new trial over alleged liability for making false statements. The court also found that expert testimony was insufficient to prove "firm-specific, nonfraud factors" contributed to the stock price decline. The judgment, which included $1.48 billion in damages and $986 million in interest, was imposed in 2013.

site_title: Italy passes law to tackle rampant corruption
summary: Italy's Chamber of Deputies approved a law to tackle rampant corruption, increasing prison sentences for graft and balance sheet fraud. The law, which was watered down, raises jail sentences up to 10 years for bribery and up to 8 years for balance sheet fraud. The legislation aims to combat corruption, which has undermined Italy's stagnant economy and ranked 69th in Transparency International's 2014 Corruption Perceptions Index. Critics say the law's loopholes in Italy's justice system will prevent effective enforcement, but Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's Democratic Party hailed it as a significant step forward.

images.alt_text: Visitors arrive at the Universal Exposition, EXPO2015, on May 2, 2015 in Milan. The last year has seen high-profile arrests of politicians and businessmen over graft allegations connected with the 2015 Expo in Milan, a 5 billion euro Venice flood barrier, and public contracts awarded by the city of Rome.

site_title: Time to view corporate governance, stewardship as partners in responsible wealth creation
summary: Corporate governance and stewardship are being viewed as partners in responsible wealth creation. Companies are frustrated by the disconnect between their efforts to communicate with shareholders and the lack of explanation for voting against them at AGMs. This disconnect highlights the need for common sense and coordination between different stakeholders, including the company secretary, chairman, and corporate governance specialists. Effective corporate governance can lead to enduring business performance, but current practices are not achieving this goal.

site_title: China infrastructure push runs up against project delays
summary: China's infrastructure push has stalled due to project delays, with nearly 40,000 Shanghai residents awaiting affordable housing. The country has allocated $427.5 billion for infrastructure projects, but financing difficulties and policy conflicts are hindering progress. Delays have become common, with some projects taking 6-12 months to secure financing. Chinese policymakers have ordered banks to maintain lending, but experts warn that financing bottlenecks will harm growth. The slowdown in infrastructure project delivery rates has fallen to 60% over the last decade, from 79% in the 1990s.

images.alt_text: The concrete building shells, attended by motionless cranes and piles of rubbish, were supposed to be an affordable housing project for nearly 40,000 Shanghai residents, but now stand testament to China's slowing economy.

site_title: Strike the perfect balance between luxury and elegance
summary: A luxury and elegance-focused bedroom makeover is suggested, balancing high-end pieces with refined taste. The article does not provide specific details on products or services.

site_title: Indonesia to call time on tax-free debt for riskiest borrowers
summary: Indonesia plans to ban firms from writing off interest costs against taxable income if debt exceeds four times equity, aiming to curb record private debt and slow economic growth. The move affects companies such as telecommunications firm PT Tower Bersama Infrastructure, which could face significant losses. The proposal aims to balance reining in surging liabilities with encouraging investment, as the country seeks to reverse its slowest economic growth in six years. The measure is part of a broader effort to curb private external debt, which soared to more than half of all foreign dues last year.

images.alt_text: Companies the world over have used interest payments to shrink their tax bills for decades. Indonesia, faced with record private debt, is trying something different.

site_title: Japan takes South Korea to WTO over food import restrictions
summary: Japan filed a trade complaint at the World Trade Organization (WTO) against South Korea's import bans and testing requirements for Japanese food, citing violations of the WTO's sanitary and phyto-sanitary agreement. Japan claims South Korea failed to justify its trade restrictions, which were imposed after the 2011 Fukushima nuclear disaster. The WTO will review the complaint, which may lead to changes in South Korea's food import policies.

site_title: Germanwings pilot suicide prompts FAA review of medical test
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is reviewing pilot medical tests following the Germanwings plane crash in France two months ago, where a suicidal pilot was responsible. A new panel of officials will recommend ways to improve pilot fitness evaluations, marking a comprehensive reassessment of pilot medical rules. The move aims to address concerns about mental health screening in the aviation industry.

site_title: New British banks seeing better returns and lending more: KPMG
summary: Britain's new banks are achieving superior returns and lending more than larger rivals since the 2007-9 financial crisis. The 'Big Five' retail banks saw a 2.1% decline in lending, while new banks increased lending by 16% last year. Smaller 'challenger banks' are driving growth, with an average return on equity of 18.2%, compared to 2.1% at larger challengers and 2.8% at the 'Big Five'. This trend may pose a challenge for the 'Big Five' as they struggle to compete with the growing challenger banks.

images.alt_text: Britain's new banks are achieving superior returns than larger rivals, picking up customers shunned by bigger lenders since the 2007-9 financial crisis, consultancy KPMG said on Friday.

site_title: Monsanto plans to divest Syngenta's seed business to get nod for takeover
summary: Monsanto plans to divest Syngenta's seed and chemistry businesses to gain regulatory approval for a potential takeover of the Swiss company. Monsanto, the world's largest seed company, has already made a $45 billion offer that was rejected, but continues to pursue a deal. The move aims to address regulatory concerns and secure a broad portfolio of fungicides, insecticides, and herbicides. A successful takeover would bolster Monsanto's earnings, which are heavily reliant on glyphosate-based herbicides and genetic alterations to seeds.

site_title: US trophy-home prices climb at slowest pace in three years
summary: US trophy-home prices rose 0.9% in the first quarter, the slowest pace in three years, as wealthy buyers expressed concerns about overpaying following a surge in values. This contrasts with a 4.3% gain for the rest of the market.

site_title: Manulife plans US$450m IPO of US assets in S'pore
summary: Manulife Financial Corp plans to list some of its US property assets in Singapore through an initial public offering (IPO) worth US$450 million in the second half of the year, using the real estate investment trust (Reit) structure. The listing has not been formally announced.

site_title: Target reports profit that beats estimates
summary: Target reported a profit of $1.10 per share in the first quarter, beating estimates of $1.03 per share. Revenue rose to $17.1 billion, surpassing expectations of $17.08 billion. The company's stronger sales of children's clothing contributed to the profit.

site_title: A year after Thai coup, stability trumps growth for business
summary: A year after Thailand's bloodless military coup, the country's business establishment remains supportive of the junta, prioritizing stability over economic growth. The coup has brought order and calm to the country, with investors welcoming the end of Thailand's febrile politics. However, critics argue that the junta's focus on constitutional reform has hindered economic progress, with delayed elections and a referendum on the new charter. Despite this, executives say they are satisfied with the current situation, as long as it provides a peaceful environment for business to operate.

site_title: India Inc calls on Modi to spend 1 trillion rupees to boost economy
summary: India's business leaders are urging Prime Minister Narendra Modi to invest 1 trillion rupees (S$21 billion) in infrastructure to boost the country's economy, which is facing modest achievements and incremental change in its first year in office. Executives are calling for simplification of land acquisition rules and implementation of a national sales tax. The government is seen as crucial in financing new projects, and the move could signal confidence in the future and inject cash into the broader economy.

site_title: Fast-track Asia-Pacific trade bill clears US Senate hurdle
summary: The US Senate has advanced a bill granting President Barack Obama fast-track authority to conclude a massive Asia-Pacific trade accord, clearing a major hurdle in his efforts to negotiate a trade agreement with 11 Pacific Rim nations. The bill, known as Trade Promotion Authority (TPA), would allow lawmakers to vote on the accord without amendments, with a final vote expected on Friday or Saturday. Supporters say the measure includes key human rights provisions and assistance for American workers, while critics argue it would lead to a "race to the bottom" and harm workers.

site_title: Debt concessions for Greece less likely as Portugal's Socialist leads
summary: Germany and other eurozone leaders are unlikely to give Greece concessions in debt repayment negotiations due to concerns that it may embolden anti-austerity parties, particularly Portugal's Socialist party, which is leading in the polls. The Portuguese party's promise to reduce austerity measures has raised worries about weakened governance.

site_title: US: S&P 500 at record on Best Buy earnings, CVS deal
summary: The S&P 500 rose to a new record on Thursday, gaining 4.97 points, as Best Buy reported strong first-quarter earnings and CVS Health announced a $12.7 billion acquisition of Omnicare. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index also reached a new high, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained essentially flat. Other notable movers included Hewlett-Packard, Apple, Amazon, and Salesforce, with various companies announcing earnings, mergers, and acquisitions.

site_title: Dollies revisit 700 years of Singapore history
summary: The Dim Sum Dollies, a Singaporean musical cabaret group, is set to revisit 700 years of Singapore's history in their upcoming show, "The History of Singapore Part 1". The group, formed in 2002, will be performing for the first time since 2008, and will include new material, including a contemporary song and references to Singapore's 1965 separation from Malaysia. The show is a lighthearted and humorous take on Singapore's history, aiming to educate and entertain audiences.

site_title: UK's Cameron to hold first talks with EU leaders on reform demands
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron will hold talks with EU leaders on Friday to discuss reforms he seeks for the EU before a 2017 referendum on Britain's membership. Cameron's demands include restricting EU migrants' access to welfare, winning an opt-out from the EU's "ever closer" union, and cutting red tape from Brussels. EU leaders have ruled out changing fundamental principles, such as free movement of workers, and some countries are open to limited concessions to keep Britain in the bloc. Cameron's goal is to achieve his aims without reforming the EU treaty, which could lead to demands from other countries.

images.alt_text: Newly re-elected British Prime Minister David Cameron will have his first talks with other European Union leaders on Friday on reforms he is seeking to the EU before holding a referendum by 2017 on Britain's membership of the bloc.

site_title: Senate proposal a US$66b capital boon for US banks
summary: A US Senate proposal could free up up to $66 billion in capital for 11 US banks, including American Express and Capital One, by raising the threshold for being deemed "systemically important" to $500 billion. The proposal, which has bipartisan support, could allow these lenders to return more capital to shareholders, potentially leading to increased payouts. If passed, the bill would remove an obstacle to returning capital for firms with large buffers above minimums, and regional banks could use excess capital to expand lending to small and mid-size businesses and consumers.

site_title: Big GLP parcel traded on ho-hum day
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a low-volume trading session, with the total turnover of S$2.2 billion and a 48% contribution from Global Logistic Properties (GLP). A large parcel of GLP shares worth S$964 million boosted the counter's total volume, but the market remained stuck in a trading range. Analysts attributed the low volume to the lack of catalysts, with some expecting the market to trade sideways with a downward bias. Shares of Ezion Holdings rebounded after hosting an analyst briefing, while Hyflux ended lower due to a lacklustre quarter forecast.

site_title: Merkel, Hollande to meet Greek PM in Riga
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel, French President Francois Hollande, and Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras will meet in Riga on Thursday to discuss a crucial debt deal for Greece, with a June 5 deadline looming. The meeting aims to outline solutions for Greece's debt crisis, which has been locked in talks with international creditors for months. The EU and IMF demand tough labour market and pension reforms, but these contradict the election promises that swept Tsipras's party into power. The meeting is seen as a last-minute effort to prevent Greece from defaulting on its debt and possibly crashing out of the eurozone.

site_title: Saudi Arabia Minister sees day when nation exports gigawatts
summary: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali Al-Naimi, predicts the nation will eventually shift from exporting fossil fuels to selling solar power, with the goal of exporting gigawatts of electricity by a future date, possibly 2040 or 2050. Despite this, he expects fossil fuels to remain dominant globally until 2050. Saudi Arabia is developing solar energy, but currently has less than 50 megawatts of capacity, a fraction of other countries. The country aims to lead OPEC in defending market share and boost power supplies to serve its economy and population.

site_title: Increase in US rents beats rise in home values for first time since 2012
summary: US rental costs increased 4% in the year ended in April, surpassing a 3% rise in home values for the first time since 2012, according to Zillow data. This marks the first time rental increases outpaced property value growth in 20 of the 35 largest US markets. The "rental crisis" exacerbates the housing market's struggle to find normalcy, making it harder for renters to save for a down payment and for homeownership. The trend is expected to continue, fueling further price growth and an unfavorable cycle in the housing market.

site_title: Making time for everyone
summary: Local watch brand moVas, founded by Sean Wai, is redefining luxury watchmaking by sourcing parts and movements from Asia, keeping prices affordable compared to Swiss-made watches. Over the past six years, moVas has convinced collectors that a watch's luxury status isn't solely determined by price tag, with designs and technical aspects becoming key factors. The brand has expanded its product line, now assembling watches in Singapore, and is planning to develop its own movements, with a focus on intricate designs and complicated movements.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Oil surges as falling US stockpiles ease glut worries
summary: Global oil prices surged on Thursday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising $1.74 to $60.72 a barrel, and Brent North Sea crude gaining $1.51 to $66.54 a barrel. Falling US crude stockpiles and declining oil shale production are expected to ease supply glut concerns. Analysts attribute the rally to rising demand and central bankers' easy-money policies, despite poor manufacturing data and geopolitical worries. The Federal Reserve's delayed interest rate hike also contributed to the dollar's decline, making dollar-priced crude more attractive for buyers.

images.alt_text: Global oil prices surged on Thursday as falling US crude stockpiles and production stirred expectations of an easing in the global supply glut.

site_title: Spotify expands to include video and predictive playlists
summary: Spotify has expanded its services to include video and predictive playlists, entering direct competition with Apple, YouTube, and other technology outlets. The new features, announced ahead of Apple's expected entry into the streaming market, include podcasts, short video clips, and playlists anticipating user interests based on time of day. Spotify partners with media outlets like Comedy Central and NBC, and also matches music tempo to a runner's pace. With 15 million paying users and 45 million more listening free with ads, Spotify aims to dominate the world of subscription streaming music services.

site_title: Statement pieces for your home
summary: A home decor article from May 2015 features statement pieces with chinoiserie design accents, including fine jinsi nanmu furniture once used by China's imperial families. Meanwhile, recent news includes the Asean countries agreeing that Myanmar's election is not a priority, a low-profile property trust's data centre gamble, and a decline in US weekly jobless claims. China urges South-east Asia to support openness as US tariffs loom, with Chinese property shares surging on reports of a sector revival. Reliance Jio delays its India IPO, and China introduces new employment aid measures amid trade tensions.

site_title: Final Letterman show draws record 14 million viewers
summary: David Letterman's final Late Show drew a record 14 million viewers, its largest audience in 21 years, according to CBS. The show averaged 13.76 million viewers, surpassing the network's largest audience with any host. Following Letterman's retirement, James Corden's The Late Late Show drew 4 million viewers directly after his debut. Letterman's emotional final show, featuring jokes and farewells from celebrities, marked the end of a 33-year career.

images.alt_text: Nearly 14 million people tuned in to watch comedy legend David Letterman broadcast his final Late Show on American television, the programme's largest audience in 21 years, CBS said Thursday.

site_title: Genting HK to sell another 4.35% stake in Norwegian Cruise Line
summary: Genting Hong Kong plans to sell 10 million shares of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings (NCLH) for $546.1 million, a 4.35% stake, to boost its cash reserves. The sale will result in a gain of $389.3 million and increase the company's net cash to $1.12 billion. Post-sale, Genting Hong Kong's stake in NCLH will be cut to 17.7% from 22%. The sale will also lead to a one-off accounting gain of $1.69 billion, but analysts focus on the $546.1 million cash proceeds.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: EU ambassador on how member countries can realise the full potential of Asean
summary: EU Ambassador Michael Pulch emphasizes the importance of Asean countries avoiding national interests that hinder regional potential. He advocates for collaboration and implementation of agreements, citing the EU's experience in creating achievable measures and enforcement methods. Pulch believes the current economic climate, with low unemployment and favorable exchange rates, is the "perfect timing" for the EU to join hands with the Asean economy, citing the EU's significant investment and trade with the region.

site_title: A Xin Yao love story revisited
summary: Singapore's musical December Rains, a Xin Yao love story, is set to be re-staged for the third time, with a new cast and fresh arrangements. Artistic director Goh Boon Teck aims to tour the production in China, marking a significant milestone for Xin Yao, a genre of Singapore music. The musical, which tells the story of two students from different backgrounds, will premiere in August at the Esplanade Theatre, with a CD launch in June. The production promises to be the best version yet, with Goh researching the 1950s Singapore for a more authentic setting.

site_title: SMEs to get help in adopting technologies
summary: Singapore has launched five new collaborative industry projects (CIPs) to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) adopt technological innovations and digital marketing tools. The projects, led by various industry partners, aim to boost sales performance, customer engagement, and marketing efforts. More than 400 SMEs will benefit from the initiatives, with 200 receiving funding and technical expertise to adopt RFID and image recognition technologies, while 150 will gain access to an integrated IT solution based on the WeChat mobile app. The projects offer up to 70% funding support for eligible adoption costs.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Burberry shares tumble after profit guidance cut
summary: Burberry shares plummeted 5% after the company cut its annual profit guidance due to foreign exchange volatility and subdued demand in Hong Kong and the US. The luxury goods maker reported a £40 million drop in expected profit, despite an 11% rise in underlying revenue. Burberry cited a strong pound and a fall in spending from Chinese customers as major contributors to the decline. The company's underlying pre-tax profit rose 7%, but currency fluctuations wiped £72 million from revenue and £38 million from profit.

site_title: Factory activity slows for 2nd month: Markit
summary: US manufacturing sector growth slows for second month, with new orders increasing at their slowest pace since January 2014, according to Markit's preliminary May report. The manufacturing PMI fell to 53.8 from 54.1 in April. Despite job growth picking up, economists warn that payroll growth may slow unless production growth revives. The strong dollar is also seen as weighing on the US economy and corporate earnings, with export sales dipping for two straight months.

site_title: The secret story of capital spending
summary: Global capital spending has failed to recover seven years after the 2008 financial crisis, with investment growth still below pre-crisis levels. Despite low interest rates and growing businesses, companies are reluctant to invest. An increase in self-employment and small businesses may be the reason, as many of these businesses don't employ anyone. This trend is seen in countries like the UK, where three-quarters of businesses are self-employed. The lack of capital spending is puzzling, as one would expect more businesses to lead to increased office furniture, computers, and machinery.

site_title: Drivers face confusion in US vehicle recall over airbag defect
summary: Takata, the Japanese airbag maker, has agreed to recall 34 million vehicles in the US due to a defect that can cause airbags to explode violently, sending metal fragments into the cabin. However, carmakers are still sorting out which vehicles need to be included in the recall, leaving consumers confused. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is working with Takata to compile a definitive list, which is expected to take several days. The recall is expected to take months to complete, with some consumers facing years of waiting for repairs.

site_title: Shenzhen's tech-heavy ChiNext 'hottest market'
summary: Shenzhen's ChiNext, a tech-heavy startup board, has seen a meteoric rise in its shares, with a 42-fold jump in Beijing Baofeng Technology's shares since its March IPO. The ChiNext index has more than doubled this year, outperforming global markets. New listings have posted average gains of 500%, making it the hottest share market in the world. Investors are warned not to get carried away, as this trend may be similar to the dotcom bubble.

site_title: China factory activity shrinks for 3rd month: flash PMI
summary: China's factory activity contracted for the third consecutive month, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.1 in May, below the 50-point growth threshold. This indicates persistent weakness in the world's second-largest economy, prompting increased policy support. The government is expected to cut interest rates further and lower banks' reserve requirements to stimulate growth, which has slowed to a six-year-low of 7% in the first quarter.

site_title: J&J invests in experimental drugs as competitive threats loom
summary: Johnson & Johnson is investing in experimental drugs with blockbuster potential to combat looming competitive threats in its pharmaceutical business. The company aims to seek regulatory approval for over 10 new drugs by 2019, with potential annual sales of over $1 billion each. This move is aimed at regaining momentum in its biggest division, which has seen its blockbuster hepatitis C treatment Olysio and top-selling arthritis drug Remicade being eclipsed by competing products. Despite the looming biosimilar threat, J&J believes it can enforce its patents and expects a gradual impact.

site_title: Chok Tong urges Abe to offer gesture of contrition to neighbours
summary: Singapore Emeritus Senior Minister Goh Chok Tong urged Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to make a gesture of contrition to Asian neighbors on the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II, going further than past Japanese leaders in seeking reconciliation. Goh emphasized the need for trust and confidence among Asian nations, citing a lack of shared strategic vision and historical mistrust. He suggested that other countries, including China and South Korea, must reciprocate with similar gestures showing a desire for reconciliation, and that Japan and China could take a cue from India's efforts to improve relations with China.

site_title: Rediscovering Chopin
summary: Olafur Arnalds' latest album, The Chopin Project, is a collaboration with classical pianist Alice Sara Ott, exploring 19th-century composer Frédéric Chopin's music through innovative recording techniques. The 28-year-old's connection to Chopin stems from his grandmother, who introduced him to the Polish composer's work, influencing his musical style. Arnalds considers Chopin as his "teacher," preparing him for this project, which blends classical and contemporary music. The album marks a personal and professional return to Chopin's music, reflecting Arnalds' deep appreciation for the composer's legacy.

images.alt_text: Christopher Lim

site_title: SPH's Seletar Mall officially opens
summary: SPH's Seletar Mall, a joint project with United Engineers Limited, officially opened on May 21, 2015, featuring over 130 shops, including anchor tenants like FairPrice Finest, Shaw Theatres, and Uniqlo. To celebrate, shoppers enjoyed free parking and a limited-edition tote bag for the first 100 shoppers who spent at least S$30. The mall's opening marked a significant development in Singapore's retail scene, offering a diverse range of shopping and dining options.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Fewer than 10 units sold at boutique condo Pollen & Bleu (Amended)
summary: Singapore Land's boutique condo Pollen & Bleu in District 10 has seen fewer than 10 units sold, with the developer expecting to hit 10-20 units by the next month. The 106-unit project offers units at a 15% discount to comparable boutique condos, with prices starting from S$1.05 million for a 549 sq ft one-bedroom unit. Developer United Industrial Corp attributes the muted response to the market and pricing, which falls within the S$1,500 to S$2,000 psf range.

site_title: US Fed signals interest rate lift-off unlikely in June amid headwinds to growth
summary: US Federal Reserve officials signaled they are unlikely to raise interest rates in June, citing weak economic data, despite expecting moderate growth to resume after a first-quarter stall. The minutes of the April meeting also highlighted concern over a stronger dollar and lower oil prices as lasting headwinds. The Fed will likely raise rates in September, according to economists' forecasts, but officials are uncertain about the timing of a potential rate increase.

site_title: Australian banks cut back on mortgage discounts for landlords
summary: Australian banks are scaling back discounts on mortgages for landlords amid a regulatory crackdown to cool the housing market. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (NPRA) urged lenders to limit mortgage growth to investors to 10% annually, prompting banks to tighten up on investor housing lending. ANZ Bank and National Australia Bank have reduced or eliminated discounts for investor-only lending, while Westpac Banking Corp has taken steps to temper investor lending growth. This move aims to curb a 40% increase in Sydney house prices over the past three years.

site_title: Najib presents RM260b five-year plan to 2020
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak presented a RM260 billion (S$96 billion) five-year economic plan, dubbed the 11th Malaysia Plan, aiming for 5-6% GDP growth per year. Despite a weak ringgit and falling oil prices, Najib emphasized "bold measures for the long-term benefit of all Malaysians." The plan includes initiatives on social inclusion, education, and infrastructure development, but critics argue that it fails to address the country's declining export growth and high household debt. Achieving the GDP targets will be challenging, and experts warn that the plan may not be enough to overcome the country's economic challenges.

site_title: Global public sector investors favour real estate, infrastructure
summary: Global public sector investors, including sovereign wealth funds and public pension funds, are shifting more funds into real estate and infrastructure projects, driven by ultra-low interest rates. The OMFIF survey of 500 global public sector investors found 44% intend to increase real estate and infrastructure investments over the next three to five years, while 50% plan no change. This trend raises concerns of asset price bubbles forming in the sector, particularly in Europe.

site_title: Top looks for stylish homes
Online content creators learn from the masters
summary: The Media Development Authority of Singapore (MDA) emphasized the need for media businesses to adapt to digital trends to grow their consumer base. MDA highlighted the importance of leveraging data analytics to understand target audiences and producing high-quality content across multiple platforms. The agency's efforts to nurture Singapore's digital content creation capabilities include the Maker Bootcamp, a two-day workshop on creating compelling videos and promoting content via social media. MDA plans to establish Creators' Space, a common space for media companies to hone their skills in digital content creation, in collaboration with industry partner Maker Studios.

site_title: PwC boosting presence in asset management sector across Asia
summary: PwC has launched its Asian Investment Fund Centre in Singapore, aiming to bolster its presence in the asset management industry across Asia. The centre will provide services such as market entry and strategy analysis, asset manager operational due diligence, and cross-border fund registration. PwC estimates investible assets in Asia will increase with the rise of the middle class, and Singapore's strategic location, including its fund passporting schemes and large private banking network, make it a preferred hub for asset management in the region. The centre will work with PwC Luxembourg to transfer expertise to Asia.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Euro boosted by data, rise in German bund yields
summary: The euro rose against the dollar for the first time this week, driven by nascent signs of a eurozone recovery and a rise in German bund yields, which narrowed the spread over US Treasuries. The euro reached a high of $1.1182, up 0.7% on the day, while the dollar index fell to 95.082. The European Central Bank's accommodative monetary policy stance and the prospect of quantitative easing are seen as limiting the euro's gains, with some analysts predicting a gradual decline in the currency.

site_title: Blackstone said to seek US$525m for old NYT office
summary: Blackstone Group LP is selling the Manhattan offices that once housed The New York Times for approximately US$525 million, seeking more than US$1,000 a square foot for the top 12 floors of the 102-year-old property. The sale comes after completing renovations and signing new tenants, including Yahoo Inc. The planned sale is private, and a person with knowledge of the plans declined to be identified. The sale price is significantly higher than the US$450 million Blackstone paid in 2011.

site_title: Rex acquires interest in offshore licence
summary: Rex International Holding's wholly owned subsidiary, Rex Bonaparte Gulf, has acquired a 30% participating interest in the offshore WA-488-P licence in Western Australia from MEO Australia at ground-floor terms. The licence, spanning 4,074 square kilometers, is located in the Petrel Sub-basin and includes the producing Blacktip gas field and undeveloped Turtle and Barnett oil discoveries. This acquisition marks Rex's entry into the WA-488-P licence, which is considered a significant discovery in Western Australia.

site_title: City buzz
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Upcoming events in Singapore include the St Petersburg Ballet's Swan Lake performance at Marina Bay Sands, the eighth and final instalment of Cake Theatre's Decimal Points series, and a charity event by the Singapore Junior Chefs Club to raise funds for the Nepal Relief effort. Boyzone will also perform in Singapore as part of their BZ20 The Anniversary Tour. A concert featuring the music of Edith Piaf, La Vie en Rose, will also take place. Additionally, folktales from India will be shared through storytelling by Kamini Ramachandran, suitable for children aged 4-8.

site_title: Xpress and its former chairman broke listing rules in 2014: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued warnings to Xpress Holdings and its former chairman, KK Fong, for breaching listing rules in 2014. The company failed to disclose creditors' winding-up applications in a timely fashion, including a claim of S$400,000 in rental arrears and S$1.2 million in facilities. SGX found that Fong only informed other directors about the winding-up application on July 16, more than a week after receiving the notices. The exchange stated that disclosure is fundamental to a fair market, and the company should have requested a trading halt immediately if it could not make an immediate announcement.

site_title: Tomorrowland or yesterday's TV special?
summary: The Disney movie Tomorrowland, directed by Brad Bird, presents a futuristic utopia with spectacular visuals but lacks depth in exploring its dark implications. The story follows Casey, a high school tech geek, as she discovers a pin that leads her to the city, where she teams up with scientist Frank to uncover its secrets. However, the film veers into dystopian concepts, but fails to reconcile them with its Disney roots, resulting in a confusing message. The film's tone shifts between dark and bright, and its plot feels like a TV show, with a cast that shines despite the limited appeal for adults.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Who's afraid of a big, fat fine? Regulators need new bogeyman
summary: Regulators fined seven of the world's largest banks a total of US$10 billion for foreign exchange market manipulation, with four banks pleading guilty to criminal charges. The guilty pleas, including Barclays, Citigroup, JPMorgan, and Royal Bank of Scotland, have not resulted in significant penalties, with shares rising more than 2% in the market. Regulators may need to impose harsher sanctions, such as full business bans, to regain the initiative and ensure accountability for the institutions.

site_title: Rather silly but quite entertaining
summary: Comedian Melissa McCarthy stars as Susan Cooper, a CIA analyst turned secret agent, in the comedy film Spy. After her partner's death, Cooper volunteers to go undercover to retrieve a nuclear weapon. With a supporting cast, including Jude Law, Rose Byrne, and Jason Statham, the film spoofs the spy genre, with McCarthy delivering a scene-stealing performance. The movie's lighthearted humor and potty-mouthed dialogue make it an entertaining parody, setting the stage for potential future films. McCarthy shines in her fish-out-of-water role, making Spy a successful addition to the comedy genre.

site_title: Salesforce is unlikely to be acquired: SAP CEO
summary: SAP CEO Bill McDermott stated that Salesforce is unlikely to be acquired due to its declining revenue and pricing power. McDermott cited Salesforce's high cost per user and potential for future revenue decline, making it an unattractive acquisition target. He also denied SAP's interest in buying Salesforce, instead focusing on SAP's shift to cloud-computing services to boost profit margins.

site_title: Cashing in on her YouTube credit
summary: Cameroon-born singer Irma Pany's YouTube video, posted in 2011, went viral, leading to a record-breaking 70,000 euros in funding for her second album, Faces, through the crowd-funding platform My Major Company. The album was released in 2014, and Pany will perform at the Music Matters Live festival in Singapore on May 22. Pany's music draws influences from her Cameroonian heritage, despite being Western and pop, and she aims to use her platform to raise awareness about inequality in Africa.

site_title: A tale of two economic zones
summary: A new book by Francis E Hutchinson analyzes the divergent economic development trends in Johor and the Riau Islands, shedding light on the conditions for benign economic outcomes in sub-national governments. The study finds that first-generation fiscal federalism's assumption of efficient sub-national governments does not apply in Malaysia and Indonesia, where rent seeking and predatory behavior prevail. The book also highlights the impact of domestic politics and decentralization on economic development strategies in the region, with the Riau Islands' economic transformation being hindered by a more liberal political system and a decline in labor relations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Analysts from various firms have made predictions on several companies. Raffles Medical Group is seen as an early entrant in the Chinese hospital market, with its Shanghai New Bund International Hospital expected to be developed and managed by a foreign-local JV. Noble Group's potential acquisition of Pacific Rubiales could showcase its new asset-light strategy, while Hyflux Ltd's involvement in a potable water plant in Myanmar suggests potential for future cooperation. However, Hyflux faces a lacklustre quarter ahead due to the delayed start of its Qurayyat desalination project. Analysts have set target prices for the companies.

site_title: US expected to lead global consolidation trend in coal
summary: The US coal industry is expected to lead a global trend of consolidation due to years of depressed prices and oversupply since 2012. US generators plan to shut 22,000 megawatts of coal-fired generation in 2015, making it uneconomical to upgrade old plants to meet stricter environmental rules. Analysts predict asset owners will re-price assets, leading to mergers and acquisitions (M&A) activity, particularly in Australia, over the next 12-24 months. The US dollar's strength has also hampered global competitiveness.

site_title: Investors should be cautious about fixed income too
summary: Investors in fixed-income assets, particularly Asian investors, have seen high yields and capital appreciation in recent years. However, caution is advised due to structural changes in the bond market, including decreased liquidity and the impact of interest rate hikes. The Bank of International Settlements warns of concentrated liquidity in most liquid securities and deteriorating conditions in less liquid ones. Regulatory capital requirements and reduced risk appetite have also led to decreased market maker activity, further exacerbating liquidity issues. Investors should be aware of these risks when investing in bonds through mutual funds and exchange-traded funds.

site_title: China link-up presents opportunity, challenge for Pakistan
summary: China has started construction on the $46 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), connecting the Chinese city of Kashgar with the Gwadar Port, providing energy and economic opportunities for Pakistan. The project is part of China's "Belt and Road Initiative" and is expected to lift Pakistan's GDP by 15%. The investment commitment is the largest foreign aid Pakistan has received since 2008, and it provides Pakistan with much-needed resources and a sense of security. However, security concerns remain, and Pakistan is raising a separate force to protect Chinese personnel on the projects. The CPEC's completion could also link with the Iran-Pakistan-India gas pipeline, benefiting all stakeholders and potentially leading to India-Pakistan peace.

site_title: SIA showcases its premium economy class
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has unveiled its new premium economy class, featuring wider seats, increased recline, and more amenities. The new product, developed over a two-year program and costing US$80m, will cater to long-haul and upper-medium-haul flights, with 36 premium economy seats on A380s and 24 on A350s. The airline aims to fill the gap between economy and business class, offering comfort without the full luxury experience. The product will be rolled out on 19 A380s, 19 Boeing 777-300ERs, and the first 20 A350s, starting commercial service on August 9, 2015.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Tesco paid new boss £4m in first 6 months
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, paid its new CEO Dave Lewis £4.1 million in the first six months, including £570,000 in salary, £97,000 in benefits, and £3.32 million in lieu of incentive awards. This follows a tumultuous year for the company, which issued four profit warnings, faced an accounting scandal, and posted a £6.4 billion annual loss. Lewis, who replaced sacked CEO Philip Clarke, is pursuing efficiency measures to mend the group's finances.

site_title: Toshiba leaving Singapore end May 2015 due to stiff competition
summary: Toshiba will withdraw from the television and appliances market in Singapore by the end of May 2015 due to strong market competition. The company sent a notice to its retailers announcing the withdrawal of some products from the local market.

site_title: The Lady Wants To Go On, after 25 years
summary: Laura Fygi, a 59-year-old Dutch singer, celebrates her 25th anniversary as a solo artist with a double album compilation of her most popular tracks. Born into a Dutch-Egyptian family, Fygi has sung in various languages, including English, Spanish, Italian, and Mandarin, despite not speaking Mandarin fluently. Her career began in the early 1980s with Dutch pop group Centerfold, and she has since released 12 solo albums, winning an Edison Award in 1991. Fygi has no plans to retire, citing her love for singing and her desire to continue performing for her audience.

site_title: Hangzhou shows way to China's new economy
summary: Hangzhou, China, is experiencing a thriving high-tech and software sector, creating a services hub that is driving local economic growth despite a nationwide slowdown. Hundreds of technology-linked companies, including venture capital funds and Big Data firms, have set up shop in the city, benefiting from tax breaks, funding for startups, and a better logistics network. Growth in Zhejiang province accelerated to 8.2% in the first quarter, outpacing the rest of China, and the city is seen as a model for China's "Made in China 2025" strategy, which aims to power the economy with services and advanced industry.

site_title: Shares of Canadian e-commerce software maker Shopify jump in debut
summary: Shopify, a Canadian e-commerce software maker, made its trading debut on the New York Stock Exchange, with shares rising 69% to a high of US$28.70, valuing the company at up to US$2.14 billion. The initial public offering of 7.7 million shares raised US$131 million, priced at US$17.

site_title: Japan unveils US$110b plan to fund Asia infrastructure
summary: Japan has unveiled a US$110 billion plan to fund Asian infrastructure projects, surpassing the expected US$100 billion capitalization of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) set by China. The plan, announced by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, aims to provide "high-quality" aid, focusing on environmental sustainability and long-term development. Japan hopes to draw private funds to meet Asia's vast infrastructure demands, while the US has expressed concerns about the AIIB's transparency and governance. Japan's aid plan may be seen as a response to China's growing regional influence, with no immediate decision on joining the AIIB.

site_title: Actors' tribute to the late Kuo Pao Kun
summary: A new play, Q: Protagonists At The Edge, pays tribute to late Singaporean drama doyen Kuo Pao Kun by incorporating his written text, ideas, and teaching principles. The metatheatrical work, devised by Ang Gey Pin, features three actors recreating scenes from Kuo's plays and exploring various theatre styles and literary devices. The play delves into Singapore's search for cultural identity, leaving the audience with questions about the nature of theatre and its relevance. The production runs from May 27 to 30 at the Esplanade Rehearsal Studio.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Apartments priced as high as HK$520m set to test HK market
summary: Hong Kong luxury apartment developers are poised to sell high-end units, with prices reaching as high as HK$520 million. The sales come on the back of the city's booming stock market, which has driven the benchmark index to an eight-year high. Analysts say the wealth effect from the stock market may support luxury property prices, but some predict prices may stay flat or decline due to government-imposed levies on foreign buyers and stamp duties.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose on Thursday, with the FTSE 100 index up 0.09%, the CAC 40 gaining 0.26%, and the DAX 30 climbing 0.14%. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks. US markets also reached fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged higher, while the STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Update: Cargill says it remains active in China and Singapore fuel oil
summary: Cargill, a commodities trader, has denied rumors that it has closed its fuel oil trading desk in Asia, saying it will remain active in Singapore and China. The company has undergone changes in its oil trading portfolio, including the departure of several traders, but has committed to growing its business in the region. Cargill continues to operate in Singapore and China, with approximately 120,000 cubic meters of storage space.

site_title: Record gap between rich and poor: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) reports that the income gap between the rich and poor in 34 advanced economies is at a record level, with the richest 10% earning 9.6 times the income of the poorest 10%. This is the highest level in three decades, up from a 7:1 ratio in the 1980s.

site_title: SGX finds Xpress, ex-chairman broke disclosure rules; issues warnings
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has found that XPRESS Holdings and its then-chairman KK Fong broke listing rules in 2014 by not disclosing winding-up actions against the company and its subsidiaries in a timely manner. The breach occurred when Fong informed the board only a week after receiving notice of winding-up applications, and the company announced them to investors more than two weeks later. The SGX has issued warnings to Xpress and Fong.

site_title: Indon wheat imports surge as bread catching up with rice as staple
summary: Indonesia has become the world's second-largest importer of wheat, with consumption doubling since 2002 due to its growing middle class seeking convenient meals. The country's appetite for bread and baked goods has surged 60% in the past four years, driven by a desire for easy-to-eat food. Indonesia's wheat imports are expected to rise to 8.1 million tonnes next year, benefiting top exporters like the US and Canada. Despite efforts to boost domestic production, the country's dependence on foreign wheat is unlikely to decrease, with analysts predicting imports of over 10 million tonnes by 2020.

site_title: Digital Realty Trust to launch 2nd S'pore data centre this year
summary: Digital Realty Trust will launch its second data centre in Singapore later this year, investing over US$200 million in the 177,000 square-foot facility in Loyang. The centre will connect via dark fibre to the company's first data centre in Jurong, extending its network and enhancing Singapore's status as a connectivity hub. The new centre is part of the company's commitment to Singapore's Smart Nation plan and will provide a neutral, agile, and open connectivity fabric to clients.

images.alt_text: "Our first data centre in Singapore marked DRT's entrance into one of Asia-Pacific's rapid expansion markets and enabled our global clients to enter the country and serve other regional markets with a trusted partner," says Mr Dunbar.

site_title: Eurozone growth stumbles but firms more optimistic
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed in May, falling to 53.4 from 53.9, but firms remain optimistic, increasing staffing levels at the fastest rate in four years. The recovery is considered on track, with 0.4% economic growth predicted for the current quarter. Firms stepped up recruitment, and demand for the bloc's goods soared due to a weaker euro. However, service firms cut prices again, albeit slightly, and prices were flat year-on-year.

site_title: US factory activity growth slows for second month: Markit
summary: US factory activity growth slows for a second month, with the Markit US Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 53.8 in May from 54.1 in April. New orders increased at their slowest pace since January 2014. Despite a rise in jobs growth, economists worry that production growth must revive to maintain payroll growth, as companies seek to boost productivity.

site_title: Indonesian state firms yet to receive capital injections
summary: Indonesia's state-owned enterprises have yet to receive promised capital injections of nearly $3 billion, due to bureaucratic hurdles. The government aims to use the funds to refurbish ports, roads, and power plants, but Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro said regulations must be issued for each capital injection. The delay is expected to hinder infrastructure development and economic growth, despite President Joko Widodo's promise to pump billions of dollars into state firms.

site_title: Ley Choon bags S$25 million contract from PUB
summary: SINGAPORE Exchange-listed Ley Choon Group Holdings has secured a S$25 million contract from the Public Utilities Board (PUB) for laying and installing a potable water transmission steel pipeline. The contract showcases the company's expertise in pipe-jacking and micro-tunnelling technology, according to CEO Toh Choo Huat. This win is expected to boost the group's competitiveness in pipe and cable laying projects.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: OLS plans move from SGX mainboard to Catalist
summary: Singapore-based OLS Enterprise plans to transfer its listing from the SGX mainboard to the Catalist board, a move aimed at providing a more flexible regulatory system for the company. To achieve this, the company has undertaken a turnaround plan, including restructuring its existing business and adding profitable ventures. The transfer is subject to SGX approval and shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting. OLS Enterprise made a net profit of S$1.1 million in the 2015 financial year, but its current business and trading price are under the minimum trading price requirement.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint increases bond offer size to S$500m from S$200m
summary: Frasers Centrepoint has increased the size of its first retail bonds offering from S$200m to S$500m following strong investor demand. The public offer was 3.9 times subscribed, with the placement tranche of S$50m fully subscribed within a day. The seven-year bonds carry a fixed interest rate of 3.65% per annum. The increased public offer size is now at S$450m.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Bootcamp brings together top local and international online video creators
summary: MAKER Bootcamp, a two-day workshop in Singapore, concluded on May 21, 2015, bringing together top local and international online video creators. Over 30 participants, including Singapore's NightOwl Cinematics and international talents like The Fung Brothers, learned how to create compelling videos and build an online brand. The initiative, hosted by the Media Development Authority of Singapore and Maker Studios, aims to nurture Singapore's digital content creation capabilities and stand out in the crowded online video market.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower; CVS buys Omnicare
summary: US stocks edged lower in opening trade on Thursday as the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 14.85 points to 18,270.55, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also declining 0.73% and 0.05%, respectively. CVS Health acquired Omnicare for $12.7 billion, aiming to boost prescription sales in assisted-living and long-term care facilities. The transaction follows recent deals in the pharma and healthcare industries, with analysts noting that the market has been relatively stable this week.

site_title: OLS Enterprise plans to move from SGX Mainboard to Catalist
summary: OLS Enterprise plans to transfer from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) Mainboard to Catalist, citing a more conducive listing platform for companies with flexible regulatory systems. The firm is currently on the SGX Watch-List. The move aims to position the company to identify suitable business acquisitions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Eurozone growth falters despite improved employment
summary: The eurozone economy showed unexpected signs of fragility in May, with the Markit Economics Composite Purchasing Managers Output Index (PMI) falling to 53.4 points from 53.9 in April. Despite a rise in employment levels, the decline in growth momentum signals that stimulus measures by the European Central Bank have yet to take effect. Eurozone companies are boosting staffing levels at a faster pace, but growth in Germany was the slowest in four months, while France showed its best spell of hiring in over three years.

site_title: HP sells stake in China unit for US$2.3b
summary: Hewlett-Packard announced it's selling a 51% stake in its China-based server business to Tsinghua Holdings for $2.3 billion, creating a joint venture called H3C worth $4.5 billion. H3C will be a sector leader in China's computer servers, storage, and technology services. The deal marks HP's exit from the Chinese server market and allows Tsinghua Holdings to take control of a significant player in the industry.

images.alt_text: Hewlett-Packard said on Thursday it was selling a 51 per cent stake in its China-based server business, creating a joint venture with Tsinghua Holdings that will be a sector leader in China.

site_title: Nobel Design reports higher profit of S$3.64m for Q1
summary: NOBEL Design Holdings reported a Q1 net profit of S$3.64 million, up from S$3.12 million, with revenue rising 9% year-over-year to S$18.68 million. Earnings per share increased to 1.733 cents. The company attributed the growth to its supply chain division and plans to explore regional product supply opportunities in Southeast Asia. Despite challenges in the European luxury furniture business and property development in Singapore, NOBEL remains cautious but hopeful about its prospects.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Australia: Shares bounce as investors swoop on bargains after months of falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.9% to a one-month high, defying global commodity and equity market falls. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 52 points to 5662.3, boosted by James Hardie Industries' 10% gain after reporting tripled annual net profit. The index's largest one-day advance since April 24 was seen as a response to months of heavy selling.

site_title: US home resales unexpectedly fall, tarnishing housing recovery
summary: US home resales unexpectedly fell 3.3% to an annual rate of 5.04 million units in April, according to the National Association of Realtors. Tight inventories led to higher prices, casting a cautious signal on the housing market. March's sales pace was revised up to 5.21 million units. The median home price rose 8.9% from the same month in 2014, driven by a 0.9% decline in the number of homes on the market. This weakness in home resales puts a dent in the broader US economy's recovery.

site_title: Sovereign, public pension funds investing more in real estate and infrastructure: report
summary: Sovereign and public pension funds are investing more in real estate and infrastructure to offset low returns in traditional markets, with 9.1% of their total assets (US$2.7 trillion) allocated to these sectors, according to the Global Public Investor 2015 report. This shift raises concerns of asset bubbles. Meanwhile, central banks continue to purchase equities, with total assets under management rising 1.8% to US$29.7 trillion in 2014.
