images.alt_text: Sovereign wealth funds and public pension funds have been moving aggressively into real estate and infrastructure to offset low returns in traditional markets, raising the risk of asset bubbles, said the Global Public Investor 2015 report.

site_title: Singapore: Trading of GLP parcel provides main feature in another ho-hum day
summary: The Straits Times Index in Singapore gained 0.18 points to 3,439.86, with a market turnover of 2.1 billion units worth S$2.21 billion. The main feature of the day was the trading of a large parcel of Global Logistic Properties (GLP) shares worth S$964 million. Despite this, the market remained stuck in a trading range, with losers outnumbering gainers 225-to-186.

site_title: Taking an alternate route
summary: Local indie filmmakers Tzang Merwyn Tong, Jeremiah Oh, and Han Yew Kwang are defying odds by having their latest films hit the big screen for longer durations. Tong's gothic-inspired film Faeryville, Jeremiah Oh's documentary Blurred Lines, and Han Yew Kwang's ensemble comedy Rubbers have received positive reactions from audiences and critics. Despite the challenges they faced during production, the filmmakers remain optimistic about their work and the future of indie cinema in Singapore. The extended runs of these films at Filmgarde Bugis+ and other cinemas demonstrate a growing interest in showcasing local talent.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Ireland says gay marriage good for business
summary: Ireland's government believes gay marriage will attract foreign investment, citing the success of US technology firms like Google and eBay. The government hopes a "Yes" vote in the national referendum will showcase Ireland as a vibrant, multicultural society. Polls indicate a two-to-one margin in favor of gay marriage, with Prime Minister Enda Kenny and the head of the state's investment body both opposing a "No" vote. A "Yes" vote is seen as crucial for Ireland's international reputation and economy, which relies heavily on foreign investment.

site_title: Manulife plans US$450m IPO of US assets in Singapore: sources
summary: Canada's Manulife Financial Corp plans to list some of its US property assets in Singapore through an initial public offering (IPO) worth US$450 million in the second half of the year. The IPO will use the real estate investment trust (REIT) structure. This listing may help revive Singapore's weak IPO market, which has struggled this year. The deal has not been formally announced, but two people familiar with the matter confirmed the plans.

images.alt_text: Canada's Manulife Financial Corp is seeking to list some of its US property assets in Singapore in the second half of the year in an initial public offering worth US$450 million, two people familiar with the deal said.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEOs ask for support as cost cuts loom
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEOs, John Fitschen and Anshu Jain, faced criticism from shareholders and acknowledged their performance had fallen short. They requested continued support as the bank cuts costs and reshapes its strategy, citing the need to reduce its global footprint. The bank's annual general meeting was marked by concerns over lagging profits, soaring fines, and sluggish reforms. The management board was reshuffled, with Jain taking on restructuring authority. The CEOs acknowledged the bank's reputation was badly damaged and efforts to restore it were needed.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank's two chief executives faced down a storm of shareholder criticism on Thursday by conceding that their performance had fallen short and asking the bank's owners for continued backing as they cut costs and reshape strategy.

site_title: First Hanergy now Goldin: Hong Kong stocks drop like stones
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted as two top-performing companies, Goldin Financial Holdings and Goldin Properties, dropped over 60% in a single day. This follows a mysterious 47% plunge in Hanergy Thin Film Power Group, erasing US$19 billion in market value. Both companies, controlled by billionaire owners, have seen rapid growth but lack analyst coverage, raising doubts over their sustainability. The market values of these companies, now exceeding US$30 billion, have raised concerns about the viability of their rallies.

site_title: German rail strike called off, but new dispute looms
summary: A drivers strike at Deutsche Bahn, Germany's largest rail operator, has been called off after the two sides agreed to mediation, allowing millions of rail passengers to breathe a sigh of relief. The strike, which had paralyzed train travel, was initially over wages, work hours, and negotiating rights. However, a new dispute has emerged with the larger railway union EVG, which is threatening industrial action unless a pay deal is reached soon. EVG is demanding a wage rise and shorter work hours, and has promised no more strikes until at least June 17.

site_title: Signs of love and life
summary: The family drama "Tribes" tells the story of Billy, a deaf boy who struggles to connect with his hearing family. When Billy meets Sylvia, a hearing woman who is also deaf, he begins to find his place in the world. The play, which explores themes of identity, community, and acceptance, has been praised for its humor and drama. The Singapore production, directed by Tracie Pang, features actors who learned sign language and met hearing-impaired people to prepare for their roles. The play runs from May 22 to June 7 at the Drama Centre Theatre.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 15.07 points to 1,795.04. 2.4 billion lots valued at RM2.3 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 628 to 259.

site_title: A Third Growth that punches above its weight
summary: Chateau Palmer, a Third Growth wine, consistently outperforms its peers in terms of quality and price, earning it the title of "Super-Second". Recent vertical tastings of 1961, 1966, and 1970 vintages showcased the wine's elegant style, medium-bodied texture, and fresh aroma, reminiscent of Margaux. Founded in 1760, the Chateau has been owned by a consortium of wine merchants and has recently adopted biodynamic farming. Its 1961 vintage, priced around 5,000 euros, is considered a rare find, with a reputation rivaling that of First Growth Chateau Margaux.

site_title: Hong Kong, China mutual fund recognition to be announced soon: sources
summary: Hong Kong and China are set to announce a mutual fund recognition agreement, allowing global asset managers to invest in China and vice versa. The deal, in the works since 2012, aims to boost Hong Kong's position as the leading asset management hub in Asia. China has an estimated 260 trillion yuan in investable assets by 2020, and the agreement will give fund managers greater incentives to set up Hong Kong-domiciled funds. The move is expected to create jobs and consolidate Hong Kong's position in the region. An announcement is expected soon, according to sources.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to raise S$525 million via equity deal
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) plans to raise S$525 million through a private placement and preferential offer to acquire a 51% stake in Keppel Merlimau Cogen. The private placement is at S$0.52 per unit, with existing unitholders offered a non-renounceable preferential offering at S$0.515 per unit. The deal is the largest in Singapore this year, accounting for 36% of KIT's outstanding units. KIFM's CEO, Khor Un-Hun, says the increased free float and institutional unitholder base will enhance KIT's liquidity and ability to raise capital for future growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.22% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.22% on Thursday, following Wall Street losses, to close at 27,523.72 on the Hang Seng Index. In contrast, mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index surged 1.87% after a weak manufacturing reading raised hopes for stimulus measures by Beijing.

site_title: World's largest particle collider busts record
summary: The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) at CERN has broken the record for energy levels, reaching 13 TeV in a test run after a two-year upgrade. This surpasses the previous highest energy of 8 TeV, achieved in 2012. The record-breaking collision marked a significant milestone in particle physics research, demonstrating the LHC's capabilities in accelerating protons to unprecedented energies.

site_title: Europe: Stocks fall at open
summary: European stock markets fell at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.10% to 7,000.19 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 dropped 0.28% and the CAC 40 in Paris slipped 0.24%. The decline followed a mixed day in US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday
summary: Singapore's Government has announced five new collaborative industry projects (CIPs) to benefit over 400 SMEs, providing better access to technology innovations and digital marketing channels. Digital Realty Trust plans to launch its second data centre in Singapore, investing over $200 million. Manulife Financial Corp is seeking to list US assets in Singapore worth $450 million in an IPO. The Singapore Exchange has issued warnings for Xpress Holdings and its former chairman over non-disclosure of winding-up actions. The Straits Times Index gained 0.18 of a point, while the market's turnover stood at $2.21 billion.

site_title: McDonald's Japan updates menu, prices after food scandals
summary: McDonald's Japan updated its menu and pricing in response to food scandals, including a human tooth found in some fries. The company introduced a new chicken patty with vegetables, a salad, and a low-calorie onion dressing. New combinations for its set meals were also offered. The changes aim to restore the company's reputation, but analysts were cautious, viewing the updates as modest. The revamp comes after a series of scandals, including the discovery of a human tooth in fries, which have damaged the chain's image.

site_title: PEC wins two new contracts worth S$70 million
summary: PEC Ltd has secured two new contracts worth approximately S$70 million, boosting its orderbook to over S$450 million. The contracts include a mechanical, electrical, and installation project at a petrochemical complex on Jurong Island, set to be completed by March next year, and a mechanical works project for a refinery on Jurong Island, expected to be completed in October next year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Southeast Asia's FX reserves are small change versus external debts
summary: Southeast Asia's FX reserves have increased by less than 1% since mid-2014, a respite from a $60 billion drop, but still expose the region to a potential dollar crunch due to growing external debts. The region's economies, particularly Malaysia, have seen sharp spikes in indebtedness, with Malaysia's external debt reaching nearly 66% of GDP. Fitch Ratings is likely to downgrade Malaysia's creditworthiness, citing weak external finances. Despite this, Southeast Asia remains a net creditor and has higher reserves relative to short-term external debt compared to many emerging markets in Latin America and Eastern Europe.

site_title: S&P raises Indonesia's rating outlook to positive
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) raised Indonesia's sovereign rating outlook to positive from stable, citing improved policies for monetary and financial sector management. This move acknowledges Indonesia's growth prospects and external resilience. S&P is the only international agency rating Indonesia in the junk category, with Fitch and Moody's rating it in the investment grade category. The positive outlook is seen as a significant upgrade for Indonesia's economy, which is expected to benefit from better management and governance.

site_title: Seoul: Shares have biggest fall in 2 weeks; won rebounds
summary: Seoul shares plummeted 0.8% to 2,122.81 points, their largest daily fall in two weeks, after reaching a three-week high on Wednesday. The South Korean won rebounded 0.2% against the dollar. The losses followed a three-day winning streak.

site_title: PSD, UK institute tie up to boost HR capabilities of Singapore Public Service
summary: The Public Service Division of Singapore and the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD) in the UK signed a memorandum of understanding to enhance HR capabilities in the Singapore Public Service. CIPD will conduct HR diagnostic assessments and offer various qualifications, starting with a pilot group of 20 HR directors. This partnership aims to promote HR as a career choice and strengthen the capabilities of HR professionals in Singapore and beyond, based on international standards of practice.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open 0.28% lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.28% lower on May 21, 2015, following losses on Wall Street due to concerns about the US economy's strength. The Hang Seng Index dropped 77.73 points to 27,507.32.

site_title: China: Stocks close at seven-year highs despite weak factory survey
summary: China's main stock indexes closed at seven-year highs on May 21, 2015, despite a weak factory activity survey showing China's factory activity contracted for the third month in May. The CSI300 index rose 1.8% to 4,840.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.9% to 4,529.42 points. Investors interpreted the weak number as suggesting China will unveil more policy support, fueling intense buying and pushing the tech-heavy ChiNext index up nearly 3% to a record.

site_title: Asia: Stocks hold gain on China PMI; US futures, dollar weaken
summary: Asian stocks rose, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index adding 0.3% due to a weaker-than-expected Chinese factory gauge, which reinforced the need for government stimulus. US equity-index futures declined, and the dollar weakened against most peers, while oil prices rose 0.3% in New York. European leaders are set to meet to discuss Greece's debt situation, and the European Central Bank increased emergency funding for Greek banks.

site_title: Government announces new collaborative industry projects for SMEs
summary: Singapore's Spring Singapore has announced five collaborative industry projects (CIPs) to support small and medium enterprises (SMEs). The projects aim to enhance access to technology innovations and digital marketing channels for over 400 SMEs across multiple industries. Three CIPs, in collaboration with A*Star, focus on technology adoption, while two projects, with private sector partners, will provide training and consultancy on digital marketing capabilities. SMEs can receive up to 70% support for qualifying adoption costs.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Cathay cabin crew threatens summer strike
summary: Cathay Pacific cabin crew threatened a summer strike if management does not scrap a new policy to reduce salaries and perks for cabin crew. The airline's 6,400 members, led by the Flight Attendants Union, have been protesting since Tuesday over cuts to wages and lunch allowances. The union has set a two-week strike starting August 18 if the company does not meet their demands, which include restoring the deleted legal protection clause. The airline has stated it is prepared to meet with the union but is confident its staff will prioritize passengers' needs.

site_title: New Zealand budget surplus next year, but less robust for future: Finance Minister
summary: New Zealand is expected to return to a budget surplus next year, with a forecast surplus of NZ$176 million for the year to June 30, 2016. However, the fiscal position will be less robust due to low dairy prices and reduced tax take. The government will not cut services to chase a surplus, and net debt is expected to peak in the coming year. The budget also includes measures to support low-income families and increase spending on education, health, and research.

site_title: Hot stock: GLP up 1.83% at S$2.79
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) shares rose 1.83% to S$2.79, making it the most actively traded stock on the Singapore Exchange. The company plans to double its US assets, adding US$5-10 billion, after acquiring IndCor Properties from The Blackstone Group for US$8.1 billion in February.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Genting Hong Kong, M Development, Rex International
summary: Genting Hong Kong sold 10 million shares of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings for $546.1 million, using the proceeds for working capital and new investments. M Development's subsidiary Winsta Group uncovered "actionable wrongs" and breaches of duties by executive directors, leading to legal proceedings against 13 defendants. Rex International Holding acquired a 30% participating interest in an offshore oil licence in Western Australia for "ground floor terms".

site_title: Oil prices gain on upbeat US stockpiles report
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia after a decline in US petroleum stockpiles and production boosted hopes of an easing global supply glut. US benchmark WTI rose 10 cents to $59.08 and Brent crude gained 16 cents to $65.19. The US Department of Energy reported a 2.7 million-barrel decline in commercial crude stockpiles, exceeding projections. A slowdown in US output could help ease global crude reserves, but analysts also warned of potential volatility from the US dollar.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks slump on poor export orders data; techs down
summary: Taiwan's stocks plummeted 1.4% on Thursday due to weaker-than-expected export orders data, with tech giants TSMC and Hon Hai Precision down 1% and 0.5% respectively. The poor data, which marked the worst showing in over two years, was attributed to softening demand for electronic gadgets from Japan and China. Despite this, the Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: VTTI to start second phase of Malaysia oil terminal in August
summary: VTTI, a 50/50 joint venture between Vitol Group and MISC Berhad, will start the second phase of its Tanjung Bin oil terminal in southern Malaysia on August 1, expanding storage capacity by nearly 30%. The second phase will add 260,000 cubic meters of storage and a jetty for Aframax vessels. The expansion is expected to boost regional demand for storage as oil pricing agency Platts prepares to include certain ports in southern Malaysia in its pricing assessments from July 1.

site_title: MAS signs third bilateral swap arrangement with Bank of Japan
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has signed its third Bilateral Swap Arrangement (BSA) with the Bank of Japan, allowing for the exchange of Singapore dollars and Japanese yen for US dollars. The facility enables swaps of up to US$3 billion for Singapore and US$1 billion for Japan, aiming to strengthen financial cooperation and support growing economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Central bankers, economists to take long view at ECB forum
summary: Central bankers and economists from around the world are gathering in Portugal for a three-day forum to discuss pressing economic issues, including inflation and unemployment in Europe. The European Central Bank has invited leading experts to take a long-term perspective on the topic, with speakers including ECB President Mario Draghi and International Monetary Fund Chief Economist Olivier Blanchard. The forum aims to exchange ideas and inform monetary policy decisions, although any statements on price developments will be closely scrutinized. The gathering is seen as Europe's answer to the US Federal Reserve's annual Jackson Hole meeting.

site_title: Malaysia targets 5-6% growth in new economic plan
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak unveiled a five-year economic plan aiming to achieve 5-6% annual GDP growth from 2016 to 2020, resulting in a 7.9% annual increase in GNI per capita. The plan targets a GNI per capita of 54,100 ringgit (US$15,690) by 2020 and increased average monthly household income to 10,540 ringgit. The government plans to strengthen revenue collection through the goods and services tax, generating 31.4 billion ringgit in revenue annually. The goal is to lead Malaysia toward becoming a fully developed economy by 2020.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Najib Razak said on Thursday that Malaysia's real gross domestic product will grow between 5 and 6 per cent annually from 2016 to 2020, resulting in a 7.9 per cent per annum rise in gross national income (GNI) per capita.

site_title: China broker Huatai Securities set to price HK$34.72b offer on top
summary: Huatai Securities Co Ltd, China's largest stock brokerage, is set to price its Hong Kong share offering on top of expectations, with a potential raise of HK$34.72 billion (S$6.0 billion). The Shanghai-listed company is offering 1.4 billion new shares in an indicative price range of HK$20.68 to HK$24.80 per share, with investors required to place orders at the top end or risk missing allocations.

site_title: Lenovo's annual revenue up 20% but profits miss target
summary: Lenovo reported a 20% increase in annual revenue to $46.30 billion, driven by its Motorola acquisition, but missed net profit targets with a 1% growth to $829 million. The company's mobile business, including Motorola, contributed 71% to revenue. Despite record smartphone shipments worldwide, net profit was impacted by increased operating expenses. Lenovo's non-PC revenue contribution rose to 28%, while operating expenses increased 40%. The company's diversification efforts continue, with a focus on emerging markets and new technologies.

images.alt_text: China's Lenovo said Thursday revenue rose 20 per cent in its past fiscal year, helped by its purchase of Motorola last year as the PC maker diversifies into the smartphone market, but net profit growth slowed to just one percent.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares edge up on Thursday opening
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 0.3 points to 1,810.41 points on Thursday, with 60.2 million lots traded worth RM 31.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 140 to 72, contributing to the slight increase.

site_title: SIA unveils new Premium Economy seats, in-flight offerings
summary: Singapore Airlines unveiled its new Premium Economy Class seats and in-flight offerings, a result of a two-year development program and $80 million investment. The new service will feature specially designed seats with 8-inch recline, 38-inch seat pitch, and active noise-cancelling headphones. In-flight entertainment will be enhanced with a 13.3-inch full HD monitor and individual in-seat power supply. Other features include full-leather finishing, calf-rest, and foot-bar for every seat, and more stowage space for personal items. The new service will be rolled out in August.

site_title: Indonesia could backtrack on rice imports as prices rise, El Nino looms
summary: Indonesia may import 1.3-1.6 million tonnes of rice this year due to rising domestic prices and the threat of El Nino, contradicting President Joko Widodo's previous pledge to curb imports. The country's rice stocks currently stand at 1.2 million tonnes, and analysts predict imports will be higher than the 1.1 million tonnes estimated for last year, benefiting key exporters like Thailand and Vietnam. Rising domestic prices and the El Nino weather pattern, which typically brings dry conditions, are driving the need for imports.

images.alt_text: A worker walks up a pile of rice at a warehouse. Indonesia's president could be forced to backtrack on promises to curb rice imports, with analysts saying the country may ship in as much as 1.6 million tonnes of the staple grain this year due to soaring prices at home and the threat of a strong El Nino.

site_title: Digital Realty Trust plans second data centre in Singapore
summary: Digital Realty Trust plans to launch its second data centre in Singapore, investing over US$200 million, in line with the country's Smart Nation plan. The new facility, spanning 177,000 square feet, will connect to the company's existing data centre via dark fibre, offering geographic diversification and increased options for IT workload deployments. The expansion is seen as a key move to strengthen Singapore's position as a leading data management and connectivity hub, enabling local and international companies to build new digital capabilities and scale critical digital services efficiently.

site_title: China able to meet 2015 GDP target of around 7%: Premier
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang announced that China can meet its 2015 GDP growth target of around 7%. This comes after Mr. Li made significant trade, finance, and investment deals worth tens of billions of dollars in energy, mining, aviation, while in Brazil.

site_title: Barred from Gulf, Bangladeshis risk lives to head south
summary: Thousands of Bangladeshis are risking their lives to join Rohingya refugees on perilous boat journeys to Southeast Asia, as poverty and desperation worsen in rural areas. Smugglers are cashing in on the misery, promising jobs in Malaysia, which has cut intakes of Bangladeshi migrants. The country's economy has grown, but one-quarter of its population remains below the poverty line, and natural disasters have further exacerbated the crisis. Experts point to a lack of jobs and plummeting crop prices as the main drivers of the exodus.

site_title: China's ZTE expects to ship 20m smartphones to US this year
summary: China's ZTE Corp expects to ship 20 million smartphones to the US this year, a 20% increase from last year, according to CEO Lixin Cheng. This marks a 50% jump in US shipments in 2014, as ZTE aims to become a top three smartphone vendor in the US by 2017. ZTE's aggressive marketing campaign, including an NBA sponsorship, boosted shipments last year and plans to forge new partnerships with more teams in 2015.

images.alt_text: An employee works on a communications equipment assembly line at a ZTE Corp. factory. Chinese smartphone maker ZTE Corp expects to ship 20 million smartphones to the United States this year, up 20 per cent from last year, the company's US Chief Executive Officer and Chairman Lixin Cheng told Reuters in an interview.

site_title: US TV pioneer David Letterman bows out
summary: US TV pioneer David Letterman has broadcast his final show, marking the end of a 33-year-long career as the longest-serving nighttime US talk show host. Letterman, 68, announced his retirement in 2014, but the episode featured a surprise lineup, including Foo Fighters and celebrities Steve Martin and Jim Carrey. Critics praised Letterman for his innovative and odd-ball antics, and he won 12 Emmy awards during his career. Letterman will be replaced by Stephen Colbert in September, after a career marked by controversy and ratings success.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's Jain to lead strategy as three deputies exit
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed co-CEO Anshu Jain to oversee strategy after a failed overhaul to boost returns. Jain takes over the strategy and organizational development unit, while Stefan Krause steps down as CFO and Juergen Fitschen assumes responsibility for global transaction banking. Co-CEOs Alan Cloete and Colin Grassie, and head of private and business clients Rainer Neske, are leaving the firm. Jain and Fitschen face a showdown at the annual general meeting as investors question the plan's success amid costly investigations into alleged misconduct and a record $2.5 billion fine.

site_title: Japan auto lobby chief: hopes for report on Takata problems by year-end
summary: Japan's auto lobby chief, Fumihiko Ike, hopes for an interim report on the cause of Takata Corp's air bag problems by the end of the year. Over 50 million cars have been recalled worldwide due to the potentially deadly air bag inflators. Ten automakers, led by Toyota, are investigating the root cause of the issue, with discussions on payment by Takata expected. The supplier has doubled its US recall to nearly 34 million vehicles, with domestic automakers likely expecting installment payments for identified manufacturing problems.

site_title: Genting HK to dispose of 20m Norwegian Cruise Line shares
summary: Genting Hong Kong will dispose of 20 million shares of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings, with 10 million shares to be sold for $546.1 million. The sale proceeds will be used for general working capital and potential new investments. The sale will result in a one-off accounting gain of approximately $1.69 billion, and dividends from NCLH will be accounted for in Genting's consolidated income statement. This will reduce Genting's stake in NCLH from 22% to 17.7%.

site_title: Japan, China to hold finance talks on June 6, may discuss AIIB
summary: Japanese and Chinese finance officials will hold bilateral talks on June 6 in Beijing to discuss ways to promote cooperation between the two countries. The talks may also cover the China-backed Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB). Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso and his counterparts will meet to explore ways to strengthen economic ties between the two nations.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 0.01% higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.01% higher at 3,440.09, following Wall Street's mostly lower close on Wednesday despite a brief jump from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes. The most active stocks included China New Town, Stratech Group, and Jaya Holdings, with a total of 68.6 million shares changing hands worth S$85.8 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 70 to 57.

site_title: Underwriters Laboratories to open S$8m 3D printing hub in Singapore
summary: Underwriters Laboratories (UL) is investing S$8 million to open a Global Additive Manufacturing Center of Excellence in Singapore, a first-of-its-kind service offering for both UL and the AM industry. The centre will provide advanced training, material and process validation programs, advisory services, and research for the local and global AM industry. Supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board, it will collaborate with local research institutes and industry partners, aiming to strengthen manufacturing competitiveness and drive the development of disruptive technologies such as AM and robotics.

site_title: Winsta Group starts legal proceedings against 13 defendants for 'breach of duties'
summary: Winsta Group, a subsidiary of investment holding firm M Development, has initiated legal proceedings against 13 defendants, including former director Sim Pei Yee, for alleged breach of duties and undisclosed transactions. The company has commenced proceedings after an interim report by accounting firm KordaMentha uncovered the transactions. Winsta Group will suspend executive functions of the defendants and appoint a professional management agent to assist with operations. M Development aims to minimize business disruption and ensure the company's continued functioning.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close flat
summary: Tokyo stocks ended flat on Thursday, reaching new 15-year highs, as minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting indicated no interest rate hike. The Nikkei 225 index rose 6.31 points to 20,202.87, and the Topix index climbed 0.21% to 1,646.80. The flat closing followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records.

site_title: Rate liberalisation nears completion, market looks now for guidance
summary: China's interest rate regime may be fully liberalized as early as July or by the end of the year, according to money market traders. The People's Bank of China raised the maximum deposit rate ceiling to 1.5 times in May, with banks responding relatively calmly to the change. The PBOC has stated that conditions are ripe for full liberalization, and analysts expect the central bank to follow the US Federal Reserve's model of using money market rates as guidance. If not in July, full liberalization is likely to occur this year, with traders now closely monitoring money market rates.

images.alt_text: China could fully liberalise its interest rate regime as early as July and almost certainly by the year-end, according to money market traders gearing up for the change.

site_title: Cargill shuts fuel oil trading desk in Asia
summary: Cargill has closed its fuel oil trading desk in Asia, following the departure of traders Ray McMinn and Tan Shet Fern. The move comes after several trader movements in the past year, leading to discussions about restructuring the company's oil trading portfolio. Cargill still operates a fuel oil desk in Geneva, Switzerland, and has reduced its scale in fuel oil trading. The company's decision to close its Asian desk marks a significant shift in its fuel oil trading operations.

site_title: South Korea confirms second case of MERS virus; third case possible
summary: South Korea has confirmed its second case of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) virus, a 76-year-old man who shared a hospital room with the first confirmed patient. The second patient, a woman who nursed her infected husband before his diagnosis, is in stable condition. Health officials believe the disease will not spread to the wider population, as those who had contact with the first patient are isolated. The fatality rate of MERS is 30-40%, with a two to 14-day incubation period, and there is no cure or vaccine available.

site_title: Omission in BOJ paper signals doubts about radical stimulus
summary: The Bank of Japan's research paper on its radical monetary stimulus programme, known as quantitative and qualitative easing (QQE), has sparked doubts about its effectiveness. The paper failed to mention how QQE affected inflation expectations, a crucial factor in its success. Despite QQE's ability to weaken the yen and boost revenue for manufacturers, it has not spurred consumer spending, and inflation has ground to a halt. The BOJ's credibility is at risk, leading to debate about a potential rethink of its policy framework, with some members questioning the program's feasibility and others calling for an alternative framework.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan headquarters pictured. A small omission in a Bank of Japan report on its radical monetary stimulus programme signals that some central bank leaders are concerned it is not working as expected, potentially laying the grounds for a rethink of its policy framework.

site_title: Majority of UK purchases made without cash in 2014
summary: The Payments Council reported that in 2014, the majority of financial transactions in the UK were made without cash, with 48% of payments being made without cash, compared to 52% in 2013. Despite this, cash remained the preferred means of paying for goods by individual consumers, with 52% of transactions being made with cash. The number of cash machines in Britain increased to a record 69,382 last year, with nine out of 10 Britons withdrawing cash from an ATM each month. The Payments Council expects the cash figure to drop below 50% next year.

site_title: Shanghai Pudong store is Disney's first in China and largest in the world
summary: Disney opened its first store in China, located in Shanghai's Pudong district, marking a significant expansion into the country. The 9,257 square foot store is the largest Disney Store globally. It is situated near a planned 34 billion yuan theme park, set to open next year.

site_title: China May flash HSBC factory PMI contracts for third month
summary: China's factory activity contracted for a third month in May, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.1, below the 50-point growth threshold. The output sub-index contracted to a 13-month low of 48.4, while new export orders and employment fell for the third straight month. Economists warn that China's economy may struggle to expand in the near term due to softer client demand and further job cuts. Deflationary pressures remain strong, leaving room for the authorities to implement further stimulus measures if required.

site_title: Rex to acquire 30% participating stake in offshore WA-488-P licence in Western Australia
summary: Rex International Holding acquired a 30% participating stake in the offshore WA-488-P licence in Western Australia from MEO Australia at "ground floor terms". The licence, covering 4,074 square kilometres, includes the Beehive prospect, a potential giant oilfield with 926 million stock tank barrels of gross unrisked prospective recoverable resources. Rex plans to conduct a 3D seismic survey to de-risk the prospect, with options to acquire additional participating interests. The deal was seen as a good opportunity to build a pipeline of future projects, with Rex CEO Måns Lidgren calling it a "good opportunity".

images.alt_text: Said Rex CEO Måns Lidgren (pictured) in a statement: "Initial due diligence analyses of the Beehive prospect in WA-488-P using Rex Virtual Drilling are encouraging and consistent with MEO's geological assessment.

site_title: Dimon's 2014 pay package gets lower shareholder support
summary: JPMorgan Chase's CEO Jamie Dimon received only 61.4% shareholder support for his 2014 pay package, a decline from 77.9% last year and significantly lower than the average 92% for other companies this year.

site_title: China's IPO market undaunted by ghosts of dotcom boom and bust
summary: China's IPO market has seen a significant surge, with the Shenzhen stock exchange's ChiNext index more than doubling this year, driven by tech-heavy listings. The ChiNext index has gained an average of 500% since the start of the year, with new listings posting record-breaking gains. Despite regulators' warnings to retail investors, share account openings have hit new highs, and margin financing has quadrupled. Experts say the market's momentum may continue due to government policy support for the tech sector, but warn of a potential bubble, citing high price-to-earnings ratios and unanalysed companies.

images.alt_text: China's investors are fuelling their own version of a dotcom bubble going by the meteoric rise in the shares of a newly-listed Internet video company.

site_title: Dollar mixed as June Federal Reserve rate hike seen as unlikely
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro and yen, but fell against the pound after Federal Reserve meeting minutes indicated a June interest rate hike was unlikely. The minutes stated that many participants believed the data in June would not meet conditions for a rate hike, citing weak economic reports in the first quarter due to "transitory" factors. This led to a mixed dollar performance, with the currency stable against the euro and yen but down against the pound.

site_title: Cars with Takata air bags in biggest recall in American history
summary: Nearly 34 million US cars and trucks are being recalled due to defective Takata air bags, linked to six deaths and over 100 injuries. The recall is the largest in US history, affecting vehicles made between 2002 and 2014. The faulty air bags can deploy sharp metal shrapnel when activated.

site_title: ECB raises Greek banks' emergency funding cap by 200m euros
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) increased the emergency funding cap for Greek banks by 200 million euros to 80.2 billion euros, marking one of the smallest increases in recent months. This lift brings the banks' available funding to around 3.0 billion euros, taking into account unused amounts. The move aims to provide additional support to Greece's debt-mired banking sector.

site_title: Goldman Sachs International Chairman Peter Sutherland to retire
summary: Goldman Sachs International Chairman Peter Sutherland, 69, will retire at the end of June after 20 years, to focus on his role with the United Nations. He will continue to advise the bank on business development. Sutherland has also held positions at BP Plc, the London School of Economics, and the World Trade Organization, and serves as a special representative for the UN on migration and development. His retirement marks the end of a long tenure at Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Petrobras turns to China for US$10b to avert crunch
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil company Petrobras has secured US$10 billion in Chinese credit to avert a financial crisis, following a debt crisis and corruption scandal. The funding, provided by China Development Bank and two other Chinese banks, is aimed at financing expansions and guaranteeing oil supply. The deal is part of Petrobras's restructuring efforts, which include US$15 billion in writedowns and a 10-fold surge in debt over the past six years. The agreement strengthens ties between China and Brazil and may provide a lifeline for Petrobras, but uncertainties remain regarding the terms of the deal.

images.alt_text: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff's strategy of turning to fellow BRIC member China to finance the country's prized state- controlled oil company is paying off as she and Premier Li Keqiang unveiled US$10 billion in Chinese credit.

site_title: Airline rally unwinding as American Air spurs price war selloff
summary: US airline stocks plummeted amid a price war triggered by cheaper fuel costs. Southwest Airlines dropped 7.5% and American Airlines fell 6.4%, marking their worst days since 2013. The airline industry's price war is expected to increase competition for customers, as carriers look to capitalize on lower fuel costs and expand routes.

site_title: New York banking regulator Benjamin Lawsky to resign
summary: New York financial regulator Benjamin Lawsky to resign in late June, ending his tenure as superintendent of financial services after 4 years. Lawsky, known for penalizing large banks billions of dollars for market and sanctions abuses, oversaw a US$485 million fine against Barclays for rigging the foreign exchange market. He will step down after a legacy of enforcing tough penalties, including a US$8.9 billion fine against BNP Paribas and a US$2.6 billion fine against Credit Suisse.

site_title: Malakoff's weak performance highlights risky prospects in Malaysian equities
summary: Malaysia's Malakoff Corporation saw its stock slip 6% on Wednesday, marking the biggest IPO for the year, amid weak domestic conditions and 1MDB uncertainties. The company's under-performance has raised concerns about the risks in the Malaysian equity market. The IPO's poor performance is not an isolated incident, as other companies have also postponed their IPOs due to similar domestic challenges. The situation highlights the volatility in the Malaysian market and the need for investors to be cautious.

site_title: UK finance study says harsh rules would crimp EU growth
summary: A UK finance study by PwC found that implementing harsh rules on the financial sector would significantly reduce its contribution to EU jobs and growth. The study warned that tougher regulation would lead to 11 million fewer jobs by 2030. The City of London's head of policy, Mark Boleat, called for "properly calibrated rules" to allow the sector to grow sustainably. The EU's planned financial transaction tax and proposed ban on proprietary trading are expected to have a negative impact on economic growth.

site_title: SL Green Realty buys 11 Madison Ave for US$2.29b
summary: SL Green Realty Corp agreed to buy 11 Madison Avenue in Manhattan for $2.29 billion, the largest single-building deal in the city since 2008. The 29-storey, 2.3 million sq ft property, home to Credit Suisse's US headquarters, will be SL Green's second-largest acquisition. The deal is expected to increase the company's dominance in midtown south, a hotbed of financial services, technology, and media companies.

site_title: Federal Reserve interest rate hike 'unlikely' in June
summary: Federal Reserve policy makers viewed a June interest rate hike as unlikely, citing a slowdown in US economic growth in the first quarter and concerns about weak consumer spending. Minutes from the April meeting showed a "wait-and-see" attitude, with most participants expecting a moderate pace of expansion and improving labor market conditions. The stronger dollar and lower oil prices were seen as potential long-term factors curbing economic activity. A September or December rate hike is still expected, with some economists revising their forecasts downward due to weaker-than-expected economic data.

site_title: California oil spill estimated at up to 2,500 barrels
summary: A pipeline burst along California's coast has released up to 2,500 barrels of crude petroleum, approximately five times the initial estimate, according to Plains All American Pipeline. The spill, which occurred near Santa Barbara, has fouled a pristine beach and a stretch of ocean, ranking as the largest to hit the Santa Barbara coast in at least 18 years.

site_title: Domestic, foreign wholesale trade down in Q1
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade declined 25.8% year-over-year in Q1 2015, primarily due to lower prices of petroleum and chemical products. Excluding petroleum, domestic wholesale trade fell 12.6%. Foreign wholesale trade dropped 18.8% year-over-year, but expanded 7.4% after accounting for price changes. The decline in domestic wholesale trade was also seen in Q4 2014, with a 16.4% decline.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China keeps an ace up its sleeve while upping ante on local debt
summary: China is facing a debt crisis with local authorities owing over $4 trillion, but the government has an ace up its sleeve - the option to bail out provinces and cities by issuing national bonds. This move could create a new market for risk-free securities and help internationalize the yuan. However, policy makers are instead attempting to introduce risk-pricing into the financial system by reducing implicit guarantees and allowing some borrowers to default. The government is also pushing banks to buy new municipal bonds and stave off a credit crunch.

site_title: Oil prices gain on 'bullish' US petroleum report
summary: US oil prices rose on Wednesday after data showed a 2.4 million barrel drop in US petroleum supplies and a 112,000 barrel daily decrease in production. West Texas Intermediate rose 99 cents to $58.98 a barrel, while Brent oil gained $1.01 to $65.03 a barrel. Analysts described the report as "bullish" and "supportive," but noted concerns about excess supply and a strong dollar may keep prices from staging a bigger rally.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mostly up as traders seek US rate hike clues
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mostly up on Wednesday, driven by traders awaiting clues on US rate hikes and reassured by penalties on leading banks for foreign exchange fraud. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.17%, while Paris's CAC 40 increased 0.31%. Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 0.04%. The rally was attributed to mining and healthcare shares, as well as US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Computer Sciences to split into two publicly traded companies
summary: Computer Sciences Corp (CSC) is splitting into two publicly traded companies, one focusing on US public-sector division and the other on commercial and foreign governments. The move comes after struggling with declining customer demand and reduced government funding. CSC will pay a special cash dividend of $10.50 a share to shareholders. The split is part of the company's efforts to adapt to a market shift towards cloud computing, and it joins other tech companies like eBay, Hewlett-Packard, and Symantec that have chosen to split into more focused businesses.

site_title: London sees record number of foreign tourists
summary: London received a record 17.4 million foreign visitors in 2014, a 3.5% increase from 2013, according to the Office for National Statistics International Passenger Survey. The city's tourism growth is attributed to events like the Wimbledon Tennis Championships and the Tour De France Grand Depart. Tourists injected £11.8 billion into the city's economy last year, with London & Partners predicting a further influx of visitors with upcoming events like the Rugby World Cup. The city's popularity solidifies its position as the world's top tourist destination.

site_title: US: Stocks close mostly lower after Fed minutes
summary: US stocks closed mostly lower on Wednesday after a brief rebound from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting minutes, which cast doubt on an interest rate hike in June. The Dow Jones fell 26.99 points (0.15%) to 18,285.40, while the S&P 500 slipped 1.98 (0.09%) to 2,125.85. The Nasdaq Composite Index inched up 1.71 (0.03%) to 5,071.74. The mixed market sentiment was attributed to differing Fed views on interest rates.

site_title: US, Britain fine six top banks nearly US$6b for forex, Libor abuses
summary: US and British regulators fined six major global banks nearly $6 billion for rigging the foreign exchange market and Libor interest rates. Forex traders from the banks met in online chatroom groups to set rates that cheated customers while adding to their own profits. The banks involved include Barclays, Citigroup, HSBC, JPMorgan, RBS, and UBS. The regulators stated that the banks' actions resulted in significant losses for customers and added to their own profits, with one Barclays employee saying "if you aint cheating, you aint trying."

images.alt_text: US and British regulators fined six major global banks a total of nearly US$6 billion between them Wednesday for rigging the foreign exchange market and Libor interest rates.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index adding 18.91 points, or 0.09 percent, to 20,215.46. The dollar rose against the yen after US Federal Reserve monetary policy meeting minutes showed a June interest rate hike was unlikely. The weak yen is positive for Japanese exporters, increasing their profits when repatriated. The dollar was at 121.20 yen, lower than 121.32 yen in New York, but still up from 121.02 yen in Tokyo earlier Wednesday.

site_title: New York celebrates opening of World Trade Centre deck
summary: New York celebrated the opening of its World Trade Centre observation deck, 15 years after the 9/11 attacks. The 100th-102nd floor observation deck offers spectacular views of the city, with New York Mayor Bill de Blasio stating, "We are back, 100 per cent." The new deck marks a significant moment in the city's regeneration and a victory over those who sought to attack it.

images.alt_text: Members of the media look out at New York Harbor from the One World Observatory observation deck on the 100th floor of the One World Trade center tower in New York during a media tour of the site on May 20, 2015.

site_title: Aussie BBQs, art to celebrate ties, SG50
summary: The Australian High Commission in Singapore is hosting 50 BBQs by 500 Australians and their friends to celebrate Singapore's 50th birthday and mark 50 years of bilateral ties. The event aims to reach out to ordinary people in the heartlands of Singapore and offer a meal of Aussie steak. Australian Foreign Minister Julie Bishop said it's a gesture of friendship from the Australian people to the people of Singapore. The BBQs will take place on one night in June.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: 1MDB's US$1.1b from Cayman are assets in US$, says PM Najib
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak claimed that $1.1 billion in 1MDB funds redeemed from the Cayman Islands were in US dollar-denominated assets in a Singaporean bank. This contradicts earlier statements that the assets were in cash. The funds are collateral for a $975 million syndicated loan to 1MDB, with lenders concerned about the collateral's value. Najib stated that the assets were redeemed to balance 1MDB's denominated liability. The move comes as 1MDB faces investigation and financial struggles.

site_title: Top energy firms tied to almost a third of greenhouse gases: study
summary: Thirty-two top energy firms, led by Russia's Gazprom, account for nearly a third of all man-made greenhouse gas emissions, a study found. The companies, which include coal, oil, and gas producers, emitted 11.7 billion tonnes of greenhouse gases in 2013, equivalent to 31% of the global total. Emissions from these firms rose 1.3% from 2010-13, despite efforts to curb emissions. The study aims to create transparency about sources of emissions, with the goal of encouraging the companies to lead the transition to low-carbon energy.

site_title: Evidence of waning appetite for Indian bonds
summary: Indian government bonds saw a decline in appetite, with a failed treasury bill auction on May 13 and forced purchases two days later. Global funds withdrew $1.4 billion in May, marking 12 consecutive months of purchases. Indian sovereign bonds are the worst performers among the largest emerging markets this quarter. Benchmark yields have risen to 7.84% and local investors are exiting fixed-income funds at the fastest pace since September, signaling more losses ahead for bonds.

site_title: Car COE slide expected to dampen headline inflation
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for big and small cars fell in the latest bidding exercise, as expected by dealers. Economists predict this trend will continue, reducing car prices and subtracting from headline inflation. COE premiums for motorcycles and open category remained stable, while those for goods vehicles and buses rose. The increased COE supply is expected to ease premiums, but pent-up demand may limit the decline in months ahead.

site_title: QE isn't a panacea for economic troubles
summary: The article argues that quantitative easing (QE) is not a panacea for economic troubles, but rather anesthetized financial markets against the shock from the 2008 implosion. Despite slow economic growth, investors continue to pour money into equities, and central banks continue to inject liquidity into the system. However, deflation remains a threat, and the IMF should examine unconventional monetary policies to ensure they meet the greater good of the global economy. Former IMF chief economist Raghuram Rajan warns that economies have reached their potential growth limits and that monetary stimulus can only produce asset inflation, not real economic growth.

site_title: Yahoo's tax-free plans for Alibaba stake clouded by IRS
summary: Yahoo's planned tax-free spinoff of its Alibaba stake is under scrutiny from the IRS, which is "thinking about" changes in how it treats spinoffs involving smaller businesses. The IRS official stated that the agency will hold off on advance rulings for new transactions, but existing requests will move forward. This could affect Yahoo's deal, which is valued at up to $16 billion and is expected to save the company $16 billion. The outcome is unclear, and Yahoo is being advised by an IRS veteran.

images.alt_text: Yahoo! Inc. investors have reason to worry about the company's plan to exit its stake in Alibaba Group Holding Ltd in the wake of new scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service of such tax-free spinoffs, tax lawyers said.

site_title: Shanghai exchange repo rate surges the most in 2 months
summary: The Shanghai exchange repo rate surged 253 basis points to 3.49% on Wednesday, the largest increase in two months, driven by increased demand for funds from initial public offerings (IPOs). A total of 2.8 trillion yuan (S$603.5 billion) will be locked up for 20 sales through Thursday. Analysts expect liquidity to return to ample as funds are released on Friday, but the overnight repurchase rate in the interbank market remained steady at 1.02%.

site_title: China, Brazil unveil multi-billion-dollar deals
summary: China has unveiled a multi-billion-dollar series of trade and investment deals with Brazil, with a total investment of US$53 billion. Premier Li Keqiang signed 35 deals, including agreements worth US$7 billion for Brazil's state-owned oil firm Petrobras. The deals aim to promote bilateral cooperation on trade, investment, agriculture, energy, and transport, and include projects such as a railway from Brazil to Peru. The move is seen as a significant boost for Brazil, which is struggling with low growth, and aims to deepen economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Johor and Riau forging new paths now
summary: The "Growth Triangle" of Singapore, Johor, and Riau Islands, formed in the early 1990s, has undergone significant changes in its development trajectory. While Johor has attracted foreign direct investment in manufacturing, the Riau Islands have shifted their focus to traditional economic activities like fishing and small-scale farming. This divergence is attributed to differing financial structures and policy priorities. Malaysian state governments have a financial interest in attracting investment, whereas Indonesian provincial governments lack direct financial autonomy. As a result, Johor's entrepreneurial drive has been unleashed, while the Riau Islands' efforts have been hindered by a lack of financial incentives.

site_title: Greece will default in June without aid from lenders
summary: Greece is expected to default on its International Monetary Fund (IMF) payment of $300 million on June 5 unless foreign lenders provide additional aid. The country's cash crisis is acute, with analysts warning of the possibility of capital controls and a deposit freeze. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras's government hopes to reach a cash-for-reforms deal in days, but EU and IMF lenders are more pessimistic, citing a lack of progress on labor and pension reform. The crisis has raised concerns about Greece's potential bankruptcy and exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Argentine farmers to register Monsanto soya seed use in crackdown
summary: Argentina's Agriculture Ministry is creating a registry to track genetically modified soya bean seeds used by farmers, aiming to prevent the resale of seeds developed by Monsanto Co. The registry will require farmers to declare seed usage and payment to the company. The move comes amid tensions between Monsanto and farmers over royalty payments for seeds obtained from prior harvests. The registry represents a compromise between the government and Monsanto, with a fund to be created for biotechnology development in the country.

site_title: Bread trumping rice makes Indonesia top wheat buyer after Egypt
summary: Indonesia has become the world's second-largest importer of wheat, surpassing Egypt, as the country's appetite for bread and baked goods has doubled since 2002. The surge in wheat imports is driven by the growing middle class's desire for convenient and easy-to-eat meals. Consumption of bread and cakes has jumped 60% in the past four years, with Dunkin' Donuts and Krispy Kreme having a significant presence in the country. The trend is expected to continue, with Indonesia's wheat imports projected to rise to 8.1 million tons next year, benefiting top wheat exporters such as the US and Canada.

site_title: Streaming giant Spotify expands into video, original content
summary: Spotify expands into video and original content, aiming to turn a profit and become a broader, more personalized platform. The upgraded platform will support videos and offer news and non-music content from major media companies. This move follows the company's challenges to its dominance in the streaming industry. By diversifying its content, Spotify hopes to attract new subscribers throughout the day.

site_title: Alberta home slump seen boosting rentals
summary: A housing slump in Alberta is boosting rentals, with oil companies reducing capital spending and cutting jobs, driving demand for rental property. Average rents in Calgary are set to rise 2% to $1,350 in 2015. Despite home prices being 17% overvalued, economic uncertainty and job cuts are leading to a decrease in home buying, with some considering staying in rented apartments. This trend is benefiting companies like Boardwalk Real Estate Investment Trust and Mainstreet Equity Corp, which own apartment buildings in the region.

site_title: Cyber attacks a growing threat to US financial system
summary: US financial system faces growing threat from cyber attacks, according to a government report. Despite efforts to erect barriers, hackers still pose a potential systemic danger, with recent incidents including large-scale data breaches and destructive attacks that compromised financial information. The Financial Stability Oversight Council warned that vulnerabilities in interconnected systems and the concentration of key services create a risk of a cyber incident impacting multiple organizations simultaneously. The report advises financial firms to assume destructive attacks are likely and develop capabilities to resume operations.

site_title: US House approves short-term financing for highways
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a two-month extension of funding for transportation projects, maintaining Highway Trust Fund funding through July 31. The extension, passed with a 387-35 vote, sets up a potential fight over long-term funding, as lawmakers have been grappling with how to pay for infrastructure maintenance and upgrades since the last plan expired in 2009. Democrats will work to find permanent funding, while Republicans aim to find alternative sources, with House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy suggesting pairing consideration of a long-term highway bill with tax reform.

site_title: Tech firms, activists press US govt for encryption
summary: US technology companies and civil liberties activists urged President Barack Obama to reject proposals to weaken encryption or include "back doors" in technology products, warning that it would compromise security. The 140 companies, including Facebook and Apple, argued that strong encryption is essential to protect against various threats. They claimed that allowing access to encrypted devices would make them less secure against other attackers, citing expert consensus. The letter was a response to FBI and NSA requests to access encrypted devices for lawful investigations.

site_title: Koos Bekker seeking to repeat Tencent success
summary: South African billionaire Koos Bekker is seeking to replicate Tencent's success by investing in emerging markets' tech deals. He has spent 15 years riding the rocket of Tencent, which is now worth US$66 billion, after Naspers Ltd invested US$32 million in the Chinese company in 2001. Bekker is now scouring the globe for new tech deals, focusing on e-commerce in developing countries, and has given the CEO job to former eBay executive Bob Van Dijk. Despite facing competition from US giants like Amazon, Bekker believes the hunger of consumers and entrepreneurs in emerging markets offers ample opportunity for Naspers to succeed.

images.alt_text: Mr Bekker says: "E-commerce is not a get-rich-quick business. You need a good amount of patience."

site_title: 6 banks fined almost US$6b in forex probe settlement
summary: Four major banks, including Citigroup, JP Morgan, Barclays, and Royal Bank of Scotland, pleaded guilty to manipulating foreign exchange rates. In a US$6 billion settlement, six banks were fined for sharing confidential client information and coordinating trades to boost profits. The misconduct occurred between 2007 and 2013, after regulators punished banks for rigging the London interbank offered rate. Barclays was fined US$2.4 billion, while UBS paid US$203 million for its role in rigging Libor. The probe has led to increased regulation of the forex market and automation of trading.

site_title: Focus on strengths in integrated market, Asean forum told
summary: Malaysia's Minister in the Prime Minister's Department, Idris Jala, emphasized the need for Asean countries to focus on their natural competitive advantages to succeed in an integrated market. He cited Malaysia's approach to diversification, such as cutting fuel subsidies and implementing a 6% GST, as examples. Idris stressed the importance of taking "tough measures" for sustainability and collaboration to realize the full potential of the Asean economy. Singapore Business Federation chairman SS Teo expressed optimism about the Asean Economic Community's success, but noted the need for local companies to adapt to the market's restrictions.

site_title: Islamic Reit shortage seen boosting demand for Johor's new trust
summary: Malaysia's Islamic real estate investment trusts (Reits) may see a surge in demand despite a sluggish property market, driven by a shortage of syariah-compliant assets and steady rental income from pension funds. Johor Corp plans to list the RM900 million Al-Salam Reit, which expects to deliver returns of around 6.3% in 2016. The company expects an overwhelming response from institutional investors, who are attracted to the higher yields offered by Islamic Reits. This is particularly true amid a decline in syariah-compliant investment instruments globally.

site_title: Greenback hits 3-week high against euro
summary: The US dollar reached a three-week high against the euro, trading at US$1.1117, driven by growing expectations of a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Analysts attribute the surge to the removal of long-term bets on the dollar, which has led to a cleaner market. The euro fell, while the yen, Norwegian crown, and rouble rose against the dollar. The Fed minutes later in the day may provide further fuel for the dollar's momentum, potentially pushing it past parity with the euro in the next year.

site_title: Japan's strong first quarter GDP data pushes stocks to new 15-year high
summary: Japan's economy grew at a 2.4% annualized rate in the first quarter, the fastest quarterly increase in over a year, driven largely by an inventory build-up. This raised hopes that the economy is back on a recovery track, with personal consumption and corporate capital spending remaining relatively weak. The stronger-than-expected growth data pushed the Nikkei 225 stock index to a fresh 15-year high of 20,252.66. Analysts expect domestic consumption to recover this year as consumer prices are likely to decline, with corporate capital spending showing a small rise.

images.alt_text: Japan's economy grew at an unexpectedly strong annualised rate of 2.4 per cent in the first quarter of this year in real or inflation adjusted terms, the Cabinet Office announced on Wednesday.

site_title: Wind power is poised to spread to entire US
summary: The US is poised to become a major wind energy producer, with all states expected to produce wind energy, according to an Energy Department report. The next generation of larger, taller turbines (up to 460 feet) is expected to increase wind development potential, particularly in the southeastern US. This could lead to 16,150 gigawatts of electricity production, more than 10 times the country's current consumption. The expansion would bring wind power to areas that were previously not feasible, such as the Great Lakes region and parts of the interior west and Pacific Northwest.

site_title: Wearable-tech maker Jawbone gets another lifeline
summary: Wearable-tech maker Jawbone received a $300 million loan from BlackRock, the largest asset management company in the world, instead of equity. The loan is secured by Jawbone's licenses, intellectual property, and accounts receivable. This debt deal allows BlackRock to protect itself from financial risks, while also providing Jawbone with the necessary funds to thrive. The investment is seen as a bailout for Jawbone, which has struggled with profitability and production issues, and may give BlackRock a significant return if the company succeeds or fails.

site_title: NYC landmarks panel rejects Seagram renovation
summary: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission rejected proposed changes to the Four Seasons restaurant inside the Seagram Building, citing no rationale for the alterations. The changes, proposed by landlord RFR Holding LLC, included replacing a non-original glass partition with planters and a movable walnut panel. The commission's decision effectively rejects the proposal, which drew opposition from Phyllis Lambert, the daughter of the Seagram Co president. The Four Seasons' lease expires in July 2016, with the restaurant's owners exploring alternative locations.

site_title: Income inequality declining in some Asian countries
summary: The gap between the rich and the poor in some Asian countries is decreasing, contrary to global trends. The population-weighted mean Gini coefficient in North and Central Asia, and in countries like Azerbaijan, Cambodia, and Thailand, has improved. The decline in income inequality is attributed to industrialization and the growth of the middle class, as well as strengthened social-safety nets in countries like Thailand and Malaysia. This trend is a departure from the past, when East Asian economies experienced rapid growth and declining inequality due to sound development policies and government intervention.

site_title: Trade halted after Hanergy plunges nearly 50%
summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power Group's stock fell nearly 50% in under an hour, prompting a trading halt, amid a sudden and unexplained decline after a long run-up in market value. The company, controlled by founder Li Hejun, cited an announcement containing inside information for the suspension. Hanergy's shares had soared six-fold in the past year to $37 billion, but analysts questioned its validity. The plunge follows a 37% drop in Yingli Green Energy Holding's shares and a broader Hong Kong market decline.

site_title: 5 teams enter Stage 2 of Rail Corridor request for proposal
summary: Five teams of architects and landscape designers have been selected for the second stage of the Request for Proposal (RFP) for the Rail Corridor development project in Singapore. The teams, chosen from 64 pre-qualified teams, will develop the overall concept Master Plan and concept proposals for the 24 km corridor. The successful team will then carry out a preliminary design and feasibility study for a 4 km stretch. A public exhibition of submissions will take place from October to November, allowing public feedback before the successful team is announced.

images.alt_text: This bit of the corridor in Bukit Timah is one of six spots along the strip to be given special consideration in the designing of the space.

site_title: TomTom shares jump after Apple renews digital maps contract
summary: TomTom shares surged 7% after Apple renewed its digital maps contract, reaching a near six-year high. The deal, which has been in place since 2012, gives Apple confidence in TomTom's technology. Analysts speculate that the renewal may be skewed in Apple's favor, but ING analyst Marc Zwartsenburg rates TomTom shares as a "buy" and predicts a potential price target of 13.5 euros. TomTom's shares have risen 57% year-to-date, with the company's stock reaching its highest level since 2009.

site_title: Banks seen fuelling UK commercial property risks with loose loan security
summary: Banks in the UK are relaxing loan security for commercial property developers, increasing the risk of another real estate collapse. They are offering senior debt at 70% loan-to-value ratios, compared to 60% three years ago. This move is driven by low interest rates and high yields from real estate investments. Financial stability officials at the Bank of England are concerned that this could lead to a bubble, and the BOE may consider "appropriate action" if underwriting standards are threatened.

site_title: Rebound in global M&A activity set to stay
summary: Global merger and acquisition (M&A) activity is expected to continue accelerating, driven by cash piles building at corporate levels, cheap borrowing rates, and a new attitude towards M&A participants. The market is increasingly recognizing the benefits of both acquirers and acquirees, and large deals are now being pursued. US companies, with significant offshore cash reserves, are driving the trend, with many deals totaling over $10 billion. The activity is spread across sectors, and investors are rewarding both buyers and sellers, indicating a potentially long-lasting M&A cycle.

site_title: Crystal Trust to be delisted on Friday
summary: Crystal Trust, formerly Keppel Infrastructure Trust, will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on May 22, 2015. The trust was renamed to avoid confusion with the enlarged trust formed through a merger. Unitholders received 2.106 units in the enlarged trust for every one Crystal Trust unit held, with a distribution-in-specie value of S$1.16 per unit based on the enlarged trust's closing price of S$0.55. The board of directors wishes to announce the delisting, subject to completion of the disposal and distribution-in-specie.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Singapore market loses its mojo
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced its third consecutive decline, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 14.36 points to 3,439.68 on Wednesday, amid a turnover of 1.6 billion units worth S$1.06 billion. The market's slump is attributed to a lack of liquidity, with money departing the market and not returning. Analysts attribute the decline to caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's minutes release and regulatory changes in the land transport sector, which may positively impact public transport operators ComfortDelgro and SMRT.

site_title: Bond weakness a sign that equity investors should tread carefully
summary: Equity markets worldwide have entered a low-volatility, low-returns phase, with the Hang Seng and Straits Times Index down 3% and 3% respectively in the past three and four weeks. The weakness is attributed to a significant selloff in bond markets, particularly the 30-year US Treasury, which has risen above 3% for the first time in 2015. Analysts believe this is due to the US Federal Reserve's hint at potential rate hikes, as well as concerns over the US economy's growth pace and valuation of Wall Street.

site_title: Uncompleted New Jersey mall gets new life from US$600m bond sale
summary: A US$600 million bond sale is set to revive construction on American Dream, a New Jersey mega mall that has been incomplete since 2011. The bond, issued on behalf of Triple Five Group, will fund construction and may be sold by November. The project, which includes an indoor ski slope and theme park, was initially slated for a 2013 opening but has faced funding issues. The sale of taxable bonds instead of tax-free ones aims to protect the borough from potential lawsuits. The project is expected to generate over 36,000 jobs in construction and operations.

site_title: Samsung quietly prepping for change of style, rather than strategy
summary: Samsung heir Jay Y Lee, 46, is preparing for a leadership transition, focusing on style over strategy, as his ailing father Lee Kun Hee remains hospitalized. Despite no formal succession plan, Lee is quietly reorganizing the conglomerate, selling non-core assets, and listing companies to ensure Samsung's growth. His management style may differ from his father's, prioritizing performance and pragmatism. Lee aims to maintain the company's smartphone business by exploring synergies with components and wearables, while also being more down-to-earth and less attention-seeking than his father.

site_title: Walmart eyes Amazon in potentially costly e-commerce battle
summary: Walmart plans to invest $1.2-$1.5 billion in e-commerce this year, aiming to compete with Amazon by leveraging its 4,500 stores as distribution points. However, this strategy may come at a high cost, with estimates suggesting it could need to spend over $1 billion to catch up with Amazon's investments. Walmart's online revenues grew 17% globally in the first quarter, but investments in e-commerce shaved 2 cents off earnings per share. The company's free shipping pilot program could help it gain ground in the market, particularly in the grocery segment.

images.alt_text: Analysts believe Walmart can make gains by capitalising on its strengths, such as its strong relationships with packaged goods makers and in groceries.

site_title: Mitsui new CEO looks to food, medicine to cure 22% profit slump
summary: Mitsui & Co, Japan's top oil trader, is shifting focus from raw materials to food, healthcare, and services to combat a 22% profit slump. New CEO Tatsuo Yasunaga aims to bolster non-resource areas, such as retail, healthcare, and infrastructure, which are less affected by commodity price fluctuations. Mitsui has set up a new division to evaluate deals in these areas and made investments in the US and Africa, including a stake in China's Citic Ltd. The company forecasts a 22% profit drop this year, and analysts expect tough conditions unless iron ore and oil prices revive.

site_title: China's back-door funding re-opens in blow to deleveraging
summary: China's finance minister, Lou Jiwei, is facing a challenge in cleaning up the country's debt-fueled investment excesses. Despite efforts to crack down on off-balance-sheet financing, regulators are considering relaxing limits on local-government financing vehicles, a key driver of China's debt surge. This move prioritizes economic growth over debt resolution, potentially undermining Lou's efforts to deleverage the economy. The relaxation of rules is seen as a significant policy easing, reversing the fiscal policy shift from tightening to loosening.

images.alt_text: Mr Lou initiated a crackdown last year on the off-balance-sheet financing that local authorities used for their projects

site_title: Ascendas in maiden development project in Indonesia
summary: Ascendas Group has made its first major development project in Indonesia, a 9.7-hectare mixed-use project in Tangerang, Greater Jakarta, with local partner PT Metropolitan Karyadeka Development. The project, Metland Cyber City, will be developed in four phases over the next few years. The first phase, spanning 1.3 hectares, is expected to begin construction next year with an estimated development cost of S$300 million. Ascendas sees Indonesia as a key market and is "on the lookout for further opportunities" in the country.

images.alt_text: Ascendas and MKD exchanging gifts at the joint venture signing ceremony. (From left) Solidi Korompis, director, PT Karyadeka (MKD director); Nanda Widya, president director, Metland; William Tay, CEO, South-east Asia, Ascendas; and Manohar Khiatani, president & group CEO, Ascendas.

site_title: Sinocare partners Citic unit to bid for Bayer's diabetes business
summary: Sinocare Inc, a Chinese blood sugar monitor maker, has teamed up with Citic Securities Co's Goldstone Investment Co to bid for Bayer's diabetes devices business, offering about $1 billion. The Chinese company is competing with Panasonic Healthcare Co, which has been in talks to buy the business since February. Sinocare aims to gain access to technology and broaden its product base in a market fueled by China's rising chronic conditions and healthcare spending. Bayer's CEO is selling the diabetes unit to focus on life-sciences operations.

site_title: High net foreign assets won't benefit Germany or global economy
summary: Germany's high net foreign assets of one trillion euros pose a significant challenge for the country and the global economy. Despite a persistent current account surplus, Germany's efforts to accumulate foreign assets may not yield the desired benefits.
