summary: Mobile shopping is expected to become a significant portion of the e-commerce market, with global spending projected to reach $119 billion this year. However, a survey by Dyn found that 85% of consumers worldwide experience different shopping experiences across physical stores, online, and mobile platforms. Consumers expect consistent quality and speed of performance on mobile devices, with 98% in China and 90% in India wanting the same experience as online shopping. Slow websites and security concerns are major issues, with 57% of consumers globally and 85% in India willing to leave a website due to slow loading times. To improve the mobile shopping experience, retailers must focus on creating an optimal user experience, prioritizing consistency, quality, and reliability.

site_title: New credit report to help hospitality firms manage credit risk
summary: Singapore's Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB) and Hospitality Alliance Singapore (HAS) have launched the SCCB Hospitality Credit Report to help local hospitality firms manage credit risk. The report assesses payment performance and provides a benchmark for businesses within the industry. Following a lacklustre payment performance in the past year, the report aims to help creditors take pre-emptive measures. The SCCB aims to enhance business transparency and provide crucial business insights to hospitality firms, increasing confidence in the region's surrounding markets.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: UOB sees more FDI flows from Europe into Asean
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) expects increased foreign direct investment (FDI) flows from Europe into ASEAN, driven by European companies seeking to tap into the region's average GDP growth of 5% and optimism over the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC). The bank's FDI advisory unit has doubled clients in the past year and plans to grow its base by 30% by end-2015, with European companies from various industries seeking to expand into ASEAN. UOB's FDI clients, including those from China, are drawn to the region's lower labor costs and demographic changes, with Singapore remaining a key hub for expansion.

images.alt_text: European companies - working in an uncertain environment back home - are eager to tap into the region's growth, says Sam Cheong (above), head of UOB's FDI advisory unit

site_title: Bringing home the bacon is easy as prices fall
summary: US restaurants are capitalizing on lower wholesale prices of bacon, which have dropped about two-thirds from a year ago, to offer innovative dishes and attract customers. With retail prices still high, consumers are paying more than seven times the wholesale price for bacon, leading some to call it "highway robbery." The low prices are driven by record US pork production and overseas demand slowing down, creating a glut in the market. As a result, restaurants are adding bacon to more dishes, and the protein-rich Paleo Diet has contributed to its explosive popularity.

site_title: Fiscal hawks at Japan MOF in a rift with Cabinet Office
summary: Japan's Finance Ministry and Cabinet Office are at odds over fiscal policy, with the ministry accusing the Cabinet Office of making overly optimistic assumptions about growth and spending. The dispute centers on the government's plan to lower public debt, with the Cabinet Office favoring a more growth-focused approach and the Finance Ministry pushing for spending cuts. The tension reflects Japan's massive debt burden, which is the heaviest in the developed world, and the government's efforts to implement fiscal reform.

site_title: AIIB mulling faster loan approval process: officials
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is considering a faster loan approval process, potentially delegating decision-making authority to senior staff without an on-site executive board, unlike existing multilateral lenders. The move aims to speed up the decision-making process, unlike institutions such as the World Bank, which borrowers have criticized for having too many conditions and authorisation layers. The proposal will be discussed during a meeting in Singapore, where China's Vice Minister of Finance and Singapore's deputy secretary will chair the talks.

site_title: Chinese hedge funds help drive commo trade boom
summary: Chinese hedge funds are driving a commodity-derivatives trading boom in Shanghai, with trading volumes surging 31% last year, despite China's slowing economic growth. The growth is fueled by new regulations and the expansion of investment funds, which now manage over $187 billion. The Shanghai Futures Exchange saw a 842 million lots traded, while the London Metal Exchange rose to 177 million. The boom contrasts with slowing physical demand, with China's growth in oil, copper, and steel consumption forecast to decelerate.

site_title: Moderate bids seen for EC plot in Choa Chu Kang
summary: A 4.9-hectare executive condominium site in Choa Chu Kang, Singapore, is expected to fetch moderate land bid prices due to its location and the sluggish sales of EC projects since late last year. Consultants predict between three to seven bids, with a top bid in the S$250-330 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) range. The site is estimated to generate 490 units, but its location, far from the nearest MRT station, and the high number of unsold EC units in the area may impact demand.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Ho Bee to showcase Gold Coast apartments
summary: Ho Bee Land is showcasing its 223-unit residential development, Rhapsody, in Surfers Paradise, Gold Coast, Australia. The project features modern apartments with "resort-style" facilities and a 5-Star Green rating. The average price is A$800 (S$845) per sq ft, with studio, one-bedroom, and two-bedroom apartments available. Rhapsody is slated for completion in January 2016 and is located near the upcoming G:link Light Rail train station. The project is being marketed by Savills in Singapore this weekend.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: HSBC to charge banks for euro, Swiss franc deposits
summary: HSBC will start charging other banks for depositing money in euros, Swiss francs, Danish crowns, and Swedish crowns due to negative interest rates. The move, set to begin in August, is a response to the European Central Bank's bond-buying program. The charges will not affect individual or corporate customers. HSBC declined to disclose the amount of deposits in the affected currencies. The bank is joining other US and European banks in passing on the cost of holding money in negative interest rate environments.

site_title: 'Stealth' crashes in penny stocks just as damaging to confidence
summary: In recent weeks, "stealth" crashes have occurred in low-priced stocks such as Civmec, Sinjia Land, and CosmoSteel, raising concerns about the lack of transparency in the market. The Singapore Exchange has issued "Trade with Caution" notices in response to unexplained share price falls, but the underlying causes remain unclear. The incidents share similarities with the 2013 penny stock collapse, where the identities of responsible parties were never determined. The lack of accountability undermines confidence in the market, and more needs to be done to tighten market discipline.

site_title: How an adman made Coke's famous jingle
summary: Bill Backer, an adman, created Coca-Cola's iconic "I'd Like to Buy the World a Coke" jingle in 1971. The ad, which features a multicultural cast singing on a hillside, was featured at the end of the Mad Men series finale, sparking buzz among TV viewers and online commentators. Backer, who was also behind campaigns for Miller beer and Campbell's Soup, had no prior connection to the show and was unaware of the commercial's placement until it aired. Coca-Cola had provided the ad to the show's creator, Matthew Weiner, a year prior, but no money changed hands, and the company is not planning to run it as a paid commercial.

site_title: JPMorgan sees second-quarter slowdown in investment banking
summary: JPMorgan analysts predict a 15% decline in investment banking revenues for eight top banks in the second quarter, driven by weakness in rates trading. Despite a strong first quarter, fixed income, currencies and commodities revenues could slump 25% in May and June. Equities divisions are expected to show only an 8% decline quarter-on-quarter, similar to advisory and underwriting divisions. UBS is JPMorgan's top pick, followed by Deutsche Bank, as the banks prepare for a potential slowdown in investment banking revenues.

site_title: Bank Indonesia resists pressure to cut interest rates
summary: Bank Indonesia maintained its benchmark interest rate at 7.5% for a third consecutive month, resisting pressure to cut rates despite a slowdown in economic growth and a weakening rupiah. The central bank also loosened lending rules to support growth, citing the need to manage inflation and external pressures. Governor Agus Martowardojo stated that the bank will maintain a tight monetary stance to anchor inflation expectations, while Vice President Jusuf Kalla said rates will be cut gradually later to stabilize the situation.

site_title: FBI probe of plane hack sparks worries over flight safety
summary: The FBI is investigating a claim by a security researcher, Chris Roberts, that he exploited weaknesses on over a dozen commercial flights, including sending commands to a jet engine in mid-air. However, experts say the claims are exaggerated, as entertainment and critical flight systems are often kept separate. Despite this, the incident has raised concerns about the safety and cyber security of US passenger planes, particularly with the busiest summer for air travel ahead. The FBI investigation comes after a series of recent incidents, including a delayed American Airlines flight due to a critical iPad app bug and the deadly Germanwings crash.

site_title: Net buys of Singapore stocks outstrip net sells
summary: Global mutual funds bought more Singapore shares than they sold in the three months to May 13, with S$1.47 billion worth of net buys compared to S$1.29 billion of net sells. In the consumer goods sector, net sells outnumbered buys, with S$85.6 million of sells compared to S$49.8 million of buys. The top stock among sells was Golden Agri Resources, while Thai Beverage Public Co was the top stock among buys.

site_title: China at risk of being seen as an outlier
summary: The US is poised to adopt a harderline stance towards China, with the Pentagon proposing air and sea patrols in the South China Sea to challenge Beijing's claims. The Council on Foreign Relations has released a report calling for containment to replace engagement, citing China's goal to "replace the United States as the primary power in Asia." The Obama administration intends to continue dialogue with China, but there is suspicion of China's motives and refusal to accept international arbitration. China's refusal to accept dispute settlement mechanisms and international norms may lead to it being seen as an outlier, further straining Sino-US relations.

site_title: Comparison platform banks on three T's to Get there
summary: Singapore-based startup Get.com has achieved double-digit monthly growth in credit card sign-ups since launching its office and soft-launching in the US four years ago. The company, founded in 2006 as DailyMarkets.com, has differentiated itself through its proprietary technology, transparency, and teamwork. Get.com compares over 600 credit cards in the US and 130 in Singapore, with partnerships from major financial institutions like Bank of America and Chase. The platform's founders, Grace Cheng and Pedro Pla, attribute their success to their risk-reward approach, low resource utilization, and focus on innovation, allowing them to maintain profitability without seeking venture capital.

images.alt_text: Get.com, founded by Mr Pla and Ms Cheng, tasted success in the US with over 200,000 signed up for credit cards through its platform since 2011. Now the Singapore startup is homeward bound.

site_title: Malaysian growth expected to ease after robust Q1: AffinHwang
summary: Malaysia's economic growth is expected to ease in the second and third quarters after a 5.6% surge in Q1 due to consumers stockpiling ahead of a new consumption tax. AffinHwang Capital predicts a slowdown in private consumption and investment, but expects a recovery to 5% GDP growth for the year. High household debt and leverage, as well as declining revenue, pose risks to the economy, with a significant slide in liquefied natural gas prices potentially narrowing the current account surplus.

site_title: Modi faces dissent over spending shake-up
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces criticism for cutting federal welfare spending on the poorest, with estimates suggesting 300 million poor people will be affected. The government claims lower spending will be compensated by increased tax revenues for states, but impoverished states and officials warn of a negative impact on critical programs, including nutrition and clean water. Modi's infrastructure stimulus aims to boost economic growth, but critics argue the spending cuts are politically risky, particularly in rural areas where the poor are most vulnerable.

images.alt_text: Students waiting to receive free mid-day meals at a government school in New Delhi. Mr Modi's cuts in federal welfare spending on the poorest of India's 1.25 billion people are coming in for sharp criticism.

site_title: S'pore wins bid to host Lions Clubs International meeting in 2020
summary: Singapore won the bid to host the 103rd Lions Clubs International Convention in 2020, expected to generate over S$58 million in tourism receipts. This will be the largest association congress held in Singapore, with the Lions Clubs Singapore partnering with the Singapore Tourism Board.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Euro dives under US$1.12 on likely ECB action
summary: The euro fell below US$1.12 due to the European Central Bank's potential to lower eurozone bond yields and boost inflation, possibly flooding the market with more euros. Sterling also declined, shedding over 1% after British inflation dropped into negative territory for the first time since 1960.

site_title: UPS agrees to pay US$25m to settle US false claims allegations
summary: UPS has agreed to pay US$25 million to settle allegations of submitting false claims to the US government, specifically for covering up delivery delays that kept government customers from receiving refunds. The allegations were made by the US Department of Justice and were settled through court documents. The settlement does not admit wrongdoing by UPS.

site_title: US consumer bureau files complaint against PayPal over credit product
summary: The US Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has filed a complaint against PayPal, alleging the company signed consumers up for an online credit product without their permission. PayPal is also accused of deceptive advertising and mishandling billing issues. Under the proposed order, PayPal would refund $15 million to consumers and pay a $10 million fine.

site_title: Housing starts jump to 7-year high, construction permits rise
summary: US residential construction surged to a 7-year high in April, with housing starts jumping 20.2% to a 1.14 million annualized rate. This marks the highest level since November 2007. Low mortgage costs and an improving labor market are driving the recovery. Construction permits also rose to a 7-year high, indicating future construction plans.

site_title: London developers raise bets on future office demand
summary: London developers are increasing their willingness to start office construction without tenants, betting on sustained demand. According to a Deloitte survey, 31 projects were initiated in the six months through March, with 22 having no tenants initially. New construction jumped 24% in the period. This surge in projects is driven by the developers' confidence in the market, which has seen a 20-year high in project starts.

site_title: Japan to earmark US$100b for Asian infrastructure: report
summary: Japan plans to invest $100 billion in Asian infrastructure projects over five years, according to a report. The plan, announced by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, aims to develop roads, bridges, railways, and other projects in the region. This move comes weeks after China outlined its vision for a new infrastructure development bank in Asia, highlighting the growing competition for influence in the region.

site_title: Robust US housing data offers hope for second-quarter growth
summary: US housing starts surged to a 7-1/2 year high in April, reaching 1.14 million units, and permits jumped 10.1% to a 1.14 million-unit rate, offering hope for second-quarter economic growth. The robust data contrasts with weaker consumption and business spending, prompting economists to lower growth estimates. The housing market's strength may lift the economy out of a soft patch, but modest retail sales and industrial production data suggest a limited rebound.

site_title: Obama tweets, and a million follow within five hours
summary: President Barack Obama tweeted his first message on Twitter, amassing a million followers in five hours, according to his verified @POTUS account. This achievement surpasses actor Robert Downey Jr's record of 23 hours and 22 minutes to reach a million followers, set in April 2014.

site_title: US regulators set hearing on recalls by Fiat Chrysler
summary: US regulators, led by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), are holding a hearing on July 2 to examine 20 recalls by Fiat Chrysler, covering over 10 million vehicles. The agency alleges a pattern of delays in fixing safety defects and notifying owners, with some owners reporting fires, crashes, and injuries. Fiat Chrysler has defended its response, but regulators may impose financial penalties and order buybacks, a rare and unprecedented move against an automaker.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees oil tumbling by Oct, with WTI at US$45
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts US crude oil prices will drop to around $45 a barrel by October, a significant decline from current prices. The firm's Global Head of Commodities Research, Jeffrey Currie, attributes this to ongoing global market imbalances that will hinder the oil rally. This is the second bearish call on crude prices from Goldman in less than a week, contradicting Brent crude futures predictions of $55 by 2020.

site_title: Singapore a hotspot for global retailers: study
summary: A recent study by CBRE found that Singapore is the second-hottest target market for global retailers, with 58 new entrants in 2014, double the number in 2013. The Orchard Road strip remains the most popular shopping location, with luxury brands such as Dior and Gucci setting up shop in the Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands. However, the study notes that new brand entries may decelerate due to declining visitor numbers from mainland China and manpower shortages.

site_title: Europe: Stocks surge at close
summary: Europe's main stock markets surged at close on Tuesday, with the CAC 40 in Paris climbing 2.09% and the DAX 30 in Frankfurt rising 2.23%. London's FTSE 100 index ended 0.38% higher. Despite British inflation falling into negative territory for the first time since 1960, gains were tempered.

site_title: Apple CEO reveals more about himself
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook delivered a speech to George Washington University's graduating class, drawing on his experiences growing up in 1970s Alabama, where he witnessed segregation and human rights abuses. Cook emphasized the importance of finding one's "North Star" and doing what is right, good, and just in life and work. The 54-year-old CEO, who has become more comfortable on stage, highlighted the need to balance personal goals with moral principles.

site_title: Millions disappear from bank accounts in China
summary: A BUSINESSWOMAN in China, Wang Li, had almost $2 million deposited into her bank account but lost $1.98 million after unauthorized transfers at a state-owned Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) branch. This incident highlights increasingly sophisticated financial scams in China, with millions of dollars involved. The incident is part of a growing trend of financial crimes in the country.

site_title: QT Vascular enrols first patients for Chocolate Touch study
summary: QT Vascular, a Singaporean healthcare company, has enrolled the first 11 patients in its First-In-Human study of Chocolate Touch PTCA, a novel drug-coated balloon for treating de novo coronary lesions. The study aims to evaluate the device's clinical utility in a less invasive manner, potentially reducing stent placement and associated risks. Initial procedural outcomes were successful, with no stent placement required and no significant dissections observed. The study's findings could provide initial evidence for a new treatment option for coronary disease.

site_title: Asean must act fast, first to save Rohingya lives and then resettlement
summary: The Rohingya, a Muslim minority group in Myanmar, face dire circumstances, with over 1.3 million stateless and denied citizenship. Thousands are stranded in boats in South-east Asian waters, risking death due to lack of food, water, or sanitation. The international community is outraged, and a solution is needed quickly. Myanmar's government has refused to take responsibility, claiming the Rohingya are illegal immigrants from Bangladesh. The UN views the Rohingya as one of the world's most persecuted minorities, emphasizing the urgent need for action.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's corporate finance heads put on leave: sources
summary: Deutsche Bank has placed two of its co-heads of corporate finance in Asia, Douglas Morton and Venky Vishwanathan, on leave due to suspected breaches of internal compliance rules and allegations of mis-selling derivatives, respectively. Morton's absence was announced internally, while Vishwanathan has been on leave since early May. The decisions are unrelated, and no interim heads of corporate finance have been appointed. The bank faces civil court cases over allegations of market manipulation related to the sale of £450 million of credit-linked notes in 2008.

site_title: Maersk Line to increase Asia-Europe rates by US$800 TEU
summary: Maersk Line plans to increase freight rates by US$800 per 20-foot equivalent unit (TEU from June 1 for containers from Asia to Northern Europe. This decision comes as the shipping company, owned by AP Moller-Maersk, aims to maintain its 20% market share on the busiest Asia-Northern Europe routes. This move follows CMA CGM's announcement of a US$1,000 rate hike, further impacting the global shipping industry.

site_title: Help us fight fakes, says Alibaba Internet security chief
summary: Alibaba's head of Internet security, Ni Liang, says cooperation is more effective than lawsuits in fighting counterfeits. The company has signed over 1,300 memoranda of understanding (MOUs) with major global brands to combat fakes. Liang argues that brands have a better chance of success by working with Alibaba, rather than suing the e-commerce giant, as seen in a recent lawsuit filed by Gucci and other luxury brands against Alibaba in New York.

images.alt_text: Mr Ni says Alibaba spent about 100 million yuan last year to covertly buy products and check their authenticity.

site_title: Investors cut US equity exposure to lowest since January '08: survey
summary: International investors cut their exposure to US equities to 19% underweight in May, the lowest level in over seven years, due to concerns over disappointing US economic indicators and a strong dollar. Despite this, 70% of respondents expect global growth to strengthen, and expectations for the first US interest rate increase have been pushed back. The euro zone remains a top destination for investors, with a net 49% overweight allocation. Investors are more cautious on bonds, with only 5% expecting yields to fall this year.

site_title: Home Depot's profit rises 14.5%
summary: Home Depot Inc reported a 14.5% rise in quarterly profit to US$1.58 billion, driven by increased spending on home repairs in North America after a harsh winter. Total comparable sales rose 6.1% to US$20.89 billion. The company's net income per share increased to US$1.21 from US$1.00 a year earlier. This growth is attributed to customer demand for home improvement products.

site_title: AEC should be seen as a work in progress
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is nearing its 2015 deadline for the Asean Economic Community (AEC), but critics argue the initiative's deliverables, including integrated production space and free movement of goods, services, and skilled labor, will not be achieved by December 2015. The AEC was not based on the European Union model, but rather a unique approach, and its accountability for domestic policy changes remains unclear. Despite these challenges, Asean will likely announce the attainment of the AEC on December 31, 2015.

site_title: Tiger cubs leading hedge fund rush into China's JD.com
summary: Hedge funds led by Tiger cubs, including Lone Pine Capital, invested heavily in JD.com's American depositary shares in Q1, holding a record 44% of the shares. This surpasses their holdings in any other US-listed company valued over $25 billion.

site_title: Myanmar imposes 5% tax on phone cards as telecoms boom
summary: Myanmar's telecommunications ministry announced a 5% tax on top-up cards for mobile phone users starting June 1. The tax is part of the country's efforts to boost revenue from the booming telecommunications industry, which has seen a significant increase in the number of mobile phone SIM cards, from 1 million to 18 million, since 2011. The tax is expected to impact users but retailers, like Myint Shwe, believe it won't significantly affect usage. The move is part of the government's efforts to diversify its economy and capitalize on the growing demand for mobile services.

site_title: UK inflation is negative for 1st time since 1960; BOE says it's temporary
summary: The UK's annual rate of consumer price inflation fell below zero for the first time in over half a century, with a 0.1% drop in April compared to the same month last year. Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said the decline was temporary and caused by last year's big one-off fall in energy prices. Economists expect inflation to rise above zero in the coming months, but Carney predicted it would pick up towards the 2% target by the end of the year.

site_title: Asia's ageing shields bonds from rout
summary: Asia's developed economies, with rapidly aging populations, are shielded from the global bond rout as central banks keep borrowing costs low amid deflation risks and pension savings. Richer economies in East Asia, such as Singapore and South Korea, prefer fixed income, increasing demand for bonds, while the US and eurozone saw a 3.6% and 3.6% decline in sovereign debt, respectively, in the past month. Asian economies with aging populations tend to have higher savings and a preference for fixed income, resulting in lower yields and benefiting bond investors.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: AEC vision some way from being realised
summary: McKinsey's Asia chairman Kevin Sneader says the Asean Economic Community (AEC) vision by 2015 is unlikely to be realized due to mixed progress, with many sectors far from integrated. Intra-Asean trade constitutes 24% of total goods trade, compared to 59% for the EU and 40% for NAFTA. Integration could lead to productivity gains of up to 20% and create $280-615 billion in annual economic value by 2030. However, non-trade barriers and limited progress in sectors like financial services and healthcare hinder progress, with foreign ownership restrictions and non-perceived 'win-win' scenarios hindering momentum.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Midas Holdings won 328.9 million yuan (S$70.6 million) in contracts for high-speed train car body components, boosting its order book to nearly 1.4 billion yuan. This provides confidence of earnings recovery in 2015. Genting Singapore's Q1 2015 results were downgraded by 10% due to extremely poor results and a negative outlook guidance. Mapletree Commercial Trust's VivoCity mall has stabilized and its rental reversion should be closer to peers, with the trust upgraded from Reduce to Hold due to good management and location.

site_title: Shanghai to legitimise car-sharing ride apps in first for China
summary: Shanghai, China, has announced plans to legitimize private-car hailing services via mobile apps, starting next month. The move, the first of its kind in China, will register drivers from leading apps Didi and Kuaidi under the same platform as taxis, removing their "pirate cab" status. The goal is to create a uniform service and increase efficiency. This contrasts with Beijing, which has fined unauthorised vehicles for offering services via apps. Smaller companies will be encouraged to join the platform, aiming to raise efficiency and promote economic growth.

site_title: Accelerator doubles pre-seed investment to S$50k per startup
summary: Singapore's flagship startup accelerator, JOYFUL Frog Digital Incubator (JFDI), has doubled its pre-seed investment to S$50,000 per startup for an 8.88% equity stake, with a follow-on S$70,000 in seed funding for the most successful startups. The program aims to support startups from Q3 2015, offering a package worth S$1.2 million, including technical resources and mentoring. JFDI will also experiment with a virtualized offering, allowing teams to participate from anywhere in the region.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata Q1 net profit down 13.3% on higher operating costs
summary: Malaysia's Axiata Group Bhd reported a 13.3% decline in first-quarter net profit to 584.8 million ringgit (S$216.8 million) due to higher operating costs. This represents a drop from 674.8 million ringgit in the same period last year. The company attributed the decline to increased expenses, including higher costs associated with network infrastructure and other operational expenses.

site_title: Seoul: Won closes down as US bond yields rise; shares up
summary: The South Korean won closed down 0.2% to 1,088.1 per dollar as US bond yields rose, reducing appetite for riskier assets. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index ended up 0.3% at 2,120.85 points.

site_title: Unilever names Pitkethly as new CFO after Huet quits
summary: Unilever appoints Graeme Pitkethly as its new CFO, replacing Jean-Marc Huët who will leave the company later this year. Pitkethly, 48, has been with Unilever since 2002 and will take over on October 1. Huët had been at Unilever since 2010 and will ensure a smooth transition.

site_title: German investor sentiment falls to five-month low in May: ZEW
summary: German investor sentiment dropped to a five-month low in May, according to the ZEW economic institute, falling 11.4 points to 41.9 points. This marks its lowest level since December 2014, primarily due to weaker-than-expected growth in the first quarter. The decline in confidence suggests a decrease in investor optimism, potentially impacting economic growth.

site_title: Update: Airbus warns of bug that could affect A400M engines
summary: Airbus has warned of a technical bug potentially affecting the engines of its A400M aircraft, which was discovered during an internal test after a military plane crashed in Spain, killing four people. The company has sent an alert to clients urging specific checks of Electronic Control Units (ECU) on each engine. The potential flaw was uncovered separately from an official investigation into the crash. Airbus Defence and Space has informed operators about necessary actions to take, with some countries grounding their planes until more details emerge.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore has been ranked as the world's second hottest city for new retailer expansion, attracting 58 new retail brands in 2014, according to CBRE. The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau and Hospitality Alliance Singapore launched a credit report to help the hospitality industry manage risks. United Overseas Bank (UOB) has doubled its foreign direct investment advisory clients in a year. Singapore Post has been chosen as the first logistics partner of Alibaba's Merchant Delivery Scheme. Commodity trader Noble Group secured a US$2.3 billion revolving loan facility from 35 global banks.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney sees "very low" inflation in next few months
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney expects inflation to remain "very low" for the next few months before rising towards the 2% target by the end of the year. This comes after the UK's annual consumer price inflation fell below zero for the first time since the 1960s. Carney noted that Britons should enjoy low energy and food prices while they last, citing the low inflation rate as a positive for consumers.

images.alt_text: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said inflation will likely remain at very low levels for the next few months before picking up towards the end of the year, after data on Tuesday showed inflation fell for the first time in decades.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to ease lending restrictions to revive growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo announced plans to ease lending restrictions to support economic growth. The bank will loosen reserve requirements for loans, mortgages, and car and motorcycle loans. The benchmark interest rate remains unchanged at 7.50%. This move aims to revive growth momentum and stimulate economic activity.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank governor said on Tuesday it will support economic growth by loosening some lending requirements for banks.

site_title: Airbus to order engine-related checks after A400M crash: sources
summary: Airbus plans to ask nations operating the A400M military transport aircraft to conduct checks related to its turboprop engines after a fatal crash in Spain. The potential anomaly involves the interface between the engines and the rest of the aircraft. The A400M has been delivered to several countries, including Britain, France, and Germany, at a cost of 20 billion euros. Airbus has no immediate comment on the matter.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 slip as Walmart earnings disappoint
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 slipped from record highs on Tuesday, as Walmart's disappointing earnings weighed on the markets. US housing data showed a 20.2% rise in new home construction, but the retail giant's earnings fell short of expectations, contributing to the decline. The Dow Jones closed at 18,295.62, down 3.26 points, while the S&P 500 fell 0.18 points to 2,129.02.

site_title: Singapore: More weakness as STI drifts lower in thin volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 5.53 points to 3,454.04 on Tuesday, with turnover totaling 1.8 billion units worth S$973 million. The decline occurred in thin volume, with most of the top active stocks trading below S$0.30. The STI has been experiencing a slow decline for months, with liquidity drying up. Despite Wall Street's record closes overnight, the STI's decline was not impacted, and proprietary traders looked to low-priced issues to salvage trading.

site_title: Thai general election to take place August 2016 at the earliest - deputy PM
summary: Thai Deputy Prime Minister Wissanu Krea-ngam announced that the country's general election, initially planned for early 2016, will now take place in August 2016 at the earliest. This decision comes after the cabinet agreed to hold a referendum on the new constitution and the military's blueprint for restoring democracy. The referendum is expected to be held in January, followed by a three to four month amendment period and an election within 90 days of that.

site_title: Hong Kong shares rally, Shanghai surges
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.37% to 27,693.54, following a strong rally in Shanghai and a record close in New York. The Shanghai Composite Index surged 3.13% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 2.63%. These gains are attributed to a strong rally in mainland China.

site_title: Update: Deutsche Bank said to put Asia corporate finance heads on leave
summary: Deutsche Bank has placed its co-heads of corporate finance in Asia, Douglas Morton and Venky Vishwanathan, on leave amid suspected breaches of internal compliance rules and alleged mis-selling of derivatives. Morton was put on leave over internal compliance issues, while Vishwanathan's leave was announced due to civil court cases over alleged mis-selling. The decisions were unrelated, and no interim heads have been appointed. The moves come as the bank faces challenges in its Asian operations, with both executives based in Hong Kong and Singapore, respectively.

site_title: Yoma building international school in Yangon
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings has signed agreements with Education Index Management to develop a British international school in Yangon, Myanmar. The school, British College Yangon, will cost US$40 million and offer a British curriculum tailored for Myanmar and foreign students aged 2-18. Construction began, and the school is expected to open for the 2016/2017 academic year, with Dulwich College International overseeing academic and operational management.

site_title: Hong Kong court approves CKH Holdings' restructuring plan
summary: A Hong Kong court has approved the restructuring plan of CKH Holdings and unit Hutchison Whampoa, following an initial announcement in January. Cheung Kong Holdings offered US$24 billion in stock to acquire Hutchison Whampoa and spin off its property assets. Shares of both companies resumed trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. This move is part of billionaire Li Ka-shing's efforts to reorganize his corporate empire.

site_title: Gazprom lowers natural gas output forecast for this year
summary: Gazprom, Russia's largest company, lowered its natural gas output forecast for 2015 for the second time, citing weak demand in Europe and competition at home. The new forecast is 450 billion cubic meters, lower than previous estimates. The company faces challenges from diversifying European demand away from Russia and domestic competition from Novatek and Rosneft. Gazprom's maximum daily output capacity will decrease to 1.5 billion cubic meters, and the Bovanenkovo project is expected to reach 51 billion cubic meters this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 13.78 points to 1,809.72. The market saw 2.1 billion lots valued at RM2 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 406 to 360.

site_title: Singapore to release detailed Q1 GDP data on May 26
summary: Singapore will release detailed Q1 GDP data on May 26, with economists expecting a possible slight upward revision to January-March GDP growth, driven by better-than-expected industrial production and exports. The city-state's economy grew an annualised 1.1% from the prior quarter, with 2.1% expansion compared to the same period last year.

site_title: HKEx to decide in coming weeks on plan to curb closing volatility
summary: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEx) plans to announce a proposal to curb closing volatility in the coming weeks, following international peers in New York and Europe. The move is favored by large investors but opposed by local retail brokers who claim it will disadvantage small investors and traders. International investors, however, see the measures as crucial for Hong Kong's status as an international financial center.

site_title: Singapore to host Lions Clubs International Convention in 2020
summary: Singapore won the bid to host the Lions Clubs International Convention 2020, the largest association congress in the city. The event is expected to generate over S$58 million in tourism receipts and attract 20,000 foreign attendees. The Singapore Tourism Board and Lions Clubs Singapore will partner to deliver the convention, which will be held in mid-2020. The event is expected to bring significant tourism and economic impact to the city.
