site_title: Vodafone sees net profits tumble
summary: Vodafone's annual net profits plummeted to £5.76 billion, a significant drop from £59.25 billion in the previous year, largely due to the sale of its stake in Verizon Wireless. Despite this, the company's annual revenues rose 10.1% to £42.2 billion, and earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) increased 7.5% to £11.9 billion. Vodafone forecasts EBITDA to be in the range of £11.5 billion to £12.0 billion for the current financial year.

site_title: Wal-Mart first-quarter same-store sales miss estimates
summary: Wal-Mart reported lower-than-expected US same-store sales growth of 1.1% in the first quarter, missing analysts' estimate of a 1.5% increase. The company's net profit fell to $3.34 billion, or $1.03 per share, down from $3.59 billion, or $1.11 per share, in the same period last year. Total revenue also fell slightly to $114.83 billion. The company's shares dropped 2% in pre-market trading.

site_title: UOB doubles FDI advisory clients in a year
summary: United Overseas Bank (UOB) announced a doubling of its foreign direct investment (FDI) advisory clients in the past year, with over 500 companies expanding into South-east Asia. The bank attributes this growth to the demand for cross-border banking expertise in the region. UOB expects total Asean trade to reach $6.6 trillion by 2030, with Singapore maintaining its position as the top FDI destination, capturing half of the region's total FDI.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds key rate despite slumping growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held its key policy rate unchanged at 7.50% despite economic growth slumping to its slowest pace since 2009. The bank instead eased some restrictions to encourage banks to boost loans, loosening reserve requirements for mortgages and car loans. This decision aims to balance managing currency risks with supporting growth, as inflation remains within the target range. The rupiah rose 0.2 to 13,100 per dollar, but has lost 5.6% against the dollar this year.

site_title: BP plans to sell part of its stake in Australian oil venture
summary: BP plans to sell 30% to 40% of its stake in the Australian oil project in the Great Australian Bight, starting in the second half of 2015, before an exploration campaign that will start in October 2016 at a cost of over $1 billion. The company aims to cut its stake from 70% to between 40% and 50%. Statoil ASA owns the rest of the project, and BP is seeking partners to work with to save costs and improve efficiency. The move comes amid opposition from environmentalists over the potential for an accident.

site_title: Government releases EC site in Choa Chu Kang for sale
summary: The Housing & Development Board announced the release of an executive condominium (EC) site at Choa Chu Kang Ave 5 for sale by tender. The site has an area of 16,381 square meters and can hold approximately 490 units. The building's maximum height is 60m above mean sea level, with a 99-year lease period. The closing date for the tender is June 30, 2015.

site_title: Boeing wins S$8.1b plane order from China carrier, lessors
summary: Boeing secured an S$8.13 billion plane order from Chinese carrier Ruili Airlines and two leasing companies, Minsheng Financial Leasing and Avic International Leasing, for 60 737 Max models. This order comes amid China's surge in travel demand and expansion of its airline fleet. Boeing expressed enthusiasm for the deal, looking forward to finalizing details with Ruili. This is part of a larger trend of Chinese carriers ordering Boeing and Airbus planes, driven by the country's growing economy and increased air travel.

site_title: Cofco units surge on US$57b China state food giant's revamp
summary: Cofco Corp, China's largest food company, has invited investment banks to submit proposals for a possible group restructuring. The move aims to improve profitability by combining units and selling peripheral businesses. Cofco's listed units surged, with Cofco Tunhe Co up 7.2%, Cofco Biochemical Co up 6.3%, and CPMC Holdings Ltd up 9.2%. The company plans to consider a group listing by 2019 and may propose restructuring possibilities such as divesting its confectionery business or merging with sister companies. The move could provide a blueprint for China's broader overhaul of its state enterprises.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index back above 20,000 mark after Wall St record
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.68% on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index climbing to 20,026.38, its first time above 20,000 in three weeks. The yen's weakness and record-setting advances on Wall Street contributed to the gains. The Topix index also rose 0.41% to 1,633.33, levels not seen since 2007. The rally comes despite US President Trump's recent threats, with traders brushing off the uncertainty.

site_title: RBA retains easing bias as slower growth leaves jobless higher
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has retained its easing bias, indicating it still has scope to cut interest rates if needed, amid slower economic growth and elevated unemployment. The central bank cut interest rates to a record 2% two weeks ago, citing weaker-than-expected spending by firms and subdued growth of domestic costs, which led to lower inflation expectations. The RBA also warned of a significant risk to demand for commodities due to China's weakening economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.24%, the CAC 40 in Paris gaining 0.56%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 winning 0.99%. This follows a rally in Asian markets, which were driven by mining and healthcare shares, as well as US-EU trade talks. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Japan to earmark US$100bn for Asian infrastructure: report
summary: Japan plans to invest $100 billion in Asian infrastructure projects over five years, including roads, bridges, and railways, through public-private partnerships. The move aims to demonstrate Japan's commitment to infrastructure development in Asia, differing from the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) led by China. Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso previously announced the plan, which will be supported by government-affiliated bodies such as JICA and JBIC. The investment aims to promote high-quality infrastructure and human resource development in the region.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 4.45 points to 1,819.05 points, with a trading volume of 79.3 million lots worth RM 36.1 million.

site_title: UK inflation negative for first time since 1960, pulled down by early Easter
summary: Britain's annual rate of consumer price inflation fell below zero for the first time since the 1960s, with a 0.1% decline in April compared to the same month last year. The drop was attributed to lower travel costs due to an early Easter. Economists had expected the inflation rate to remain at zero. This marks the first time the Consumer Price Index (CPI) has come in negative since 1996, and the first time consumer prices have shown deflation since 1960.

site_title: Singapore is the world's second hottest city for new retailer expansion: CBRE
summary: Singapore ranks as the world's second hottest city for new retailer expansion, attracting 58 new retail brands in 2014, according to CBRE. Tokyo leads with 63 new brands, followed by Taipei, Hong Kong, Beijing, and Manila. London remains the world's most international shopping destination, with 57.9% of international retailers present, while Singapore's cosmopolitan consumer market draws retailers as a test bed for the Southeast Asian market, despite a challenging retail environment.

images.alt_text: Singapore is the second hottest city in the world - after Tokyo - for new retailer expansion, having attracted some 58 new retail brands in 2014, according to the latest report by global property adviser CBRE.

site_title: China releases guidelines for economic reform priorities in 2015
summary: China's State Council announced guidelines for 2015 economic reform priorities, focusing on streamlining administrative procedures, boosting the yuan's global role, and promoting financial reforms. The goal is to restructure the economy to boost consumption, replacing exports and investment. Specific areas targeted for reform include state enterprises, taxation, the Shenzhen Hong Kong stock connect, and deposit rates. The guidelines aim to deepen reform and push forward the development of the real economy, calling 2015 a "crucial year" for economic change.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise as dollar holds rebound; wheat extends advance
summary: Japanese shares rose 0.3% on Tokyo's Topix index, following a record-setting day in the US. The dollar rebounded against major and emerging-market peers, buying 119.94 yen, while wheat futures gained 0.5% due to reduced US crop yields. Investors await US housing data and Federal Reserve minutes, amid doubts about the economic recovery's strength. The greenback's lowest level since January has fueled stock gains and kept interest rates near zero.

site_title: BP, Sinopec form marine fuels bunkering joint venture
summary: BP and Sinopec Fuel Oil have formed a 50:50 marine fuels bunkering joint venture, BP Sinopec Marine Fuels, based in Singapore. The JV will serve ports in Singapore, the UAE, Belgium, the Netherlands, and China, including major hubs such as Fujairah, Antwerp, and Shanghai. This joint venture marks a significant continuation of the partners' existing collaboration and is expected to provide marine bunker sales in key global locations.

site_title: Alibaba says Kering suit over fake Gucci sales has no basis
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. is fighting a new lawsuit filed by Kering SA, claiming the e-commerce operator facilitates the sale of counterfeit merchandise, including Gucci and Yves Saint Laurent products. Alibaba denies the allegations, stating the complaint "has no basis" and will be fought vigorously. The company has previously cooperated with Kering to remove fake products from its platforms, but the new lawsuit alleges Alibaba's algorithms aid in the sale of counterfeits, prompting concerns about the company's efforts to combat fakes.

site_title: Hin Leong said to mull Universal Terminal sale after IPO pulled
summary: Hin Leong Trading, the largest shareholder of Universal Terminal Pte, is considering the sale of a $500 million stake in the Singapore oil-storage provider. The company, 65% owned by Hin Leong, postponed its initial public offering in December 2014 and is now approaching potential buyers. PetroChina Co, which owns the remaining 35%, has not commented on the matter. The sale would mark a significant shift in Universal Terminal's ownership structure, with Hin Leong potentially exiting the company after an initial public offering was pulled.

site_title: Singtel to launch Next Gen GPON pilot service for residential customers
summary: Singtel plans to launch a Next Generation GPON pilot service for residential customers in Singapore, offering 10 gigabits-per-second fibre broadband. This will be the first telco in Singapore to provide this service, allowing customers to enjoy sharper 4K video and richer colours. The pilot phase will begin in the next quarter, with the option to upgrade from the current 1-gigabit-per-second bandwidth available on Singtel's Unlimited Fibre plan.

site_title: AirAsia looks to sell stake in loyalty programme: sources
summary: AirAsia Bhd is in talks to sell a minority stake in its loyalty programme joint venture, AirAsia BIG, to private equity firms valued at approximately US$330 million. The sale, which could value the business at around US$100 million, would involve selling around 30% of the stake. This move is part of AirAsia's efforts to monetize its affiliates, as the airline faces challenging times. The sale process is confidential and has not been commented on by AirAsia.

images.alt_text: AirAsia Bhd is in talks to sell a minority stake in its loyalty programme joint venture to private equity firms, in a deal that could value the business about US$330 million, people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Australia: Shares close near three-month lows
summary: Australian shares dropped 0.8% to 5,615.2 points, nearing a three-month low, as iron ore weakness weighed on sentiment. Energy and property stocks fell over 1%, while resources stocks declined 2% this week. However, newly-listed South32 rebounded 14% after its debut. New Zealand stocks also edged lower, with the NZX 50 index down 0.3%.

site_title: India mulls S$15 billion outlay to get rural poor online
summary: India is considering a S$15 billion (700 billion rupees) outlay to connect rural villages to the internet, doubling the spending on a high-speed internet grid. The National Optical Fibre Network project aims to link 250,000 village clusters to the internet, central to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Digital India initiative. The increased spending could boost opportunities for local companies and help address the issue of 1.1 billion Indians remaining offline, mostly in rural areas.

images.alt_text: India is considering doubling spending on a high-speed Internet grid to connect villages across the country to 700 billion rupees (S$14.6 billion), Communications Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said.

site_title: Noble signs US$2.3b revolving loan facility deal with 35 banks
summary: Noble Group has successfully closed a US$2.3 billion revolving loan facility from 35 global banks to refinance existing debt and for general corporate purposes. The facility includes a 364-day revolving credit facility at 85 basis points margin and a three-year revolving credit at 95 basis points margin, with a utilisation fee structure. The agreement aims to provide Noble with increased financial flexibility and stability.

site_title: Get ready for solar boom from China plants as Asia demand swells
summary: China's solar panel production is forecast to grow by almost a third this year, driven by falling prices and increasing demand in Asia, particularly China and Japan. The industry is expected to see its best year since 2011, with companies like Trina Solar and JA Solar Holdings Co investing heavily to boost production. The surge in demand is expected to benefit companies in China, which produce over 75% of the world's panels, and could help countries meet their renewable energy targets, including China's goal of getting 20% of its energy from renewable sources by 2030.

site_title: Changjiang Fertilizer responds to SGX query on staff costs, expenses
summary: Changjiang Fertilizer Holdings reported staff costs of 5.2 million yuan (S$1.1 million) for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015, despite ceasing business operations since FY2013/2014. The company attributed the costs to ongoing negotiations with local governments to settle labor contracts. Changjiang Fertilizer also incurred general and administrative expenses of 3.4 million yuan, including staff costs, work stoppage costs, and directors' remuneration. The company's selling and distribution expenses were 35,000 yuan, attributed to staff costs. The company's response was in response to a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query.

site_title: Oil halts drop near US$60 as US supplies seen falling third week
summary: Oil prices halted a four-day decline near US$60 a barrel after US crude stockpiles were forecast to fall for a third week. Futures were little changed after dropping 2.2% in the past four trading sessions. Saudi Arabia shipped more oil in March, exacerbating the supply glut. The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) has resisted calls to reduce output, fueling speculation that prices may encourage production. Oil prices have recovered from a six-year low, but volatility remains, with some analysts predicting the bottom may not be yet seen.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 4.28 points higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.28 points or 0.12% to 3,463.85 on May 19, 2015, with Sino Construction, Stratech Group, and Jaya Holdings being top gainers. A total of 68.8 million shares worth S$87.6 million changed hands, with 84 gainers outnumbering 62 losers.

site_title: Apple said to suspend plans to introduce television set: WSJ
summary: Apple has suspended plans to introduce a television set, citing instead a new Apple TV set-top box and related online services. The decision was made over a year ago, according to people familiar with the matter. The company's focus now shifts to dominating two new categories: television and automotive, as activist investor Carl Icahn believes. Icahn's letter to CEO Tim Cook claims Apple's shares are undervalued and worth $240.

site_title: Iran hopes to return oil exports to levels before sanctions
summary: Iran's deputy oil minister expects to return oil exports to pre-sanctions levels of 2.5 million barrels per day within three months if a deal to lift sanctions is finalized. The country hopes to regain its traditional trade in Asia, with the potential to take over 50% of exports. However, OPEC's decision on output cuts will depend on sanctions being lifted, and Iran has expressed confidence that its oil production will not cause a price crash.

site_title: Credit assessment initiative launched to help hospitality industry manage risks
summary: The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau (SCCB) and Hospitality Alliance Singapore (HAS) have launched a credit assessment initiative for the hospitality industry, providing key business information and risk analysis for 80 firms linked to seven associations. The SCCB Hospitality Credit Report aims to support firms in evaluating low, medium, and high-risk business transactions when extending credit terms to partners in Singapore. This marks the first-of-its-kind credit assessment initiative in the industry.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau and Hospitality Alliance Singapore on Tuesday announced the launch of the all-new SCCB Hospitality Credit Report.

site_title: Global energy subsidies to hit US$5.3 tn this year: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned about the significant impact of global energy subsidies, which are expected to reach $5.3 trillion in 2015, surpassing government health spending. This represents 6.5% of the global economy and poses adverse effects on economic growth, efficiency, and inequality. The IMF considers these estimates to be "shocking" and a major negative factor for global economic growth.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund voiced alarm Monday about energy subsidies across the world, saying they were expected to reach US$5.3 trillion in 2015, more than government health spending.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's Neske said to resign as consumer unit cut
summary: Deutsche Bank's head of private and business clients division, Rainer Neske, is set to resign amid plans to cut back the firm's consumer unit. The bank's supervisory board will meet on May 20 to discuss the changes, with Christian Ricken as a probable candidate to replace Neske. The bank's CEOs, Juergen Fitschen and Anshu Jain, plan to sell a stake in the Postbank retail unit and scale back the securities division in the biggest overhaul since taking charge three years ago.

site_title: Starbucks teams up with Spotify after abandoning compact discs
summary: Starbucks has partnered with Spotify, ending its 20-year run of selling compact discs. Customers can provide feedback on the music played at their local Starbucks and earn "stars" redeemable through the Starbucks Rewards loyalty program. Spotify users will also access playlists created by baristas. The partnership marks a shift towards streaming music, with Starbucks' CEO, Howard Schultz, acknowledging the decline of physical music sales. The collaboration aims to make baristas the "DJ" of the coffee chain, offering customers a more personalized music experience.

site_title: An enlarged Keppel Infrastructure Trust starts trading on SGX
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) started trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on May 19, 2015, after acquiring CitySpring Infrastructure Trust (CIT) for 1.33 billion CIT units. The acquisition included the Senoko Waste-to-Energy Plant, Keppel Seghers Tuas WTE Plant, and Keppel Seghers NEWater Plant. KIT is now the largest Singapore infrastructure-focused business trust listed on SGX.

site_title: US signs US$1b loan guarantee for Ukraine
summary: The US signed a $1 billion loan guarantee deal for Ukraine, aiming to support the country's economic reform agenda and help it overcome a Russia-backed insurgency. The agreement is part of a $7.5 billion package of support from bilateral and multilateral partners. Finance Minister Natalie Jaresko thanked the US for its continued support, while US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew emphasized the importance of Ukraine's economic reforms. The loan guarantee will help stabilize Ukraine's economy and pave the way for future growth and prosperity.

site_title: Siemens sells US$7.8b in debt seen backing energy expansion
summary: Siemens AG raised $7.75 billion in its largest dollar bond sale, providing the company with the necessary funds to expand into the US oil-and-gas equipment business. The sale comes as the company seeks to cut costs amid underperformance in its shares, which have fallen 23.3% compared to the broader German market. The company's CEO, Joe Kaeser, is focusing on energy generation and distribution and has agreed to purchase Dresser-Rand Group Inc for $7.6 billion.

site_title: Shale poised to pummel another market as US LNG plants arrive
summary: US shale gas is poised to disrupt the global LNG market, shifting from long-term contracts to spot trading. The first LNG tanker from the Sabine Pass terminal in Louisiana is set to leave in December, giving consumers more bargaining power. By 2020, spot trading is expected to account for almost half of transactions, and LNG is likely to surpass iron ore as the most valuable commodity after oil. The US is expected to become the third-largest LNG exporter by 2020, transforming the market and giving consumers more influence in LNG prices.

site_title: SingPost scores as first logistics partner of Alibaba Merchant Delivery Scheme
summary: SingPost has become the first logistics partner of Alibaba's Merchant Delivery Scheme, launched on May 19, 2015. The partnership provides discounted logistics services to Alibaba.com members in Singapore and Southeast Asia. Verified Members and Gold Suppliers can enjoy discounts on SingPost's "Speedpost" and "Ezyparcel" services. The scheme aims to offer cost-effective and seamless logistics solutions to small businesses conducting international trade. Alibaba Group and SingPost will also provide professional consultation services to enhance the logistics experience of Alibaba.com members.

images.alt_text: Singapore Post (SingPost) has emerged as the first logistics partner of the Alibaba Merchant Delivery Scheme launched on Tuesday by Alibaba.com.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GSS Energy, Accordia Golf Trust, Noble Group
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: GSS Energy has invested $5 million in Ramba Energy's exploration programme in Sumatra, Indonesia, expanding its operations and enhancing growth potential. Meanwhile, other stocks to watch include PSC, with Popiah king Sam Goi making a mandatory offer for the rest of the company at $0.40 a share. The STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by positive investor sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Accordia Golf Trust posts 5.16 yen DPU for eight months
summary: Accordia Golf Trust posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 5.16 yen for the eight-month period ending March 31, 2015, which is 7.2% lower than forecast. The company reported a net loss of 981 million yen in the fourth quarter, with operating income of 9.8 billion yen. This marks a 5.1% decrease from forecast.

images.alt_text: Accordia Golf Trust (AGT) - which debuted on the Mainboard last August - on Tuesday posted a distribution per unit (DPU) of 5.16 yen (5.71 Singapore cents) for the period from Aug 1, 2014, to March 31, 2015 (FY2014/2015).

site_title: Uber joins Baidu as Nokia's maps unit draws multiple bidders
summary: Uber is teaming up with Baidu and Apax Partners to bid for Nokia's maps business, which may fetch up to $4 billion. A bidding war is intensifying, with other groups including Tencent Holdings, NavInfo Co, and EQT Partners AB also vying for the unit. Microsoft and US private-equity firms Hellman & Friedman, Silver Lake Management, and Thoma Bravo are also in the running, with some offering minority stakes. The deal could be a major move in the tech industry's shift towards autonomous driving and mapping services.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; Apple supplier Hon Hai jumps
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.7% in early trade on May 19, 2015, following gains in other regional bourses. Apple supplier Hon Hai Precision surged 2% after a media report indicated the company would pay a record cash dividend to investors, boosting overall electronics shares by 0.7%. The main TAIEX index rose to 9,672.14 points, extending a 0.3% gain from the prior session.

site_title: China PM on Brazil visit, promising big investment
summary: Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang announced a $50 billion infrastructure investment plan during his three-day visit to Brazil, aiming to boost the country's economy amid a fifth straight year of poor growth and spiraling inflation. The investment includes a proposed $10 billion rail link and a new subway line for the 2016 Rio Olympics. Li's visit also aims to increase Chinese influence in the region, following recent agreements with Russia and India worth $25 billion and $22 billion, respectively.

site_title: London developers increase their bets on future office demand
summary: London developers are increasing their bets on future office demand, with 31 new projects started in the six months through March, the second-highest amount in 20 years. Of those, 22 had no tenants at the outset, with new construction jumping by 24%. Developers expect further rises in rents and more pre-let deals, and their confidence is translating into more active construction sites across London. This increase in developer activity suggests a sustained demand for office space in the city.

site_title: China tells drivers to manage their anger after road-rage incident in Sichuan
summary: China has urged drivers to manage their anger after a viral video of a woman being dragged from her car and beaten by a driver in Sichuan. The incident, which occurred in May, is part of a growing trend of road rage incidents in China, with 100 million reported since 2012. The Ministry of Public Security has called on drivers to be "civilised" and follow traffic rules, amid a surge in vehicle ownership and a 10% increase in road rage incidents in the first four months of this year.

site_title: GSS invests US$5m to join Ramba's Sumatra exploration plan
summary: GSS Energy, a Singapore-listed company, has invested US$5 million in Ramba Energy to participate in its exploration program at the West Jambi block in Sumatra, Indonesia. The investment aims to expand GSS's operations in Sumatra, enhancing its growth potential. The block has an estimated 426 million barrels of un-risked oil equivalent potential. Two onshore wells are expected to be drilled from the second half of this year. The move aligns with GSS's strategy of investing in Indonesia's near-production or producing oil and gas sector.

site_title: Ascena agrees to buy Ann Taylor owner for US$2.1b
summary: Ascena Retail Group Inc agreed to buy Ann Inc for approximately US$2.16 billion, unifying the Ann Taylor and Lane Bryant brands. The deal, valued at a 21% premium, aims to attract more working women and increase earnings by "significantly" in the first year after closing. Ann Inc has struggled to adapt to changes in the women's apparel business, and the acquisition is expected to generate US$150 million in annual savings within three years. The deal is set to be completed in the second half of this year.

site_title: China war on smog seen dooming coal amid 'cheap but dirty' purge
summary: China's efforts to combat smog are expected to further reduce coal demand, leading to a potential doom for the industry. The country's benchmark power-station coal prices have fallen 59% since 2008, with analysts predicting no recovery. China is shifting to alternative energy sources, including hydro, nuclear, and electric cars, as President Xi Jinping vows to punish environmental destroyers. The country plans to cap carbon emissions by 2030 and has already seen a decline in coal-fired power capacity, with new capacity expected to be lower than retired capacity until 2020.

site_title: Bombardier shuffles leaders again as business-jet chief replaced
summary: Bombardier Inc. has replaced the head of its business-jet unit, Eric Martel, with David Coleal, who previously served as executive vice president at Spirit AeroSystems Holdings Inc. and held executive positions at Bombardier's Learjet business. The move comes as the company struggles with delays and cost overruns on its CSeries commercial jet project. New hire Jean-Paul Pellissier will review the company's supply chain. This latest executive change is part of a broader effort by CEO Alain Bellemare to reverse Bombardier's slide.

site_title: The characteristics of effective brands
summary: Effective brands thrive by aligning with strategic objectives and adapting over time. Strategic brand building requires long-term thinking, customer understanding, and competitive differentiation. Brands should focus on creating a unique value proposition, maximizing visibility and availability, and staying relevant in a turbulent market. A key aspect of strategic brand building is defining what a brand is not, establishing guardrails to maintain consistency, and charting a course towards "blue oceans" of uncontested market space. Consistency across all touchpoints is crucial for achieving brand success.

site_title: Google wins court bid to avoid copyright law 'swiss cheese'
summary: Google Inc. has won a federal appeals court bid to avoid a ruling that would have made "Swiss cheese" of copyright law. Actress Cindy Lee Garcia, who appeared in an anti-Muslim film that sparked violent protests, had sued Google to block her appearance in the video. The court ruled that Garcia has no remedy under US copyright law, allowing Google to avoid a ruling that would have given her the power to shut down distribution of the movie. The decision is seen as a victory for Google and the entertainment industry, with lawyers praising the court's protection of online service providers.

site_title: McDonald's biggest euro bond sale extends record draw from US
summary: McDonald's sold 2 billion euros ($2.3 billion) of bonds, its largest euro bond sale, with maturities in 2019, 2022, and 2027. The sale comes as US borrowers in the euro area issue a record 49.8 billion euros of bonds this year, taking advantage of lower borrowing costs. The move is expected to help fund share repurchases, with Standard & Poor's estimating a potential $4.5 billion raise. This is part of McDonald's efforts to boost profitability after reporting a sixth consecutive quarterly sales decline.

site_title: Korean firms have the edge to succeed in India, says Modi
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi emphasized the potential for South Korean firms to succeed in India during a two-day visit to Seoul. Modi stated that bilateral trade between India and South Korea is underutilized, with a focus on infrastructure development and manufacturing. He invited South Korean companies, including Hyundai, Samsung, and LG, to invest in India's growing market. South Korea's government has pledged $10 billion in loans and funding for Indian infrastructure projects, aiming to boost economic ties between the two countries.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound after volatile session
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded after a volatile session, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.12%, Paris's CAC 40 index gaining 0.37%, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 climbing 1.29%. Greece's cash crisis concerns eased after reports of a more constructive government, contributing to a 1.62% gain in the Athex Composite index. The European single currency fell to $1.1353, but weaker currency helped lift stocks, particularly exporters. Greece aims to reach a loan deal with EU-IMF creditors by the end of May to resolve a cash shortage.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 close at record highs
summary: US stocks closed at record highs on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 26.32 points to 18,298.88 and the S&P 500 notching its third consecutive record at 2,129.20. The Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 30.15 points to 5,078.44, driven by Apple's 1.1% surge after activist Carl Icahn called for more share buybacks. Other notable moves included Endo International's $8.05 billion acquisition deal and ANN's 19.9% surge following its acquisition by Ascena Retail Group.

site_title: Greece nears debt deal in May as money runs low
summary: Greece is near a cash-for-reforms deal with its euro zone partners and IMF to meet debt repayments next month, according to Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis. The country has proposed a debt swap to release 27 billion euros of bonds held by the European Central Bank, but lenders have refused to discuss debt relief until Greece reaches a reforms deal first. Greece faces payments of 1.5 billion euros to the IMF and 6.7 billion euros to redeem government bonds in July and August, with the government hoping to meet debt repayments and pay government workers and pensioners in June.

site_title: After the spinoff, BHP saddled with US$2.8b reject assets
summary: BHP Billiton Ltd, despite selling $15 billion of unwanted assets, remains saddled with 9 hard-to-shift assets valued at over $2.8 billion. These assets, including a US thermal coal mine and UK oil and gas platforms, are hindering CEO Andrew Mackenzie's efforts to halve the size of BHP's core portfolio. The company's slimmed-down parent or demerger company South32 Ltd are not interested in acquiring these assets, which are now hampering BHP's goal of focusing on high-margin businesses such as crude oil, iron ore, and copper.

images.alt_text: Despite BHP Billiton Ltd's spin off and sale of about US$15 billion of unwanted assets over the last three years, the biggest miner remains saddled with a portfolio of even harder-to-shift rejects.

site_title: Governments must make up for fall in full-time salary jobs: ILO
summary: The International Labour Organisation (ILO) warns that governments must implement policies to address the decline of full-time salaried jobs worldwide. Only 25% of workers have stable employment, while 75% are in non-traditional jobs, such as part-time, self-employment, or temporary contracts. This shift has resulted in lost economic demand, exacerbating inequality, and costs the global economy $3.7 trillion. The ILO Director-General, Guy Ryder, emphasizes the need for governments to adapt to changing labour patterns and ensure income security for those without traditional employment, rather than solely focusing on promoting full-time jobs.

site_title: Funds lose faith in rally as Opec seen boosting supply
summary: Speculators are losing faith in the oil rally as Opec is expected to keep increasing supply, according to US Commodity Futures Trading Commission data. Opec's production rose to 31.21 million barrels a day in April, the highest level since 2012, and Saudi Arabia boosted output to its highest level in at least three decades. As a result, oil prices fell to $59.69 a barrel, down from $60.75 a barrel earlier in the week, and speculators reduced their net-long position in West Texas Intermediate crude.

site_title: Singtel given stern warning for negative marketing campaign
summary: Singtel was issued a stern warning by the Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA) for its negative marketing campaign against rivals M1 and StarHub through marketing agency Gushcloud last June. The warning follows the closure of IDA's investigation, stating that Singtel will not tolerate practices that bring disrepute to the telco industry. Singtel has terminated Gushcloud's services and taken measures to ensure staff understand and adhere to professional values and integrity. The company's shares slipped 0.03 cents to close at 4.33 Singapore dollars.

site_title: Enhanced Post-Diploma Certificate courses to start in October
summary: The Ministry of Education in Singapore has launched Enhanced Post-Diploma Certificate (PDC) courses starting in October, aimed at refreshing skills in ICT, engineering, and applied sciences. The courses are designed for graduates of relevant polytechnic programs and working adults, offering a fee waiver for Singapore citizens who have not taken the courses previously. The courses will last two months and are part of the national SkillsFuture movement, providing opportunities for individuals to develop their skills and remain industry-relevant.

site_title: Ascott sets target of 10,000 apartment units in Europe by 2020
summary: Ascott, a serviced residence business unit of CapitaLand, sets a target of 10,000 apartment units in Europe by 2020, nearly doubling its current 5,000 units. The company plans to achieve this through acquisitions, particularly in gateway cities like Paris, London, and Hamburg. Ascott has already invested over S$1.5 billion in the Citadines apart'hotel chain and plans to refurbish 33 properties in Europe by end-2016. CEO Lee Chee Koon emphasized the company's commitment to the European market, with a focus on expanding through acquisitions.

site_title: MasterCard thrives in Venezuela
summary: MasterCard is thriving in Venezuela despite the country's economic collapse. Runaway inflation and soaring crime are driving Venezuelans to rely on credit cards, with the company's business growing in line with its Latin American operations. MasterCard collects US dollars for fees, avoiding the country's foreign exchange restrictions, and has taken steps to protect the value of bolivars, including buying property in US dollars. The company's head of Latin America, Gilberto Caldart, notes the paradox of Venezuelans using more credit cards despite reduced purchasing power.

site_title: Market continues to languish
summary: The Straits Times Index closed 3.53 points weaker at 3,459.57 on Monday, with Hong Kong's 0.8% slide contributing to the weakness. Local equities drew comparisons to China and Hong Kong, where daily volumes are higher. However, situational plays emerged, such as Ezion Holdings, which fell 4.6% after being sued by Atlantic Marine Services. Analysts RHB Research, OCBC Investment Research, and CIMB called "buy" on Ezion, citing parallels to a previous lawsuit.

site_title: BOJ chief economist optimistic about Japan's short-term outlook
summary: Bank of Japan chief economist Eiji Maeda expressed optimism about Japan's short-term economic outlook, citing improving household spending and consumer sentiment. The economy is expected to move from a recovery to an expansionary phase, with core machinery orders showing signs of strength and the housing market picking up. Falling oil prices are also expected to shave over 10 trillion yen off Japan's energy bill, boosting the economy. The Bank of Japan may consider further easing to bolster economic growth and inflation expectations, although market expectations suggest a wait-and-see approach.

site_title: Insurers urged to seek solutions to low interest rates
summary: Singapore insurers face challenges from persistent low interest rates, which have led to shrinking net investment yields and margin pressures. Analysts recommend insurers reprice products, adjust new business guarantees and bonuses, or increase liquidity and credit exposure to manage capital exposure. Insurers with strong risk-adjusted capitalisation and stable underwriting profitability are better positioned to absorb the increased risk and capital requirements. Although interest rates are expected to rise eventually, the US Federal Open Market Committee's cautious approach has delayed borrowing cost increases, affecting insurers' yields and profitability.

site_title: Yoma project 'is 1st in Myanmar to have water-treatment plant'
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has announced the opening of a water-treatment plant at Pun Hlaing Golf Estate in Myanmar, the first of its kind in the country. The plant, designed and supplied by Hyflux, can produce 1,000 cu m of drinking water per day, using proprietary technologies for brackish water treatment. This move aims to provide high-quality drinking water to residents in the estate, aligning with Yoma's commitment to international standards of living.

site_title: JD.com in online pharmacy tie-up with Shanghai Pharma
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant JD.com has partnered with Shanghai Pharmaceuticals Holding Co Ltd to develop its online healthcare business. The move comes as China's online healthcare market is expected to grow, with the government set to open up the sale of prescription drugs online soon. This partnership follows a similar move by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd, which partnered with US drugmaker Merck & Co Inc to explore online health services. The partnership aims to capitalize on China's vast pharmaceutical market, currently the world's second-largest.

site_title: EU reform is more than renegotiation
summary: The UK's relationship with the European Union is more complex than a simple renegotiation. The upcoming referendum on continued membership will be influenced by reforms already implemented and those in the pipeline. Reforms such as the slimmed-down agenda of the European Commission and a real-terms cut in the EU budget could benefit the UK, but may not be enough to sway voters. Completing the single market and securing free-trade deals with other countries could also be key selling points for reform, and the government may consider holding a referendum earlier than planned to limit economic uncertainty.

site_title: Ukraine in political, economic chaos as govt fails to deliver
summary: Ukraine is plagued by political and economic chaos, a year after President Petro Poroshenko's election. The government has failed to deliver on promises to root out corruption, and infighting has splintered the pro-European majority coalition in Parliament. The economy is in shambles, with a 17.6% GDP decline in the first quarter of 2015. Efforts to forge a settlement with Russian-backed separatists have stalled, and the country is on the brink of bankruptcy. Public confidence in the government has slumped, and the international community is increasingly frustrated with the slow pace of change.

site_title: SMEs, tackle labour crunch by marketing to workforce
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) need to shift their focus from analyzing consumers to engaging prospective employees, says consultant Danny Lai. In a tight labor market, companies must create a desirable work environment by branding and marketing themselves to attract talent. Lai advocates for more research and marketing efforts to understand job applicants' preferences and create an attractive company culture. He also predicts that job ads will evolve to showcase a company's culture and values, moving beyond traditional "supermarket ads."

site_title: Ezion dismisses conspiracy suit as 'frivolous'
summary: Ezion Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore service provider, has dismissed a conspiracy suit filed by Atlantic Marine Services BV as "frivolous and without merit." The Amsterdam-based company accused Ezion of inducing an AP Moeller-Maersk unit to breach charter agreements by creating the impression that AMS was in financial trouble. Ezion has denied the allegations and stated that it will continue discussions with an oil major, with no expected impact on its earnings or net tangible assets. The suit is scheduled for a closed hearing on June 2.

site_title: CBRE Hotels: Singapore hotel market to stay challenging for buyers
summary: The Singapore hotel market is expected to remain challenging for buyers due to high prices and limited asset supply. Despite robust interest, only one deal was recorded in Q1 2015, and the market is expected to turn more challenging due to slower tourism growth and new supply impacting room rates and occupancy. Luxury hotels are performing better, but mid-tier hotels are struggling. The Singapore Tourism Board projects visitor arrivals to languish in the 15.1-15.5 million range, and tourism receipts to grow at a muted pace.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Disney gets help from Nasa, Google to inspire girls into sciences
summary: Disney Junior's new series "Miles From Tomorrowland" aims to inspire girls into sciences by portraying a strong female character and accurately depicting coding as a social, team-based activity. The show's creators consulted with Google and NASA experts to ensure authenticity and to counter stereotypes about female programmers. The goal is to encourage girls to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and math, as research shows a link between media representation and career choices.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings' drilling rigs are vulnerable to cancellations due to the deteriorating rig market, prompting a downgrade to "sell" with a target price of S$0.88. StarHub's Q1 earnings were stronger than expected, driven by unusually strong iPhone 6 demand, and analysts view this positively for future earnings. Thai Beverage's beer business has shown signs of recovery, with estimates raised due to operating leverage and price increases, leading to an "add" recommendation with a target price of S$0.87.

site_title: Kenanga Investors favours small-cap stocks, especially exporters and builders
summary: Malaysia's top-performing fund manager, Kenanga Investors, is favoring small-cap stocks, particularly exporters and builders, due to a bull-market rally expected to continue as earnings improve and valuations trail larger peers. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Small Cap Index has surged 11% this year, more than triple the KLCI's 3.5% gain. Analysts predict a 21% increase in profits for small-cap companies in the next 12 months, compared to a 3.5% gain for the KLCI. Key holdings include builders IJM Corp and Gamuda Bhd, benefiting from infrastructure spending and a recovering US economy.

site_title: Larsen & Toubro ready to help infotech unit scale up in preparation for its IPO
summary: Larsen & Toubro, India's largest engineering company, is planning to spend up to $1 billion on acquisitions to boost its software-services unit, L&T Infotech, ahead of its initial public offering. The company aims to scale up and compete with larger rivals. L&T Infotech may spend between $100 million and $1 billion on acquisitions, and the unit's valuation is estimated to be around $1.5 billion to $2 billion. The IPO will help unlock value for the parent company, and L&T Infotech will be the second Larsen unit to be listed after L&T Finance Holdings Ltd.

site_title: Russian smartphone in quest to break into cut-throat global market
summary: Russian startup YotaPhone aims to break into the global smartphone market with its dual-screen phone, despite the country's history of struggling to produce competitive consumer products. President Vladimir Putin has shown interest in the phone, and the company's creator, Vladislav Martynov, has emphasized the importance of globalization in creating a globally competitive product. The YotaPhone's prototype was introduced in 2012 and has since received attention at international tech conferences, but sales have been elusive, even in Russia.

site_title: Foreign creditors face bankruptcy riddle in China
summary: Foreign creditors of Chinese companies face uncertainty as the country's economy slows and Beijing becomes more willing to let companies fail. Despite China's Enterprise Bankruptcy Law, which allows defaulting companies to file for bankruptcy, foreign bondholders often face interference from local government officials, who prioritize domestic interests over creditor claims. This has led to inconsistent outcomes in bankruptcy proceedings, with some foreign creditors receiving minimal returns or nothing at all. As China's slowdown continues, lawyers expect an uptick in bankruptcy filings, but warn that political factors will distort the outcome.

site_title: April new home prices down y-o-y for 8th straight month
summary: China's new home prices fell 6.1% in April from a year ago, marking the 8th consecutive month of decline, but prices remained flat from March. Nationwide prices steadied, while prices in smaller cities continued to fall. Analysts expect home sales to see year-on-year growth in the second half of the year and home prices to bottom out in smaller cities. However, property investment growth is expected to slow, potentially knocking off one percentage point from economic growth, and China may miss its 7% growth target for 2015.

site_title: PM Lee: Make service part of S'pore culture, DNA
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for all stakeholders in the service industry to improve the country's service standards. The local service industry accounts for 70% of GDP, but progress is still needed. Lee urged businesses to set the tone and prioritize customer-centric service, while service staff must be proud of their jobs, care for customers, and strive to go the extra mile. He also highlighted the importance of customer respect, saying that mistreating service staff can make it harder to provide good service.
