The train was traveling at 106 miles per hour, more than twice the speed limit, when the engineer deployed the emergency brakes just before the derailment. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is investigating the cause of the accident, which occurred in a curve with a speed limit of 50 miles per hour. The engineer's actions may have contributed to the severity of the crash, and officials warn that the death toll could still rise as some passengers remain unaccounted for.

site_title: Birthday blues?
summary: A US shoemaker remains reliant on China despite 190% tariffs, with Levi seeing revenue growth offsetting most of the impact. Adidas and Puma are considering reviving their running shoe lines amid tariff threats. Meanwhile, BT has launched a Telegram channel for daily updates, and Cordlife is offering enhanced support to clients affected by damaged tanks in Singapore. Additionally, a mandatory offer for PSC shares has been made at S$0.40 per share, and DBS has downgraded Genting Singapore to 'hold' due to tariffs dampening the outlook.

site_title: Will the next startup capital to rival Silicon Valley please rise?
summary: A digital race is underway among global cities to become the next startup capital rivaling Silicon Valley. Cities like Singapore, Tel Aviv, and Bangalore are competing for engineering and marketing talent, fueling economic growth for their communities. According to research by tech writer Zafar Anjum, cities need great physical infrastructure, vast population, and innovative policies to succeed. Despite having key infrastructure, Singapore ranks 17th globally due to lower risk aversion, lack of role models, and limited access to key markets. The book "Startup Capitals" examines the top 10 startup cities and poses critical questions for policymakers to innovate and grow.

site_title: US wholesale prices dip in April
summary: US producer prices fell 0.4% in April, marking the third consecutive decline this year. The 1.3% year-on-year decline is the largest since 2010. A strong dollar and decreasing energy costs contributed to the drop, supporting views that the Federal Reserve will only raise interest rates later in the year, rather than sooner. This trend suggests underlying inflation pressures remain benign.

site_title: Encore! Encore!
summary: The Esplanade Studios' recent celebration of 50 iconic Singapore plays showcased the country's satisfying but under-celebrated arts canon. The season featured full-length productions, dramatised readings, and forum discussions, highlighting forgotten gems and well-loved plays. Notable productions included Oliver Chong's staging of Haresh Sharma's Off Centre and Tracie Pang's production of Huzir Sulaiman's The Weight Of Silk On Skin. Despite some omissions and weak productions, the season affirmed the existence of a satisfying Singapore canon and encouraged a yearly celebration of the country's plays.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Otto Marine posts US$13m net loss in Q1
summary: OTTO Marine reported a net loss of US$13.2 million in Q1, compared to a loss of US$14.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 92% to US$148 million, driven by the shipyard segment, which saw a US$90.6 million increase due to the sale of a substantially completed vessel.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: GM invests US$1b, adding 2,600 jobs at Tech Center campus
summary: General Motors Co is investing US$1 billion through 2018 to renovate and expand its 60-year-old Tech Center campus in Warren, Michigan, adding 2,600 jobs. The project includes construction of new design studios and a multi-storey information technology building. The investment aims to enhance GM's talent in areas like infotainment and advanced powertrains, in response to growing regulatory and competitive pressures.

site_title: Get your news from Facebook
summary: Facebook has partnered with media outlets such as the New York Times, BuzzFeed, and National Geographic to publish stories directly on its mobile news feeds through a program called Instant Articles. The partnership aims to improve the quality of news on Facebook and deliver stories faster to its 1.44 billion active users. Media partners will receive revenue from ads placed within articles or split sales on ads placed by Facebook, while the social network gains by keeping traffic on its app.

site_title: Tiger Balm soothes Haw Par's pains in leisure, property
summary: Haw Par Corp's first-quarter net profit rose 10.6% to S$13.5 million, driven by a 29% increase in healthcare turnover. Tiger Balm business helped alleviate weakness in leisure and property segments, with healthcare operating profit increasing 53.4%. However, leisure arm Underwater World Singapore and Pattaya reported a 28.5% decline in sales, and property revenue fell 7.6%. The company posted a net fair-value loss of S$65.3 million on available-for-sale financial assets. A mixed outlook for the next 12 months was announced, citing benefits for healthcare but challenges for leisure.

images.alt_text: The maker of Tiger Balm products posted a 10.6 per cent rise in Q1 net profit to S$13.5 million.

site_title: US consumer confidence declines for 5th consecutive week
summary: US consumer confidence declined for the fifth consecutive week, falling to 43.5 in the period ended May 10, its lowest level since early March. Views on the US economy dropped to a five-month low, and confidence retreated among full- and part-time workers. The Bloomberg Consumer Comfort Index is its best year to date since 2006, but sentiment about the economy remains dim, with Americans' economic views dropping to 34.5, the lowest since mid-December.

site_title: US capital spending seen falling to 4-yr low in 2015
summary: US corporate spending on capital projects is expected to fall to a 4-year low in 2015, with energy and other sectors cutting spending amid global growth concerns. Analysts project a 11% decline in total S&P 500 capex spending to $641.6 billion, the lowest level since 2011. Companies themselves are projecting a similar decline, with energy companies accounting for the largest fall in spending levels, down 14.1% from last year.

site_title: Vector Aerospace's new facility to beef up regional presence
summary: Vector Aerospace has opened its first MRO facility in Asia, a $50 million maintenance, repair and overhaul center in Singapore. The facility, which started operations in October, is expected to strengthen the company's regional presence and provide clients with a cost-effective solution. The 5,200 square meter facility will be equipped with full engine overhaul and test capability, employing up to 140 employees and serving Bombardier Q400 airliners. The facility aims to service over 30 engines by end-2015 and double this figure next year, benefiting engine owners and operators with faster turn times and superior customer service.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Hyflux Q1 profit down 85% on lower divestment gains
summary: Hyflux Ltd posted a net profit of S$5.6 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2015, down 85% from S$37.9 million a year ago due to lower divestment gains and revenue of S$60.4 million, down 32% from S$88.3 million. Construction work on the Qurayyat Independent Water Project in Oman has begun and is scheduled to start commercial operation by May 2017. The company expects increased operational activities in the second half of the year.

site_title: US jobless claims tick lower
summary: US jobless claims decreased to 264,000 in the week ending May 9, a 1,000 decline from the previous week, according to the Labor Department. This lower number was in line with analyst expectations.

site_title: Flitting from the real world to the imaginary
summary: Russian artist Anna Berezovskaya's new solo exhibition at Redsea Gallery features intricately detailed oil paintings with a strong sense of symbolism and artistic style. Her poetic realism style blends surreal and abstract elements, inspired by Russian culture and literature. Each painting takes 1.5 months to complete, with meticulous planning and execution. Berezovskaya's work transports viewers into her own world, with themes of mystery, discovery, and the human experience. The exhibition runs from May 15 to June 14, with prices ranging from S$8,000 for sketches to S$27,000 for paintings.

site_title: Market drifts as volume stays poor
summary: The Straits Times Index ended at 3,455.78, with a 2.61% gain, as it drifted lower for most of the session. Volume remained poor at 1.5 billion units. Singtel finished unchanged at S$4.36, while CapitaLand rose S$0.01 to S$3.55 on a S$650 million convertible bond issue. Nam Cheong's shipbuilding sector shares dropped S$0.01 to S$0.315, with OCBC Investment Research downgrading its rating to "sell". Ezion Holdings' offshore and marine sector shares fell S$0.03 to S$1.19. Deutsche Bank warned that Asia's economies face a difficult second quarter, with exports data disappointing and domestic demand softening.

site_title: Fest's finest fare
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts (SIFA) returns with exceptional works, including Wild Rice's ambitious play "Hotel," which tells the story of Singapore through a series of scenes spanning 100 years. The play is directed by Ivan Heng and Glen Goei, and written by Alfian Sa'at and Marcia Vanderstraaten. Another highlight is Theatre De La Ville's production of "Six Characters In Search Of An Author," an absurdist masterpiece by Luigi Pirandello. Additionally, Proton Theatre's "Dementia" examines the transition of Hungary from socialism to capitalism. Music performances include Black Arm Band's "Dirtsong" and a special recital of Franz Schubert's "Winterreise." Performance art includes Daniel Buren's "Cabanons," a minimalist circus experience.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
The two-part play Hotel takes you through 100 years of Singapore history - from 1915 to 2015 - seen through the eyes of ordinary people
Six Characters In Search Of An Author has inspired numerous other important plays and playwrights for almost a century.
Dementia examines how money and profit undermine social mores and human relationships.
THE festival's possibly most moving music event is Dirtsong (above) by Black Arm Band.

THIS special recital of Schubert's song cycle Winterreise (Winter Journey) is unmissable. Not only will it be played by Markus Hinterhauser and sung by Matthias Goerne, one of the world's finest baritones, but it will also be performed against a stunning backdrop of animated images created by the famous artist William Kentridge (above).

Cabanons by Daniel Buren and the Buren Cirque: Aerialists, tightrope walkers, acrobats, hoopers, jugglers, musicians and the ringmaster perform in three small-ish tents, each accommodating only about 150 people (above).

site_title: Bombardier to cut 1,750 jobs, pare output
summary: Bombardier Inc is cutting approximately 1,750 jobs as it reduces production of its Global 5000 and 6000 jets to align with shrinking demand from Russian oligarchs and Chinese billionaires. The company cited "softness" in Latin America, China, and Russia as factors for the production cuts, which build on the 1,000 jobs already eliminated in January.

site_title: Dollar hit by poor US retail sales data
summary: The US dollar fell to its weakest point against a basket of major currencies since January, driven by poor US April retail sales numbers. The euro surged past US$1.14, while sterling hit a six-month high of US$1.5815. Traders attributed the decline to stop-loss orders triggered by the weak sales data, which undermined expectations of a US economic recovery. The dollar index fell 0.6% to 93.175, while the yen and Australian dollar were also lower against the US currency.

site_title: Silverlake Axis Q3 net profit up 22%
summary: SILVERLAKE Axis reported a 22% rise in net profit to RM77 million for the third quarter ended March 2015, driven by a 70% growth in revenue from maintenance and enhancement services following the implementation of Goods and Services Tax (GST) in Malaysia. Revenue rose 5% to RM143 million, led by software project services. The company benefited from increased GST-related enhancement contracts from existing customers.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: UK experts urge US$2b global fund to develop antibiotics
summary: UK experts urge the global pharmaceutical industry to establish a $2 billion global innovation fund to develop new, effective antibiotics to combat rising resistance. The fund would help kickstart research into developing new antibiotics, with the goal of preventing 10 million deaths worldwide by 2050. Economist Jim O'Neill, author of the report, emphasizes the need for investment in antibiotic research to ensure the world has the necessary drugs to combat the growing threat of antimicrobial resistance.

site_title: Boogie-woogie in the Botanic Gardens
summary: Swiss-born pianist Nico Brina is set to perform at the Singapore Botanic Gardens as part of Zurich Insurance Group's SG50 celebrations. Brina, known for his unique ability to play the piano with his feet, nose, and hands while singing, will perform Elvis Presley's "All Shook Up" and other upbeat tracks. The free event, called the Zurich Blue Piano Experience, will take place on May 24 at 6pm and will feature fringe activities such as face-painting and giveaways. Admission is free, and the event is open to everyone.

site_title: India's bad loans may not have peaked yet: Rajan
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan stated that India's bad loans may not have peaked yet, despite a doubling of non-performing assets over the past three years. The central bank is working with lenders to recognize and resolve these assets, which has hindered lending to key sectors such as infrastructure. Rajan expressed frustration over banks' slow response to interest rate cuts, and emphasized the RBI's support for an independent public debt management agency, saying there is no disagreement with the government on the issue.

site_title: Oil price rout hits O&M firms in Q1
summary: Offshore and marine (O&M) firms are experiencing financial difficulties due to the decline in oil prices. Nam Cheong, an OSV builder, reported lower-than-expected earnings, prompting a downgrade from analysts. Swiber, an offshore engineering firm, sank into the red. The decline in Brent crude prices to below US$80 per barrel in November 2014 has led to a bloodletting in the industry. Analysts are warning of potential losses for O&M firms in the coming quarters.

site_title: Ex-bond king Bill Gross has something to prove
summary: Bill Gross, the former "bond king," has shifted his focus from managing a large portion of assets to less than 1% at Janus Capital after leaving Pimco, a US$2 trillion firm he co-founded. Despite his exceptional performance at Pimco, where his fund returned an average of 7.8% per year, Gross's performance at Janus has been disappointing. He aims to outperform the market on a daily basis and is exploring unconventional strategies, including arbitrage and leveraging derivatives. Gross, 71, says he wants to prove he still has the skills to manage a fund and prove himself in the financial world.

site_title: Property giants Vanke, Wanda join hands to do joint projects
summary: China's two largest property companies, Vanke and Wanda, have formed a strategic partnership to develop over 100 billion yuan (S$21 billion) of joint projects. The companies will buy land and develop mixed-use projects together, leveraging their respective strengths in commercial and residential real estate. The partnership aims to ease concerns among investors and boost gross margins for both companies. Wanda chairman Wang Jianlin stated that the partnership is not just about buying land and building Wanda Plazas, but about cooperation at a "deeper level" for massive projects.

site_title: Pressure mounts on Greece to make deal and avert default
summary: Greece is under pressure to reach a deal with creditors, including the eurozone and IMF, to avoid default and access more aid. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras is urging a meeting of finance ministers to consider an aid disbursement before the end of the month. The country's economy fell into recession in the first quarter, and officials are working to raise at least 3 billion euros to meet minimum budget targets. Disagreements remain over restructuring the social security system and making concessions to creditors, with Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis calling for a deal that leads to an economic recovery and exit from the crisis.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q1 profit slumps 73% to S$63m
summary: Genting Singapore's Q1 net profit plummeted 73% to S$62.7 million, down from S$228.5 million in the same period last year. Revenue declined 23% to S$639.2 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.52 Singapore cents from 1.87 cents. The firm attributed the decline to a weak premium gaming market. No dividend was recommended for the period.

site_title: En primeur and how to finish a good dinner
summary: The 2014 en primeur campaign for Bordeaux wines has begun, with prices ranging from 240 to 280 euros per bottle for top vintages. Lesser vintages mature earlier, offering a lower cost and savings for wine collectors. Buying a mix of great and lesser vintages, as well as different crus, is recommended for a balanced collection. The author suggests reconsidering the need for iconic, expensive wines, as there are now numerous excellent wines from various regions. Vintage port, a rare and elegant wine, is also discussed, with the 1966 Taylor's Vintage Port being highlighted as a great example.

site_title: Draghi: ECB policy potent so far
summary: Mario Draghi, ECB president, stated that the European Central Bank's non-standard measures have proven effective in rescuing the 19-nation economy. Despite low interest rates, Draghi said there is little indication of generalized financial imbalances emerging. The ECB has cut interest rates to a record-low 0.05% and implemented unconventional actions such as providing loans to banks and buying government bonds. Draghi believes structural reforms will make the ECB's policy more powerful and increase confidence in economic prospects.

site_title: Indian PM meets China's Xi on home ground
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Xi's ancestral home province of Shaanxi, highlighting ancient ties. The two discussed a simmering border dispute, as well as India's attempt to join the UN Security Council, and China's plans to invest in Pakistan. The visit aims to strengthen economic cooperation and attract foreign investment for India's infrastructure. Despite the meeting, ties between the two nations remain strained over the border dispute, with China accusing Modi of "playing little tricks" over security issues.

images.alt_text: Chinese President Xi Jinping welcomed Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to his ancestral home province Thursday, highlighting ancient ties as the Asian giants reportedly discussed a simmering border dispute.

site_title: Goldman Sachs, Indian developer to invest US$250m in real estate
summary: Goldman Sachs and Indian developer Nitesh Estates Ltd plan to invest $250 million in buying income-producing real estate assets in India. The investment comes as the country eases tax regulations to enable companies to set up and list real estate investment trusts (REITs). Goldman has already invested $37 million in a shopping center in Pune, India, marking the first investment by the joint venture. The investment is seen as a sign of the cyclical recovery in India, which is expected to boost GDP growth.

site_title: ThaiBev Q1 net profit up 10% on higher sales in all key businesses
summary: ThaiBev's Q1 net profit rose 10% to 6.6 billion baht, driven by higher sales in all key businesses, including spirits, beer, and non-alcoholic drinks. Sales grew 11% to 45.7 billion baht, with spirits and beer contributing significantly to the net profit. However, the company incurred a net loss in its non-alcoholic drinks segment due to heavy investment in product launches. The company's shares closed at 74.5 Singapore cents, up 0.7%.

site_title: Reliance turns to China to reprise cheap phone revolution in India
summary: Reliance Industries is in talks with Chinese manufacturers to produce affordable phones, targeting the Indian market. The company aims to replicate its successful low-cost revolution from over a decade ago. Reliance has spent $13 billion on its 4G service, Reliance Jio, and faces challenges without affordable devices. Chinese firms, including Gionee, Huawei, and Xiaomi, are also seeking a platform to expand their presence in India. Reliance's 4G service is set to launch in the coming months, marking its return to telecoms, and could be a game-changer in India's growing mobile market.

site_title: Takata offers to pay costs of recalls through installments
summary: Takata Corp is proposing to pay costs related to its recalled air bags through installment payments, allowing the company to avoid large upfront payments. This plan is being met with agreement from automakers, with Takata Chief Financial Officer Yoichiro Nomura stating that the company has sufficient cash flow. As of the financial year ended March, Takata has not breached conditions that would allow its banks to call back loans.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down 0.98%
summary: Tokyo stocks fell 0.98% on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 closing at 19,570.24 and the Topix index at 1,591.49, due to a stronger yen hurting exporters. This follows a disappointing US retail sales report and lackluster lead on Wall Street.

site_title: Hyflux Q1 net profit down 85% to S$5.6m on lack of divestment gains
summary: Hyflux, a water solutions firm, reported a net profit of S$5.6 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2015, down 85% from S$37.9 million a year ago. Revenue declined 32% to S$60.4 million, mainly due to lower engineering and construction activities. Lower other income, largely due to a lack of divestment gains, contributed to the decline. The company closed Thursday trading at 86.5 cents, down 1.5 cents or 1.7%.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Thursday

site_title: Greek finance minister calls for ECB debt payments to be pushed back
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis called for European Central Bank debt payments to be pushed back due to the country's unsustainable debt. site_title: SIA posts 47% rise in net profit for Q4
summary: Singapore Airlines reported a 47% year-on-year rise in net profit for the fourth quarter of FY14/15, reaching S$39.6 million. Revenue increased to S$3.88 billion, while earnings per share rose to 3.4 Singapore cents. The full-year net profit was S$367.9 million, a 2.3% increase. The board recommended a final dividend of 17 Singapore cents per share.

summary: European stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.41% to 6,921.22 points. Asian equities also retreated, with Tokyo taking the biggest hit as the yen advanced against the dollar. The decline followed below-forecast US data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end 0.14% higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.14% to 27,286.55 on Thursday, mirroring gains in Shanghai. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.34%, while Shanghai's composite index added 2.55 points.

site_title: CWT's Q1 profit down 16 per cent to S$29m
summary: CWT Ltd, a logistics and commodity group, reported a 16% drop in Q1 net profit to S$29.2 million due to a slowdown in trade services and lower commodity trading volume, resulting in a 59% plunge in revenue to S$1.87 billion. Start-up costs for new logistic hubs also contributed to the decline. Earnings per share stood at 4.87 cents, while net asset value was S$1.338 per ordinary share.

site_title: BoE's Carney says "possible" rates will be higher in a year
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney stated that it's possible interest rates may be higher in a year due to the economy's evolution. He emphasized that the central bank won't raise rates too quickly, as it could slow the economy. This statement was made in a BBC radio interview on May 14, 2015.

site_title: Jailed Chinese tycoon's gains reaching US$1b in rally
summary: Jailed Chinese tycoon Huang Guangyu's stake in Gome Electrical Appliances Holding Ltd has seen gains of nearly US$873 million, more than doubling its value since April, amid a surge in Hong Kong's stock market. Huang's wealth has doubled, but his company's performance is attributed to market perceptions rather than its actual performance. This is part of a broader market rally that has inflated the wealth of Asia's richest men, with some seeing their fortunes surge by as much as 45% this quarter.

site_title: Airports of Thailand Q2 net profit up on robust traffic
summary: Airports of Thailand reported a 32% increase in second-quarter net profit to 4.89 billion baht (US$145 million) due to robust air traffic during the peak tourist season. The company's net profit rose from 3.69 billion baht in the same period last year, driven by strong growth in tourist numbers, especially from China. The airport operator, which operates six major airports in Thailand, has enjoyed strong growth as tourist numbers rise.

site_title: Hitachi's annual profit down, points to surge this year
summary: Hitachi reported a 8.9% decline in annual net profit to 241.3 billion yen ($2.0 billion) due to a one-off surge in the previous year. However, operating profit rose 12% to 600.48 billion yen, driven by strong demand for lifts in China and auto parts and electronics products. The company forecasts a rebound this year, estimating a 310 billion yen net profit on sales of 9.95 trillion yen.

site_title: Greece risks deep recession if talks with creditors fail: EBRD
summary: Greece risks a major recession if it fails to reach an agreement with creditors, according to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). The country's economy is expected to show zero growth this year and expand by 2% in 2016 if Athens secures a deal with eurozone countries and the IMF. However, a failure to agree would plunge Greece into recession, undermining the improving outlook in Central Europe, and dampen growth forecasts for countries like Poland, Hungary, and Slovenia.

site_title: CapitaLand proposes to issue S$650m convertible bonds
summary: CapitaLand proposes to issue S$650 million convertible bonds, which can be converted into new shares, to be placed with institutional and accredited investors. The bonds will be issued with a lead manager and underwriter, J.P. Morgan (S.E.A.), and pricing is expected to take place on May 14, 2015. The company plans to use the proceeds mostly to refinance existing indebtedness and for working capital.

site_title: Raffles Education Q3 net profit slips 80%
summary: Raffles Education Corp reported a 80% decline in its Q3 net profit to S$4.7 million from S$23.8 million in the same period last year. Revenue remained flat at S$31.2 million. Earnings per share dropped to 0.47 Singapore cents from 2.32 Singapore cents. No dividend was recommended. The group attributed the decline to the exclusion of LangFang Oriental Institute of Technology's contribution in the previous year's Q3.

site_title: Haw Par Q1 profit up 10.6% on healthcare growth
summary: Haw Par Corp's first-quarter net profit rose 10.6% to S$13.5 million, driven by a 53.4% increase in healthcare operating profit to S$13.5 million. Revenue rose 18.6% to S$45.6 million, mainly due to healthcare turnover growth of 29%. However, leisure and property segments incurred losses, with sales from these segments down 28.5% and 7.6%, respectively. The company paints a mixed outlook for the next 12 months, citing benefits for healthcare but challenges for leisure.

site_title: Neo Group to buy 55% stake in surimi-based seafood supplier
summary: Neo Group, a Singapore-based food catering company, plans to buy a 55% stake in Thong Siek Holdings Pte Ltd, a seafood supplier, for S$7.35 million. The acquisition aims to enhance supply chain and manufacturing capabilities, with Neo Group to leverage Thong Siek's expertise to expand its operations globally. The deal is expected to create new business-to-consumers income streams and expand customer base, with a marketing office to be set up in the UK to target new markets.

site_title: Japan's loss-making Sharp says banks to provide US$1.7b bailout
summary: Japan's loss-making electronics company Sharp Corp has secured a $1.7 billion bailout from banks, including Mizuho Bank and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ, in a debt-for-equity swap. This move will allow Sharp to restructure and cut 10% of its global workforce, including 3,500 jobs in Japan, after reporting a net loss of $2.46 billion for the past financial year. The bailout is Sharp's second major rescue in three years, amid intense pricing pressure from Asian rivals.

site_title: China's fiscal spending jumps 33.2 pct year-on-year in April
summary: China's fiscal spending jumped 33.2% in April, exceeding expectations, as the government seeks to support a slowing economy. Total spending reached 1.25 trillion yuan ($201.57 billion), with increases in environmental protection, transportation, and social security. This follows a wider budget deficit set for 2015 and comes as economic growth slowed to a six-year low in the first quarter. Fiscal revenues rose 8.2% in April, driven by increases in domestic value-added tax and consumption taxes.

site_title: US to focus on Bank of England forex probe: report
summary: The US Department of Justice is set to scrutinize the Bank of England's inquiry into suspected rigging of foreign exchange markets, with a focus on what the central bank knew about traders' behavior. The DoJ has secretly requested an interview with Royal Bank of Scotland's former forex trading boss, James Pearson. Despite finding no evidence of staff collusion, a senior Bank of England official was suspended amid the probe. This development comes amid speculation that five banks, including RBS and Barclays, are close to a settlement with regulators over alleged forex market manipulation.

site_title: Growing supply to keep pressure on iron ore prices: BHP Billiton
summary: BHP Billiton expects a growing iron ore supply to outpace demand, putting pressure on prices. Global supply is estimated to rise between 100-110 million tonnes, while demand is expected to grow 30-40 million tonnes. This will keep prices below $60, down from a decade-low of $46.70 in April. The company plans to cut production costs by 21% and reduce spending to withstand a downturn in commodity prices. The outlook suggests that boosting earnings will not be dependent on restraining production, but rather on being the most efficient supplier.

site_title: CapitaLand to buy back convertible bonds to cut 'outstanding indebtedness'
summary: CapitaLand plans to repurchase S$1 billion of convertible bonds due 2022 for cash to reduce outstanding indebtedness and debt service obligations. The company also intends to repurchase S$1.3 billion and S$1.2 billion of convertible bonds due 2018 and 2016, respectively. The repurchases will be funded by proceeds from a planned S$650 million convertible bond issue, which may be upsized to S$800 million. The move aims to reduce the company's debt and improve its financial position.

site_title: Singapore: Mixed session in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,455.78, down 2.61 points, in a low-volume session. The index had drifted lower for most of the day, with volume at 1.5 billion units worth S$971 million. Despite this, the STI maintained a 0.4% gain on Thursday. Key stocks like Singtel and PSC were relatively unchanged, with Singtel receiving a "buy" rating from Nomura, citing its diversified business and decent dividend yield.

site_title: UK fund 3i emerges from restructuring with strong earnings
summary: UK private equity firm 3i emerged from a three-year restructuring with strong earnings growth, posting a full-year return on investment of 719 million pounds. Its net asset value rose 14% to 396 pence a share, despite a negative hit from currency fluctuations. 3i sold assets worth 831 million pounds and plans to rebalance its portfolio, targeting fewer than 40 companies. The company proposed a final dividend of 14 pence a share and expects to commit between 500-750 million euros to new investments annually.

site_title: Greece's Varoufakis says debt swap fills Draghi's "soul with fear"
summary: Greece's finance minister Yanis Varoufakis proposes a debt swap with the European Central Bank, pushing back 27 billion euros of bonds owed to the ECB. The proposal aims to alleviate ECB chief Mario Draghi's concerns, as it would not irritate Germany with a bond-buying program. However, the idea was initially met with a cool reception from euro zone partners, and Varoufakis's proposal now faces uncertainty, despite his government's efforts to focus on a cash-for-reforms deal with lenders.

images.alt_text: Repayment of what Greece owes to the European Central Bank should be pushed into the future, but it is not an option because it fills ECB chief Mario Draghi's"soul with fear", Greece's finance minister said on Thursday.

site_title: Battered US oil firms scramble to delay looming retirement wave
summary: The US oil industry is facing a looming retirement wave, with many baby boomer workers considering or already planning to retire due to the current downturn in the market. Energy firms are struggling to balance cost-cutting measures with the need to retain experienced scientists and engineers, who are essential for oil exploration and drilling. Industry data show that over 125,000 jobs have been cut worldwide since 2014, and the industry is bracing for a significant generational gap once the current workforce retires.

site_title: Hotel Grand Central Q1 net profit surges to S$76.6m on hotel sales in S'pore, NZ
summary: Hotel Grand Central reported a net profit of S$76.6 million for Q1 2015, a 769% increase from the previous year. The gain was attributed to the disposals of two hotels in Auckland and Singapore. Total revenue decreased 11% to S$33.8 million due to hotel sales and lower exchange rates. Earnings per share rose to 12.32 cents, while net asset value per share increased to S$1.50. The counter closed unchanged at S$1.50.

site_title: India awards Airbus US$1.9 billion military plane order
summary: India's defence ministry has agreed to purchase 56 Airbus C295 military transport aircraft for $1.87 billion, as part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to modernize the country's military. The deal was approved by the defence acquisition council, along with other orders worth $875 million. The aircraft will replace India's ageing fleet and are expected to be built jointly by Airbus and Tata Advanced Systems. This deal aims to reduce India's reliance on foreign defence imports and increase domestic manufacturing, with the goal of having 70% of hardware manufactured domestically by the decade.

site_title: NATO, EU work to tighten cooperation against 'new threats'
summary: NATO and the European Union are strengthening cooperation to counter "new threats" from Russia's assertive policies in the ex-USSR and violence in the south. EU foreign policy chief Federica Mogherini and NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg discussed tensions with Russia over Ukraine and the migrant crisis in Libya. They emphasized the need for information sharing and coordination, with Mogherini stating that NATO and EU are "different in nature" but share values. The two sides will discuss long-term strategic implications and hybrid warfare, with NATO aiming to deter and prevent hybrid threats.

site_title: Japan's Sharp to report US$1.6b loss, thousands of job cuts: reports
summary: Japanese electronics giant Sharp will announce a US$1.68 billion fiscal year loss and thousands of job cuts as it fights to stay afloat. The company's 200 billion yen loss is more than six times its earlier prediction, with up to 6,000 jobs, or 10% of its global workforce, at risk. Sharp will unveil a drastic capital reduction plan and may sell its headquarters building and accept a 200 billion yen rescue package from its banks to help wipe away years of losses.

site_title: NOL narrows loss in Q1 by cutting costs
summary: Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) reported a narrowed net loss of $10.78 million in Q1, down from $97.94 million the previous year. The shipping firm cut operational costs to alleviate the loss, with turnover falling 16% to $1.58 billion. NOL's liner business loss per share decreased to 1.40 US cents, while its discontinued logistics business generated earnings per share of 0.98 US cent. The group's net asset value per share was marginally less than 67 US cents.

site_title: Chinese airlines look inland for outbound opportunities
summary: Chinese airlines are expanding their global services to inland cities, offering flights to destinations like San Jose, Nairobi, and Sydney. Air China, China Eastern Airlines, and China Southern Airlines are adding routes to New York, Paris, and Sydney from cities such as Wuhan and Chengdu. The move is driven by China's growing outbound leisure travel market, which saw a record 100 million passengers last year, and is expected to rise 10% this year. The airlines are also increasing seats on China-US routes, surpassing American carriers for the first time.

site_title: CapitaLand halts trading pending an announcement

However, revenue increased 49.4% to S$915 million, driven by residential projects in Singapore and Vietnam. The halt comes after the company's previous quarterly results, which showed a 9.4% increase in net profit from continuing operations. The market is awaiting the announcement for further details.

site_title: Oil prices fall on weak China data
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on weak Chinese economic data, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate dropping 34 cents to $60.16 and Brent crude easing 25 cents to $66.56. The decline was attributed to weak data from China, including a 10.0% drop in retail sales and a 5.9% rise in industrial output, which fell short of economists' forecasts. Despite a larger-than-expected decline in US crude stockpiles, analysts say the global crude supply glut remains, driven by increased production from other producers.

site_title: Pacific Radiance's Q1 profit plunges 95%; revenue down 25%
summary: Pacific Radiance reported a 95% decline in Q1 net profit to US$902,000, down from US$17.83 million in the same period last year, due to a 25% decrease in revenue to US$31.54 million. The decline was mainly attributed to a 71% drop in subsea business revenue and a 13% decline in offshore support services business revenue. The company acknowledged challenging market conditions, but has experience managing such challenges in the oil and gas business cycle.

site_title: A US$750 billion gap in India's push for China-like infrastructure
summary: India's infrastructure sector faces a significant funding gap of US$750 billion, exceeding twice the size of Singapore's economy. The gap is largely due to the inability of current funding techniques to meet the requirement. The government is exploring alternative methods, including establishing more lenders, wooing private investors, and allowing private companies like India Infrastructure Finance Co Ltd to target a larger share of infrastructure loans. This is crucial for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's development agenda, which aims to invest US$1 trillion in infrastructure from 2012 to 2017.

site_title: QT Vascular narrows Q1 loss on firmer sales
summary: QT Vascular reported a narrower net loss of $5.6 million in Q1 2015, down from $9.2 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased 16.1% to $3.3 million, driven by higher sales of balloon catheters. The company sold 8,098 units, a 71.5% increase from last year. However, operating expenses rose 27.1% to $8.3 million, mainly due to increased research and development expenses. The company's cash balance decreased to $9.7 million, mainly due to litigation costs. The litigation case is unlikely to have a material impact on profitability.

site_title: Thai banks set for slower profit growth as consumers struggle to repay loans
summary: Thai banks are expected to experience slower profit growth due to a surge in bad loans, primarily from consumers struggling to repay loans on cars, homes, and electronics. Household debt in Thailand has reached a record 85.9% of GDP, and a stagnant economy has led to decreased consumer confidence. Analysts predict a decline in combined net profit for Thailand's eight biggest banks to 4-6% this year, down from earlier estimates of 9-10%. The economy's growth is expected to be around 3.7% this year, but downside risks, including potential economic contraction and reduced consumer spending, may impact the outlook.

images.alt_text: A Krung Thai Bank Plc ATM in downtown Bangkok. site_title: Honda to recall 4.8m more cars globally for Takata air bags
summary: Honda Motor Co. announced a global recall of 4.8 million cars to replace potentially fatal air bag inflators made by Takata Corp, following similar recalls by Toyota and Nissan. This is the largest automotive recall to date, linked to six deaths. The defective air bags can erupt with too much force, spraying shrapnel inside the car. Honda has borne the brunt of the recalls, and the company will replace the air bag inflators to ensure passenger safety.

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 8.7 points higher
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 8.7 points, or 0.25%, to 3,461.87, driven by gains from Great Eastern Holding, DBS Group Holdings, and Challenger. 41.8 million shares worth S$61.3 million traded, with gainers outnumbering losers 88 to 44. site_title: CITIC Securities' teams up with China Renaissance to serve Internet firms
summary: CITIC Securities, China's largest brokerage, is partnering with boutique investment bank China Renaissance to provide merger and acquisition, restructuring, and IPO services for internet firms. The partnership aims to develop new revenue sources as Beijing plans to allow commercial banks to own brokerage licenses, increasing competition. China Renaissance, which handled $4.4 billion in Chinese domestic M&A deals last year, will also help with OTC and A-share listings, as well as financial product development.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open 0.52% lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.52% lower on Thursday, as the yen strengthened against the dollar, negatively impacting Japanese exporters. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 103.20 points to 19,661.52. The dollar remained weak after falling on a poor US retail sales report.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened 0.52 per cent lower on Thursday as the yen strengthened in a negative move for Japanese exporters.

site_title: China's ICBC, Brazil's Caixa to start US$50 billion fund
summary: China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) and Brazil's Caixa Econômica Federal will create a US$50 billion fund for Brazilian infrastructure investments, to be financed entirely by ICBC. The fund will support projects such as a railway link from Brazil's Atlantic coast to Peru and a steel production joint-venture. The plan, set to be announced during Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's visit to Brazil next week, follows China's pledge of US$250 billion in investment in Latin America over the next 10 years.

site_title: Wal-Mart to challenge Amazon Prime with US$50 shipping service
summary: Wal-Mart is launching a US$50-a-year unlimited free-shipping service, targeting Amazon Prime, which offers similar benefits. The service will be available by invitation only in select markets, offering over 1 million items for 3-day delivery. This move aims to improve customer service and compete with Amazon in e-commerce, where the company has been trying to make inroads.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close mixed despite bright growth data
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed mixed on Wednesday despite solid first quarter economic growth in the eurozone, with France outpacing Germany. Paris' CAC 40 index fell 0.26%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 declined 1.05%. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.23% driven by upbeat British unemployment data. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks propelling shares, while US-EU trade talks were a focus.

site_title: Cosmosteel's Q2 profit tumbles 88%, outlook challenging on slower orders from energy sector
summary: Cosmosteel Holdings reported a 88% decline in Q2 net profit to S$267,000, down from S$2.2 million last year. Revenue fell 22% to S$33.2 million, with the energy sector accounting for 76.5% of total revenue. Cosmosteel remains cautious about its outlook for the rest of the year, expecting challenging revenue generation and pressure on gross profit margins.

summary: Swiber Holdings, a global EPIC services provider, reported a net loss of US$1.3 million for Q1 2015, down from a net profit of US$48 million a year ago.
