summary: Asian markets declined on Thursday following below-forecast US retail sales data, with Tokyo taking the biggest hit as the yen advanced against the dollar. The euro, however, gained ground after eurozone economy data showed growth, beating expectations. US growth remains slow, making a Federal Reserve interest rate rise unlikely. The euro pushed up to $1.1355 and 135.36 yen against the dollar, while the yen strengthened against the dollar, reaching 119.15 yen per dollar.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust's Q3 DPU up 8% at 1.9 cents
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.9 Singapore cents for its Q3 2015, an 8% increase from the previous year. Net property income (NPI) rose 24.5% to 1.16 billion yen, driven by a 42.4% surge in gross revenue. The trust expects to generate robust cash flows in the next reporting period and 12 months. The outlook for Japan's retail industry remains positive, with the government's inflation drive expected to stimulate the economy.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.2 points to 1,806.22 points on Thursday, driven by a 116-52 gainers-to-losers ratio. Volume reached 32.8 million lots worth RM 16.4 million.

site_title: Sheng Siong gets nod to operate supermarkets in China
summary: Sheng Siong Group, a Singapore supermarket chain, has received Chinese approvals to operate supermarkets in China through a joint venture with Kunming LuChen Group. The venture, Sheng Siong (China) Supermarket Co, Ltd, has a US$10 million registered capital and will be 60% owned by Sheng Siong, 30% by LuChen Group, and 10% by Tan Ling San, an executive director of Sheng Siong. This marks a promising diversification opportunity for Sheng Siong into China's large market.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Lum Chang in deal to acquire Jersey unit trust for £51.32m
summary: Construction firm Lum Chang Holdings has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire a full stake in a Jersey unit trust for £51.32m. The unit trust owns a single asset, a fully leased commercial property in London. The deal was facilitated by two special-purpose vehicles in Jersey, through Lum Chang's 70% owned subsidiary, UK Property Investment. The acquisition is expected to be completed once regulatory approvals are received.

site_title: China aims to boost Internet speeds, cut prices
summary: China's State Council announced plans to accelerate broadband network development, aiming to increase urban speeds by 40% and cut prices. This move is expected to boost internet speeds and accessibility, potentially benefiting global network equipment makers and home-grown players like Huawei Technologies Co Ltd.

site_title: Loyz Energy reports US$100,000 profit for Q3
summary: Loyz Energy reported a net profit of US$100,000 for its Q3, surpassing the net loss of US$3.11 million in the same period last year. Revenue surged to US$4.7 million, driven by the sale of crude oil from its Thailand concessions. The company expects significant growth from its Thailand fields and aims to deliver Ebitdax of US$12 million for the financial year ending June 30, 2015.

site_title: Safety crisis grows as Toyota, Nissan expand recalls
summary: Japan's three biggest carmakers, Toyota and Nissan, are expanding recalls of at least 6.5 million vehicles due to faulty air bags that can send shrapnel into passengers. Toyota will recall 5 million cars from 2003-2007, while Nissan will recall 1.56 million cars. The recalls add to over 17 million vehicles recalled since 2008 for similar issues. Regulators in Japan and the US are investigating Takata air-bag inflators that can deploy with excessive force. The latest recalls deepen the global automotive industry's safety crisis.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp will recall about 5 million more cars involving 35 models manufactured from March 2003 to November 2007, after finding air-bag inflators in Japan that could be susceptible to abnormal deployment in a crash, according to an e-mail from the company.

site_title: India gold demand likely to rise in Q2 on lower prices, festival buying: WGC
summary: India's gold demand is expected to increase in Q2 due to lower prices and robust economic growth, with the World Gold Council predicting an improvement over the first quarter. The festival of Akshaya Tritiya will boost buying, with sales increasing by 15% on that day alone. India's jewellery demand rose 22% to 150.8 tonnes in the January-March quarter, while investment demand fell to a six-year low. India's total gold demand rose 15% to 192 tonnes in the first quarter, surpassing China's 273 tonnes, and is expected to reach 900-1,000 tonnes in 2015.

site_title: Now for the clean-up: China crafts plan for local-debt mess
summary: China's regulators have crafted a plan to address the local-debt mess that resulted from the 2015 credit boom. The plan involves swapping high-yielding, short-term loans for lower-cost, longer-term municipal debt, with the goal of reducing the central government's debt-to-GDP ratio. Officials are offering inducements to banks to take on the new bonds, aiming to avoid a nationalization of borrowing. This move aims to stabilize the local government financing and alleviate pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China: Stocks fluctuate as traders weigh policy easing prospects
summary: Chinese stocks fluctuated as investors weighed the prospect of policy easing after data missed economists' estimates. Technology and telecom companies gained, while property developers slumped. The Shanghai Composite Index added 0.2% to 4,383.56. ZTE Corp. led a rally for phone companies, while Tencent Holdings Ltd. reported a record profit. The data showed fixed-asset investment slowed to its weakest pace in over 14 years, and new loans plunged.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks swung between gains and losses as investors weighed the prospect of more policy easing after monetary data missed economists' estimates.

site_title: Toshiba says to mark down reported profit for three years
summary: Toshiba Corp reported it will mark down its operating profit for three years by at least 50 billion yen due to an internal probe into accounting irregularities. The investigation found under-reported building costs and inadequately booked losses from construction work. The company's shares rose 5% and its American Depositary Receipts surged 12% after the announcement, soothing investors' fears of a major scandal. Toshiba has delayed its quarterly earnings announcement and canceled a year-end dividend, with financial results now expected until June or later.

site_title: Britain's Labour to name new leader in September
summary: Britain's Labour Party will name its new leader on September 12 after Ed Miliband resigned following the party's election defeat. Nominations will close on June 15, with candidates including Liz Kendall, Chuka Umunna, Andy Burnham, and Yvette Cooper. The party faces divisions over its left-wing campaign, with former prime minister Tony Blair's supporters criticizing Miliband's approach. The new leader will be in place for the party's annual conference on September 27.

site_title: Nam Cheong's Q1 profit falls 45% on weaker revenue from shipbuilding, chartering
summary: Nam Cheong, a Malaysian shipbuilder, reported a 45% decline in Q1 profit to RM39.3 million, due to weaker revenue from shipbuilding and chartering. Revenue fell 20% to RM326.3 million, with shipbuilding generating RM310.7 million and vessel chartering RM15.6 million. The company's order book stood at RM1.6 billion as of March 31.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Indian PM Modi leaves for China with trade on mind
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi left for China on an official visit to boost trade ties between the two Asian superpowers, setting aside historic mistrust. Modi will focus on foreign investment in India's crumbling rail and infrastructure during his three-day trip, which includes stops in Xian, Beijing, and Shanghai. This visit aims to deliver on election promises and enhance economic cooperation between the two nations.

images.alt_text: In this photograph taken on September 18, 2014, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi (right) shakes hands with Chinese President Xi Jinping during a meeting in New Delhi. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi will visit China next week, Beijing said on May 5, 2015, as New Delhi tries to balance its trade deficit with its neighbour despite a simmering border dispute.

site_title: LVMH's Sephora launches China online store
summary: Sephora, a subsidiary of LVMH, launched its first online store in China on JD.com, a move to tap into the country's booming e-commerce market. The cosmetics chain chose JD.com due to its focus on fighting counterfeit goods, a significant issue in China's online retail market. Sephora will be the largest cosmetics store on JD.com, and the company plans to partner with other e-commerce platforms in the future.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing activity slows in April
summary: New Zealand manufacturing activity slowed in April, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) falling to 51.8 from 54.6 in the previous month. The decline was attributed to a sharp rise in the New Zealand dollar against the Australian dollar. Despite this, all five sub-indices showed expansion, with employment rising during the month.

site_title: BMW one big, happy family as squabbles damage rival Volkswagen
summary: BMW's Quandt family praises the company's successful management transition as rival Volkswagen faces turmoil. The Quandts, who control 47% of BMW, welcomed Harald Krueger as CEO, contrasting their smooth succession process with Volkswagen's leadership crisis. Volkswagen's Ferdinand Piech was ousted as chairman, and his influence is waning, amid speculation he may sell down his stake. Meanwhile, BMW's outgoing CEO Norbert Reithofer received praise for his nine-year tenure, which saw sales and revenue rise significantly.

site_title: India learns to "fail fast" as tech start-up culture takes root
summary: India's tech start-up culture is embracing the "fail fast" approach, similar to Silicon Valley's, allowing for creativity and success. This shift comes as high-achieving children are now expected to take risks and accept failure as a normal part of entrepreneurship. With billions of dollars in venture fund investment, India's $150 billion tech industry is transitioning from a back-office powerhouse to a creative force, marking a major cultural shift in the country. This acceptance of failure is seen as a key factor in India's growing tech industry.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as retail equities drop
summary: US stocks remained flat on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 slipping, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose. Retail sales report showed no change in April sales, and Macy's earnings missed expectations, causing other retailers to drop. Facebook unveiled a deal with news publishers, while Danaher announced a planned split into two companies. Pipeline company Williams acquired Williams Partners and hiked its dividend, driving its shares up 22.7%.

site_title: BI to stick to data in deciding any rate cuts
summary: Bank Indonesia will consider loosening monetary policy if inflation and the current account deficit are under control. The central bank will be data-dependent in its decisions, following recent government comments that the country should cut rates gradually. Governor Agus Martowardojo aims to maintain a tight monetary stance, while Vice-President Jusuf Kalla has suggested gradual rate cuts. The bank's policy decision will be released on May 19, balancing economic support with inflation control and a persistent current account shortfall.

site_title: StanChart seeking buyers for US$350m Hong Kong pension business
summary: Standard Chartered is seeking buyers for its US$350m Hong Kong pension business, marking its second sale in less than six months. The sale, not part of the bank's restructuring, aims to offer better services to clients. The new owner will receive a 15-year distribution agreement, and the sale is expected to be completed in the near future as the bank prepares for new CEO Bill Winters.

site_title: Indonesia extends landmark logging moratorium
summary: Indonesia has extended its two-year moratorium on logging in primary or virgin forests and peatlands, protecting an area of around 43 million hectares. The ban, which was initially signed in 2011, aims to preserve the country's vast tropical rainforest and combat climate change. However, environmental groups criticized the extension, saying it still allows deforestation for strategic national projects and does not strengthen protection for other types of forests. The logging ban has become the world's third-biggest carbon emitter due to palm oil, mining, and timber companies.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has extended a landmark moratorium aimed at preserving the archipelago's vast swathes of tropical rainforest, but environmentalists said Thursday the logging ban did not go far enough.

site_title: UK online fashion retailer Farfetch snaps up London's Browns
summary: Farfetch, a UK-based online fashion retailer valued at US$1 billion, has acquired London's upmarket retailer Browns in a cash and shares deal. The move aims to combat parallel trading, where luxury brands are resold online by consumers, by partnering with official distributors. Farfetch's sales are expected to rise to over US$500 million this year, driven by growing interest from investors in the fast-expanding online fashion sector, particularly among Millennials.

site_title: Hong Kong stock up 0.38% at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.38% to 27,351.63 at open, mirroring Shanghai's 0.26% gain. Despite a soft lead from New York, the Hang Seng Index remained steady.

site_title: KrisEnergy's Q1 profit swings to US$46.3m, from one-off gains
summary: KrisEnergy's Q1 profit surged to US$46.3 million, up from a net loss of US$17.97 million in the previous year, due to one-off gains from acquisitions. Revenue fell 46.1% to US$11.42 million due to lower oil prices. The global oil market outlook remains challenging, according to the company.

site_title: UK surveyors report biggest house price rises since August
summary: UK house prices rose at their fastest rate since August, with a +33 balance in April, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. This marks the first time since August that prices are rising in all regions. However, the supply of homes coming on to the market fell at its fastest rate since May 2009. RICS urges the government to directly support home-building, calling the affordability crisis a "national emergency."

site_title: Korea's fuel-cell strategy takes page from China solar playbook
summary: South Korea is investing heavily in fuel-cell technology, mirroring China's successful solar panel strategy. Conglomerates like Doosan Corp and Posco are buying or partnering with US fuel-cell makers to develop cheaper production methods. The goal is to make fuel cells more economical for industrial and commercial use, with the aim of becoming a major player in the global market. South Korea's efforts could help the US fuel-cell industry, which has struggled to become profitable.

site_title: Weak start to US spending this quarter may delay Fed liftoff
summary: US retail sales barely budged in April, defying projections for a small increase, with a 0.2% drop from January through March. This weak start to spending may delay the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike, with economists now projecting the first increase could occur in September instead of mid-year. The sluggish spending and economic growth performance cast doubts on the Fed's ability to justify policy tightening, with the median forecast of economists suggesting a later start to liftoff.

site_title: Singtel's Q4 profit grows 4.5% at S$939m
summary: Singtel's Q4 net profit rose 4.5% to S$939m, driven by growth in customers and data services at its regional mobile associates. Revenue increased 5.1% to S$4.34 billion. The company declared a final ordinary dividend of 10.7 cents, bringing the total dividend per share to 17.5 cents. CEO Chua Sock Koong attributed the performance to strong execution of core business and aspirations to become a significant global player in cyber security.

site_title: Mega property deals return as US real estate offers haven
summary: US commercial real estate transactions surged 45% in dollar volume in the first quarter, driven by large deals and foreign capital pouring in. The largest property purchase since the financial crisis was General Electric's $23 billion sale to Blackstone Group and Wells Fargo. Foreign investors, including sovereign-wealth funds, are seeking a haven and driving prices for top buildings in cities like New York and San Francisco to record highs. The market's growth is expected to continue, with the second quarter potentially being the biggest on record for property transactions.

site_title: Oil dips as US refineries slowdown stirs demand worries
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday, despite a significant decline in US crude inventories, due to concerns about weak demand. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate fell 25 cents to $60.50 a barrel, while Brent North Sea crude dropped 5 cents to $66.81 a barrel. A slowdown at refineries, operating at 91.2% of capacity, raised worries about demand, despite the approach of the US summer vacation season. Oil prices have dropped 45% since June due to high US supplies and weak global economic growth.

site_title: A work in progress for UN Security Council seat
summary: Kazakhstan is running for a two-year non-permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council, its first bid. The country is competing against Thailand for the years 2017 and 2018, with issues of non-proliferation, energy, water, and food security at the forefront of its candidacy. Kazakhstan has a strong track record of involvement in UN activities, including nuclear disarmament, human rights, and counter-terrorism. Its commitment to sustainable development and millennium goals is also seen as a key factor in its bid.

site_title: Airbus wins US$1.87b Indian military order for cargo planes
summary: India agreed to purchase 56 transport aircraft from Airbus for $1.87 billion, replacing its aging Avro fleet. The C-295 planes will be jointly built with Tata Advanced Systems Ltd and manufactured in Europe and India. The order is part of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to modernize the military, with total military projects valued at over $40 billion. Other approved orders include BAE Systems howitzers, BrahMos cruise missiles, and Russian Kamov helicopters, as well as the construction of India's second domestically built aircraft carrier.

images.alt_text: India agreed to buy 56 transport aircraft from Airbus Group NV for 119.3 billion rupees (US$1.87 billion) to replace an aging fleet, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks to modernize the country's military.

site_title: Rush of Chinese money on HK bourse brings tax windfall
summary: Hong Kong's taxman collected a record HK$400 million daily in April from trading duties, largely due to a surge of Chinese money into the city's stocks. The daily turnover on the Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd's equity markets hit a record HK$291.5 billion. The increased tax revenue helped prompt the government to revise its budget and hand out tax rebates, with a potential return of HK$20,000 to every taxpayer. The government is also planning to expand a trading link between Shanghai and Hong Kong.

images.alt_text: The taxman collected HK$400 million (S$68.7 million) a day in April from trading duties as daily turnover on Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd's equity markets surged to a record HK$291.5 billion, according to calculations by Bloomberg.

site_title: Bond rout leaves bears on wrong side of central banks
summary: The global bond market has experienced its largest two-year rout, with investors facing a challenging situation as central banks show no signs of increasing interest rates. Despite a $433 billion loss in international debt markets and rising yields, central banks in the US, Europe, and Japan continue to conduct quantitative easing. Economists, including those at JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank, believe the market volatility is driven by fear rather than a change in economic fundamentals, and that monetary policy will remain loose to support global growth.

site_title: Cathay Life buys Walbrook Building in biggest London office deal this year
summary: Cathay Life Insurance Co. has purchased the Walbrook Building in London's financial district for £575 million (S$1.2 billion), the largest single-property deal in the UK capital this year. The 410,000 sq ft office space and 35,000 sq ft stores and restaurants were previously owned by Minerva Ltd, acquired by Ares Management LP and Delancey Real Estate Asset Management Ltd. The deal boosts London's landlord profits amid a shortage of office space, with vacancy rates at their lowest since 2001.

site_title: Indonesia's Mulia Group buys land from 1MDB
summary: Indonesia's Mulia Group has agreed to pay RM665 million (S$245 million) for a plot of land and development rights to a landmark tower in Kuala Lumpur's Tun Razak Exchange (TRX), owned by 1MDB. This deal comes after Tabung Haji, another state-linked company, dropped its bid for the tower due to public outcry. The sale is part of 1MDB's efforts to offload assets due to its financial struggles, with debts totaling RM42 billion.

site_title: SATS reports higher Q4 and full-year profits
summary: SATS, a food solutions provider, reported a 21.1% increase in Q4 net profit to S$51.6 million, driven by a 8.5% rise in full-year net profit to S$195.7 million. Revenue declined 1.9% to S$1.75 billion in the full year, while Q4 revenue fell 5.8% to S$425.1 million, largely due to weaker results from its Japan subsidiary and the divestment of an Australian subsidiary.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

Food solutions provider SATS reported on Thursday that its net profit for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2015, rose 21.1 per cent to S$51.6 million, compared to S$42.6 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: Facebook dives deep into news with publisher deal
summary: Facebook has launched "Instant Articles," a feature that allows news publishers to deliver articles directly to readers, potentially reshaping the news landscape. The service, launched with partners including The New York Times, National Geographic, and The Guardian, hosts news items on its servers to provide faster access. Publishers can sell ads in the articles and track traffic, while Facebook maintains control over the content. Critics argue that the move gives Facebook too much control over news, while supporters see it as a way for news organizations to adapt to the digital shift and innovate their business models.

site_title: Shrinking Russia jet fleet threatens Airbus-Boeing order backlog
summary: Russia's fleet of Airbus and Boeing jets is shrinking for the first time in 15 years due to economic contraction and sanctions. The number of planes deployed by Russian airlines declined by 11 jets between August and April 1, with passenger numbers falling 2.3% to 17 million. Airlines are curtailing capacity, and manufacturers like Airbus and Boeing are working to defer deliveries or offer sale-leaseback deals to boost cash flow. The decline in demand is expected to impact orders for long-range aircraft, such as the Boeing 747-8 and Airbus A380, and may lead to order cancellations if the economy continues to stutter.

site_title: Brazil looking to China for investment, trade
summary: Brazil is seeking Chinese investment in its infrastructure, particularly in railroads, highways, ports, and airports, as the country prepares to host the 2016 Olympics. Chinese Prime Minister Li Keqiang will meet with Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff to discuss investments and trade. China has been Brazil's largest trading partner since 2009, with bilateral trade reaching $83.3 billion in 2013. However, demand for Brazilian commodities has declined, putting pressure on the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: Brazil signalled on Wednesday it will look to China for major investments in its infrastructure as it prepares to host next year's Olympics amid an economic slump.

site_title: Forex losses, interest costs in Q1 drag Vard into the red
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-based shipbuilder, reported a net loss of 92 million Norwegian kroner (S$16.4 million) in the first quarter due to foreign exchange losses and higher interest expenses. Revenue rose 14.6% to 3.06 billion kroner, but Ebitda margin dropped to 2.1% due to weaker operating performance. The company's order book value declined to 15.63 billion kroner, and new vessel contracts were not secured during the quarter. Vard attributed the decline to a challenging market environment and increased counter-party risk. The company is implementing a cost-cutting program to address the challenges.

site_title: US train engineer slammed on emergency brakes before crash
summary: A US passenger train derailed in Philadelphia on Tuesday, killing at least seven people and injuring over 200. The train was traveling at 170km/h, more than twice the approved limit, when the engineer slammed on the emergency brakes, but the train still derailed. The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is investigating the cause of the crash, which occurred at a curve where a speed control system was not in place. The engineer's full emergency brake application only slowed the train by 6km/h, highlighting the difficulty of stopping a train quickly.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties' Q4 profit plunges 34.5% to US$105m
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 34.5% decline in Q4 net profit to US$104.86 million due to higher non-controlling interests, lower EBIT, and higher income-tax expense. Revenue increased 6.2% to US$166.76 million. For the year, net profit dropped 29% to US$486.2 million, while revenue rose 13.3% to US$708.01 million. Despite near-term challenges, GLP remains optimistic about medium- and long-term logistics market dynamics and its market-leading positions.

site_title: Sterling retreats from 5-month high
summary: The British pound retreated from a five-month high after the Bank of England lowered its growth forecasts for Britain to 2.4% and reduced interest rate projections, citing the currency's strength. The pound fell to a low of US$1.5635, down 0.1% on the day. The euro remained steady, supported by a narrowing yield gap between Bunds and US Treasuries. The Bank of England's dovish stance prompted heavy selling in the pound, with investors awaiting a potential interest rate hike in the middle of 2016.

site_title: ADB-AIIB amity hints at change in architecture of financing
summary: Asian Development Bank (ADB) President Takehiko Nakao hinted at a potential deal with the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) that could alter the architecture of international financial institutions. During the ADB annual meeting in Baku, Nakao and AIIB Vice-President Jin Liqun pledged cooperation and discussed concrete options for collaboration. The ADB may consider a "special capital increase" for emerging-economy members like China, which could grant them a bigger say in the bank's governance. This move could lead to China's increased involvement in the ADB and potentially shift the balance of power among global development institutions.

site_title: Dollar falls, euro rises in tale of two data signals
summary: The US dollar fell after a weak US retail sales report, while the euro gained strength due to improving eurozone economic data. The US retail sales report showed stagnated consumption in April, missing analyst estimates, and year-over-year growth was the weakest since 2009. In contrast, the eurozone's economic growth strengthened to 0.4% quarter-over-quarter in the first quarter, driven by the European Central Bank's bond-buying program and lower oil prices. The dollar's decline may hinder the Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates this year.

site_title: BOE sees inflation rising, leading to higher interest rates next year
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) expects inflation to rise in coming months, leading to higher interest rates in 12 months. The BOE reduced its real growth forecasts to 2.5% this year and 2.6% in 2016, citing poor first-quarter growth and uncertainty over the UK general election. Despite this, the bank expects growth to rebound to 0.7% in the second quarter and maintain its 2% inflation target. The BOE's monetary policy committee voted to maintain the bank rate at 0.5%, but Governor Mark Carney hinted at possible rate hikes in 2016 if inflation picks up.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q1 earnings dip 5.3%
summary: ST Engineering reported a 5.3% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$129.97 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015, due to headwinds in its US shipbuilding operations. Revenue dipped 2.6% to S$1.51 billion, with lower contributions from aerospace, electronics, and marine businesses. Despite this, the company expects to achieve comparable revenue and profit before tax for FY2015.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Concur moves Asia-Pac HQ to Singapore
summary: Concur, a US-based travel management company, has relocated its Asia-Pacific headquarters to Singapore to capitalize on the region's large business travel market. The company, which employs about 2,000 staff, sees opportunities in Singapore, India, Hong Kong, and other South-east Asian markets. Concur expects its growth in Asia to be driven by Singapore and the region, with China being the most promising market in the long term. The company's expansion aims to leverage cloud technology and travel-management software to provide clients with greater visibility and transparency, resulting in cost savings and improved decision-making.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Landslide victory paves way for reforms
summary: Kazakhstan's President Nursultan Nazarbayev secured a landslide victory with 97.7% of the vote in a snap election, marking his fifth consecutive term. The elections came after a proposal by the Kazakhstan Parliament to bring forward the presidential elections from 2016. Nazarbayev outlined his focus on implementing reforms, including the Nurly Zhol policy, to strengthen the country's economy and address external challenges. He announced the creation of a National Modernisation Commission to oversee the implementation of five institutional reforms, aiming to strengthen Kazakhstan and join the top 30 developed countries.

site_title: Honda joins Toyota, Nissan in air bag recall
summary: Honda joins Toyota and Nissan in a global air bag recall, covering 6.56 million vehicles with Takata-made inflators. The recall comes as Japan and US regulators investigate the issue. Toyota will recall 5 million cars, while Nissan will notify customers in June. Honda will also recall its vehicles without specifying the number.

site_title: Future of 2 unions hangs in the balance
summary: The UK's Conservative Party victory has increased the likelihood of the country leaving the EU and potentially breaking up the UK, reducing Britain's global influence. This shift in power could have lasting implications for Britain's role in the world, particularly in the context of European and UK unions.

site_title: Ezion net falls 9% to US$41m in Q1
summary: Ezion, a Singapore-based service rig owner, reported a 9% decline in Q1 earnings to US$41 million, below expectations. Despite this, shares rose 1.5 S cents to S$1.22 on 17.7 million shares traded, indicating analysts believe the company's outlook remains brighter than its peers in the downbeat offshore support industry.

images.alt_text: Service rig owner Ezion still appears to have a brighter outlook than its peers in the downbeat offshore support industry even though its first-quarter earnings came in below expectations, analysts said on Wednesday.

site_title: IMF: S'pore restructuring raises wages but curbs growth
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has revised Singapore's economic forecast, predicting an average growth of 2.5-3% in 2015, lower than its initial range of 2-4%. The restructuring of Singapore's economy has led to a permanent increase in real wages, but it continues to curb growth due to global financial volatility and China's slowdown. The IMF highlights external risks, including elevated household and corporate debt levels, and notes that Singapore's strong fundamentals, such as a strong external position and large fiscal buffers, can help absorb shocks.

site_title: Choppy waters for insurance sector but risks now better managed
summary: The insurance industry has become more stable, despite declining returns, since the global financial crisis. A senior representative from the Geneva Association notes that slower global growth and low interest rates may lead to industry consolidation. This could be driven by firms in the property and casualty insurance line, as chairman of Axis Capital Holdings Michael Butt suggests.

images.alt_text: While returns are declining, the insurance industry has become significantly more stable in the years since the global financial crisis, said a senior representative of the Geneva Association, a high-powered insurance think tank.

site_title: AEF to focus on infrastructure
summary: The Astana Economic Forum (AEF) will take place from May 21-22 with a focus on "Infrastructure: driver of sustainable economic growth". The eighth edition of the major international forum will bring together thousands of participants from over 150 countries, including business leaders, policy officials, and Nobel Prize laureates. The event is held with the support and participation of Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbayev.

site_title: China mulls oil asset spinoffs as part of reforms: sources
summary: China is considering spinning off its biggest energy companies' oil and gas pipelines into independent businesses as part of sweeping industry reforms. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has held talks with pipeline owners and utilities since last year. The move aims to increase efficiency and competitiveness in the industry. Details of the plan, including the companies involved and timeline, are not publicly available. The reforms are part of broader efforts to modernize China's energy sector.

site_title: Knight Frank promotes two key personnel
summary: Knight Frank Singapore has promoted Low Kin Hon to deputy group managing director and Ian Loh to executive director as part of its succession planning. Low Kin Hon, with 30 years of valuation experience, will oversee the valuation department alongside Danny Yeo and Tan Tiong Cheng. Despite the challenging real estate environment due to cooling measures, Low Kin Hon is confident the company will adapt and grow. Both promotions are part of a group of key personnel being groomed to take over the company when veteran head honchos retire.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: WHO findings on weed killer will not speed up EU safety review
summary: European Union regulators will not accelerate a decision on restricting the use of glyphosate, the active ingredient in Roundup, despite the World Health Organization's (WHO) classification of it as "probably carcinogenic to humans". The EU's safety review will proceed as scheduled, despite the WHO's findings, which link glyphosate to cancer.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Global Logistic Properties, SATS, KrisEnergy, UOB-Kay Hian
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore stocks to watch include Singtel, Global Logistic Properties, SATS, KrisEnergy, and UOB-Kay Hian. Singtel reported steady net profit of S$939 million in Q4 2015, while Global Logistic Properties' net profit plummeted 34.5% to US$104.86 million. SATS' net profit rose 21.1% to S$51.6 million. KrisEnergy's net profit surged to US$46.3 million, despite lower revenue. UOB-Kay Hian's net profit grew 0.8% to S$18 million. The outlook for the global oil market remains challenging, with KrisEnergy acknowledging the decline in global oil prices.

images.alt_text: Singapore Telecommunications (Singtel) on Thursday announced that net profit for the fourth quarter ended March 31, 2015, held steady at S$939 million.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ST Engineering reports net profit of S$130 million, down 5.3% from the previous year, with core earnings falling 2.2%. The company maintains its full-year guidance, but expects a decline in profit before tax. Wing Tai Holdings sees strong sales and maintains its "buy" rating, citing its deep value and potential for a lifting of cooling measures. Singapore Post reports a 12% year-over-year revenue rise, driven by acquisitions, but notes near-term earnings growth will be tempered by developmental expenses.

site_title: BreadTalk's Q1 net profit rises 11%
summary: BreadTalk Group reported an 11% increase in Q1 net profit to S$2.0 million, driven by revenue growth in all divisions. The bakery division saw a 11.3% rise in revenue, while the restaurant division's revenue grew 13.2% due to improved performance from Din Tai Fung. Earnings per share increased to 0.71 Singapore cents, up from 0.64 cents last year. No dividend was recommended for the period.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Oxley's Q3 earnings soar to S$11.9m; revenue up 48% at S$152m
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a net profit of S$11.9 million for the third quarter ended March 2015, up from S$1.02 million a year ago, driven by a 48% increase in revenue to S$152.2 million. The company has launched 30 projects and completed 13, with total unbilled revenue at S$3.26 billion. Despite a 49% drop in revenue for the nine-month period, the group cited factors that could impact its business, including property cooling measures and currency fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Stricter loan rules for Auckland property
summary: New Zealand's central bank plans to tighten lending restrictions for residential property investors in Auckland, requiring a deposit of at least 30% for any bank loan to buy property in the area. The new policy, set to come into force on October 1, aims to curb an overheated housing market in Auckland, driven by supply constraints and increased demand. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) believes the restrictions will improve the resilience of the banking system to a potential downturn in the Auckland housing market.

site_title: Two startups aim to take SMEs to next level
summary: Two Singaporean startups, Page Advisor and Alpha7, aim to boost productivity and market services for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). Page Advisor, a mobile marketplace for home maintenance and lifestyle services, offers over 1,500 service providers and a 100% money-back guarantee. Alpha7, a technology consultancy platform, plans to help foreign SMEs set up operations in Singapore and the region, with a focus on Asean's growing market. Both startups aim to level the playing field for SMEs, providing access to new consumers and jobs, and improve quality control and revenue models.

site_title: STI up despite weak China data, US sell-down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 10.84 points, or 0.3%, to 3,453.17, driven by minor gains from Singtel and the Jardine group, as well as an advance in energy-related stocks despite weak China data and a US sell-down. The local market largely brushed off the economic data, which dragged Hong Kong and Shanghai indices lower. Notable movers included Singtel, Jardine Matheson, and Hongkong Land, with oil and gas companies showing muted reactions to higher oil prices.

site_title: India's inflation cools, factory output weakens
summary: India's inflation rate dropped to 4.87% in April, the lowest in four months, and industrial output growth slowed to 2.1% in March, lower than forecast. Economists predict another interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India due to low inflation and slower-than-expected growth. Analysts, including Rupa Rege Nitsure and Siddharth Roy, call for the RBI to lower rates to boost growth and help businesses. The RBI has already cut rates twice this year, but held steady at its last meeting citing banks' failure to pass on lower borrowing costs to customers.

site_title: More stimulus seen as China economy loses steam in April
summary: China's economy showed signs of losing momentum in April, with the money supply growing at its slowest pace on record and investment growth reaching its lowest in nearly 15 years. The data raised concerns that Beijing's growth target of 7% for the year is at risk, and policymakers may need to take bolder measures to address job losses and debt defaults. This further pressures authorities to reassess their policies to maintain economic stability.

site_title: CDL looks to more fund management deals this year
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) plans to explore more fund management deals this year, following the successful monetization of its Quayside Collection assets on Sentosa Cove. The company reported a 2.8% year-on-year increase in net earnings to S$123.03 million in Q1 2015. CDL is considering deals involving existing assets, contingent on favorable conditions.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: SoftBank's Son taps former Google exec as successor
summary: SoftBank Corp chairman and CEO Masayoshi Son has named Nikesh Arora, 47, as his successor. Arora, a former Google executive, will become SoftBank's representative director and president on June 19. Arora joined SoftBank last year as chief business officer and will take over from Son, who has been instrumental in the company's growth. The appointment marks a significant transition for the Japanese tech giant, with Arora bringing his experience from Google to the role.

site_title: South Korean exports slip into reverse as Japan steps on the gas
summary: South Korea's exports have slipped into reverse for the fourth consecutive month, with shipments dropping in value and volume. The won's strength against the euro and yen has undercut sales, in contrast to Japan, where currency depreciation has boosted exports. Analysts predict the Bank of Korea may cut interest rates to 1.5% to support exports, citing a pressing issue facing the nation. Domestic demand has shown signs of a pickup, but the weak export figures weigh on economic growth in Korea's trade-dependent economy.

site_title: AOL chief executive's bumpy journey to the big Verizon offer
summary: AOL's CEO Tim Armstrong led the company's transformation into a mobile ad specialist through strategic deals, including the acquisition of video advertising platform Adap.tv. Despite initial setbacks, Armstrong's focus on automation and "programmatic" ad platforms helped AOL achieve growth in 2014, with global advertising revenue increasing 15%. Verizon agreed to pay $4.4 billion for AOL, citing its advertising technology and content for the mobile web, with Armstrong set to remain CEO and oversee operations. Armstrong's success vindicated his approach, with investors praising his ability to "punch above his weight" despite AOL's small size.

site_title: Singapore set to continue to grow as top commo trading hub in Asia
summary: Singapore is poised to continue its growth as a top commodity trading hub in Asia, despite the global slump in oil and metal prices. The country's reliance on foreign businesses, particularly in Australia, Japan, and South Korea, has been impacted by the downturn. To sustain its commodities industries, Singapore's government should continue to support foreign investors, as seen with many trading houses already relocating to the country. Singapore's status as an international trading hub has attracted major players like Xstrata, Anglo American, and BHP Billiton, which has fueled the growth of the industry.

site_title: Realtor.com out to grab Zillow's top spot
summary: News Corp has acquired Realtor.com, the parent company of Realtor.com, for $864 million, aiming to challenge Zillow Group's dominance in online real estate listings. Realtor.com argues its listings provide more accurate information, while Zillow defends its "Zestimates" feature, which estimates home prices. The competition is escalating, with both companies vying for real estate agents' marketing spending, estimated at $9.7 billion this year. The rivalry is set to intensify as the housing market grows, with Realtor.com and Zillow using various tactics to gain an edge.

site_title: Surbana wins another African masterplanning contract
summary: Surbana International Consultants has secured a US$10-15 million masterplanning contract in the Democratic Republic of Congo to develop a regional structure plan for Kinshasa province and a detailed master plan for the city. This marks Surbana's ninth project in Africa and its largest masterplanning contract to date. The 14-month project aims to address urban development challenges in Kinshasa, a city of over 9 million people, and will be undertaken in collaboration with Surbana's Chinese partner Greater Kingdom Ltd.

site_title: Abbott rules out early election, says Budget not aimed at political revival
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has ruled out an early election, stating that the government will run to a full term. The government's budget, announced on Tuesday, includes a tax cut for small businesses and a package to make childcare more affordable, aimed at restoring business and consumer confidence. Despite a projected deficit of A$35.1 billion, analysts say the budget is a "softer, cuddlier budget" that avoids structural reforms, and Abbott aims to capitalize on improved poll ratings since a leadership challenge in February.

site_title: Australia's wage slowdown a double-edged sword
summary: Australia's wage growth slowed to 2.3% in the first quarter, the lowest in at least 16 years, limiting household spending and tax revenues. The slowdown has been steady for four years, affecting the Liberal National government's budget forecasts and revenue from income tax. Despite this, wages growth has restrained inflation, allowing the Reserve Bank of Australia to lower interest rates to a historic low. The jobless rate has remained stable, and productivity growth has kept real unit labour costs comparable to 2010 levels.

site_title: Fu Yu swings into the black with Q1 profit of S$4m
summary: Fu Yu Corp reported a net profit of S$4.0 million for the first quarter ended March, compared to a net loss of S$1.4 million a year ago. Revenue decreased 2.3% to S$58.1 million due to reduced orders from the contract manufacturing business in Malaysia, but was partially offset by increases in the China and Singapore segments. The company posted an earnings per share of 0.54 Singapore cent, compared to a loss per share of 0.19 Singapore cent previously.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Kazakhstan's warming ties with China
summary: Kazakhstan strengthened its ties with China through a framework agreement signed during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit on May 8. The agreement includes infrastructure, energy, and housing deals worth over $14 billion, solidifying Kazakhstan's role as a major site of Chinese investment. The two countries aim to increase bilateral trade volume to $40 billion this year, with Kazakhstan being crucial to China's Silk Road Economic Belt. This marks the second visit by a Chinese state leader to Kazakhstan in six months, highlighting the country's growing diplomatic and strategic importance to China.

site_title: Politics deals temporary setback to PM Modi's reform agenda
summary: India's government, led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has faced a setback in passing two crucial bills aimed at kickstarting the country's economy. The bills, related to the Land Acquisition Act and Goods and Services Tax, were not passed during the recent Budget session of Parliament. Despite having the largest majority in the Lok Sabha in 30 years, the ruling BJP is in a minority in the upper house, the Rajya Sabha, due to its indirect electoral college composition. This temporary setback may slow down Modi's economic reform agenda.

images.alt_text: One year after coming to power with a bold economic reform agenda, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has run into speed breakers in the form of India's chaotic political process.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's Q1 profit rises 6.8%
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp reported a 6.8% increase in net profit to S$67.6 million for the first quarter ended March, driven by a 1.3% rise in revenue to S$963.5 million. The bus business revenue grew 2.2% to S$478 million, led by a 5.5% increase in Singapore taxi revenue. Operating profit rose 1.6% to S$103.1 million, with 55% coming from Singapore and 45% from overseas.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Embraer to sell 2,060 jets to N America in US$96 billion deal
summary: Embraer announced a US$96 billion deal to deliver 2,060 jets to the North American market over the next 20 years, with a projected net gain of 35% of global sales in the 70-130 seat passenger jet market. The company's E175 model has dominated North American orders since 2013, and Embraer aims to capitalize on the growing demand for larger regional jets to fill capacity gaps between regional and mainline operations.

site_title: Retail shakeout in Tiong Bahru
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has cracked down on businesses in Tiong Bahru, Singapore, that use residential ground floor units for commercial purposes, following complaints from residents. Several businesses, including startups and design agencies, were asked to vacate their premises after being found to be in breach of planning rules. The URA cited concerns over noise, traffic pollution, and displacement of heritage trades. Business owners and residents are divided on the issue, with some calling for a more nuanced approach to balancing commercial and residential uses in the area.

site_title: Yanlord's Q1 bottom line hit by triple whammy
summary: Yanlord Land reported a 94% drop in net profit to 15.46 million Chinese yuan (S$3.4 million) for its Q1 2015, hit by lower turnover, foreign exchange loss, and negative joint venture profit. Revenue slumped 43% to 1.01 billion yuan. The developer attributed the decline to lower gross floor area delivery and expects revenue recognition in subsequent periods. The company cited China's real estate sector normalization as uncertain, but remains confident in its performance.

site_title: Consumer spending drives eastern Europe
summary: Eastern European economies likely experienced strong growth in the first quarter, driven by consumer spending. Poland's GDP surged 3.3% and the Czech Republic's grew 2%, outpacing previous quarters. Low oil prices and a euro area recovery fueled consumer spending, outweighing concerns about the conflict in Ukraine and Greece's potential exit from the euro. The International Monetary Fund predicts full-year growth of 2.6% in the region, supported by private consumption and cheaper oil.

site_title: Local banks' brokerage fees gain 6.4% in Q1
summary: Singapore's three major banks' brokerage fees rose 6.4% in Q1, with UOB-Kay Hian Holdings showing a slight decline. DBS Group Holdings and OCBC Bank's fees increased 5% and 49% respectively. UOB-Kay Hian's net profit grew 0.8% to S$18 million, driven by a placement deal and a buoyant market in Thailand. The company expects a more positive trading environment in the second half of 2015.

site_title: Sure and steady preparations for Expo 2017
summary: Construction on Kazakhstan's Expo 2017 project, a 174-hectare complex in Astana, is nearing completion, with about 30% of work done and the majority of installation and construction work set to be finished by September 2016. The project, themed "Future Energy", aims to develop alternative energy sources and transportation methods, and will feature technology-intensive exhibits and a museum of the future. Over 3,500 workers are involved in the construction process, with the number expected to rise by 20% during peak construction periods.

site_title: Sharp dip in oil prices boosts euro region's Q1 growth
summary: The euro region's economy experienced a 0.4% growth in the first quarter of 2015, beating expectations, driven by stronger-than-expected performances from France and Italy, while Germany's growth slowed more than predicted. The euro region's GDP rose 0.4% after expanding 0.3% in the previous quarter, with consumer spending being a significant growth driver. However, Greece fell back into recession, and policymakers warn that the upswing may not be sustainable unless governments implement economic reforms.

site_title: Australian retailers get boost from tax break for small business
summary: Australian retailers received a boost from the federal budget with an immediate tax deduction for buying office supplies under A$20,000, up from A$1,000 previously. The tax break is expected to help small businesses spend more and stimulate the economy. Major retailers such as Myer Holdings Ltd and GUD Holdings Ltd rose in the first trading session following the budget announcement. The government is also offering a A$5 billion loan facility to promote infrastructure investments in remote northern Australia, benefiting mining services companies.

site_title: Tesco to close last 6 Homeplus stores in UK
summary: Tesco, the UK's largest retailer, is closing its last six Homeplus stores on June 27, potentially affecting 450 jobs. The decision comes as part of Dave Lewis's efforts to cut costs and improve the group's finances. The remaining stores will be closed, with alternative roles offered to affected employees. This move follows years of declining market share and is part of Tesco's broader strategy to restructure and regain financial stability.

site_title: Westwood Residences rides into EC market
summary: Westwood Residences, a bike-themed residential development, has entered Singapore's executive condominium market with 480 units, priced at S$800 per square foot. The 99-year leasehold project features facilities for bike enthusiasts, including a mini-velodrome and bike maintenance area, as well as a "BMX adventure" park and kids' playground. Despite an oversupply of EC units, developers remain optimistic about the market's potential, citing strategic location and product differentiation. The project is expected to obtain a Temporary Occupation Permit in 2018.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Japan on track to hit growth and inflation targets, says BOJ chief
summary: Japan's economy is on track to meet growth and inflation targets, according to Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda. Despite a recent national consumption tax hike, the economy has shown positive signs, with downward pressure on prices disappearing from April. The BOJ's inflation target of 2% is expected to be met by mid-2016. The government has also pledged to focus on economic growth, rather than fiscal consolidation, following Tokyo's decision to delay raising the consumption tax to 10% by early 2017.

site_title: Renesas puts Ang Mo Kio industrial site up for sale
summary: Renesas Semiconductor Singapore is selling its industrial site in Ang Mo Kio for over S$55 million, equivalent to S$160 per square foot. The site, consisting of three buildings and one annexe, has a gross floor area of 341,539 sq ft and a remaining tenure of about 26 years. The sale is due to the company's decision to move its operations out of Singapore, with production set to shift to other back-end manufacturing subsidiaries and partners. The site will be sold through expressions of interest, closing on June 25.

site_title: 5 banks may settle forex rigging charges next week
summary: Five major banks - JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, and UBS - are expected to settle with US and British authorities next week for their role in rigging the foreign exchange market. The settlement, which began two years ago, involves fines of up to $1 billion and four of the banks will plead guilty to US criminal charges. The deal, aimed at averting prosecution, is expected to be signed by multiple regulatory bodies, including the US Department of Justice and the Federal Reserve.

site_title: China April home sales up as property market stabilises
summary: China's home sales rose 16% in April to 485.4 billion yuan, the first increase this year, after interest-rate cuts and eased property curbs boosted demand. The sales volume declined 4.8% in the January-April period, narrowing from a 9.2% decline in the first quarter. Analysts say the stabilization of the property market signals a potential bottoming-out, but question whether sales can continue to rise after pent-up demand is unleashed. The central bank's stimulus measures, including interest-rate cuts and tax reductions, have supported the industry.

site_title: Derailment on Amtrak kills five, shuts down north-east US service
summary: A derailing of an Amtrak train carrying 243 people killed at least five and injured dozens more on Tuesday, shutting down service in the north-east US. The train, headed from Washington to New York, derailed near a bend in the track, with 65 people taken to hospitals, including six in critical condition. The cause of the crash was unknown, but officials suspected a hot journal box may have caused an axle to snap. Amtrak service on the north-east corridor is likely suspended for the rest of the week, with multiple agencies responding to the massive response.

images.alt_text: Emergency responders searching for passengers following an Amtrak train derailment in the Frankfort section of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

site_title: Condo rents flat in April; HDB rents dip
summary: Singapore's private residential rents remained flat in April, while HDB rents slipped 0.7% compared to the previous month, according to SRX Property data. Tenant demand fell 11.9% in private rentals and 13.2% in public rentals. Analysts attribute the slowdown to tenants being cautious with their rental budget and the large supply of new private residential completions. R'ST Research director Ong Kah Seng expects condo rents to fall by up to 7% this year due to the stalemate between tenants' offer rents and landlords' asking rents.

site_title: Maersk beats forecasts, loses shipping market share
summary: Maersk Line, the world's largest container shipping business, reported a net profit of $714 million in the first quarter, beating forecasts, but lost market share and disappointed analysts. Despite a 1.6% decline in market share, CEO Nils Andersen stated the company would catch up. The profit was driven by lower bunker fuel prices, but freight rates fell 5% and the volume of goods transported fell, weakening vessel usage rates. The company's oil business performed better than expected, but its overall revenue fell to $10.5 billion.

site_title: Burmese ruby sells for record US$30m at auction
summary: A 25.59 carat "pigeon blood" ruby sold for a record US$30.33 million at a Sotheby's auction in Geneva, surpassing previous records for a ruby and a Cartier jewel. The "Sunrise Ruby" from Myanmar was part of a collection of Cartier jewels and was expected to sell for between US$12 million and US$18 million. Another rare stone, a 8.72 carat fancy vivid pink diamond, sold for US$15.9 million, also at the auction.

site_title: Krueger starts in his predecessor's shadow
summary: BMW's new CEO Harald Krueger faces a challenging test in emerging from the shadow of his predecessor Norbert Reithofer. Krueger, 49, must navigate the changing luxury car market, with competitors like Tesla Motors, and make decisions on BMW's expensive projects, including the electric "i" subbrand. His predecessor's strategy may be harder to break with due to Reithofer's possible shift to chairman without a recommended two-year break. Krueger's ability to leave his mark on the company will be crucial in determining BMW's future direction.

site_title: FSL Trust posts US$5m Q1 profit
summary: FSL Trust, a Singapore-based ship lease trust, reported a US$5m profit in the first quarter of 2015, marking its fourth consecutive profitable quarter. The trust's solid demand for tankers helped offset losses due to shippers' lease defaults during the industry downturn. This positive trend is attributed to strong demand for tankers.

site_title: Retail sales little changed on reluctance to splurge
summary: US retail sales remained unchanged in April, following a 1.1% gain in March, as consumers showed reluctance to splurge amid slow wage growth. The median forecast of economists called for a 0.2% gain, but the actual reading fell short. Steady hiring and low borrowing costs will support household spending, accounting for 70% of the economy, but wages remain stuck in a tepid range. Non-fuel imports dropped 0.3% in April, the biggest decline since 2009, with declines in discretionary items such as cars and electronics.

site_title: EU growth surprises hide clear pattern
summary: European economies surprised forecasts with varying growth rates in the first quarter of 2015. Germany reported a 0.3% increase, while France and Italy saw 0.6% and 0.3% growth, respectively. Britain's GDP gain was also higher than expected, while Spain's 0.9% growth aligns with its reputation as a reform-driven economy. The eurozone as a whole saw a 0.4% quarterly increase, a weak showing given falling oil prices and a recovering economy.

images.alt_text: A 0.4% quarterly increase in eurozone GDP, also announced on Wednesday, points to a regional recovery which is real but slow.

site_title: Election result discredits pollsters' view on Brexit
summary: The UK's general election result, won by Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives, has discredited pollsters' views on Brexit, with many believing the British would never vote to quit Europe. The upcoming referendum on possible British departure from the EU will be one of the most difficult two-year periods in post-war Britain. Cameron's negotiating demands, including an end to free cross-border movement of citizens and withdrawal from European social legislation, will be crucial. The EU has expressed willingness to negotiate, but many member states, including Germany, France, and Italy, have set out non-negotiable positions, making a smooth negotiation process uncertain.

site_title: Promoting global harmony
summary: Kazakhstan is set to host the Congress of World and Traditional Religions in Astana from June 10-11, themed "Dialogue of Religious Leaders and Politicians in the Name of Peace and Development". The event aims to promote global harmony and dialogue among religions and cultures. Kazakhstan also emphasizes its commitment to nuclear non-proliferation, with Deputy Minister Yerzhan Ashikbayev reiterating the importance of strengthening the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The country has made significant contributions to disarmament and non-proliferation, including the disarmament of its post-Soviet nuclear arsenal.

site_title: One French institution embraces another
summary: Renowned French chef Guy Savoy has relocated his three-Michelin-starred restaurant to a grand top-floor space at the historic Monnaie de Paris, the oldest institution in France. The new restaurant offers stunning views of the Seine and features a 4,300 sq. ft. kitchen with new equipment. A seafood-focused restaurant, Savoy's new space will open in June, followed by the MetaLcafé brasserie in 2016. The move marks a new chapter for Savoy, who praised the bright and airy workspace, saying "every day feels like Christmas."

site_title: UK wage growth strengthens as jobless rate declines
summary: The UK unemployment rate has fallen to 5.5% in the first quarter, its lowest since 2008, as jobless numbers dropped 35,000 to 1.83 million. Wage growth also strengthened, with regular pay increasing 2.2%, the largest jump since 2011. The Bank of England's interest rate is expected to rise by mid-2016 as the labor market continues to strengthen.

site_title: OKP Holdings bags S$19.7m job from LTA
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singaporean infrastructure firm, has secured a S$19.7 million contract with the Land Transport Authority (LTA) for road-related projects in Singapore's east sector. This marks the firm's second contract from LTA in 2015, and it brings OKP's net construction order book to S$386.9 million until 2019.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China is missing ingredient in oil's recovery from six-year low
summary: US oil production may reverse as prices rise, potentially smothering gains made in the recent 40% rebound from a six-year low. Global oil demand is expected to grow just 1.3 million barrels a day to 94.58 million next year, insufficient to close the gap with rising supply. China's fuel demand growth is also slowing, with fuel use growing at half the rate of the past decade. Analysts warn that unless demand accelerates, the rally is in danger, and the market may remain well oversupplied in 2015.

site_title: Boardroom's Q1 net profit doubles to S$1.6m
summary: BOARDROOM Ltd posted a two-fold jump in net profit to S$1.6 million for the first quarter ended March 2015, driven by 14% revenue growth from its corporate secretarial and accounting services. Earnings per share increased to 0.83 Singapore cents from 0.41 cents last year.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Uncertainty over Brexit issue unsettling Asia investors
summary: Uncertainty over the UK's future in the EU is unsettling Asian investors, who fear that a potential "Brexit" would lose Britain its major drawcard for attracting foreign money. The UK's gateway to the European market, business-friendly laws, and educated workforce make it an attractive destination for Asian businesses, with Japan alone having around 900 companies with operations worth $8 billion annually. Analysts warn that two years of uncertainty will worry investors, and a possible lengthy debate will deter companies from spending money in Britain, potentially leading to a loss of investment and a decline in the UK's status as a European business and financial hub.

site_title: China reduces oil product export quotas in Q2: traders
summary: China has reduced oil product export quotas by over 40% in the second quarter, according to traders. The country initially awarded refiners 9.75 million tonnes of quotas for the year, but has now given them an additional 5.6 million tonnes, bringing the total to 9.75 million tonnes. This decision is part of China's efforts to control oil product exports and meet domestic needs.

site_title: Singha plans 100b baht property splurge to overcome booze curbs
summary: Thailand's Singha Estate Pcl plans to invest 100 billion baht (S$4 billion) in hotels, shopping centers, and property projects over five years, boosting revenue to 20 billion baht by 2019. The expansion aims to overcome earnings erosion due to higher taxes and curbs on alcohol marketing. The company will invest 60% in commercial property and 40% in residential real estate, with projects including a 10-billion-baht commercial project in Bangkok and luxury condominium sales. Analysts predict the expansion will face challenges, but the company's strong financial position and growing demand for residential homes and hotel rooms are seen as positives.

site_title: Dyna-Mac's Q1 profit falls 76%
summary: DYNA-MAC reported a 76% drop in Q1 net profit to S$1.7 million, down from S$7.1 million a year ago, due to mostly initial-stage projects. Revenue was halved to S$39.8 million from S$78.9 million. Earnings per share fell to 0.17 Singapore cents from 0.70 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US import prices fall for 10th straight month
summary: US import prices fell 0.3% in April for the 10th consecutive month, reflecting a strong dollar and low crude oil prices. The 10.7% decline in 12 months through April indicates benign inflation pressures, potentially delaying interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. This keeps inflation below the Fed's 2% target, allowing the central bank to maintain its ultra-low interest rate policy.

site_title: Tencent wields WeChat ace in battle for online entertainment
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd is using its wildly popular WeChat app to challenge Alibaba Group Holding Ltd for leadership in China's online entertainment market. With 500 million monthly active users, WeChat allows Tencent to channel users to its entertainment services, securing exclusive deals with top-tier content providers. Tencent has spent billions building its content library and investing in entertainment firms, while Alibaba has teamed up with Hollywood studios and spent over $3.5 billion on stakes in video and gaming firms. The battle for market share is expected to double revenue to over $46 billion by 2018.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to Trump's tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Oil extends gains after US fuel stocks drop
summary: Brent crude oil rose above $67 a barrel, reaching a five-month high, after US crude stockpiles fell for a second straight week. US crude stocks dropped 2.2 million barrels to 484.84 million barrels, while Brent for June increased 41 cents to $67.27 a barrel. A weaker US dollar also contributed to the gains, making oil cheaper for holders of other currencies. Despite a bearish report from the International Energy Agency, analysts say the market's fundamentals still look relatively loose, supporting oil prices.

site_title: Oxley's Q3 net profit jumps more than 10-fold
summary: OXLEY Holdings reported a 10-fold jump in net profit to S$11.9 million for Q3 2015, from S$1.02 million a year ago. Revenue rose 48% to S$152.2 million, driven by progress on 11 mixed-residential projects. Earnings per share increased to 0.40 Singapore cent from 0.03 Singapore cent.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US: Stocks open higher
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following a weak April retail sales report that sparked expectations of a delayed interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 55.59 points, the S&P 500 advanced 10.36, and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 33.45. The disappointing retail sales report, which fell short of expectations, was seen as a potential chill on the Fed's plan to raise near-zero interest rates.

site_title: UOB-Kay Hian Q1 net profit up 0.8% on Thailand, placement deal
summary: UOB-Kay Hian Holdings reported a 0.8% increase in Q1 net profit to S$18 million, driven by a placement deal and Thailand. Total revenue rose 6.9% to S$89.8 million, while commission income decreased 1.3%. The company expects a more positive trading environment in the second half of 2015, citing buoyant Hong Kong and Shanghai markets and stabilizing oil prices.

site_title: Delta sets US$6b of buybacks, dividends on fuel savings
summary: Delta Air Lines approved a US$5 billion stock-repurchase plan and increased its dividend by 50% to 13.5 cents per share, as the company benefits from fuel savings. The buyback will run through Dec 2017, while Delta projects saving US$2.2 billion on fuel this year, following a 37% drop in jet fuel prices since their peak in September.

site_title: Building the necessary blocks for employability
summary: Educational reforms are needed to support national talent strategies in the rapidly changing job market. The traditional 20th-century model of formal education is no longer sufficient, as new functions and skill sets emerge constantly. Lifelong learning and vocational education are essential for employability, as seen in countries like Switzerland, Singapore, and South Korea. The Swiss system emphasizes vocational training from a young age, resulting in a highly skilled and innovative workforce. Formal education must be modernized to include basic skills, interpersonal and team skills, and a curiosity to learn, with close partnerships between companies, schools, and authorities.

site_title: US retail sales unchanged in April on weak autos, furniture
summary: US retail sales remained unchanged in April, contrary to economists' expectations of a 0.2% increase, due to weak sales of automobiles and furniture. This suggests the economy is struggling to rebound after a slow first quarter. Retail sales for March were revised to a 1.1% increase from the initial 0.9% report.

site_title: CityDev Q1 net profit up 2.8% to S$123m on higher revenue from development, hotels
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) reported a 2.8% increase in net profit to S$123.03 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015. Revenue rose 11% to S$814.94 million, driven by contributions from property development and hotel operations. Earnings per share increased to 13.5 cents, and net asset value per share rose to S$9.43. The counter closed 9 cents higher at S$10.19 after announcing its results.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: BreadTalk posts 11% rise in Q1 net profit
summary: BreadTalk Group reported a 11% increase in net profit to S$2.0 million for Q1 2015, from S$1.8 million a year ago. Revenue rose 8.6% to S$152.45 million, with all divisions recording an improvement. The bakery division saw a 11.3% rise in revenue excluding Thailand, which transferred its business to a new joint venture last year.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
BreadTalk Group posted a 11 per cent increase in net profit to S$2.0 million for the first quarter ended March, from S$1.8 million a year ago.

site_title: MH370 search finds uncharted shipwreck
summary: Australian-led search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 uncovers a previously uncharted shipwreck in the southern Indian Ocean. The wreckage, containing an anchor and other man-made objects, was found using a high-resolution sonar scan and an underwater camera. The discovery was made in a 120,000-square-kilometer search area, where no wreckage from the flight has been found. Officials say the shipwreck does not appear to be related to the missing plane, but the search continues, with experts stating that if the plane is in the search zone, they will find it.

site_title: Eurozone grows 0.4% in first quarter: Eurostat
summary: The eurozone economy expanded by 0.4% in the first quarter, exceeding analyst expectations. France's growth outpaced Germany's 0.3% expansion, while Italy's economy edged out of recession with a 0.3% growth. In contrast, Greece fell into recession with a 0.2% contraction amid stalled bailout talks. The growth is attributed to lower oil prices, a weakened euro, and increased ECB stimulus, according to economists.

site_title: Singha plans US$3b property splurge to overcome booze curbs
summary: Thailand's largest beermaker, Singha Estate Pcl, plans to spend $2.96 billion over five years on hotels, shopping centers, and property projects to offset declining earnings due to higher taxes and curbs on alcohol marketing. The company aims to boost revenue to at least $2 billion by 2019. Singha Estate, a unit of Boon Rawd Brewery Co, will invest 60% of the budget in commercial property and the remainder in residential real estate.

site_title: Sin Heng's Q3 profit plunges 52.3 per cent to S$3m
summary: Sin Heng Heavy Machinery reported a 52.3% plunge in its third-quarter profit to S$3 million, mainly due to a 33% drop in trading revenue. Revenue fell 27.2% to S$39.1 million, with earnings per share at 0.53 cents. The company's net asset value was 23.29 cents per ordinary share. This marks a 12.5% decline in nine-month net profit to S$9.1 million.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Sotheby's scores its second-best post-war, contemporary art total
summary: Sotheby's achieved its second-best post-war, contemporary art total with a US$380 million sale, setting records for artists Christopher Wool and Sigmar Polke. The auction featured top works by Roy Lichtenstein, Gerhard Richter, and Andy Warhol, with Mark Rothko's 1954 oil painting selling for US$46.5 million, slightly below its pre-sale estimate. Despite a few works falling short of buyers, only seven of the 63 offered items failed to find buyers, marking a successful contemporary art sale for the auction house.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 4.41 points to 1,803.02. Over 1.68 billion lots worth RM2 billion were traded, with 420 gainers outnumbering losers 355.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned its H2 revenue may be lower than expected, with an operating loss similar to the first half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and the People's Bank of China agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Petrobras to seek up to US$1.3b in local bond sale
summary: Petrobras plans to sell up to US$1.3 billion in domestic bonds as early as next week. The state-run Brazilian oil producer is seeking to raise 3 billion reais (US$994 million) through infrastructure bonds, with the potential to reach 4 billion reais. Banco Bradesco, Banco do Brasil, Grupo BTG Pactual, and Banco Votorantim are managing the transaction. Petrobras is authorized to issue up to US$19.1 billion in debt this year and is exploring various financing options.

site_title: Indonesia to tighten corporate debt financing rules
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry plans to tighten corporate debt financing rules, aiming to better manage foreign debt exposure and boost tax revenue. The new regulation will limit interest payments as tax deductible to firms with a debt-to-equity ratio of 4:1 or less, starting next year. Currently, all interest payments are recognized as tax deductible with no such ratio limit. The move aims to reduce the risk of foreign investors and improve the government's tax revenue.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: Moody's Investors Service compared the credit profiles of Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, citing differences in their business models and risk profiles. This could lead to credit differentiation over time. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise and concern over the US's planned tariff increase, while the Asian garment industry braced for higher tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.
