summary: Singapore has launched an International Trading Programme (ITP) at Nanyang Technological University (NTU) to train high-quality traders for the energy, commodities, and metals industries. The programme, established by IE Singapore, NTU, and five industry partners, will admit around 100 NTU students annually, starting this academic year. The programme aims to develop a deep understanding of the commodity value chain and provide opportunities for Singaporeans to access good jobs and internationally oriented careers in the trading sector, in line with the national SkillsFuture initiative.

site_title: As Airbnb grows to 1m rooms, hotels watch
summary: Airbnb has surpassed 1 million rooms available worldwide, yet hotel chains have yet to take substantial action against the platform. Despite this, some hotels are exploring ways to compete, such as joining Airbnb or requiring hosts to adhere to safety standards. Business travelers are increasingly using Airbnb, and the platform's presence is helping to restrain hotel prices in some markets. However, traditional hotels remain loyal to their customers, citing the benefits of predictability, services, and comfort.

site_title: How BTBAF helped young talents to bloom
summary: The Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BTBAF) has marked 10 years of supporting artistically gifted underprivileged children in Singapore. Since its launch in 2005, the fund has enabled 7,000 children to pursue various art forms, resulting in transformative emotional, social, and intellectual development. The fund has grown to include two arts training centers, and its beneficiaries have gone on to perform in concerts, exhibitions, and other events, with many pursuing arts training at the tertiary level. The fund's success is attributed to its ability to nurture artistic talents and instill entrepreneurial spirit.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Qantas shares surge on forecast fall in 2015 fuel bill
summary: Qantas shares rose 7.2% to their highest level in over six years after the airline predicted a 36% drop in jet fuel prices, resulting in a potential A$550 million savings. This decrease in fuel costs will reduce Qantas's biggest expense, allowing the company to invest in other areas. With an average fleet age of 7.2 years, Qantas can afford to wait before buying new planes, potentially saving on finance costs. The airline's fuel bill could be as low as A$3.92 billion this year, a significant decrease from previous forecasts.

site_title: More buys than sells of Singapore stocks
summary: Global mutual funds bought more Singapore shares than they sold in the three months to May 6, with net purchases totaling US$1.41 billion and net sells of US$1.09 billion. SingTel was the top stock among buys, with a volume of US$428 million, while Keppel Land was the top stock among sells, with a volume of US$220.7 million. In the US$1-2 billion market cap segment, buys outweighed sells, with Super Group Ltd being the top buy and Parkway Life Reit being the top sell.

site_title: Up in arms against the onerous FATCA
summary: The Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) has taken effect, requiring foreign financial institutions to identify and report US citizens' financial accounts to the IRS. Critics argue the law infringes on the freedom and right to privacy of overseas Americans, and Republicans Overseas is challenging its constitutionality in a US court. The challenge, led by Senator Rand Paul, argues FATCA violates the Treaty Clause, Fourth Amendment, and Eighth Amendment. If successful, the repeal of FATCA could lead to a "level playing field" with other countries, as the US and UK are the only ones subject to the law.

site_title: US small business confidence jumps; energy capex up
summary: US small business confidence rose 1.7 points to 96.9 in April, according to the National Federation of Independent Business, with energy companies showing surprisingly bullish views on capital expenditure and hiring plans. The NFIB survey found 60% of firms reported capital outlays, up 2 points, and 44% bought new equipment, up 4 points. This bolsters views that energy spending cuts were front-loaded into the first quarter, supporting a rebound in economic growth after a dismal first quarter.

site_title: India's inflation cools, factory output weakens
summary: India's inflation rate fell to 4.87% in April, its lowest level in four months, due to lower food costs. Industrial output growth slowed, increasing calls for an interest rate cut next month. This is the slowest pace since December and is in line with economists' predictions. The data suggests the Reserve Bank of India may lower interest rates to boost economic growth.

site_title: UK industrial output gains 0.5% in March
summary: UK industrial output rose 0.5% in March, the largest gain since September, driven by a surge in oil and gas extraction and manufacturing growth for the second consecutive month. Economists had expected no change, according to a Bloomberg survey. This surprise rise provides a fresh boost to the UK economy, which has been facing challenges, including a contraction in the second month in a row.

site_title: Noble Agri appoints new CEO
summary: Noble Agri, the agribusiness unit of Noble Group and Cofco Corporation, has appointed Matthew Jansen as its new CEO, replacing interim CEO Yusuf Alireza. Jansen, 48, brings 20 years of experience from Archer Daniels Midland, including seven years leading the Brazilian operations. His appointment comes at a critical time for Noble Agri, which has faced scrutiny over account inflation and pledged increased transparency. Frank Ning, chairman of Noble Agri and Cofco Corporation, said Jansen's experience makes him "ideally suited" to drive the company's growth.

site_title: Google admits driverless car crashes on California roads
summary: Google has admitted that its driverless cars have been involved in 11 minor accidents on California roads over the past six years, with none of the incidents attributed to the cars' systems. Despite the accidents, Google claims its self-driving cars have not caused a single accident and have driven nearly a million miles autonomously. The company's admission comes as the public lacks objective data on the safety of driverless cars, with proponents arguing that computer-driven vehicles can improve automotive safety by reacting faster to dangers and reducing driver error.

site_title: Norway cuts growth outlook as oil sector woes deepen
summary: Norway's government revised its 2015 budget, citing deeper-than-expected woes in the oil sector. The country's energy companies will cut investment spending by 13.1% and tax revenue will fall sharply, reducing the government's surplus. The revised budget forecasts a 7.7% surplus, down from 11.7%, and expects GDP growth on the mainland to slow to 1.3% this year, with unemployment averaging 4% and oil prices averaging 480 krone a barrel. The government predicts growth could rebound to 2% in 2016 as oil prices are forecast to rise.

site_title: Textron bets on rebound with new Cessna
summary: Textron Inc, the parent company of Cessna, is investing in new products and acquisitions to boost profit as it bets on the US luxury aviation market's recovery from a recession-era collapse. CEO Scott Donnelly is focusing on growth, with development teams working on a new, undisclosed Cessna jet. The company's investments aim to capitalize on the market's rebound, with Textron's US$12.6 billion in revenue. This move is part of the company's strategy to drive growth and increase profits.

site_title: Four policy planks Nepal can pursue in reconstruction
summary: Nepal is entering the second phase of its recovery from the devastating earthquake that struck the country nearly two weeks ago. Relief efforts, including clean water, food, and medicine, have reached most affected areas, but additional aid is still needed, particularly in remote regions. The country is now focusing on reconstruction, with four key policy planks that can be pursued: promoting sustainable infrastructure, enhancing disaster preparedness, supporting small-scale entrepreneurship, and prioritizing education and healthcare.

site_title: SIA expected to unveil better Q4 results
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is expected to report better-than-expected Q4 results, driven by lower fuel costs and lower hedging losses. Analysts predict a marginally higher net profit than consensus estimates, with Maybank Kim Eng projecting a core net profit of S$165.7 million for the fourth quarter. SIA's subsidiary Tiger Airways is expected to return to profitability in FY2016, with CAPA-Centre for Aviation predicting modest profits. Shares in SIA closed at S$11.65 on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US: Stocks drop as bond yields spike
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 112.50 points at 17,992.67, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index down 12.97 and 36.86 respectively. Bond yields in the US remained high, outweighing news of Verizon's $4.4 billion acquisition of AOL. European equity markets also declined, with fears of a bond market rout causing a collapse in stocks.

site_title: US job openings decrease from highest level in 14 yrs
summary: US job openings decreased to 4.99 million in March, a 150,000 drop from a 14-year high, suggesting companies may have slowed hiring amid slowing growth. The data follows the weakest payrolls growth since June 2012, indicating more moderate gains. Economists expect a decelerated pace of employment growth this year, with less slack available in the labor market.

site_title: ASL Marine Q3 profit slumps
summary: ASL Marine, a Singapore-based shipyard, reported a 65.7% slump in its third-quarter earnings to S$1.94 million, due to the industry downturn and a global glut of offshore support vessels. Revenue fell 56.2% to S$63.42 million, with the shipbuilding segment incurring a gross loss of S$1.6 million. However, the company's ship repair and conversion segment saw improved margins due to a one-off special project. Despite this, the group's shares closed flat at S$0.435, and Chairman Ang Kok Tian expects upcoming infrastructure projects to boost demand for the company's support equipment.

site_title: Thai Airways swings into the black for Q1, shares climb
summary: Thai Airways International reported a net profit of 4.54 billion baht for the January-March quarter, reversing a net loss of 2.6 billion baht in the same period last year. The airline attributed the gain to a 9.65 billion baht foreign exchange gain and increased tourism traffic, which offset rising restructuring costs. Passenger numbers grew 17% and the cabin load factor reached 75.4%, leading to a 6% increase in shares. Thai Airways' two-year restructuring plan aims to reduce operating costs and capacity by 20%.

site_title: Mixed showing by firms in Sinar Mas Group
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 84% decline in net profit to US$17.2 million in the first quarter due to softer crude palm oil prices and lower plantation output. In contrast, Sinarmas Land saw a 70% jump in net profit to S$79.78 million, driven by improved revenue and foreign exchange gains. Other firms within the Sinar Mas conglomerate, including Bund Center Investment, also reported positive results, with Bund Center posting a 35% increase in net profit to S$6.56 million.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Don't make golf clubs take a sad stroll to finishing hole
summary: The Singapore Land Authority plans to acquire Jurong Country Club's 67-hectare site for a high-speed rail terminus, forcing the club to close its 18-hole course and clubhouse in 2016. The club will be compensated, but its future remains uncertain. This is not an isolated incident, as at least three golf courses will lose some or all of their property in the next five years, including Keppel and the Marina Bay public course. The lack of clarity on land use plans for golf clubs has led to significant financial losses for members, with estimated losses ranging from S$150 million to S$200 million. Authorities should provide more clarity on land use plans to affected clubs to prevent similar situations.

images.alt_text: Ven Sreenivasan

site_title: GM's ignition switch death toll hits 100
summary: General Motors' ignition switch death toll has hit 100, surpassing the company's initial estimate of 13 fatalities. The crisis is cementing its status as one of the deadliest automotive safety issues in American history. Over 4,300 claims have been filed, with more than 184 injuries approved. The number of fatalities is expected to fall short of the estimated 270 killed in the Ford Explorers Firestone tyre incident. GM has paid $35 million in fines and $600 million to compensate victims, and is under investigation by the Justice Department for possible criminal charges.

site_title: SingPost Q4 profit down 51.6% at S$38.5m
summary: SingPost reported a 51.6% decline in Q4 net profit to S$38.5 million due to a change in accounting policy for investment properties. Underlying net profit grew 14.9% to S$41.1 million, driven by e-commerce and logistics businesses. Revenue rose 28.7% to S$248.7 million, with logistics segment growing 26.1% to S$464.8 million. The company expects benefits from investments in regional network and parcel business to materialize in the coming years, and will continue to focus on mergers and acquisitions to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Switzerland's first driverless car hits Zurich roads
summary: Switzerland's first driverless car, a Volkswagen Passat equipped with sensors, computers, and special software, began testing on Zurich roads on May 5, 2015. The car will be tested until May 14, 2015. Swisscom, the telephone firm behind the project, aims to digitize the economy. The company's official stated that the goal is to test the feasibility of driverless cars in Switzerland.

site_title: Kingsmen Q1 profit falls 14.5% on lower interior design demand
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported a 14.5% drop in Q1 net profit to S$0.79 million due to lower interior design demand from high-end luxury retailers. Revenue fell 3.9% to S$51.9 million, with the exhibitions and museums division seeing a 23.2% increase in revenue from major projects. However, this was offset by a 22.3% drop in retail and corporate interiors revenue.

site_title: Rotary Engineering Q1 profit down to S$7m
summary: Rotary Engineering's net profit for the first quarter ended March 2015 decreased to S$7.07 million, a 50% drop from S$14.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue fell 55% to S$89.39 million due to the completion of major projects. Earnings per share declined to 1.2 Singapore cents from 2.5 Singapore cents. The decline was attributed to the completion of major projects.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Singapore tackles skills gap in cyber security sector
summary: Singapore is tackling the growing skills gap in the cyber security sector by developing into a regional hub to attract specialists and build expertise. The country's Smart Nation initiative aims to provide instant connectivity and access to vital services, but this digital connectivity also poses a major challenge for companies and citizens due to the increasing threat of cyber attacks. To address this, Singapore is investing in various initiatives, including the launch of an AI and Digital Innovation office at the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD).

site_title: NTU launches international trading course with private sector, IE Singapore
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) has launched an International Trading Programme in partnership with IE Singapore and five private corporations, offering training for 100 NTU students annually. The program focuses on the energy, commodities, and metals industries. Industry partners, including Borouge and Chevron, will provide feedback on syllabus design and internships. The program aims to equip students with skills required in the industry, with the first cohort starting this academic year.

site_title: London, S'pore 'can serve Asia's insurance needs'
summary: MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon says London and Singapore can complement each other in providing insurance and risk-management solutions to Asia, leveraging London's expertise and Singapore's proximity to Asian markets. London controls over £60 billion in premiums, while Asia's demand for insurance is driven by rising affluence and a growing middle class. MAS has a "smart regulation" approach, aligning with international standards and minimizing compliance burden. The Monetary Authority of Singapore will host the 42nd General Assembly of the Geneva Association in Singapore, bringing together global insurance chiefs to discuss regulations and climate risks.

images.alt_text: Mr Menon told his British audience that financial stability was key to MAS, and that sound regulation entailed promoting a vibrant financial sector.

site_title: US$83b infrastructure spending fails to keep lights on in S Africa
summary: South Africa's government has spent $83 billion on infrastructure over the past five years, but the country still struggles with a reliable electricity supply, resulting in frequent power outages. Despite improved roads, airports, and rail lines, the power constraints hinder economic growth. The energy shortfall is attributed to stalled approval of new power plants, leaving the primary electricity supplier, Eskom, with malfunctioning plants. The government aims to resolve the crisis by 2018, but economists warn that the interventions have been too little, too late, and that the country's growth is limited to 2% this year due to power shortages.

site_title: HK-Taiwan stock link unlikely to happen soon: traders
summary: Hong Kong and Taiwan are unlikely to establish a stock link in the near future due to potential infrastructure costs and political hurdles. The proposed link, which would allow direct trading between the two markets, is seen as unnecessary and expensive by traders, who argue that investors already have access to both markets through existing links with Shanghai. Taiwan's presidential election in January 2016 and the country's stance on independence from mainland China also pose significant challenges to the proposal.

site_title: Super Group Q1 profit down 24% on tax incentive expiry
summary: Super Group, a Singapore-based instant food and beverage maker, reported a net profit of S$13.6 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2015, down 24% from S$17.8 million in the same period last year, due to lower revenue and the expiry of a tax incentive. Revenue declined 2% to S$121.7 million. The company attributed the decline to reduced sales and higher costs.

site_title: Singapore, London can provide insurance solutions for Asia: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore and London can collaborate on providing insurance solutions tailored to Asia's needs, leveraging London's expertise and Singapore's market knowledge. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) aims to achieve "smart regulation" through alignment with international standards, intensive supervision, and outcome-focused regulations. This collaboration is driven by growing demand for insurance in Asia, fueled by increasing affluence, population aging, and awareness of catastrophic risks. By working together, Singapore and London can develop responsive and relevant insurance solutions for the Asian market.

site_title: Moore's Law hits 50 as chip industry faces new challenges
summary: Intel Corp co-founder Gordon Moore marked 50 years since predicting the doubling of transistors on computer chips every two years, known as Moore's Law. The law, first proposed in 1965, has driven progress in the electronics industry for five decades. Despite the milestone, the chip industry faces new challenges, including the transition to new technologies and the increasing complexity of integrated systems. Moore's Law remains a significant predictor of progress in the industry, with its continued relevance a testament to its enduring impact.

site_title: SingPost's Q4 net profit down 51.6% on lower fair-value gain
summary: SingPost's Q4 net profit fell 51.6% to S$38.5 million due to a change in accounting policy for investment properties. Underlying net profit rose 14.9% to S$41.1 million, driven by growth in e-commerce and logistics businesses. Revenue increased 28.7% to S$248.1 million. The company recommended a final dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents per share, totaling 6.25 cents for the year.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: OKH Group turns in a loss for Q3
summary: OKH Global reported a Q3 loss of S$1.63 million, down from a net profit of S$642,000 last year, due to a 24% decline in revenue to S$6.08 million. The firm attributed the decline to the absence of development income and lower third-party construction services income. However, higher income from property investments partially offset the reduction. The group's 9-month revenue of S$249.1 million surpassed the full-year 2014 revenue of S$223.1 million.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Oil trades above US$60 as US production growth seen slowing
summary: Oil prices rose above $60 a barrel amid forecasts that US production growth is slowing. The US Energy Information Administration reported a 1% decline in US oil production in May and a further decline in June. This led to a 2.2% increase in oil futures, the highest in three days. Crude inventories in the US fell to 487 million barrels, and the number of active oil rigs decreased to 668, a 58% drop since December.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff salvo by President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow considers higher fees for its £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Singapore Wrap: Tuesday, May 12
summary: Singapore property resale prices and volume declined in April, with a 0.7% drop in SRX's price index. The Straits Times Index also fell 0.8% on Tuesday, shedding 28.47 points. The US equities drop influenced the Singapore market.

site_title: Q&M Dental to acquire 8 clinics for S$20m
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to acquire eight dental clinics in Singapore for S$20.30 million. The acquisition includes 100% ownership of four clinics for S$12.5 million, two clinics for S$3.8 million to S$2.60 million, and one clinic for S$4 million. Upon completion, Q&M will have 69 clinics and 225 dentists, increasing its team size by 25%. The deals follow Q&M's proposed acquisition of TP Dental Surgeons for S$28.60 million last month.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Yongnam posts Q1 profit despite drop in revenue
summary: Construction firm Yongnam Holdings reported a net profit of S$733,000 for the first quarter of 2015, despite an 8.2% drop in revenue to S$65.9 million. Lower contributions from its specialist civil engineering business and revenue from ongoing projects such as the MRT Downtown Line 2 and structural steelwork projects on Marina One and Changi Terminal 4 contributed to the decline. Earnings per share stood at 0.06 cents, while net asset value was 23.72 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: UOL's Q1 net profit falls 39 per cent in the absence of one-off gain
summary: UOL Group's first-quarter net profit fell 39% to S$74.2 million due to the absence of a one-off gain from the sale of land in Malaysia. Excluding this gain, the net profit would have decreased 3%. Revenue also declined 42% to S$238.3 million. Despite this, property development revenue more than doubled to S$77.3 million, driven by progressive revenue recognition for several projects. The company expects demand for private residential properties to remain muted due to property cooling measures and rising interest costs.

site_title: Hang Seng to sell stake in Industrial Bank for US$2.7b
summary: Hang Seng Bank Ltd will sell up to 950.7 million shares of China's Industrial Bank Co at 17.68 yuan each, worth up to US$2.7 billion, to boost capital. The sale will reduce Hang Seng Bank's stake in Industrial Bank to 0.88%. The proceeds will support future business expansion and the lender will regularly review its remaining shareholding. This sale is part of a trend of global banks divesting shares in Chinese financial institutions due to increased regulatory scrutiny and capital requirements.

images.alt_text: Hang Seng Bank Ltd, the Hong Kong lender controlled by HSBC Holdings Plc, will sell a second stake in China's Industrial Bank Co for as much as US$2.7 billion to boost capital.

site_title: Verizon buying AOL for US$4.4b
summary: Verizon is buying AOL for approximately US$4.4 billion, giving the telecom giant increased digital content and advertising platform space. AOL's assets include popular content providers like The Huffington Post and TechCrunch, as well as a subscription business and original video content. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to close this summer and will not impact AOL's leadership, with Tim Armstrong set to continue leading operations. Verizon shares were initially down 0.68% following the announcement.

site_title: BHP plans deeper cost cuts to battle commodity rout
summary: BHP Billiton plans to cut its iron ore production cost by 21% to $16 per tonne in 2016, as the company battles a downturn in commodity prices. The move is part of a broader cost-cutting effort, with BHP reducing capital and exploration expenditure to $9 billion. This aims to lower costs and increase production of steel ingredients to gain market share in a highly competitive market.

site_title: Adidas not approached by activist investors - CEO
summary: Adidas CEO Herbert Hainer stated that the company has not been approached by activist investors seeking a takeover bid. Despite previous reports, Hainer said nobody has expressed interest in buying Adidas due to the company's strong financial position and market conditions. Adidas has hired advisers to prepare for potential hostile takeover bids, but Hainer defended the move, citing the need to ensure the right intentions of potential investors.

site_title: Indonesia to raise tax on imported raw materials to help manufacturers
summary: Indonesia's government plans to lift taxes on imported raw materials used by manufacturers to attract investment and boost economic growth, which slowed to 4.71% in the first quarter. This measure is part of a package of new government measures aimed at speeding up spending and monetary policy changes. The move is expected to help jump-start the economy, which has been in a slowdown since 2009. The central bank is also preparing to implement monetary policy changes.

site_title: Koh Brothers Q1 profit dips marginally to S$4.71m
summary: Koh Brothers' first-quarter net profit declined marginally to S$4.71 million, driven by a share of loss from joint ventures, despite a 16% increase in revenue to S$117.4 million. The group's earnings per share stood at 1.12 cents, while its net asset value was 57.22 cents per share. No dividend was proposed.

site_title: Bund Center Q1 profit up 35% on higher hotel revenue, leasing income
summary: Bund Center Investment reported a 35% increase in net profit to S$6.56 million in Q1 2015, driven by a 12% rise in revenue due to higher hotel revenue and leasing income. The hotel continues to outperform the average occupancy rate and average room rate in Shanghai. Earnings per share rose to 0.22 Singapore cents, with no dividend recommended.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Thakral Corp posts S$358,000 loss for Q1
summary: Thakral Corp reported a net loss of S$358,000 for Q1 2015, down from a profit of S$172,000 in the same quarter last year. Revenue decreased 56% to S$79.82 million due to a strategic shift away from fast-moving consumer goods. Gross profit increased 15% to S$7.3 million, driven by the investment division's improved performance. The company expects Australia's real estate sector to remain positive and aims to return to profitability in the future.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: ASL Marine Q3 earnings dive on industry downturn
summary: ASL Marine reported a 65.7% drop in net profit to S$1.94 million in its third-quarter earnings, mainly due to a decline in shipbuilding orders and revenue of 56.2% to S$63.42 million. The shipbuilding segment incurred a gross loss due to subcontractor cost overruns. However, the company's ship repair and conversion segment showed better profit margins, offsetting the loss. The group's outstanding shipbuilding orders stood at S$257 million for 18 vessels as of March 31.

site_title: Kingsmen Creatives' Q1 profit falls 14.5%
summary: Kingsmen Creatives reported a 14.5% drop in Q1 net profit to S$0.79 million, from S$0.92 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 3.9% to S$51.9 million, primarily due to lower demand from the high-end luxury retail segment. However, the exhibitions and museums division saw a 23.2% increase in revenue, driven by major projects. The company expects its exhibitions and museums business to continue to perform well, while its retail division is expected to benefit from the expansion of affordable luxury brands in Asian markets.

site_title: Alibaba rolls out 3-hour delivery service for healthcare goods
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd has launched a 3-hour delivery service for healthcare goods in five Chinese cities, including Beijing and Shanghai. The service, called 'Ji Su Da', links shoppers to over 1,500 drugstores through a partnership with pharmacy chains. Cainiao, an Alibaba affiliate, collects and delivers orders. The service aims to provide a seamless shopping experience for consumers who need non-prescription drugs and healthcare products quickly. This move follows Alibaba's efforts to compete with rival JD.com in the logistics network space.

site_title: Singapore: Shares end 0.8 per cent lower
summary: Singapore shares closed 0.8% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index falling 28.47 points to 3442.33, following a drop in US equities. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB declined, while Golden Agri-Resources rose. Losers outnumbered gainers 284 to 154, with the US reassessing emergency liquidity lines for Greece's banking system on Wednesday.

site_title: Guocoleisure posts Q3 profit of US$4.4m
summary: Guocoleisure reported a net profit of US$4.4 million for the third quarter, despite a 14.5% year-on-year decline in revenue to US$77.4 million. The company's nine-month net profit increased 19.7% to US$35.8 million. Revenue was impacted by lower gaming and property development segments, with hotel revenue stable despite refurbishments. The company's earnings per share and net asset value were 0.4 US cents and 83 US cents per ordinary share, respectively.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 6.8 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed 6.8 points lower on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index at 1,798.61. A total of 1.62 billion lots worth RM1.7 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 576 to 240.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close 1.12% lower
summary: Hong Kong shares declined 1.12% on Tuesday, following a two-day rally, as investors took cues from a sell-off in New York amid Greece's stalled bailout reform talks. The Hang Seng Index dropped 311.02 points to 27,407.18, while mainland China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.56% to 4,401.22.

site_title: Broker's take: DBS raises Frasers Hospitality Trust's target price to S$0.96
summary: DBS Group Research has raised the target price of Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) to S$0.96 from S$0.95, following the acquisition of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth in Australia. The hotel's estimated initial net property income yield is between 6-6.5%. DBS analysts believe the acquisition will expand FHT's portfolio and increase its exposure to the growing Sydney market, leading to a projected 17% return. They reiterate their buy recommendation, citing a benign supply outlook and a 4.2% growth in RevPAR in 2014.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China stocks steady after rate-cut rally, Hong Kong weaker
summary: Chinese stocks remained steady on Tuesday, with the CSI300 index rising 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.7%, following a 0.5% gain on Monday. Real estate stocks retreated on profit-taking, but Shenzhen's start-up board ChiNext remained bullish. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index dropped 0.3%. Analysts attribute the market's stability to the recent interest rate cut, but warn that valuations are no longer low, suggesting a consolidation period ahead.

site_title: Australia unveils budget to counter hit from commodities
summary: The Australian government has unveiled a budget aimed at stimulating economic growth and supporting small businesses, shifting focus from reducing the deficit after harsh cuts in welfare and education. The Aus$5.5 billion small business package includes tax cuts and a boost to family-focused policies. The budget forecasts a 2.1% deficit in 2015-16 and a return to budget surplus by 2019-20, despite a 50% fall in iron ore prices and weak wages growth. Defense spending has also increased, with Aus$9.9 billion allocated over four years, including funding for combating the Islamic State group.

site_title: YHI's Q1 profit climbs 8.4 per cent to S$2.1m
summary: YHI International, an automotive manufacturer, reported an 8.4% rise in first-quarter net profit to S$2.1 million, driven by a 7.9% increase in revenue. The company's distribution business saw a 1.5% increase in revenue, while its manufacturing business surged 24.7%. Despite challenges from weak global demand and intense competition, YHI plans to invest in R&D and expand its customer base. The group has also received approval to sell its factory in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Sinarmas Land Q1 net profit jumps 70% on higher revenue, forex gain
summary: Sinarmas Land reported a 70% jump in Q1 net profit to S$79.78 million, driven by 19% revenue growth and a foreign exchange gain of S$23.9 million. Revenue from commercial, office, and industrial land sales in Indonesia increased, offset by lower revenue from completed shophouses. The company attributed its earnings to a stronger dollar and higher foreign direct investment in the first quarter. Despite lower commodity prices, Sinarmas Land remains committed to seeking new investment opportunities outside of Indonesia and remains "cautiously aggressive" in the international real estate market.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Japan puts focus on growth to repair finances
summary: Japan's government has shifted focus to boosting economic growth to repair public finances, aiming for 2-3% real GDP growth and 3% nominal GDP growth. The plan, which includes raising the nationwide sales tax to 10%, aims to reduce the primary budget deficit to 1% of GDP by 2018 and return to a primary budget surplus by 2020. However, critics argue that the plan does not address spending cuts and may not meet fiscal discipline targets, potentially putting the country's credit rating under further pressure.

site_title: Chinese tech founders to join US$1.2b Fosun sale
summary: Chinese tech founders Jack Ma and Ma Huateng are investing in Fosun International Ltd's US$1.2 billion share sale, with funds backed by Alibaba Group and Tencent Holdings. The sale is part of Fosun's plan to take advantage of a Hong Kong market rally. Fosun's parent, backed by billionaire Guo Guangchang, is selling 465 million shares at HK$20 each. The deal comes as Fosun prepares a US$1.84 billion merger with Ironshore Inc and continues its acquisition spree.

site_title: No change to Australia's AAA rating after budget: S&P
summary: Australia's AAA rating with a stable outlook remains unchanged after the government's budget, according to credit agencies Standard & Poor's and Moody's. The budget forecasts moderate and declining deficits, with a deficit of 2.1% of GDP in 2015-16. S&P noted that Australia's budget performance will improve over the next few years, driven by spending restraint. Moody's also stated that Australia's sovereign credit profile benefits from economic and fiscal buffers, maintaining its stable outlook on the AAA rating. Deficits are seen as moderate and declining, with a forecast return to surplus by 2019-20.

site_title: Super Group net profit down 24% to S$13.6m
summary: Super Group, an instant food and beverage maker, reported a net profit of S$13.6 million for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2015, down 24% from S$17.8 million the previous year. Revenue dipped 2% to S$121.7 million. The decline was attributed to lower gross margins and an increased effective tax rate due to the expiry of a tax incentive. Management expects market challenges and will take actions to mitigate their impact on the group's businesses.

site_title: BOJ to boost reserves as record easing
summary: Japan's central bank, the Bank of Japan, is seeking approval to retain 25% of its profit as capital to boost its reserves, aiming to maintain financial health amid record asset purchases. The move aims to absorb potential losses as Governor Haruhiko Kuroda pursues 2% inflation. The bank's total assets have grown to 70% of Japan's annual economic output. The decision is seen as a precautionary measure to prepare for potential losses while pursuing unprecedented bond purchases.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slump on Greece fears
summary: European stock markets declined on Tuesday, mirroring Asian and US market trends, due to concerns over Greece's eurozone future. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.90%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 fell 1.19%, and Paris's CAC 40 lost 1.07%. These losses followed similar declines in Asia and the US, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid uncertainty about Greece's economic prospects.

site_title: UOL Group Q1 net profit slips 39% in absence of one-off gains
summary: UOL Group's Q1 net profit fell 39% to S$74.2 million due to a one-off gain from land sale in 2014. Excluding this gain, profit would have dropped 3%. Revenue decreased 42% to S$238.3 million, but property development revenue more than doubled to S$77.3 million. Shares closed 0.7% lower at S$7.51.

site_title: China says April economic growth within "reasonable range"
summary: China's economic growth in April was within a "reasonable range," according to the National Bureau of Statistics. Industrial output growth quickened slightly to 5.6% in March, but economists expect a slight increase to 6.0% in April. Infrastructure investment rose 20% in the first four months of the year. Despite positive factors, China still faces a "complicated and grim economic environment" at home and abroad, with growth in the US and Japan slowing. The government will fine-tune its policies to ensure a steady growth rate.

site_title: Thai Airways returns to Q1 net profit, shares climb
summary: Thai Airways International reported a net profit of 4.54 billion baht (US$286 million) in the first quarter, reversing a net loss of 2.6 billion baht in the same period last year. The airline attributed the turnaround to a 9.65 billion baht foreign exchange gain and increased tourism traffic, which offset rising restructuring costs. Passenger numbers grew 17% and cabin load factor rose to 75.4%. Shares climbed nearly 6% to 12.70 baht, their highest since April 30, after the earnings disclosure.

site_title: Golden Agri Q1 net profit falls 84% on lower CPO prices
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 84% decline in Q1 net profit to US$17.2 million, due to lower crude palm oil prices and lower plantation output. Revenue fell 19% to US$1.55 billion, with Ebitda decreasing 37% to US$126.4 million. Weaker CPO prices and dry weather conditions in Indonesia led to a 32% decline in revenue from the plantation and palm oil mills segment. The company expects its operating performance to be affected by fluctuating commodity prices and sustainability of the global economic recovery.

site_title: Hot stocks: Pacific Andes, China Fishery among actively traded stocks
summary: Pacific Andes Resources Development and its subsidiary, China Fishery Group, were among the most actively traded stocks on the Singapore Exchange on Tuesday, with over 75 million shares traded. Pacific Andes saw a 4.6% increase to S$0.068 per share, while China Fishery changed hands around 47 million shares. This made Pacific Andes the most actively traded stock on the exchange.

site_title: IOM calls on SEAsia to rescue thousands of migrants stranded at sea
summary: The International Organization for Migration (IOM) has called on Southeast Asian governments to rescue thousands of migrants stranded at sea, fearing up to 8,000 Bangladeshis and Myanmar's Rohingya minority are in peril. A Thai crackdown has curbed smuggling routes, leading to migrants' dwindling supplies. Nearly 2,000 migrants have been rescued or reached shore in Malaysia and Indonesia in recent days, but many remain at risk.

site_title: Greece tapped reserves at IMF to make debt repayment
summary: Greece tapped its International Monetary Fund (IMF) holding account to make a 750 million euro debt payment, using about 650 million euros from the account and 100 million euros from its cash reserves. The move calmed immediate fears of a Greek default, but Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis said a deal to release further funds is needed in the next couple of weeks. The IMF's holding account must be replenished in several weeks.

images.alt_text: Greece tapped emergency reserves in its holding account at the International Monetary Fund to make a crucial 750 million euro (US$839 million) debt payment to the Fund on Monday, two government officials said on Tuesday.

site_title: Norway cuts growth outlook as oil sector woes deepen
summary: Norway's government has revised its 2015 budget due to the contracting offshore energy sector, cutting investment spending and tax revenue. The country will spend more than expected of its saved-up oil wealth, with the overall budget surplus shrinking to 7.7% of GDP. GDP growth on the mainland is expected to slow to 1.3% this year, but could rebound to 2.0% in 2016. Unemployment is forecast to average 4.0% in 2015, above previous estimates. The government expects oil prices to rise in 2016.

site_title: Pteris Global bags 71m yuan contract from Eastern Air Logistics
summary: Pteris Global's subsidiary, CIMC-Tianda Airport Support, secured a 71 million yuan (S$15.3 million) contract from Eastern Air Logistics for cargo handling system equipment at Shanghai Pudong International Airport's west cargo area, expected to be completed by end-2016. The company also entered a strategic framework agreement with SF Express for the supply of sort systems.

site_title: SIAEC posts 36.5 per cent drop in net profit for Q4
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) reported a 36.5% drop in net profit for the fourth quarter, with net profit decreasing from S$65.2 million to S$41.4 million. Revenue declined 11.3% to S$276 million, while earnings per share fell to 3.69 Singapore cents. The company attributed the decline to lower airframe and component overhaul revenue. Despite this, SIAEC remains confident that demand for engine and aircraft maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) work will pick up in the future, with a fleet management joint venture with Boeing aimed at positioning itself for growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Cook says Apple in talks with Alibaba over Apple Pay in China
summary: Apple Inc is in talks with Chinese banks and Alibaba Group Holding Ltd to launch its mobile payments system, Apple Pay, in China. CEO Tim Cook expressed his desire to bring Apple Pay to the Chinese market, citing its potential for rapid growth. China is expected to become Apple's largest market, surpassing the US, with the company aiming to increase its store presence from 22 to 40 by next year. This move could further solidify Apple's position in the Asian market.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit up 44.6% to S$4.8m
summary: SBS Transit's Q1 profit surged 44.6% to S$4.8 million, driven by higher average fare and ridership, as well as lower energy costs. Revenue rose 10.9% to S$247.2 million. Earnings per share increased to 1.54 cents, up from 1.07 cents last year. No dividend was proposed. This growth is attributed to the company's position as Singapore's largest bus operator and rail network manager, operated by ComfortDelGro.

site_title: Oil prices dip on cautious euro zone sentiment, strong dollar
summary: Oil prices dipped on Tuesday due to a cautious euro zone sentiment and a strong dollar. Greece paid 750 million euros to the International Monetary Fund, but concerns over future payments persisted. Oil prices fell 17 cents to US$64.74 a barrel for Brent crude and 9 cents to $59.16 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate. Analysts attribute the price drops to oversupply and production outpacing demand, marking the end of recent rallies.

site_title: Mooted Hong Kong-Taiwan stock link runs into wall of scepticism
summary: A proposed stock link between Hong Kong and Taiwan has faced skepticism, with some traders and investors viewing it as a flawed attempt to replicate the success of the Hong Kong-Shanghai stock connect. The proposed link aims to capitalize on arbitrage opportunities created by the large discount between shares of Chinese companies listed in both markets. Despite the potential for increased turnover, the proposal has yet to gain traction, highlighting the challenges of replicating the success of the Hong Kong-Shanghai stock connect.

site_title: Another strong earthquake hits Nepal
summary: A strong earthquake with a magnitude of 7.1 struck Nepal on Tuesday, 68 km west of Mount Everest, sending people in Kathmandu rushing out of the streets. The quake occurred weeks after a devastating earthquake that killed over 8,000 people. Shockwaves were felt as far away as New Delhi. The US Geological Survey reported the quake's location.

images.alt_text: A strong earthquake shook Nepal on Tuesday, sending people in the capital Kathmandu rushing out on to the streets weeks after a devastating quake killed more than 8,000 people and destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes, eyewitnesses said.

site_title: Shale oil production cuts to get bigger next month, EIA says
summary: US shale oil production is expected to decline by 54,227 barrels a day in May and another 86,000 barrels in June, reaching a five-month low of 5.56 million barrels, according to the Energy Information Administration. This decline is attributed to lower crude prices and reduced drilling activity. However, some drillers, including Pioneer Natural Resources, are preparing to deploy more rigs in US fields as prices recover. Analysts predict that production will continue to decline, with some forecasting a drop of 137,000 barrels a day in the second quarter.

site_title: US media CEOs are top paid even in year when stock prices lagged
summary: US media CEOs received a median compensation of $32.9 million in 2014, significantly higher than any other industry group, according to regulatory filings. This marks the seventh successive year media executives have topped the list, with food & staples retailers coming in second at $24.5 million.

site_title: India's small infrastructure firms turn to market as banks lag
summary: India's smaller infrastructure firms are turning to share sales to fund new projects amid a slowdown in bank credit due to rising bad loans and slowing earnings growth. The government aims to invest US$1 trillion in infrastructure over five years, with half coming from private companies. Smaller firms are capitalizing on the country's stock market boom to secure funding, a revival in infrastructure spending seen as key to accelerating growth in Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Australia looks to avoid voter backlash with 'fair' budget
summary: Australia's Treasurer Joe Hockey has announced a "responsible and fair" budget aimed at avoiding voter backlash, focusing on families and small businesses. The budget seeks to address the country's slumping revenue and huge deficit, following a poor reaction to the government's maiden budget last year, which cut welfare, education, and health spending. The conservative government hopes to mitigate the impact of the deficit and regain public support, after a challenge to Prime Minister Tony Abbott's leadership following the previous budget.

site_title: Asia: Shares mostly lower on Wall St loss, Greek fears
summary: Asian markets declined on Tuesday following losses on Wall Street, with Tokyo slipping 0.51% and Hong Kong losing 0.36%. However, Shanghai rose 0.48% after China's interest rate cut raised hopes for further economic measures. Greece's bailout reform talks continue, with the EU-IMF bloc's finance ministers stating that Greece cannot receive the final 7.2-billion-euro tranche until it makes key reforms.

site_title: Toshiba slumps a second day as analysts suspend ratings on probe
summary: Toshiba's stock fell 3.2% to 391 yen, extending a 19% decline over two days, after Goldman Sachs suspended ratings due to an investigation into improper accounting on projects. Toshiba is reviewing accounting methods for nuclear, hydroelectric, and wind power equipment, and may restate earnings as far back as 2013. The company's probe covers various units, including air-traffic control and railway systems. This is the sixth bank to suspend ratings since Toshiba announced the investigation on May 8.

site_title: Goldman must pay National Australia US$80 million, panel says
summary: A Financial Industry Regulatory Authority arbitration panel has ordered Goldman Sachs to repay US$80 million, including US$60 million in interest, for its role in a mortgage security that National Australia Bank invested in before the 2008 financial crisis. The panel found "knowing and material omissions and misstatements" in Goldman Sachs's marketing materials, which masked the firm's significant conflict of interest with clients. National Australia Bank originally sought US$230 million in damages, but the ruling settles the case.

site_title: Singapore developers face competition from home sellers in slow market
summary: Singapore's slow housing market is forcing developers to reconsider pricing as resales now account for nearly half of all private residential transactions. Falling rentals and expected mortgage payment increases are prompting homeowners and investors to sell. The stock of completed homes is expected to grow 7% this year, pushing vacancy rates higher. To appeal to buyers, property agents are advising clients to rent furniture and decor. Analysts warn that the low-to-mid-range market may be next to feel the pinch, with smaller companies like Hock Lian Seng Holdings Ltd facing pressure from a rising inventory of unsold units.

site_title: Qantas shares surge as airline says fuel bill to drop this year
summary: Qantas shares rose 6.6% to their highest level in over six years, reaching A$3.54, after the airline announced a 36% drop in jet fuel prices would reduce its fuel bill by A$550 million this year. The company's fuel bill could be as low as A$3.92 billion, leaving more money to invest elsewhere. CEO Tino La Spina stated that the airline's balance sheet is in optimal shape, allowing it to wait before buying new planes, potentially saving finance costs by buying back plane leases.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index closes flat
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index closed flat on Tuesday, offsetting early losses with late bargain-hunting. The Nikkei 225 rose 0.02% to 19,624.84, while the Topix index rose 0.25%. Investors are watching Greece's bailout talks, and global stocks have been driven by US-EU trade talks and US stock records.

site_title: Japan should focus on spending cuts in meeting fiscal goal: LDP panel
summary: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) panel on fiscal reform recommends focusing on spending cuts to meet its goal of turning its primary budget deficit into a surplus by 2020. The proposal, set to be presented to the panel, urges the government to cut spending in areas such as social welfare, citing the need to address the country's massive fiscal deficit. Relying solely on economic growth would be insufficient, and the panel emphasizes the importance of finding ways to reduce spending to meet the fiscal 2020 deadline.

site_title: Kerry, China leaders to meet in Beijing on May 16-17
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry will meet senior Chinese leaders in Beijing on May 16-17, amid heightened concerns over China's maritime claims and North Korea. Kerry will discuss the US-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue and Chinese President Xi Jinping's expected US visit in September. This meeting comes as the US navigates China's growing influence in the region and global financial system, particularly with the establishment of the China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.

site_title: Coming soon to your smartwatch: ads targeting captive eyeballs
summary: Advertisers are developing ads for smartwatches, anticipating a boom in wearables after the Apple Watch's introduction. About 15,000 people using the Golfshot app on Android-based smartwatches saw a sponsored message take over the screen for five seconds. This marks the first wearable ads to go live, with no product with a Web-connected screen expected to be safe from future ads, including home coffee makers and cars. Advertisers are rushing to create ads and marketing messages for the nascent industry, further blurring the lines between advertising and personal experiences.

site_title: In bid to diversify, Brunei aims for stock exchange by 2017
summary: Brunei plans to launch a stock exchange by 2017, aiming to diversify its economy and catch up with regional economic integration plans. The country relies heavily on oil and gas exports, with GDP expected to shrink by 1.5% in 2015. The Autoriti Monetari Brunei Darussalam (AMBD) has set up a team to oversee the project, with initial focus on listing equities and bonds, and a deep and liquid market expected in several years. This move aims to boost the domestic financial sector, provide an alternative funding source for small businesses, and improve corporate governance.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks open lower
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 5.54 points to 1,799.95 points. The decline was due to a higher number of losers (92) compared to gainers (75). Volume was 61.1 million lots worth RM 29.8 million.

site_title: BOJ not considering changing interest paid on excess reserves
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank is not considering lowering or cancelling interest payments on excess reserves held by commercial banks. These interest payments help the BOJ achieve its goal of expanding the monetary base, according to Kuroda. The decision is seen as a move to maintain the current monetary policy framework.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda said on Tuesday he is not considering lowering or cancelling the interest that the central bank pays on excess reserves that commercial banks keep at the BOJ.

site_title: GE says EU has halted review of Alstom deal
summary: European competition officials have suspended their review of General Electric's proposed $14 billion acquisition of Alstom's energy business, temporarily halting the investigation process. The suspension does not signify a major barrier to winning approval, and GE is willing to explore remedies to get the deal done. The US industrial giant still has not received a statement of objections from the agency, and the delay may push the approval timeframe back several weeks from the original August 6 deadline. GE chief executive Jeff Immelt met with EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager earlier this month.

site_title: Taiwan stocks down slightly, early buying taken over by tech concerns
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index fell 0.1% to 9,656.40 on Tuesday, as early buying gave way to concerns over the tech sector. Quanta Computer and Acer shares declined 2.7% and 4% respectively, while Compal Electronics fell 7% after reporting a net profit drop. The broader electronics subindex also dropped 0.6%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$30.749 to the US dollar. The decline followed a nearly 2% fall in the index since the start of the month.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index slipping 12.68 points, or 0.06%, to 19,608.23, amid uncertainty over the Greek debt deal. Eurozone finance ministers failed to reach an agreement on Greece's bailout funds, citing tough negotiations. Sharp rose 2.63% and Toshiba fell 5.53% in Tokyo trading, while the euro remained weak early Tuesday.

site_title: EasyJet well positioned after posting winter-season profit
summary: British low-cost airline easyJet reported its first winter-season profit, driven by strong forward bookings and lower fuel costs due to lower oil prices. The airline forecasts growth in revenue and profit for the 12 months ending September, despite a 25 million-pound hit from air traffic control strikes in April. EasyJet attributed the disruption to cancelled flights in France.

site_title: France's central bank sees 0.3% growth in second quarter
summary: France's central bank predicts 0.3% economic growth in the second quarter, driven by solid industrial production. This growth is expected to continue in May after a strong April. However, the bank forecasts a slight dip in construction activity this month. The forecast is a positive sign for the eurozone's second-largest economy.

site_title: Tesla to modify new cars to match China's charging standards
summary: Tesla will modify its new cars to meet China's national charging standards, aiming to boost sales in the world's largest auto market. The company will support the upcoming standards and ensure vehicle compatibility. Tesla's China General Manager Zhu Xiaotong stated that solving charging issues is vital for electric vehicle promotion. The company is expanding its charging network to alleviate "range anxiety" and retraining its sales force. This move comes after Tesla saw "encouraging signs of a return to growth in orders" in China, with CEO Elon Musk describing the sales force as "brain-dead."

site_title: Hong Kong stock slip 0.19% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.19% in early trading on May 12, 2015, following a sell-off on Wall Street linked to concerns over Greece's debt talks. The benchmark Hang Seng index eased 54.02 points to 27,664.18, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.20%. This contrasts with other Asian markets, where the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.73% and the Singapore Stock Index notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint offers S$200m seven-year bonds at 3.65%
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited is offering S$200m seven-year bonds at 3.65% yield. The company is selling S$150m to the public and S$50m to institutional investors, with DBS as the sole bookrunner and underwriter. The bonds will be issued in the name of FCL Treasury Pte Ltd, with Frasers Centrepoint Ltd as the guarantor. The offering ends on May 20, and the issuer may cancel or increase the offering if demand falls short or exceeds expectations.

site_title: Genting Malaysia unit to sell stake in Genting Hong Kong for RM$1.7b
summary: Genting Malaysia Bhd, a Malaysian gaming firm, has announced plans to sell its 17.81% stake in Genting Hong Kong Ltd for at least RM1.7 billion (S$628.5 million) in cash. The sale, which could include open market or off-market transactions, has not been finalized, with no buyers identified at this stage. The minimum disposal price per share is set at US$0.33, representing a significant increase from the original purchase price of US$0.42 per share between 1998 and 2006.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Bumitama Agri, APTT, Changtian Plastic & Chemical, Wheelock Properties, Achieva
summary: Bumitama Agri reported a 41% decline in net profit to 181.57 billion Indonesian rupiah due to lower selling prices and higher costs. APTT posted a net loss of S$5.56 million due to increased capital expenditure. Changtian Plastic & Chemical's net profit surged to 13.8 million yuan on disposal gains, but revenue fell 29.3%. Wheelock Properties reported a 14% decline in profit to S$12.26 million, while Achieva plans to shift focus to becoming a marina owner and operator after four years of losses.

site_title: Sharp and Toshiba shares plunge
summary: Sharp's shares plummeted 31% in Tokyo as the electronics giant plans a 99% capital reduction to wipe away years of losses. Toshiba also fell 16.55% after withdrawing its earnings forecast and citing accounting problems on infrastructure projects. The Japanese conglomerate faces massive selling pressure and may revise past earnings. Both companies are struggling with declining sales and increased competition, with Sharp's TV unit particularly affected. The rare capital reduction move aims to address years of losses and stabilize the companies' finances.

site_title: Condo resale prices and volume slip in April: SRX
summary: Singapore's resale prices of non-landed private homes slipped 0.7% in April, with the Core Central Region and Outside Central Region experiencing declines of 0.1% and 1.5% respectively. City-fringe homes in Rest of Central Region saw a 0.4% rise. Compared to last year, resale prices dropped 4%, with prices 6.9% lower than the peak in January 2014. Resale volume also decreased 2.7% to 440 units, but was 1.9% higher than the same period last year.

site_title: Audi edges ahead of BMW in luxury-car sales
summary: Audi surpassed BMW in luxury car sales in April, with 152,850 deliveries, a 2.5% increase, compared to BMW's 148,896, a 5.6% increase. Mercedes-Benz posted an 11% gain to 148,072 cars. BMW vows to defend its annual lead despite aging models, with new models such as the Gran Tourer and a pickup truck planned.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as market eyes Greece talks
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, snapping a two-day surge, amid concerns over Greece's negotiations with international creditors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.47%, the S&P 500 fell 0.51%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.20%. The market eyed the tough talks, which may impact the global economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed as Airbus leads French stocks lower
summary: European stock markets were mixed on Monday, with French stocks declining due to the crash of an Airbus military plane, which led to a 2.1% drop in Airbus shares. However, gains in mining stocks and a rate cut in China supported the market, with the pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rising 0.3%. Despite declines in major euro-zone indexes, heavyweight miners and retailers such as Delhaize and Ahold contributed to the broader market's gains.

site_title: Apple working with WWF China to manage sustainable forests
summary: Apple is partnering with the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) China to manage 1 million acres of forests in China over five years. The project aims to plant trees, implement environmental standards, and reduce land and water usage to produce paper. This initiative is part of Apple's broader efforts to reduce its environmental impact, including powering facilities with renewable energy and reducing its supply chain's impact. Apple's CEO, Tim Cook, announced the new green initiatives during his visit to Beijing.

site_title: Shale drillers capitulating in Europe as Poland proves no Texas
summary: Shale drillers in Europe, particularly in Poland and the UK, are struggling to capitalize on the US shale boom due to high costs, complex regulations, and fierce environmental opposition. Despite Europe's desire to reduce its reliance on Russian gas, the continent's geological conditions and bureaucratic hurdles have hindered the development of shale gas. The UK's Cuadrilla Resources has yet to drill a well in Poland, and other major companies such as Exxon, Chevron, and Shell have abandoned their operations in the region. Europe's estimated shale reserves are significant, but the lack of a critical mass of wells and environmental concerns have led to a collapse of investor enthusiasm.

images.alt_text: When Cuadrilla Resources Ltd opened an office in Poland in 2009, it had a reason to be optimistic: the shale boom was transforming the US into the world's largest producer of natural gas.

site_title: Picasso painting at US$179.4m sets world auction record
summary: Pablo Picasso's 1955 painting "Les Femmes d'Alger (Version ''O'')" sold for US$179.4 million at Christie's, setting a world auction record. The painting, which depicts semi-naked courtesans, was part of a special evening auction that also featured works by Alberto Giacometti, Jean Dubuffet, and Chaim Soutine, among others. The sale surpassed Christie's presale target of US$500 million and included other notable works, including Giacometti's bronze sculpture, which sold for US$141.3 million.

site_title: Euro drops as eurozone meeting misses Greek debt deal
summary: The euro dropped against other major currencies after a eurozone finance ministers' meeting in Brussels failed to reach an agreement on Greece's bailout funds. The meeting stated that Greece cannot receive the final 7.2-billion-euro payment until it makes key reforms. The Eurogroup welcomed progress, but acknowledged the need for more time and effort to address remaining issues. The decision may lead to Greece's potential default, increasing economic uncertainty in the eurozone.

images.alt_text: The euro dropped against other major currencies on Monday after a meeting of eurozone finance ministers failed to reach an agreement on debt-riddled Greece's bid for bailout funds to avoid default.

site_title: Noble Agri appoints new CEO
summary: NOBLE Agri, the agribusiness unit of commodity trader Noble Group, has appointed Matt Jansen as its new CEO. Jansen, previously senior vice-president and president of Archer Daniels Midland's (ADM) global oilseeds, takes the role after seven years leading ADM's Brazilian operation. He replaces an unnamed CEO. Noble Group owns a 49% stake in Noble Agri, having sold a 51% stake to Chinese state-owned firm Cofco last year.

site_title: US$ slides as reflation expectations turn losers into winners
summary: The US dollar has seen a significant decline, its biggest loss since 2011, as reflation expectations have risen. This shift in market sentiment has led to a surge in currencies like the euro, Norway's, Sweden's, and Canada's, which were previously weighed down by deflation concerns. Investors are becoming more optimistic about these nations due to central-bank stimulus, leading to a reversal in fortunes for last year's worst performers.

site_title: Oil prices dip on drilling data
summary: US oil prices dipped on Monday, with West Texas Intermediate falling 14 cents to $59.25 a barrel and European benchmark Brent oil falling 48 cents to $64.91 a barrel. The decline is attributed to concerns over oversupply, with US data showing increased petroleum drilling in some areas.

site_title: Fair-value, exchange gains boost Cordlife's Q3 bottom line
summary: CORDLIFE Group reported a net profit of S$18.1 million for Q3 2015, a surge of over 10 times from the previous year. Revenue rose 20.9% to S$14.3 million, driven by an increase in client deliveries. Financial-asset and derivative gains totaled S$11.3 million, and exchange differences contributed S$4.6 million to the boost.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Australia Budget deficit under forecasts: Treasurer
summary: Australia's government budget deficit is expected to undershoot market forecasts, with Treasurer Joe Hockey stating it will "beat" the predicted A$40-A$41 billion shortfall. The budget aims to set a credible trajectory back to surplus and is deemed the "right budget for the times."

site_title: Singapore: STI opens 1.06 points higher
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.06 points or 0.03% to 3,471.86, driven by China's central bank cutting rates for the third time in six years and concerns over Greece's debt problems. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 69, with Pacific Andes International Holdings and Noble Group among the most active stocks. A total of 35.8 million shares worth S$51.2 million changed hands.

site_title: Malaysia faces Fitch judgment day as oil fails to allay concern
summary: Malaysia's credit rating is set to be reviewed by Fitch Ratings, with concerns over the nation's deteriorating finances ahead of the second-quarter review. Despite an oil rally that has made Malaysian bonds Asia's best performers over the past three months, the government's shrinking current-account surplus and build-up of contingent liabilities remain a concern. Fitch warns that the rating view will not be driven by small changes in oil prices, and the nation's underlying economic and governance weaknesses remain unchanged.

site_title: India's mixed economic data to build case for faster reforms
summary: India's mixed economic data is expected to pressure Prime Minister Narendra Modi to accelerate reforms as he approaches his first anniversary in office. Despite a cooling inflation rate, driven by global oil price falls, India's economy remains sluggish. Modi's government has promised to reboot growth and tame inflation, but progress has been slow. As Modi prepares to address the economy, experts are calling for faster reforms to boost growth and stabilize the economy.

site_title: Greece makes progress but warns of cash crunch
summary: Greece has made progress in its bailout talks, repaying 750 million euros to the IMF and avoiding a default. However, eurozone finance ministers rejected Greece's request for a 7.2-billion-euro tranche, citing the need for key reforms. Greece warned that it faces a cash crunch within two weeks without a deal, raising concerns about the country's economic stability. The country's radical new government remains committed to implementing reforms to secure the remaining bailout funds.

site_title: 'Natural' rate of US unemployment could fall to 4.4%: Fed paper
summary: The Chicago Federal Reserve Bank research suggests the natural US unemployment rate could fall to 4.4% by 2020, potentially allowing the economy to sustain a lower rate of joblessness without inflation concerns. This could support more dovish interest rate policies. The estimated natural rate is lower than the Fed's average estimate of 5.1%, indicating the Fed can keep rates lower for longer to spur investment and job creation. However, the natural rate is difficult to estimate and changes over time.

site_title: Smartphones among top gadgets for Americans: survey
summary: Smartphones have become the third most owned electronics item in US homes, with 72% of households possessing one. This is up 8 percentage points from the previous year. Televisions remain the most owned, in 97% of US households, followed by DVD players. The survey also found tablet computers are present in 54% of US households, with laptop computers and digital cameras also in the top 5. Basic cell phones are declining, while fitness trackers and digital media streaming devices are on the rise.

site_title: This US$2.1 billion shale deal will be the first of many to come
summary: Noble Energy Inc has agreed to acquire Rosetta Resources Inc for $2.1 billion in an all-stock deal. This deal is the first major shale transaction since the oil price collapse in 2015 and signals a wave of industry consolidation. Rosetta shareholders will receive 0.542 Noble shares for each share held, valuing Rosetta at $26.62 per share. The deal is seen as a model for future transactions and promises to quickly change the industry as companies expand in new areas or soak up struggling rivals.

site_title: Google self-driving cars not crash-proof
summary: Google's self-driving cars have been involved in accidents despite their advanced technology, with seven rear-end collisions and a couple of side-swipes, according to Chris Urmson, head of Google's autonomous car program. These incidents occurred mainly at traffic lights and on freeways. The accidents highlight that even highly advanced self-driving cars are not crash-proof, emphasizing the need for continued improvement in safety and technology.

site_title: US backs existing arbitration procedures for foreign investors
summary: The US has defended existing arbitration procedures for foreign investors, citing the lack of evidence that they undermine national sovereignty. US Undersecretary Stefan Selig stated that Investor-State Dispute Settlement (ISDS) mechanisms have not resulted in a loss of sovereignty for countries and instead increase investment security. The US believes ISDS makes countries more attractive investment destinations. EU Trade Commissioner Cecilia Malmstroem proposed creating an international investment court to address concerns, but the US has not rejected the proposal, instead suggesting that it needs to see the proposal before commenting on its merits.

site_title: Separate car dealers from buyers in COE bidding
summary: In Singapore, COE (Certificate of Entitlement) bidding system has raised concerns about price fixing, with dealers often submitting high bids on behalf of buyers. Dealers have intimate knowledge of supply and demand, and their decisions are influenced by each other, potentially controlling market prices. To address this, splitting COEs in half for dealer and private bids could help demonstrate that prices reflect market demand, rather than dealer manipulation. This system change would give buyers more freedom to choose and show COE prices are an accurate reflection of market prices.

site_title: China, India drive 'tipping point' in global income inequality levels
summary: China and India have driven a significant reduction in global income inequality levels, with billions lifted out of poverty. The World Economic Forum cites this as a major turning point in addressing the issue, which is a key concern for politicians and religious leaders worldwide. The US presidential election campaign has highlighted the topic, with candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton emphasizing their commitment to the working class. Meanwhile, Pope Francis has described global economic inequality as a "pure scandal." This shift in global economic dynamics has major implications for addressing income inequality.

site_title: Changtian Plastic & Chemical's Q1 net profit soars on disposal gain
summary: Changtian Plastic & Chemical Limited reported a 13.8 million yuan net profit in the first quarter of 2015, primarily driven by a 12.2 million yuan disposal gain from machinery and equipment. Revenue fell 29.3% to 20.3 million yuan due to lower sales volume and prices amid tough market conditions. The company's sales of adhesive tapes, UV cured release film, and release papers declined significantly. Construction of a new plant to produce Nylon-6 chips is 37% complete, with machinery installation expected in May 2015.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: China mulls over opening up its securities market further
summary: China is considering further opening up its securities market to foreign investment banks, potentially allowing them to buy majority stakes in local joint ventures and expand into areas like stock broking and wealth management. This move could bring in more institutional money to help mitigate the boom-bust cycles of its stock markets and align the interests of the government and foreign banks. However, foreign firms face challenges, including limited market share and lack of expertise in areas like secondary-market trading and managing Chinese block trades. China's President Xi Jinping may use negotiations on a bilateral investment treaty to extract concessions, potentially delaying an easing of restrictions.

site_title: Bumitama Agri's Q1 profit plunges 41%
summary: Bumitama Agri's Q1 profit plummeted 41% to 181.57 billion Indonesian rupiah due to lower crude palm oil and palm kernel prices, higher cost of sales, and foreign-exchange losses. Revenues held steady at 1.33 trillion rupiah. The company expects soft crude palm oil prices, but supports are in place to sustain demand for biodiesel, which could provide price support. Despite this, the palm-oil industry's long-term fundamentals remain strong, with the company focusing on yield and production improvement, cost containment, and capacity building.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint in A$464m sale, leaseback of Sydney hotel
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has announced a proposed A$464 million sale-and-leaseback arrangement for the Sofitel Sydney Wentworth hotel in Sydney, Australia. Frasers Sydney Wentworth Trust will grant a 75-year leasehold interest to FHT Sydney Trust 3, an Australian sub-trust, for A$224 million, funded by equity and debt financing. The transaction marks a significant sale for the iconic heritage-listed hotel, with Frasers Hospitality Reit's sub-trust taking on the long-term ownership.

site_title: Oil rally seen fading with millions of barrels still unsold
summary: Oil prices, which have risen over 40% in London since a six-year low in January, are expected to decline as a surplus of unsold crude oil persists. Barclays, Societe Generale, and Morgan Stanley predict prices will slip before the end of the quarter due to slowing US crude output and rising global inventories. About 80 million barrels of Nigerian and Angolan crude remain unsold, equivalent to three weeks of combined production from those countries. The disconnect between futures and physical markets is growing, with exchange for physical contracts at a discount of 55 cents a barrel.

images.alt_text: Rallying oil prices are masking a persisting surplus that will thwart further gains, according to Barclays Plc, Societe Generale SA and Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Retailers turn to virtual reality to lure shoppers back into stores
summary: Retailers are turning to virtual reality to attract gadget-addicted customers back into stores. A push to remake in-store shopping is underway, with VR technology playing a key role. Companies are using immersive experiences to engage shoppers and create memorable experiences, such as a skydiving simulation. This shift aims to bridge the gap between online and offline shopping, offering a unique and interactive way to experience products.

images.alt_text: North Face offers a virtual reality experience using Oculus and Jaunt technology to provide customers with a view of what it's like to rock climb and base jump.

site_title: Asia Pay Television Trust declares 2 cent DPU for Q1
summary: Asia Pay Television Trust posted a net loss of S$5.56 million for Q1 2015, compared to a net profit of S$17.89 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 6.6% to S$82.29 million due to higher cable television revenue. The trust declared a 2-cent distribution per unit for Q1.
