site_title: Rosberg cruises to Spanish Grand Prix win
summary: Nico Rosberg won the Spanish Grand Prix, beating teammate Lewis Hamilton for the first time this season. Rosberg took the lead with a commanding victory, cutting Hamilton's lead to 20 points. Hamilton had lost the battle for pole position and struggled to catch up throughout the race. This was Rosberg's first win of the season, and it marked a significant shift in the Formula One world championship.

site_title: US Museum returns looted statue to Cambodia
summary: The Cleveland Museum of Art in the US returned a 10th-century sandstone statue of the Hindu monkey god Hanuman to Cambodia, ending a decades-long absence. The statue, stolen from a jungle temple in the 1970s, was received by Cambodian officials on Sunday night. The artwork was part of a larger agreement to return looted statues, following similar returns of the "Kneeling Attendants" statues in 2013. The return is seen as a significant step in preserving Cambodia's cultural heritage and is welcomed by the Cambodian government.

site_title: Greece hoping for nod of approval at eurozone meeting
summary: Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras expressed hope for a loan deal with creditors at an upcoming eurozone meeting, seeking a clear confirmation of progress made in talks. The deal, which has been elusive for nearly four months, should respect the mandate of his leftist government from January elections. Tsipras' comments came as the country faces financial strain and a potential exit from the eurozone.

site_title: Fosun International plans up to US$1.2b in HK share sale: term sheet
summary: Fosun International plans to raise up to $1.2 billion in a Hong Kong share offering, with the sale of $1 billion of new shares priced between HK$19.48 and HK$20.32 each, a discount of up to 7%. The deal is being led by Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, and others. Trading of Fosun International shares was halted on Monday, with the shares being offered in an indicative range. The offering could increase by $200 million if there is additional demand.

images.alt_text: The Chinese conglomerate founded by billionaire Guo Guangchang plans to sell US$1 billion of new shares, the terms showed.

site_title: Asian stocks rise after China rate cut, US payrolls
summary: Asian stocks rose after China cut interest rates for the third time in six months, dampening speculation of a US Federal Reserve rate hike in June. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.6% and Japan's Topix index rose 1.2%, while US jobs data failed to prompt a Fed rate hike. Ten-year Treasury yields fell for a third day, and bond rates in Australia to Japan slipped. Asian markets also rose in anticipation of a potential extension of the US stocks rally despite new Trump threats.

site_title: Crude-oil bulls threatened as shale patch revives drilling plans
summary: The US shale oil industry is reviving its drilling plans, threatening to revive crude oil prices. Money managers increased their net-long position in West Texas Intermediate crude by 3.9% in the week ended May 5, the highest level since July. Companies like EOG Resources Inc. are resuming drilling plans, despite a government prediction of lower output this month. This could worsen the US supply glut and raise concerns about the market.

site_title: Vallianz's Q1 profit rises 5% to US$4.97m
summary: Vallianz Holdings reported a 5% increase in net profit to US$4.97 million for Q1 2015, driven by higher revenue from charter, brokerage, ship management, and shipyard services. Revenue jumped to US$60.73 million from US$27.71 million in the same period last year. The growth was attributed to acquisitions made in the final quarter of 2014.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Airbus to continue A400M test flights following crash
summary: Airbus plans to continue test flights for the A400M military transport plane despite a fatal crash in Spain. The incident prompted Britain, Germany, and Turkey to ground their fleets, while France limited the use of its six A400Ms to critical flights. The crash is the latest setback for the project, which has faced delays and cost overruns. Airbus will continue to assess the safety of the aircraft before resuming commercial operations.

images.alt_text: Europe's biggest aerospace company, Airbus, said on Sunday it would continue test flights for the A400M military transport plane after the fatal crash of one of the aircraft on a test flight in Spain.

site_title: In South Korea, skin care cosmetics for men are big business
summary: In South Korea, men are increasingly investing in skin care, boosting the country's booming cosmetics industry. The nation's beauty market, valued at $10 billion, has seen a significant surge in sales from men's products, with over 10% of domestic sales now coming from men. Products such as toners, essences, and BB cream are popular, with brands like Innisfree and Tony Moly catering to the growing male market. The trend is seen as a reflection of South Korea's competitive society, where looking good is seen as a key factor in career advancement and social acceptance.

site_title: Politics trumps economics as Abbott stakes future on dull budget
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has released his first budget, prioritizing politics over economics as he seeks to maintain voter support. The budget aims to help families and small businesses, stepping back from budget repair measures despite Australia's finances deteriorating due to slowing growth and plunging commodity prices. The government faces a challenge to Abbott's leadership and is also grappling with an aging population and an outdated taxation system.

site_title: Wearable gadgets give rise to extreme tracking
summary: A growing trend of wearable gadgets and personal tracking devices is revolutionizing the way people monitor and optimize their physical and mental health. Experts like Larry Smarr and Vinod Khosla believe that aggregating data from these devices can reveal patterns and correlations that can inform decisions about diet, exercise, and environment to prevent disease. However, critics raise concerns about the accuracy, privacy, and potential surveillance implications of this trend, with some devices even tracking sensitive personal data.

site_title: Swiss business doing well months after franc shock
summary: Swiss businesses are adapting to the strong Swiss franc, which rose after the country's central bank abandoned its cap in January. To mitigate the impact, companies are adjusting prices, entering new markets, and implementing flexible working hours. While some sectors, such as tourism and machinery, are struggling, others like high-end cosmetics and watchmakers are benefiting from the franc's strength. Economists predict modest growth in 2015, with some firms forecasting a 0.7% growth rate, despite concerns about potential deindustrialization and job losses.

site_title: EU's unraveling plans for Greek debt may win Tsipras IMF support
summary: Greece's ballooning debt load casts doubt on the International Monetary Fund's role in future bailouts. The European Commission forecasts Greece's debt to be 174% of gross domestic product next year, 15 percentage points above the level projected in February. This raises concerns about the IMF's ability to provide more funds. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' plans to get previously agreed aid flowing may be crucial in securing IMF support.

site_title: First Resources' Q1 profit falls 38.5%, hit by lower palm-oil prices
summary: FIRST Resources reported a 38.5% drop in Q1 net profit to US$27.7 million, primarily due to lower palm-oil prices and declining sales volumes. Revenue fell 46% to US$96.3 million, while Ebitda declined 21% to US$53.4 million. The company attributed the decline to weak crude oil and soya-bean oil prices, as well as slowing demand in China, which will continue to exert pressure on palm-oil prices in the near term.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Dollar suffers as reflation trade transforms losers into winners
summary: The US dollar has suffered its largest loss since 2011 due to the reflation trade, which has transformed last year's losers into winners. Investors are becoming more optimistic on economies outside the US, with signs that central-bank stimulus is generating sustainable growth. The euro, Norwegian krone, Canadian dollar, and Colombian peso have all gained at least 4% in the past month. Hedge funds are trimming their bets on a stronger dollar, and emerging-market countries, particularly in Asia, are seen as better investment opportunities.

site_title: Hong Kong, China stocks lifted by rate cut
summary: Hong Kong and mainland China stocks rose on Monday after Beijing cut interest rates for the third time since November, boosting investor confidence. The Hang Seng index rose 259.70 points to 27,837.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index increased 0.60% to 4,231.27. The rate cut followed a strong US jobs report, lifting market sentiment and extending the rally in Asia.

site_title: Uber fundraising points to new US$50b valuation
summary: Uber is fundraising again, with early talks of a new round of financing that could value the company at $50 billion, making it the world's most valuable private startup. The new capital will not be used for expansion, but rather for strategic partnerships. This fundraising comes as many Silicon Valley startups have been on a fundraising tear, with Uber's valuation nearly tripling that of other elite startups. The company's valuation surpasses that of Xiaomi, FedEx, and Nissan Motor, and is the highest private valuation of a startup, surpassing Facebook's $50 billion valuation.

site_title: TPG-backed DTZ to buy Cushman & Wakefield for US$2b: WSJ
summary: DTZ, a commercial real-estate services firm backed by TPG, agreed to buy Cushman & Wakefield Inc for US$2 billion, retaining the Cushman & Wakefield name. The combined company will have over US$5 billion in annual revenue and 250 offices in 50 countries. This deal comes after Exor, the parent company of Cushman & Wakefield, received non-binding expressions of interest last month. The acquisition is expected to strengthen the combined company's global presence in the commercial real-estate services market.

site_title: China Fishery's Q2 profit down 75.5% to US$4.3m
summary: China Fishery Group reported a 75.5% decline in Q2 net profit to US$4.3 million due to the Peruvian government's closure of the north-centre fishery. Revenue fell 57% to US$76.7 million, and earnings per share decreased to 0.21 US cents. The company's parent, Pacific Andes Resources Development, also saw a 74% drop in net profit to HK$46 million. Despite a lower group net-debt-to-equity ratio, the firm's gearing levels are expected to be reduced, positively impacting interest expenses and the balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint unveils A$464m sale and leaseback of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited has announced a proposed A$464 million sale-and-leaseback of Sofitel Sydney Wentworth, a 436-room heritage-listed hotel in Sydney. The deal involves a 75-year leasehold interest to Frasers Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust for A$224 million, funded by equity and debt financing. The initial term of the master lease is 20 years, with an option to renew for another 20 years, and a fixed rent of A$6.0 million per annum. The deal aims to reduce the company's borrowings and gearing, strengthening its balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise following China rate cut, US jobs
summary: Japanese stocks rose for a second day, driven by China's interest rate cut and a rebound in US hiring. The Topix index climbed 1.5% to 1,612.16, while the Nikkei 225 Stock Average added 1.5% to 19,674.36. Mitsubishi Corp gained 3% after announcing a share buyback, while Sharp Corp fell 31% after considering a capital cut and preferred share issuance. The rally was also fueled by a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records on the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: India fund outflows flag more bond pain amid worst BRIC losses
summary: India is witnessing the fastest outflow of local investors from debt funds in three months, with a 25 billion rupee (S$520 million) exit in April. This trend is linked to the worst performance of Indian bonds among BRIC markets this quarter. The benchmark 10-year rupee sovereign yield surged 19 basis points in the last two weeks, and experts warn that returns could worsen further due to a rebound in oil prices and a drop in the rupee. Indian government notes have lost 0.5% this quarter.

site_title: US markets pay little heed to Yellen's warning
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen warned that stocks were overvalued and bond yields too low, but markets largely ignored her, rebounding near record highs and bond yields even lower than before her speech. The April jobs report, which showed a strong job creation number but no sign of rising wages, reinforced this trend. As a result, Yellen is caught between the economy, which still has room to improve, and the markets, which are fuelled by easy money and speculation.

site_title: Cameron charges Osborne with renegotiating UK's EU membership
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron has appointed George Osborne as Chancellor of the Exchequer and First Secretary of State, tasking him with renegotiating Britain's European Union membership. The renegotiation aims to reclaim powers from Brussels before a proposed EU referendum, which Cameron has promised will take place. Cameron has expressed confidence in securing a favorable outcome, with the goal of maintaining Britain's EU membership with a new relationship.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to foster sukuk market as stocks open to foreigners
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to foster its sukuk market by streamlining the process of structuring Shariah-compliant bonds. The move aims to boost the kingdom's debt capital market, which has been underdeveloped due to competitive lending rates from banks. Saudi companies have borrowed $6.7 billion in Shariah-compliant loans so far this year, but none have sold sukuk. The regulator plans to set clear guidelines, similar to Malaysia's sukuk market, to create incentives for investors and improve trading of sukuk. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy away from oil.

site_title: Alibaba boosts its stake in online retailer Zulily to 9.3%
summary: Alibaba Group Holding has increased its stake in US online retailer Zulily Inc to 9.3%, with a $56.2 million investment, bringing its holdings to 11.5 million shares. This move aims to boost international e-commerce sales, which currently account for 9% of Alibaba's total revenue. Alibaba chairman Jack Ma aims to achieve 50% of sales from outside China, as the nation's economy is expected to grow at its slowest pace since 1990.

site_title: Australian business confidence steady in April: NAB
summary: Australian business confidence remained steady in April, according to a National Australia Bank survey, holding at +3 despite a slight pullback in sales and employment. The index of business conditions dipped 2 points to +4, undoing half of its March gain. Confidence and investment were restrained, with the capital expenditure index easing 3 points to +6. Profitability eased 3 points to +5, while measures of labour costs and prices remained subdued. The Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to cut interest rates to 2% in April may have had little impact on the economy.

images.alt_text: Australian businesses reported a slight pullback in sales and employment in April while confidence stayed restrained despite record-low interest rates, a survey showed on Monday.

site_title: Thrills galore at MMA fight night on May 22
summary: Dejdamrong Sor Amnuaysirichoke, a Muay Thai specialist, is set to become the first-ever Muay Thai world champion to win an MMA world title at One Championship's Warrior's Quest event on May 22. He will face Filipino MMA exponent Roy Doliguez in the strawweight world championship bout. Around 12,000 fans will attend the event, which also features other notable fighters and sponsors. The event marks the eighth time One Championship has organized a major fight card in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Centurion's Q1 profit falls 58% in the absence of one-off item
summary: Centurion Corporation reported a 58% decline in Q1 net profit to S$9.4 million due to the absence of a one-off gain from the sale of industrial factory units. Revenue rose 44% to S$25.3 million, driven by a 56% increase in accommodation business revenue. Excluding the one-off gain, the group's operational profits increased by S$63,000.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
An artist's impression of the $200 million dormitory in Jalan Papan near the Jurong Island checkpoint.

site_title: Otto Marine warns of net loss for Q1
summary: Offshore marine group Otto Marine expects to report a net loss for its first quarter ended March 31, 2015, citing lower vessel usage and reduced charter rates in a challenging oil and gas market. The company attributes the expected losses to decreased vessel utilization, lower charter rates, and provision and impairment charges. Otto Marine has taken steps to cut costs and boost competitiveness, focusing on existing markets and exploring new opportunities.

site_title: Goldman sees China rebound as history repeats for top forecaster
summary: Goldman Sachs economist Song Yu predicts China will rebound from its economic slowdown, mirroring last year's recovery. Song, ranked the best overall forecaster of China's economy, attributes the anticipated rebound to the Chinese government's loosening monetary, fiscal, and administrative policies. The central bank has cut interest rates for the third time in six months, further supporting Song's stance. Other top forecasters also do not foresee a hard landing scenario, echoing Song's optimism.

site_title: S'pore businesses still mired in pessimism
summary: Singapore businesses remain pessimistic about the next six months, with 52% expecting business prospects to worsen year-on-year, according to the latest Business Times-UniSIM Business Climate Survey. Construction firms are the most downbeat, with pessimism rising most from a year ago. The survey also found that 57% of firms reported a contraction in profits, and 54% reported declines in orders or new business secured. Despite this, GDP growth is expected to pick up slightly in Q2, with economists predicting between 2.1% and 2.4% growth.

site_title: Sell in May and go away? Not when Goldilocks is around
summary: US stocks staged a significant rally on Friday, finishing near records, as the jobs report showed a "Goldilocks" economy with 223,000 jobs added in April and a 5.4% unemployment rate. Retail sales and industrial-production data are expected to provide similar signals, potentially leading to a break out of the tight 2015 range. However, the consumer's "Goldilocks moment" could be spoiled by rising oil prices, higher interest rates, and stock market volatility, which may take time to slow down consumer spending.

site_title: Revenue soars, losses rise as Spotify expands
summary: Spotify reported a 45% increase in revenue to $1.3 billion in 2014, but also net losses of $197 million, up from $68 million in 2013. The company cited investments in product development, international expansion, and personnel increases as reasons for the loss. With 15 million paying users and 45 million free users, Spotify is the most popular music streaming service, with 91% of revenue coming from subscriptions. The company's free tier has been a subject of debate in the music industry, with some critics questioning its impact on music sales.

site_title: Investment firms move in on 'fix and flip'
summary: Wall Street investment firms such as Colony Capital, Blackstone Group, and Cerberus Capital Management are offering bridge loans to real estate investors who buy, renovate, and sell homes quickly for a profit. These loans, known as hard-money or asset-based loans, allow investors to borrow cash for home purchases and construction with a year to repay. Borrowing costs have decreased significantly, with rates ranging from 8-12% and fees decreasing from 3-5 points. The move represents a deepening bet on the housing market by Wall Street-backed companies, which aim to capitalize on rising prices and limited new construction.

images.alt_text: Average gross profit for completed flips in Q1 was US$72,450, up from US$61,684 a year ago and the highest since 2011.

site_title: For 1MDB, it cannot be business as usual
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state-backed firm is facing a probe amid allegations of misuse of funds, prompting concerns about its business practices. Despite no updates on the probe's progress, 1MDB has made a land sale to Malaysia's pilgrims fund Lembaga Urusan Tabung Haji for RM188.5 million, sparking criticism for governance lapses and potential conflict of interest. The sale has raised questions about whether 1MDB can conduct business as usual with investigations ongoing and calls for transparency and accountability mounting, particularly amid Prime Minister Najib Razak's besieged leadership.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Transformer blast shuts down nuclear reactor close to New York
summary: A transformer fire at the Indian Point nuclear power plant 65 km north of New York City was quickly extinguished, shutting down the reactor. Officials stated that the plant is stable and poses no threat to nearby residents. The fire occurred at 5:50pm on Saturday and was put out 25 minutes later. This incident is not uncommon, according to the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

site_title: Why China is ready to let Wall Street firms invade its markets
summary: China is considering granting foreign investment banks greater access to its securities market, potentially easing restrictions imposed for years. Despite local banks dominating 98% of China's revenue, foreign firms remain confident. Citic Securities' Zhang Jian stated he's not concerned, suggesting a shift in China's stance. This move could benefit foreign firms, but it also raises concerns about increased competition for local banks. The decision is seen as a strategic move to modernize China's financial sector and attract more foreign investment.

site_title: Play your credit cards right for extra cash back
summary: A handful of credit card issuers, including American Express, Barclays, Capital One, and Citigroup, have launched cards offering 2% cash back on every dollar spent, a long-sought goal for many consumers. However, making these products profitable proves challenging due to unpredictable customer behavior and varying merchant fees. Despite this, these issuers are exploring alternative revenue streams, such as data monetization, and have created cards with unique features to differentiate themselves. For example, the Barclaycard Arrival Plus World Elite MasterCard offers an effective 2.2% yield, while the Fidelity Investment Rewards American Express provides 2% cash back with no annual fee.

site_title: China says trade levels will improve in H2
summary: China's Commerce Ministry expects trade levels to improve in the second half of the year, despite a 6.4% drop in exports and a 16.2% decline in imports in April. The ministry attributed the decline to external market challenges, including a strong yuan and high financing costs. The ministry plans to cut red tape to facilitate trade and maintain growth momentum for exports. The poor trade performance raises concerns about second-quarter economic growth, potentially dipping below 7% for the first time since the global financial crisis.

site_title: Trouble ahead for Widodo as Indonesian economy skids
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo is facing growing economic challenges as his country's growth slumps to its lowest level since 2009. Data shows the economy is smaller in real terms than when he took office, prompting critics to question his administration's competence. Widodo has vowed to lift growth to 7% on average, but slow progress and sniping from within his party have left him increasingly isolated. A cabinet reshuffle is expected, with mid-ranking ministers potentially dropped, as the government struggles to spend billions on infrastructure projects.

site_title: California drought hits Starbucks water source
summary: Starbucks will stop sourcing water for its Ethos Water brand in California, citing the state's severe drought, which prompted mandatory water cuts. The company will move production to its Pennsylvania supplier and search for a new source and supplier for its West Coast Ethos Water distribution. This decision comes after a report showed Ethos Water was sourced in "exceptional drought" areas. Starbucks has donated over $12.3 million to water education programs globally since 2005.

site_title: India shines brightest among slumping emerging markets
summary: India's economy has seen a significant turnaround since Narendra Modi became Prime Minister last year, with estimated growth rates of 6.9% in 2013 and 7.4% in 2014. The Modi administration aims to achieve a minimum 8% growth rate for 2015, surpassing China's expansion for the first time in over a decade. This growth has placed India as the brightest emerging market, outperforming other countries in the region.

site_title: Staying ahead of the future
summary: The article discusses the key skills required for the future workforce in Singapore, with a focus on three areas: data analytics, design, and cross-cultural understanding. Experts emphasize the importance of lifelong learning and adapting to technological advancements. They highlight the need for skills such as creative thinking, computational thinking, and emotional intelligence. The article also notes that traditional education systems may need to be revised to prepare students for the rapidly changing job market. Employers and educators agree that a combination of technical skills, practical experience, and soft skills is essential for success in the future.

site_title: UK polls, tepid US jobs data may boost STI in short term
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) may experience a short-term boost due to the UK polls and tepid US jobs data, which could lead to increased market volatility. Despite this, concerns over liquidity and economic uncertainty are persisting, with daily trading volumes below S$1 billion and the proportion of daily business generated by the 30 STI components decreasing. The market is also watching the UK's potential exit from the European Union and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions, which could impact the STI's performance in the long term.

site_title: US agency asked Germany to spy on Siemens: report
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) allegedly asked its German partner service BND to spy on Siemens, a German engineering and technology giant, citing suspicions that Siemens was supplying communications technology to a Russian secret service. Siemens denies being a target of such surveillance. The "BND affair" has strained Chancellor Angela Merkel's government and raised concerns about industrial espionage. The Merkel government has refused to release a list of NSA's requested search terms, citing ongoing consultations with Washington, which has threatened to scale back cooperation.

site_title: Citi named best Asia-Pacific transaction bank
summary: Citi has been named the best transaction bank in the Asia-Pacific region by The Asset magazine's Triple A Treasury, Trade and Risk Management Awards for 2015. The bank won 52 awards, including 22 country awards and 21 client solution awards. Citi Singapore also won four country awards, including best transaction bank and best in treasury & working capital for public sector. Citi's head of Asean and Singapore, Melvyn Low, was named transaction banker of the year (Asean) and the bank's virtual card account solution received the editors' triple star.

site_title: Asian bankers face US$43b dead deals after oil plunge
summary: Asian investment bankers face significant challenges, with over $43 billion in announced mergers and acquisitions scrapped in the past year. The decline in mergers and initial public offerings, particularly in Singapore, is attributed to low commodity prices and sluggish growth in Southeast Asian economies. This has led to job losses, with Goldman Sachs reducing its Singapore team by 30% and top bankers at HSBC and Bank of America departing. The downturn is expected to continue, with companies reluctant to do deals or go public in the region.

site_title: China still has most impact on Singapore firms' sales: survey
summary: China remains the economy with the greatest impact on sales performance for Singapore firms, with 27% of respondents citing it as a major factor. Indonesia has overtaken Malaysia, which fell out of the top three rankings. The US was cited by 13% of firms, while Indonesia was the second most cited, particularly among small firms and those in financial services. The survey suggests a reduced dependence on traditional markets, with companies diversifying into new markets. Other significant economies for Singapore firms include Australia, Vietnam, and Thailand.

site_title: Europe air forces ground A400M after crash
summary: Europe's air forces suspended flights of the Airbus A400M after a military transport aircraft crashed in Spain, killing four people and injuring two. The incident occurred during a test flight and is the first crash of the aircraft. Investigations are underway, with Airbus stating that the accident does not indicate a design flaw. The A400M is Europe's most costly defense program, with a budget of 25 billion euros, and several countries have suspended or reduced their orders due to technical and software issues.

site_title: Is a bubble in China stocks being inflated?
summary: China's A-share and H-share markets have seen a sharp rally driven by liquidity and policy easing measures, despite a disconnect from economic fundamentals. The rally, which started in the third quarter of 2014, has seen A-shares double in less than 10 months and daily turnover reach record highs. However, concerns about the sustainability of the rally and the potential for a bubble to burst remain. The Schroders Asian equities team believes that the rally is being fueled by a combination of factors, including the government's accommodative monetary policies, a surge in leveraged trading, and the introduction of market-liberalising measures such as the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect scheme.

images.alt_text: The consumer discretionary sector in China offers more value today. The risk-to-reward is attractive in this sector given the scope for an improvement in consumption later this year, especially if the wealth effect from the equity market is sustained.

site_title: Rio faces mounting Olympics bill as delays pile up
summary: Rio de Janeiro is facing mounting Olympic expenses due to delays in venue construction and contract tendering, raising concerns about the financial burden on Brazil's struggling economy. With less than 500 days until the Olympics, only about 10% of 56 Olympic projects are completed, and a quarter of projects have yet to start. Experts warn that a last-minute scramble will drive up costs, potentially doubling the current 40-billion-real (S$17.9 billion) price tag. The Brazilian government has guaranteed to finance any cost overruns, but the economic implications are still uncertain.

site_title: Directors' buying down; buyback activity rebounds
summary: Singapore Exchange directors' buying activity declined, with 16 purchases worth S$700,000 from May 4-8. However, buyback activity rebounded with 14 repurchases worth S$11.6 million. OSIM International resumed buying back shares after a 19% drop in first-quarter profit, while Hong Leong Asia's executive director Kwek Leng Peck increased his holdings by 14%. Other companies with significant shareholder trades include Hwa Hong Corporation, Roxy-Pacific Holdings, and Serial System Limited. Franklin Resources became a substantial shareholder of SembCorp Marine, and BlackRock Inc recorded its first sale in Suntec Reit since becoming a substantial shareholder.

images.alt_text: The buying among directors fell, based on filings on the Singapore Exchange from May 4 to 8, with eight companies that recorded 16 purchases worth S$700,000.

site_title: Fuss-free food for modern cave dwellers
summary: A new restaurant, Fyr Cycene Ond Drinc, has opened in Singapore, offering a unique dining experience that combines ancient language and caveman culture with modern food. The restaurant, located on Boon Tat Street, serves simple yet high-quality food cooked over fire in a Josper charcoal oven. The menu features dishes such as seafood and meat with sauces and garnishes, with set lunch options starting from S$25 for two courses. The restaurant's quirky concept and friendly pricing make it a reliable source of fuss-free sustenance for modern cave dwellers. Rating: 6/10.

site_title: Budget focus will be on jobs, growth and opportunity, says Aussie PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott is set to deliver a "measured, responsible and fair" national budget focusing on jobs, growth, and opportunity. This year's budget aims to support families and small businesses, following controversy surrounding last year's budget. Analysts predict the budget will avoid controversies, a stark contrast to the previous year's plans.

site_title: BP, striking workers reach deal at US refinery
summary: BP and striking workers at its Whiting, Indiana, oil refinery have reached a four-year contract agreement, allowing workers to return to work as of May 18. The tentative deal was agreed on May 1 and a ratification vote is scheduled for Monday. The strike, which began on February 8, lasted for three months.

site_title: McDonald's April sales beat analysts' forecasts as US declines slow
summary: McDonald's reported April sales that beat analysts' forecasts, with global same-store sales falling 0.6% and US sales declining 2.3%. This improvement slows the decline in the US and gives CEO Steve Easterbrook momentum to implement his turnaround plan, which includes cost cuts and menu changes. Same-store sales gained 1% in Europe and fell 3.8% in the Asia-Pacific region. McDonald's shares rose 1.5% to $98.23, with the company aiming to boost sales and profitability.

site_title: US urges Greece to reject Russian gas pipe plan and accept West's
summary: The US has urged Greece to reject Russia's proposed gas pipeline project and instead support a Western-backed project linking Europe to natural gas supplies in Azerbaijan. US State Department envoy Amos Hochstein said Greece's participation in the project would increase its appeal to Western investors, reducing the EU's dependence on Russian gas. The Russian pipeline, known as Turkish Stream, aims to bypass Ukraine and bring gas to Europe through Turkey and Greece, but Washington views it as a "political" project rather than an economic one.

site_title: China cuts interest rates for 3rd time in six months
summary: China cut interest rates for the third time in six months, lowering its benchmark lending rate to 5.1% and deposit rate to 2.25%, in an effort to stimulate the slowing economy. The move comes after weaker-than-expected April data, with the People's Bank of China citing "relatively big downward pressure" on the economy. The central bank also noted that real interest rates remain higher than the historical average, but the move aims to lower companies' borrowing costs and boost economic growth.

site_title: Governance: form or substance?
summary: A corporate governance report highlights the disparity between the "form" and "substance" of governance practices in organizations. Despite the "nine-year rule" requiring directors to undergo rigorous reviews of their independence, many directors continue to serve beyond nine years without substantial review, and some are deemed independent despite having close relationships with the company. This can lead to failures in governance, abuse, and severe consequences. To address this, governance should reflect both form and substance, with processes integrated into business operations to create real value and improve business outcomes.

site_title: IBM's Watson supercomputer headed for omniscience?
summary: IBM's Watson supercomputer is expanding its capabilities beyond its initial fame in the "Jeopardy" quiz show. The AI system is now being used as a business consultant and analyst for various industries, including healthcare, finance, and oil and gas. Watson has partnered with companies to develop personalized care for cancer patients, improve patient care with big data, and help banks compare investment offerings. The supercomputer is also being used in culinary applications, such as creating new recipes and flavor combinations. IBM has invested $1 billion in Watson and plans to work with nearly 20 business sectors.

site_title: Oil scores new 2015 peaks on tumbling inventories in US
summary: Oil prices reached 2015 peaks due to a surprise decline in US crude reserves, with Brent reaching $69.63 and WTI reaching $62.58 per barrel. However, prices slid on Friday as oversupply concerns resurfaced. The decline in US crude stockpiles, despite a record high, was attributed to a slight decrease in production. Gold prices edged higher following the US job report, while base metals rose due to a weak dollar, but concerns over China's economic slowdown limited gains.

site_title: Pilot strike may hit TAP Portugal's privatisation
summary: A 10-day pilot strike at TAP Portugal, a loss-making airline, threatens to derail the government's plans to privatize the airline. The strike, which began on May 1, is over the government's refusal to meet the pilots' demand for a 10-20% stake in the airline in the case of privatization. The strike has already cost TAP 17 million euros in the first five days and could result in job cuts and route reductions. Investors have until Friday to submit offers, but the strike has raised concerns about the airline's financial stability and the success of the privatization plan.

site_title: Thousands evacuated as typhoon hits north Philippines
summary: Typhoon Noul hit the northern tip of the Philippines on May 10, 2015, prompting the evacuation of almost 3,000 people due to warnings of flash floods, landslides, and storm surges. The storm is expected to move north towards Japan, according to the government weather station.

site_title: Cuba says in advanced talks with China's Huawei over telecoms
summary: Cuba is in advanced talks with Chinese telecoms equipment company Huawei to expand business on the island. Cuban Finance Minister Lina Pedraza confirmed the negotiations, stating that the country is open to foreign companies but wants to avoid the "negative parts of the internet." This comes after Huawei already operates in Cuba. No immediate comment was provided by a Huawei spokesman.

images.alt_text: Cuba is in advanced talks with Chinese telecoms equipment company Huawei to do more business on the Communist island, Cuban finance minister Lina Pedraza said on Friday. "A lot of companies are in negotiations. Just yesterday I was with a businessman who is operating with us and he spoke with us for a long time. He's Chinese by the way,"

site_title: Carlos Slim seeks US$80m for his New York house
summary: Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim is selling his Manhattan townhouse, the 20,000 sq ft Duke Semans Mansion, for $80 million, nearly doubling the $53 million he paid for it in 2010. The listing by Sotheby's International Realty is the most expensive ever for a townhouse in New York City, according to appraiser Jonathan Miller.

images.alt_text: Mr Slim, world's third-richest person, bought the 20,000 sq ft home for US$44 million in July 2010 as an investment

site_title: China cuts interest rates to boost economy
summary: China's central bank cut its benchmark lending rates by 25 basis points to 5.1% on May 10, 2015, in an effort to boost the slowing economy. The People's Bank of China also reduced one-year benchmark deposit rates by 25 basis points, effective May 11. This is the third rate reduction since November. The move aims to support the healthy development of the economy.

site_title: S'pore startup scene not frothy: ACE chairman
summary: Singapore's startup scene is not experiencing an "entertainment bubble," according to Steven Fang, chairman of the Action Committee for Entrepreneurship (ACE). Fang cites specific startup successes, including regional and global companies emerging from Singapore. This contradicts concerns sparked by recent investments and developments in the country's startup ecosystem. Fang emphasizes that the successes demonstrate a solid foundation for entrepreneurship in Singapore.

site_title: Najib: Land purchase by pilgrims' fund from 1MDB not bailout
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak denied that a land purchase by the country's haj pilgrims' fund from 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) was a bailout, claiming the deal was manipulated to make it appear as if pilgrims' money was used to save the debt-ridden state fund. The 0.64-hectare land was bought for RM188.5 million.

site_title: Less vessel usage, lower charter rates to lead to Q1 net loss: Otto Marine
summary: Otto Marine expects to report a net loss for its first quarter ended March 31, 2015, citing a decrease in vessel utilization and lower charter rates in the oil and gas industry. The company has taken steps to cut costs and will release its financial results on May 14, 2015.

site_title: Is Asia ready for the Internet of Things?
summary: The Internet of Things (IoT) is expected to reach nearly $7.1 trillion in global revenues by 2020, presenting opportunities for IT vendors and businesses in Asia. However, few in the region are clear on how to capitalize on IoT's potential. Key issues for businesses to consider include data analysis, cybersecurity, and standardization. As IoT continues to grow, it is essential for Asia-Pacific businesses to address these challenges to remain competitive.

site_title: Islamic finance could help close infrastructure funding gap, says ADB
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) are exploring Islamic finance as a potential source of funds for large infrastructure projects in Asia, amid the shrinking of oil revenues. This could benefit capital markets in non-Islamic financial centers. Experts expect a surge in the issuance of Islamic financial instruments tailored for long-term infrastructure projects. This could help bridge the US$8 trillion infrastructure funding gap in Asia.

site_title: Economy pulls Cameron through
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron's economy-driven victory in the British election is expected to ease his task of negotiating concessions from Europe ahead of a potential EU referendum. However, the outcome's double-edged nature, with the Liberal Democrats and Scottish Nationalists performing poorly, complicates European negotiations. The result reduces uncertainty over Britain's future path, benefiting sterling and UK financial markets, but does not address the country's significant international and domestic deficits.

site_title: United Airlines to cut some transatlantic flights in winter
summary: United Airlines plans to cut certain transatlantic flights after the peak summer travel season, citing a strong US dollar weighing on international demand. The carrier will halt service to Stockholm and Oslo from its Newark, New Jersey hub between September 5, 2015, and May 4, 2016. Additionally, it will suspend one daily flight between Newark and Paris from October 25 through March 2016, but will use a larger aircraft. The moves are expected to impact passengers and the airline's revenue.

site_title: Cameron to act swiftly on key election promises
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron aims to swiftly implement key election promises in the first 100 days of his new Conservative government, focusing on EU reforms and reducing emigration from poorer eastern European nations.

images.alt_text: UK Premier David Cameron aims to swiftly implement key promises in his election manifesto in the first 100 days of the new Conservative government.

site_title: US expected to approve Brazil fresh beef imports
summary: The US is expected to approve imports of Brazilian fresh beef this year, following President Dilma Rousseff's visit to Washington in June. Brazil, the world's top beef exporter, plans to provide technical data and documentation by the end of May or early June. The US had promised the first shipments of fresh beef could occur in August, with Brazil aiming to meet this deadline. This move would allow the US to tap into Brazil's steady supply of cooked beef, which is already being exported to the country.

site_title: China's Greenland to expand in Canada
summary: China's Greenland Group plans to expand into Canada, targeting medium-sized projects like its Toronto hotel-condo project. The company aims to capitalize on population growth in cities like Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver, and Calgary. Greenland's international expansion is part of a plan to speed up growth, with overseas sales expected to reach $3.9 billion this year. The company has already invested $6 billion in the US and developed projects in London and Sydney.

site_title: Airbus A400M grounded across Europe after fatal crash
summary: The Airbus A400M military transport aircraft has been grounded across Europe after a fatal crash in Spain, killing four people and injuring two others. The incident occurred during a test flight near Sevilla, Spain, and is the first crash of the aircraft. Airbus has launched an investigation and suspended flights until the reasons for the crash are clear. The A400M is Europe's most costly defense program, with a budget over $5.6 billion, and its program has faced technical and software issues, leading to cancellations and cost escalations.

site_title: Economy, markets test patience of Fed chief Yellen
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on the economy and markets may signal a potential rate hike, but the timing remains uncertain. Yellen stated that stocks are overvalued and bond yields are too low, but recent job data suggests the economy still has room to grow. The April jobs report showed strong job creation, but stagnant wages and a low labor force participation rate indicate slack in the job market. Analysts believe the Fed may need to raise rates despite the economy's weakness to prevent asset market bubbles.

site_title: Australian police thwart imminent bomb attack, teen charged
summary: Australian police thwarted an imminent terror attack after discovering explosives at a Melbourne home and arresting a 17-year-old boy. The teen was charged with terrorism-related offences and remanded in custody. The threat was deemed "imminent" and the explosives were rendered safe. The incident has raised concerns about radicalised teenagers in the country, with no apparent link to Islamic extremism. The boy's family is described as "caring" and "distraught" over the arrest.

site_title: CONTENTS
summary: Asean agreed that Myanmar's election is not a priority, contradicting Malaysia's stance. Meanwhile, US weekly jobless claims fell unexpectedly. China urged South-east Asia to back openness amidst US tariffs, and Chinese property shares surged on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. Reliance Jio, owned by Ambani, delayed its India IPO beyond this year. China also unveiled new steps to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Rosberg ends Hamilton supremacy with flawless Spanish win
summary: Nico Rosberg ended Lewis Hamilton's winning streak in the Spanish Grand Prix, driving to a near-flawless victory and his 9th career win. Rosberg led from pole position, with Hamilton finishing behind him despite a daring comeback. The win trimmed Hamilton's lead from 27 points to 20. Sebastian Vettel came home third for Ferrari, while local hero Carlos Sainz took 10th place in a wheel-to-wheel battle with teammate Jos Verstappen.

site_title: App helps sell the last seats at sold-out events
summary: Seaters, a ticket-fielding platform and app, was created to help fans purchase last-minute seats at sold-out events. The platform, developed by Jean-Sebastien Gosuin and two Belgian entrepreneurs, aims to reduce empty seats by redistributing unsold tickets to fans. Seaters charges a 20% handling fee and has already been used by BNP Paribas to redistribute employee tickets to sponsored events in Europe. The app is seen as a fair trade solution to the ticket resale market, aiming to eliminate empty seats at events.

site_title: Oil mixed as US jobs report gives modest lift to WTI
summary: US oil prices rose 45 cents to $58.93 a barrel after a modest jobs report, lifting the US benchmark WTI. However, Brent North Sea crude fell 15 cents to $65.39 a barrel due to renewed oversupply concerns. The US jobs report showed firm job growth and a dip in the jobless rate, implying some demand for oil. A falling oil rig count also suggests that US crude output will fall in the medium term, supporting prices.

site_title: Eurozone set to report solid growth - for a change
summary: The eurozone is expected to report solid growth for the first time in years, with forecasted 0.5% growth, surpassing Britain's growth rate. This positive trend is attributed to five underlying drivers, including stronger external demand, easier domestic financial conditions, and a weaker euro exchange rate. The European Central Bank's bond purchase program is also seen as a contributing factor. Meanwhile, the UK economy shrinks for the second month, and the Bank of England is expected to maintain its interest rate policy unchanged.

site_title: EU casts shadow over Cameron's election success
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron won his election with a narrow majority, but faces a daunting task in navigating the UK's relationship with the European Union. Cameron has pledged to hold a referendum on EU membership by 2017, but must appease eurosceptic rebels within his own party and European partners. He is seeking reforms on migration and benefits, but may struggle to secure concessions, particularly on freedom of movement of labor, and risks antagonizing European colleagues.

site_title: North Korea says test-fires submarine-launch ballistic missile
summary: North Korea announced the successful test-firing of a submarine-launched ballistic missile, with leader Kim Jong Un overseeing the test-launch. The test, if confirmed, would indicate progress in the secretive state's pursuit of building missile-equipped submarines. The test was reportedly conducted from a location off-shore, with the submarine diving underwater and a ballistic missile surfacing and soaring into the air. The test was seen as a significant development in North Korea's pursuit of building missile-equipped submarines, despite international sanctions banning the development or use of ballistic missile technology.

site_title: China's weak April trade stirs talk of more stimulus measures
summary: China's trade in April saw exports decline 6.4% year-on-year and imports fall 16.2% for the sixth consecutive month. Analysts expect further stimulus measures to boost the economy. The poor trade performance prompts concerns about China's GDP growth, which is set to slow. This raises pressure on policymakers to implement additional measures to support the economy.

site_title: New headgears to bring virtual reality to your home screens
summary: Oculus, acquired by Facebook, plans to launch a consumer version of its Rift headset in early 2016, marking a significant step forward for virtual reality (VR) technology. The company's move is expected to boost investment in VR software, with total VR sales projected to jump to 39 million in 2018 and generate $4.6 billion in revenue. Other hardware makers, including Sony and HTC, are also working on consumer headsets, and software companies are developing apps for various industries, with revenue expected to double for some firms.

site_title: Seeing and believing: Virtual reality set to conquer living rooms
summary: Virtual reality technology is set to conquer living rooms as Oculus, a Facebook-owned company, plans to start shipping a consumer version of its Rift headset in early 2016. This marks a significant shift in the industry, with estimates suggesting 39 million VR headsets will be sold in 2018, generating $4.6 billion in software sales. Gaming and entertainment apps are expected to drive initial adoption, but the advent of user-friendly gear will also spur adoption in educational institutions, the military, and industry, with companies like Ford using VR headsets for car design testing.

site_title: Cameron wins stunning victory in watershed UK vote
summary: Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative Party won a stunning victory in the UK general election, securing 331 out of 650 parliamentary seats and a majority centre-right government. The election marked a significant shift north of the border, with the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP) winning a historic landslide. Cameron reconfirmed as prime minister and announced plans to form a Conservative majority government, promising to deliver an in-out referendum on the UK's EU membership by the end of 2017.

site_title: American Express: Evolving through the ages
summary: American Express, founded in 1850 as a delivery business, has evolved into a global financial services company. Initially capitalizing on the shortcomings of the US postal service, it diversified into financial services with the introduction of the world's first traveller's cheque in 1891. The company entered the travel industry in 1915, becoming synonymous with luxury travel after its 1922 charter of the first around-the-world cruise. Today, American Express continues to offer premium travel and lifestyle cards, while expanding into cashback and miles-accruing cards. Despite intense competition, the company remains strong in the premium space and is adapting to changing technology and market trends.

site_title: Obama, Saudi King Salman to meet at White House before summit next week
summary: US President Barack Obama will meet with Saudi King Salman at the White House on Wednesday, ahead of a summit with Gulf Cooperation Council leaders next week. The meeting aims to discuss regional and bilateral issues, according to White House spokesman Eric Schultz. This meeting is part of Obama's preparations for the upcoming summit, which will bring together leaders from the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council.

site_title: TPG Capital close to Cushman-DTZ deal
summary: TPG Capital is close to acquiring commercial property brokerage Cushman & Wakefield Inc for about $2 billion, combining it with DTZ Group to create one of the world's largest real estate services firms. The deal, in advanced discussions with Cushman's owners, Exor SpA, would create a global company rivaling CBRE Group and Jones Lang LaSalle. TPG, which bought DTZ last year, aims to capitalize on the combined company's $2.9 billion in annual revenue and 50% market share in China's commercial property sales. An agreement could be announced as soon as next week.

site_title: China pursuing huge South China Sea land reclamation: US
summary: China has dramatically increased land reclamation efforts in the South China Sea, building artificial islands at an unprecedented pace to bolster its territorial claims. The US estimates 800 hectares have been reclaimed, with 75% of the total in the last five months. This has expanded China's acreage by 400 times, raising concerns about its military dimension and potential impact on the US Pacific naval and economic power. The US Pacific Fleet commander described China's efforts as creating a "Great wall of sand."

site_title: US: Stocks surge as jobs report hits 'sweet spot'
summary: US stocks surged on Friday after the Labour Department reported a solid 223,000 jobs added in April, with unemployment falling to a seven-year low of 5.4%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.49% to 18,191.11, while the S&P 500 jumped 1.35% to 2,116.10. Economists believe the Federal Reserve may wait until September to lift the near-zero federal funds rate, citing the jobs data as a "sweet spot" for Wall Street.

site_title: Greece and creditors 'very close' to a deal, says minister
summary: Greece and its international creditors are "very close" to a loan deal, according to a junior Greek minister. The deal aims to release 7.2 billion euros in remaining bailout loans, but European officials have downplayed the likelihood of an agreement. Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has called for an "honourable compromise" and his government plans concessions, including a new VAT rate and emergency tax contributions, to raise an additional 5-6 billion euros. A repayment to the IMF is expected to be honoured, but a default remains a concern if a deal is not reached.

site_title: German train drivers end week-long strike
summary: German train drivers ended a week-long strike, the longest in Deutsche Bahn's history, on Sunday. The strike, led by the GDL union, aimed to address wages and working hours. The industrial action had crippled rail traffic, but Deutsche Bahn plans to restore services to normal by Monday morning. Cargo services will resume mid-week, with the strike costing the operator 200 million euros. The GDL union's leader, Claus Weselsky, said the country and railway customers deserved a break, while Deutsche Bahn described the strike as "excessive and disproportionate".

site_title: Bitcoin exchange receives first licence in NY state
summary: New York state's Department of Financial Services granted the first licence to itBit, a Bitcoin exchange, allowing it to operate legally in the US. The licence was granted after itBit received a banking trust charter from the state. This move brings new rules to the virtual currency industry.

site_title: UK press says Cameron's toughest fight yet to come
summary: David Cameron's surprise majority in the UK election has marked a remarkable triumph of quiet conservatism, but his second term in office is expected to be tougher. The Conservative party faces challenges to keep Scotland in the UK and Britain in the EU, with the Scottish National Party winning 56 of 59 Scottish seats. The UK Independence Party secured one seat despite a strong anti-immigration message. The papers warn that Cameron must use his slim majority effectively and find a way to unite the country, with some predicting a "watershed" moment for the UK.

site_title: Japan's Toyota, Mazda eye green alliance: report
summary: Toyota and Mazda are considering a comprehensive partnership to develop environmentally-friendly technology, aiming to address global environmental regulations. The two companies plan to collaborate on fuel cell and plug-in-hybrid technology, with Toyota supplying technology to Mazda and Mazda offering its proprietary "Skyactiv" green technology to Toyota. The partnership is part of an effort to boost sales of electric and fuel cell vehicles, amid tightening regulations in countries like California and China. Toyota and Mazda have a history of collaboration, having worked together in fields such as hybrid-vehicle technology and commercial vehicle procurement.

images.alt_text: Japanese automakers Toyota and Mazda are considering a comprehensive tie-up in environmentally-friendly technology amid tightening regulations to cut greenhouse gas and tough emerging market competition, a report said on Saturday.

site_title: Dollar rises as US jobs data leaves rate hike at bay
summary: The US dollar rose against the euro after a strong jobs report in April, with the economy adding 223,000 jobs and the unemployment rate falling to 5.4%, a seven-year low. The report, which was in line with expectations, suggests the Federal Reserve may not raise interest rates in June, providing a boost to the dollar. The details of the report showed only slight signs of a tightening labor market, further supporting the dollar's gain.

site_title: China consumer inflation rises to 1.5% in April: govt
summary: China's consumer inflation rose to 1.5% in April, the highest since December, slightly easing concerns over deflation. This is below market forecasts of 1.6%. The producer price index also fell 4.6% for the 38th consecutive month. These readings may give the Chinese government more room to implement stronger monetary stimulus measures to address the country's slowing economy, which expanded 7.4% in 2014 but slowed further to 7.0% in the first quarter of 2015.

images.alt_text: Consumer inflation in China rose to 1.5 per cent in April, authorities said Saturday, potentially easing concerns over deflation in the world's second-largest economy but below market forecasts.

site_title: Billionaire no more: Ukraine president's fortune fades with war
summary: Ukraine President Petro Poroshenko's fortune has significantly decreased due to the ongoing war. In 2013, he predicted a European Union trade pact would boost Ukraine's economy and increase his Roshen Confectionery Corp's exports. Eighteen months later, Poroshenko's wealth has declined, contradicting his initial prediction. The economic downturn in Ukraine is a result of the war's impact on the country's economy.

site_title: Bombardier planning to list minority stake in rail unit
summary: Bombardier plans to list a minority stake in its rail unit, with an initial public offering expected in the fourth quarter, primarily in Germany. The move comes after the company reported a quarterly profit that exceeded market expectations. However, Bombardier also warned of potential production cuts for its Global business jets. The rail division's listing is seen as a strategic move to raise capital and diversify the company's funding sources.

site_title: Greek PM forecasts a happy ending
summary: Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras forecast a positive outcome to negotiations with creditors on a cash-for-reform deal, despite no breakthrough on key sticking points. Eurozone finance ministers' chairman noted progress, but no deal is expected by Monday. Greece faces a cash crisis, with sources indicating no resolution on pension, labor market reforms, and budget targets.

site_title: App gives fans another shot at sold-out events
summary: A new app called Seaters is launching to give fans a second chance at buying tickets to sold-out events. Created by a team of Belgian entrepreneurs, the platform uses a waiting list to provide a percentage probability of getting tickets, and charges a 20% handling fee. Seaters aims to reduce ticket waste by redistributing available seats to fans, teams, food vendors, and sponsors. The app has already been used by BNP Paribas and French soccer club Olympique Lyonnais, and has been accepted into a startup incubator in Paris.

site_title: GIC to buy stake in Hutchison's mobile business
summary: Singapore's sovereign fund GIC will acquire a 33% stake in British mobile operators Three UK and O2 UK from Hutchison Whampoa Limited for £3.1 billion. Alongside four institutional investors, GIC will invest £1.1 billion in Hutchison 3G UK Holdings Ltd, the combined Three UK and O2 UK business. The deal marks a significant investment by GIC in the UK mobile market, with the investment expected to be completed in the coming months.

site_title: Luxury watch retailers eye lower-tier brands
summary: Luxury watch retailers in Singapore are expanding their lower-tier brands to attract new customers and build a new generation of watch collectors. Following global luxury brands' move to launch timepieces at lower price points, retailers like The HourGlass, Cortina Watch, and Sincere Watch are setting up new stores carrying less expensive models. This trend aims to bridge the gap between high-end and affordable luxury watches, with prices under S$5,000. The retailers believe this move will attract new buyers and eventually lead to sales of more expensive timepieces.

site_title: US hiring rebounds; jobless rate hits seven-year low
summary: The US economy added 223,000 new jobs in April, bringing the unemployment rate down to a seven-year low of 5.4%, according to the Labor Department. However, wages barely grew, and underemployment remained elevated. The job gains were strongest in construction, healthcare, and professional services, while mining and oil and gas experienced losses. Analysts say the recovery is a sign of the economy's strength, but more time is needed to prove the winter slowdown was "transitory."

images.alt_text: The US economy pumped out a solid 223,000 new jobs in April and unemployment ticked down to a seven-year low of 5.4 per cent, the Labor Department said Friday.

site_title: This B is better
summary: The Mercedes-Benz B200 has undergone an update with improved handling and a nicer interior. The facelift addresses previous criticisms of the model's performance and handling. The B200 features a 1.6-litre turbocharged petrol engine and a seven-speed dual clutch transmission. The updated model is available in two variants, the B180 and B200, offering improved driving dynamics. This update aims to enhance the B-Class' appeal, making it a more competitive option in the mini-MPV market.

site_title: Parliament to discuss SMRT's telco tie-up
summary: Singapore's Parliament will discuss SMRT's telco tie-up with OMGTEL, with Member of Parliament Baey Yam Keng questioning how the government will ensure high telco standards and protect public transport services. The SkillsFuture Earn and Learn programme will also be debated. Additionally, four Bills are due for a second reading, including one regulating third-party taxi-booking apps, and six new Bills will be introduced, including a Bankruptcy (Amendment) Bill and a Financial Advisers (Amendment) Bill.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Symphony for the senses
summary: Hangzhou, a city in China's Zhejiang Province, is renowned for its beautiful scenery, rich history, and vibrant food culture. The city's famous West Lake, a man-made lake dating back to the 8th or 9th century, is a must-visit attraction. Hangzhou's cuisine is characterized by the blending of sweet and salty flavors, with popular dishes including Dongpo Pork, braised stinky tofu, and steamed fish. The city is home to numerous restaurants serving traditional Hangzhou cuisine, such as Lao Tou Er You Bao Xia, Zhiwei Guan, and Pu Shu. Visitors can also experience the local tea culture by visiting tea plantations, including the famous Longjing tea plantation. With its unique blend of history, culture, and cuisine, Hangzhou is a delightful destination for foodies and travelers alike.

site_title: Straco Q1 earnings soar on Flyer turnaround
summary: Straco, a Singapore tourist attraction operator, reported a significant turnaround in earnings for the first quarter, driven by the successful integration of the previously loss-making Singapore Flyer observation wheel. The company's earnings soared, and it expressed a positive outlook for both China's and Singapore's domestic tourism markets, with the upcoming SG50 campaign potentially boosting earnings this year.

site_title: Testing times ahead for UK after Tory win
summary: The UK general election results in a surprise victory for the Conservative Party, with a significant majority. The outcome has major implications for the country's future, including the possibility of an "in-out" EU referendum in or before 2017, which could lead to Britain's exit from the European Union. The SNP's strong showing in Scotland also raises concerns about the territorial integrity of the UK and the potential for Scottish independence. The Conservative Party's leader, David Cameron, will now face the challenge of governing with a small majority, potentially leading to a supply and confidence deal with other parties.

site_title: Toyota tries to create new kind of security
summary: Toyota Motor Corp is introducing a new stock called Model AA shares, offering buy-and-hold investors a 5-year investment period with interest payments capped at 2.5% annually. The shares aim to attract investors who prioritize stability over short-term gains, as institutional investors are unlikely to buy due to the long-term lockup period. Toyota plans to raise up to $5.5 billion from the offering, using the proceeds for research and development, including fuel cell technology for its next-generation cars.

images.alt_text: 'We want investors to look at us with a warm attitude, compared with the current attitude of: "How much profit will Toyota make this year, or next year?" We really want them to change.'- Toyota president Akio Toyoda (above).

site_title: Going Latin
summary: Two new restaurants, Vasco and Braseiro, are set to introduce Peruvian and Latin American cuisine to Singapore. Vasco, headed by former Esquina chef Andrew Walsh, offers a straightforward menu inspired by snack foods from the region, including ceviches, empanadas, and Cuban sandwiches. Braseiro, a three-storey Brazilian barbeque restaurant, serves a fusion of Latin American and casual French cuisine, with a fixed price menu that includes free-flowing French fries and salad. Both restaurants aim to boost the growth of Peruvian cuisine in Singapore, with Vasco's executive chef, Walsh, planning to open a new restaurant, Cure, in June.

site_title: Mothers know best
summary: A growing number of mothers are turning entrepreneurs, leveraging their experience to create kid-friendly businesses and products. By tapping into their real-time feedback from their children, these women are developing successful ventures. Examples include Rae Yun, founder of children's lifestyle store ohhappyfry.com, and the creation of products tailored to children's needs. This trend highlights the value of mothers' expertise in building businesses that cater to their own demographic.
