summary: Singapore's accountancy sector is set to benefit from a new programme, the ACCA-ISCA Joint Pathway Programme, launched in July. The programme, developed by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants (ISCA), aims to provide high-quality education and training to aspiring accountants. The programme will offer alternatives to the traditional path to an accounting career, with a focus on flexibility and career guidance. It also includes a regional internship programme, prizes, and scholarships to support students and mid-career professionals in their accounting and finance careers.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Ryanair eyes Europe's top airports in revamp
summary: Ryanair plans to expand its operations to every major European airport beyond London Heathrow, Paris Charles de Gaulle, and Frankfurt am Main. CEO Michael O'Leary aims to attract more business and leisure passengers, as well as older travellers. The airline is taking advantage of the retreat of network airlines like Lufthansa and Air France-KLM, which are offering more attractive terms to discount operators. Ryanair's goal is to tap into the remaining European airport market, offering lower fares and increasing its market share.

site_title: StarHub to offer new communications service
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telco, has partnered with Avaya to offer a new Unified Communication (UC) service called Smart UC for small and medium-sized businesses (SMBs). The service, set to be launched, will provide a common communication platform for voice calls, web access, conferencing, and other business needs. The solution will be delivered via StarHub's SIP infrastructure as a fully managed service, allowing customers to easily reap the benefits of UC without a large upfront IT investment. The service will cater to businesses of all sizes, with a premium option for companies with over 50 users.

site_title: Indonesia to speed up spending, deploy policy mix to revive growth
summary: Indonesia plans to revive economic growth by speeding up government spending and deploying a mix of monetary policy changes. The country's economy grew at 4.71% in the first quarter, below expectations, due to weak oil prices and low government spending. The government aims to boost tax collection and implement policies to boost consumer demand. Bank Indonesia will coordinate with the government to deploy policies on exchange rates, interest rates, and macro-prudential measures. The government's budget deficit is expected to be around 2.3% of GDP, a slight increase from its target of 1.9%.

site_title: Travel demand growth for Asia Pacific airlines outpaces broader industry in March
summary: Asia-Pacific airlines recorded the strongest growth in passenger demand among regions in March, with an 11.1% increase, outpacing global demand growth of 7.4%. The region's underlying traffic trends reveal strong demand, with passenger demand surpassing capacity growth. Load factor rose to 80% in Asia-Pacific. Despite regional trade slowdown and eurozone economic weakness, domestic markets in China and India saw double-digit growth in demand. Other regions, including the Middle East, Europe, and Latin America, also posted growth in demand, while African carriers experienced falling demand due to economic developments.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: A red-hot April for China's services sector
summary: China's services sector experienced its fastest growth this year in April, with the HSBC/Markit China Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching a four-month high of 52.9. Despite this, final prices of services hit a 15-month low due to firms cutting prices to boost sales. The strong stock market rally and consumer confidence contributed to the growth, but the low price levels indicate the sector still faces headwinds.

site_title: Two UAE traders sued for 'spoofing' gold, silver futures
summary: Two UAE traders, Heet Khara and Nasim Salim, were sued by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) for allegedly "spoofing" gold and silver futures markets. The CFTC claims they placed bids and offers they intended to cancel before execution, similar to a British trader who manipulated futures markets for five years. Khara and Salim are accused of acting in a coordinated fashion and should be permanently barred from trading and fined from their illegal profits. A hearing is scheduled for May 19 to determine their trading ban.

site_title: Federal's Q1 profit surges to S$16m on higher sales
summary: Federal International's net profit surged 449.1% to S$16 million in Q1 2015, driven by a 160.9% increase in revenue to S$57.5 million, largely due to its trading business. The company focused on core trading, increasing products offered and regional footprint in South-east Asia. Out of committed sales orders, S$12.4 million was delivered and billed, with S$47.3 million outstanding. The company also signed a US$917,000 contract for land rigging in Indonesia.

images.alt_text: Prisca Ang

site_title: Launch of Damansara residential units this weekend
summary: GuocoLand Malaysia is launching 60 residential units in DC Residency, a luxury integrated development in KL's Damansara Heights, for sale to Singapore buyers this weekend. The units, ranging from 899 sq ft to 2,705 sq ft, are priced at RM1,400 (S$518) per square foot on average, a 12% discount from the listing price. The development, expected to be completed by the end of 2015, will feature a 5-star hotel, office towers, and a lifestyle mall, with the office towers already 80% committed.

site_title: Apple under US scrutiny over talks with record labels for Beats revamp
summary: US antitrust officials are scrutinizing Apple's efforts to secure deals with record labels for its revamped Beats Music streaming service, potentially complicating the service's launch. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is investigating whether Apple is using its dominance in music downloads to disadvantage rival services like Spotify. Apple has approached artists for exclusive rights and partnerships, but the FTC is concerned that these efforts may change the way music labels work with other streaming services.

site_title: Gupta: Laggard lenders will vanish in a decade
summary: DBS chief executive Piyush Gupta predicts that Western banks will vanish within a decade due to their slow adaptation to digital banking, shifting consumption patterns, and data-privacy issues. Asian banks, on the other hand, are innovating and rolling with the changes, with examples including Ping An Bank and Hana Bank. Gupta notes that non-banks such as Nutmeg are also disrupting the industry by offering lower fees and commoditizing wealth management.

site_title: Indonesia palm oil shippers to pay new levy from end May
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo has signed rules implementing a new levy on palm oil exports, starting May 31. The levy, set at US$50 per tonne for raw palm oil and US$30 for processed products, aims to fund biodiesel subsidies and industry development. The government expects to raise approximately US$700 million in annual revenue. The levy will be managed by a government-led body, with the threshold for export tax remaining at US$750 per tonne. The move is part of Indonesia's efforts to promote biofuel use and reduce carbon emissions.

site_title: ARA Asset Management earnings up 6% for Q1
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 6% increase in net profit to S$18.97 million for Q1 2015, driven by a quadrupling of its share of profits of associates. Revenue remained flat at S$37.7 million, while recurrent management fees rose 1% and Reit management fees increased 13%. The company's assets under management rose to S$27.2 billion. Earnings per share rose to 2.24 Singapore cents.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit's Q1 DPU beats forecast
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.44 Singapore cents for Q1 2015, beating its forecast by 2.9% and marking a 44.4% increase from the prior period. Gross revenue exceeded forecasts by 7% due to better-than-expected occupancy and higher rental reversions. Net property income was 12.1% higher than forecast, driven by lower utilities and maintenance expenses. Portfolio occupancy rose to 98.6%, with office renewal rates increasing by 37.3% and 12.2% at OUE Bayfront and Lippo Plaza, respectively.

site_title: EZ-Link launches insurance alternative for the spa industry
summary: EZ-Link, a Singapore-based electronic payment card company, has launched its Trust Programme as an insurance alternative for consumers purchasing prepaid spa packages. The programme allows customers to store their prepaid funds in a trust account, which can be refunded in the event of a spa closure. EZ-Link partners with UOB bank to hold the funds, and merchants pay a percentage of each package sold to participate in the programme. The initiative aims to provide consumers with peace of mind and protect them from losses due to sudden spa closures.

site_title: Confronting the UK's trinity of deficits
summary: The UK's new government faces significant economic challenges, including a public sector budget deficit of £101.8 billion (5.7% of GDP) and a current account deficit of £97.9 billion (5.5% of GDP), the largest since 1948. Household debt also remains high at 95% of GDP. To address these "triple deficits," the government must adopt a balanced approach to reducing spending and improving the balance of payments. Economic flexibility and past experience of weathering crises may be key to overcoming these challenges.

site_title: China tests yuan gold fix process
summary: China conducted trial runs for its planned yuan-denominated gold fix, involving major Chinese banks and a few foreign banks, as it moves to create a benchmark price. The Shanghai Gold Exchange (SGE) plans to launch the fix this year, potentially challenging the century-old London fix. The SGE's international platform will act as the central counterparty, and participation will be open to members of its international board. The launch of the fix could add pressure on the London benchmark, which is used worldwide by producers, refiners, and central banks.

site_title: As growth slows, China worries about job losses
summary: China's economy is slowing down, with growth expected to fall below 7% in the coming months, sparking concerns about job losses. To prevent mass layoffs, the government is offering incentives and tax breaks to companies that retain workers. The Liaoning government has reduced its job creation target to 400,000, a significant decrease from its initial target of 700,000. Experts warn that the government may struggle to meet its goal of creating 10 million new jobs this year, citing a flawed unemployment rate and mounting pressure on the labor market.

site_title: Germany and Britain becoming surprisingly more similar
summary: Germany and Britain are becoming increasingly similar in terms of their economies, politics, and demographics. Both countries have large economies, with Germany and Britain being the two largest economies in Europe, and both have heavily traded with the EU. They also have similar GDP per capita and unemployment rates. The two countries are experiencing similar post-war fragmentation, with the rise of regional parties and a decline in support for traditional two-party dominance. The UK's upcoming election will confirm this phenomenon, with the two main parties likely to score a combined average of 68% of the vote, similar to Germany's two main parties.

site_title: Mathematics tracks the hip-hop 'revolution'
summary: Researchers tracked pop music evolution from 1960 to 2010 and found that hip-hop is the single most important event shaping the American charts. The genre emerged in the 1980s in New York City, with a significant spike in 1991, featuring artists like LL Cool J. Using algorithms and computer analysis, the study identified three revolutions: 1964, 1983, and 1991, with the latter being the largest. The study's findings suggest that music trends are not uniform, contradicting common claims, and provide a new method for analyzing cultural trends.

site_title: New York to test out micro-unit concept
summary: New York City is set to test the micro-unit concept with a 55-studio building in Manhattan, featuring 24-34 square meter prefabricated studios with kitchenettes and amenities. The pilot program, which began construction in May, aims to address the city's housing shortage and provide affordable housing options for singles and cohabiting couples. If successful, the regulation lifting the 37 square meter minimum housing size limit may follow, offering more choice to New Yorkers and potentially reducing rent prices.

site_title: Baltimore as a parable of inner city trauma
summary: Baltimore unrest highlights the social and cultural issues afflicting cities with large African-American populations, contradicting the liberal narrative of focusing on political and economic factors. The city's unrest, sparked by the death of Freddie Gray in police custody, occurred during a White House Press Association dinner where President Barack Obama addressed a predominantly white and wealthy audience. The event highlights the disconnect between the hopes of the Obama era and the ongoing struggles faced by young African Americans in cities like Baltimore.

site_title: Prudential's bancassurance gap lowers Singapore Q1 APE sales
summary: Prudential plc reported a 19% decline in Singapore's annual premium equivalent (APE) sales to £72m in Q1 2015, due to the cessation of bancassurance agreements with Maybank and SingPost in 2014. Excluding the discontinued agreements, APE sales in Singapore declined 7%. New business profit in Singapore grew 2% despite the drop, driven by higher-value protection products. The company attributed the decline to a "low long-term interest rate environment" and attributed its strong growth in Asia to its importance to the group's long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Smartphone streaming strikes at copyright owners
summary: Thousands of people may have streamed the Pacquiao-Mayweather fight on smartphone apps Periscope and Meerkat without paying the official $100 fee, raising questions about copyright restrictions. The apps' terms of service claim to not allow streaming of copyrighted content, but the lack of clear definitions and fast removal times may render the law ineffective. Tech firms and copyright holders are left to navigate the issue, with some calling for a revision of copyright law and others considering legal action.

site_title: COE premiums stabilise in latest bidding exercise
summary: Singapore's COE premiums stabilised in the latest bidding exercise, with all categories except Cat A softening. Cat A, for cars below 1,600cc or 130 hp, rose to S$68,589. The increase is attributed to impending changes to the CEVS (Certified Electronic Vehicle Scheme). The new quota will offer a 41% increase in COEs over the next three months.

site_title: Britain's exit could severely jolt EU, says bloc's trade commissioner
summary: Britain's potential exit from the EU could severely impact the bloc, according to EU trade commissioner Cecilia Malmstroem. She stated that a popular vote would have "tremendous effects" on the EU, but emphasized that the EU is not yet at that point. The comment came as Britain is set to hold a referendum on its EU membership.

site_title: Microsoft mulling bid for Salesforce: sources
summary: Microsoft is considering a potential bid for Salesforce, a cloud computing company with a market value of nearly $50 billion. The acquisition would give Microsoft an additional $6 billion in annual cloud revenue and make it the largest provider of web-delivered software. However, the deal would be costly and complex, with significant integration costs and potential disruptions to the software market. Analysts, including Mark Moerdler at Sanford C Bernstein & Co, say the risks of the acquisition outweigh the rewards, citing challenges in merging the two companies' cultures and the potential for many Salesforce executives to cash out their stock options and leave.

images.alt_text: As Microsoft Corp mulls over whether to launch a bid for Salesforce.com Inc, it will have to weigh the benefits of a big expansion in cloud computing against the drawbacks of a high price and a costly, time-consuming integration.

site_title: India as the world's next major trading bloc?
summary: India is moving towards forming a single market with 29 states, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to implement a uniform service tax and simplify labor and land laws. This could boost economic growth, with predicted growth rates of at least 7.5% over the next five years. The new market could benefit poorer states, which may experience faster growth rates than the national average. However, a political battle is expected, with Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party controlling 11 states, while the main opposition Congress party-led bloc holds nine.

site_title: Orange in talks over Jazztel assets
summary: Orange is in talks with potential buyers to sell parts of Jazztel's fibre network as a condition for regulatory approval of its 3.4 billion-euro takeover deal. The company plans to rent out capacity on the network to the buyer, aiming to bring back a fourth national competitor to Spain's broadband market. The deal, worth S$5.1 billion, would see Orange sell approximately 720,000 fibre connections in five cities, and the buyer would have the right to piggyback on Orange-Jazztel's fixed network. Regulatory approval is expected by June 1.

site_title: Petra Foods Q1 profit falls 42.8% on Indonesian slowdown
summary: Petra Foods reported a 42.8% decline in Q1 net profit to US$7.7 million due to a slowdown in the Indonesian economy. Revenue fell 13.5% to US$106.2 million, with Indonesian sales dropping 16.6% to US$73.5 million. The company expects a "challenging" operating environment in Indonesia for the rest of the year, but not a continuous decline.

site_title: US producer Magnetation is latest casualty of iron slump
summary: US producer Magnetation LLC filed for bankruptcy due to a worldwide oversupply of iron ore, triggered by economic slowdown in China and expansion by major producers. The company, which owns plants in Minnesota and Indiana, listed assets of $500 million against $1 billion in debt. A debt-restructuring agreement with creditors is planned, with holders committing $135 million to finance it. The move is the latest casualty of the iron slump, which is expected to keep prices between $55 and $65 over the medium term.

site_title: Private payrolls growth moderates; productivity falls
summary: US private payrolls increased 169,000 in April, the fewest since January 2014, below economists' expectations of 200,000 jobs. The report also showed non-farm productivity fell 1.9% annually, the first back-to-back decline since 2006, due to harsh winter weather. Despite this, workers put in more hours, increasing at a 1.7% rate, while unit labor costs rose 5.0% and compensation per hour increased 3.1%. The data may heighten worries about the economy's potential rebound and squeeze corporate profits.

site_title: Managing great expectations at Alibaba
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd saw its market value erode by about US$70 billion since November due to concerns over slowing growth and a shift to mobile shopping in China, threatening the company's dominance as a marketplace. The Chinese economy, projected to grow at its slowest pace since 1990, is also affecting advertising revenue. Investors worry that Alibaba's record-breaking US$25 billion fundraising last year may not be enough to mitigate these challenges. The company's founder, Jack Ma, may have been correct in warning of high expectations.

site_title: Think long-term - businesses must build a growth, not just a yield, market
summary: Businesses must prioritize long-term growth over yield when it comes to pleasing shareholders, according to a recent editorial. Despite the demand for high dividend yields, investors should focus on a company's underlying business model and earnings potential. Over-reliance on payouts can leave companies vulnerable to market fluctuations. Stocks exposed to the business cycle and promising local private enterprises can offer growth opportunities, while businesses with high dividend yields often come with higher risks. Investors should be taught to assess stocks based on their long-term potential rather than short-term gains.

site_title: How Singapore can make a difference in Nepal's reconstruction
summary: A 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck Nepal on April 25, 2015, causing widespread devastation and a death toll of over 7,000. The disaster destroyed an estimated 300,000 houses and damaged historic monuments, with reconstruction costs estimated to exceed US$10 billion. The author, who experienced the earthquake firsthand, highlights the need for international support to aid in Nepal's reconstruction efforts, with Singapore being one of the countries that can make a significant difference.

site_title: Fans sue Pacquiao over injury
summary: Two Nevada men filed a class-action lawsuit against Manny Pacquiao, alleging he concealed a shoulder injury before his loss to Floyd Mayweather. The plaintiffs claim Pacquiao's failure to disclose the injury before the bout violated Nevada Deceptive Trade Practices Act. Pacquiao's attorney says the lawsuit will be dismissed, stating the injury occurred nearly a month before the bout and Pacquiao was cleared to fight by doctors and the Nevada Athletic Commission. The lawsuit seeks millions in damages from Pacquiao, his manager, and promotional company Top Rank.

site_title: Outer boroughs of NYC see housing boom
summary: A housing boom is underway in New York City's outer boroughs, with builders of rental and for-sale properties drawn to Brooklyn and Queens due to more affordable land and lower expenses. Developers plan 37,243 residential units in Brooklyn and 17,352 in Queens, surpassing Manhattan's 44,427 homes. Luxury projects, such as AvalonBay's 200 rentals and 50 condos in Sheepshead Bay, are expected to cater to high-demand areas like Coney Island and Flushing, where international buyers are driving growth. This shift is seen as a response to rising costs in Manhattan, with investors seeking value elsewhere.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close with small gains
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed with gains on Wednesday, driven by a sharp rise in the euro against the dollar. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.09%, while the CAC 40 in Paris rose 0.15% and the DAX in Frankfurt climbed 0.20%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare sectors, which were boosted by investor confidence.

site_title: China's cybersecurity push breeds start-ups
summary: China's cybersecurity push has triggered a surge in start-ups developing local technology, following the 2013 Snowden disclosures that prompted the government to accelerate the replacement of foreign systems. Entrepreneurs like Zhang Long, who has no technology background, are capitalizing on the trend, with his Linux-based operating system SPGnux gaining traction among government offices. Despite concerns from Chinese banks about security, the sector is attracting international venture capitalists, with Beijing backing the enterprise computing sector. The industry's growth is also driven by the government's efforts to promote local technology and reduce reliance on foreign systems.

site_title: SGX's first step towards 'comply or explain' for sustainability reporting
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is introducing a "comply or explain" regime for sustainability reporting, requiring listed companies to follow guidelines or explain their reasons for not doing so. The exchange expects to submit changes to listing rules and a reviewed reporting guide by the end of 2015, with implementation targeted for 2017. The move aims to enhance disclosure and transparency to investors, following a growing global trend of sustainability reporting.

site_title: Tariffs set to rise 5% this year in US as occupancy rates increase
summary: US hotel occupancy rates are expected to reach record highs in 2015, with 65.1% occupancy at more expensive hotels. Room rates are projected to rise 5.3% this year, driven by group bookings and a growing economy. This growth is expected to contribute to a 5.2% increase in travel spending in the US. While higher prices may lead to a decline in occupancy rates in the long term, hotels currently have room to raise prices, with some expecting a 1.2% decline in occupancy between 2016 and 2017.

site_title: MTP meant to 'nudge' firms to strengthen fundamentals: SGX
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has implemented a minimum trading price (MTP) of S$0.20 for mainboard-listed stocks to nudge companies to strengthen their fundamentals. The rule aims to improve liquidity and reduce speculation, benefiting investors with lower trading costs. Companies that fail to meet the MTP by March 1 next year will be placed on a three-year watchlist. Analysts have raised concerns about the rule, but SGX head of listing compliance June Sim says it encourages companies to focus on organic growth and improve their financial performance.

site_title: Helmsley Building sold for US$1.2b
summary: MONDAY Properties has sold the Helmsley Building in New York for US$1.2 billion to RXR Reality. The 34-storey building, built in 1929, has 1.4 million square feet of office space and is 94% occupied. The sale marks the departure of MONDAY Properties from New York's office building market, but the company plans to return. The building's net operating income increased to US$45 million, up from US$34 million four years ago, and has undergone a US$200 million renovation since 2002.

site_title: Asian buyers account for a third of Sotheby's US$368m sales
summary: Asian buyers dominated a Sotheby's auction in New York, accounting for over a third of the $368.3 million sales. Top lots included Vincent Van Gogh's "L'Allee Des Alyscamps" sold for $66.3 million and Claude Monet's "Lily Pond Painted in 1905" sold for $54 million. The auction, which also included works by Pablo Picasso, saw Asian buyers outbid Sotheby's Asia chairman Patti Wong for several pieces, including a Picasso portrait of his lover Francoise Gilot. The market appears to be showing no signs of slowing down, with dealers citing low interest rates and high stock market values as contributing factors.

site_title: Emirates to deliver 'sledgehammer' response to US subsidy allegations
summary: Emirates plans a strong response to a US report alleging the airline and its Gulf counterparts received $40 billion in unfair government subsidies. Emirates President Tim Clark called the report "weak" and invited US carriers to follow suit if disproved. The airline's CEO, Ahmed Al Maktoum, said it would take two years to prepare a rebuttal, citing the lengthy time it took US carriers to compile the report. Emirates denies the allegations, which were made by Delta, American, and United Airlines, and claims it competes fairly in markets served by US carriers.

site_title: Barclays Asia cash-equity unit finally turns profit
summary: Barclays' Asia-Pacific cash-equity unit is expected to turn a profit by the end of 2016, seven years after it began operations. The unit has implemented cost cuts and refocused on its most profitable clients, including electronic and portfolio trading, ETFs, and research. This turnaround is expected to boost return on equity (ROE) in the broader Asian equities business, which is currently in single digits. The unit's restructuring comes amid a global revamp of Barclays' investment bank, which has been impacted by tighter regulations and higher capital requirements.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Marine's target price is raised to S$4.04, with analysts expecting the company to meet its S$3.8 billion order win estimate, driven by strong enquiries for fixed platform work and FPSO conversions. In contrast, OSIM International's FY15 earnings per share are lowered by 15%, resulting in a target price of S$2.08. Analysts at Maybank Kim Eng Research cut their rating on OSIM from BUY to HOLD due to weaker markets and higher costs.

site_title: HK luxury watch retailers cut prices to stay ahead
summary: Hong Kong luxury watch retailers are cutting prices to remain competitive after sales plummeted by at least 40% in the first three months of the year due to the Swiss Central Bank's surprise move to free the exchange rate between the Swiss franc and the euro. The retailers, including Emperor Watch & Jewellery, Chow Tai Fook, and Global Timepieces, are calling for unified prices to become more competitive, citing lower prices in other duty-free countries. This move is aimed at protecting Hong Kong's position as the world's biggest watch market.

site_title: BMW Q1 profit beats estimates
summary: BMW reported a 21% increase in first-quarter earnings before interest and taxes to 2.52 billion euros, beating analyst estimates. Revenue jumped 15% to 20.9 billion euros. The company attributed the profit jump to currency tailwinds and a revival in local demand in Europe and the US. BMW stuck to its forecast of "solid" growth in 2015, with record sales and pretax earnings. The company also reported a 30% surge in X5 deliveries and a doubling of 4-Series coupe sales, offsetting an 8% decline in 3-Series sedan sales.

site_title: Bad news for British economy as polls forecast an unstable govt
summary: The UK is heading towards a potentially unstable government as polls forecast a Conservative or Labour-led coalition, with both parties having about a third of the votes. This uncertainty is expected to negatively impact the UK economy, which already has high government debt and household debt. The National Institute of Economic and Social Research has cut its growth forecast for 2015 to 2.5%, citing weaker construction and manufacturing activity. A change in government could lead to a decline in the stock market and dampen confidence, with inflation potentially surging due to sterling weakness and a recovery in US dollar-priced oil.

site_title: Forecasts for CBD office rents clipped
summary: Singapore's CBD office rents are expected to stagnate or ease for the rest of 2015 due to weak leasing demand and tepid economic growth. Property consultants, such as CBRE and Savills Singapore, have revised their forecasts, predicting a flat average gross effective monthly rental value for Grade A office spaces. This downward pressure presents opportunities for tenants to lock in leases at attractive rents, with a few big leasing transactions expected later this year or next year. New office completions and supply quantum are expected to impact the market, but market watchers note that a few industries, such as trading houses, are showing growth.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Euro rises to 2-month high on German bund sell-off
summary: The euro rose to a two-month high against the dollar due to rising German 10-year bund yields and narrowing the gap with US Treasuries. The eurozone's business activity showed a solid pick-up, and Greece made a $300.47 million interest payment to the International Monetary Fund. These factors, along with a softer dollar, contributed to the euro's increase.

site_title: Celebrating roads less travelled
summary: The 30th edition of the Singapore Business Awards (SBA) was held at Resorts World Sentosa, celebrating achievements among individuals and companies in corporate Singapore. The event, jointly organized by The Business Times and DHL, marked 30 years since the first Businessman of the Year award was given out in 1985. This year's celebration highlighted the growth and prestige of the SBA, solidifying its position as Singapore's oldest and most prestigious business award.

site_title: No deal with Greece on Monday: Dijsselbloem
summary: Eurogroup chair Jeroen Dijsselbloem stated that no deal with Greece is possible at the next Eurogroup meeting, citing unresolved issues between Greece and its lenders. French Finance Minister Michel Sapin also acknowledged that an agreement is not imminent. This development comes after talks in Paris on Wednesday.

site_title: US oil stocks drop for first time since January: EIA
summary: US crude oil stocks dropped for the first time since January, falling 3.9 million barrels, according to the Energy Information Administration. Gasoline stocks rose 401,000 barrels, while distillate inventories rose 1.5 million barrels. Refinery crude runs increased by 247,000 barrels per day, and US crude imports fell by 905,000 barrels per day. The decline in crude stocks is attributed to higher refinery utilization rates and lower imports, suggesting a potential shift in the US oil market.

site_title: Greece makes IMF interest payment, but no cash-for-reforms deal yet
summary: Greece made a small interest payment to the IMF on May 6, but a cash-for-reforms deal remains elusive. The country's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras blamed the eurozone and IMF for the lack of agreement, despite EU officials accusing Greece of failing to produce enough concessions. The Eurogroup's chief, Jeroen Dijsselbloem, stated that an agreement by Monday is no longer possible. Greece's cash crunch worsens as it struggles to meet IMF payments and pay wages and pensions.

site_title: Tech-driven manufacturing needs new mindsets and skills
summary: Singapore's manufacturing industry is undergoing a transformation with the advent of Industry 4.0, driven by disruptive tech. This shift requires new mindsets and skills, making the SkillsFuture initiative timely to help workers adapt. The program aims to develop skills for the future, aligning with the country's need to evolve in a digital economy.

site_title: Indian parliament's lower house passes goods and services tax reform
summary: India's lower house of parliament passed a bill to transform the country into a common market by harmonizing state and central levies into a national sales tax, known as the goods and services tax (GST). The bill, expected to boost manufacturing, requires approval from the upper house and at least half of India's 29 states. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley described the GST as the country's biggest reform since independence, which could add 2 percentage points to the growth of Asia's third-largest economy.

site_title: Cityspring Trust swings into profit in Q4; DPU at 0.82¢
summary: Cityspring Infrastructure Trust reported a Q4 DPU of 0.82 Singapore cents, unchanged from the previous year, and a net profit of S$9.55 million, a significant improvement from a net loss of S$3.7 million in the same period last year. Revenues decreased by 10% to S$121.46 million due to lower contributions from subsidiaries. The trust expects its Australian subsidiary Basslink's cash earnings to fluctuate due to tariff changes. The trust also announced its acquisition of Keppel Infrastructure Trust's assets and liabilities, expected to be completed on May 18.

site_title: Apple announces seven-part bond for buybacks, dividends
summary: Apple has announced a seven-tranche US dollar benchmark bond with maturities of two to 30 years to finance stock repurchases and dividends. Bookrunners JP Morgan, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, and Goldman Sachs will price the deal later in the day. The bond is part of Apple's efforts to return capital to shareholders.

site_title: Viva budgets S$20 million for Technopark@Chai Chee makeover
summary: Viva Industrial Trust plans to renovate Technopark@Chai Chee with a S$20 million investment starting in the second quarter of 2015. The renovation will incorporate retail and lifestyle features, with the first retail offerings expected to open by the end of 2015. The ground-floor carpark and unutilized areas of three blocks will be converted into retail space, and the development's facade will be improved.

site_title: Honda SUV model leads PI sales
summary: The Honda Vezel has taken the top spot as Singapore's most popular parallel import (PI) model, with 380 units registered in the first quarter of 2015. This surpasses the traditional Toyota model, which was previously the top PI model. The Toyota Harrier is the runner-up with 338 units registered, and the Toyota Vellfire is third with 48 units. The total PI market saw a 189% increase to 1,169 cars registered, with Honda being the second most popular brand.

images.alt_text: A small, cool SUV from Honda has powered past the traditional Toyota model to claim the mantle as Singapore's most popular parallel import (PI) model as the total PI market boomed on an expanding COE quota.

site_title: Blackstone said to sell apartments for about US$650m
summary: Blackstone Group LP sold over 4,600 US apartments to Strata Equity Group and Mexican investors for approximately $650 million, capitalizing on strong demand for rental housing. The 12 apartment complexes, built between 1989 and 2012, will be renovated and are located in Atlanta, Denver, Houston, and Austin. Demand for apartments has increased due to a falling US homeownership rate and rising rents, with average US apartment rent reaching a record $1,132 in the first quarter. This sale marks the beginning of Blackstone's investment in its new global property fund, BREP VIII.

site_title: Fed 'remains watchful' on fixing banking system risk: Yellen
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that while banks have become more robust, the financial system still faces emerging risks. Regulators are working to address the perception that large banks are "too big to fail" by ensuring they can be resolved without government support. Steps include requiring banks to have sufficient total loss-absorbing capacity and prepare "living wills" for orderly resolution. Yellen emphasized the importance of regulation and vigilant supervision to address distorted incentives and promote job creation, innovation, and inclusive economic growth.

site_title: Hiap Seng unit wins US$11 million contracts for offshore gas compressors
summary: Hiap Seng's 87%-owned subsidiary, HS Compression & Process, has secured two US$11 million contracts for offshore gas compressor packages, scheduled for completion in March 2016. The projects, which have begun, are expected to positively contribute to earnings but not significantly impact net tangible assets or earnings per share for the year ending March 2016.

site_title: Why battle for Net neutrality in the US matters globally
summary: The US is at risk of passing legislation that would undermine net neutrality, potentially creating an Internet controlled by a few multimedia conglomerates. This could lead to unequal treatment of data, hindering free trade and openness. A neutral internet allows all voices to be heard and multiplied globally, regardless of source or size. The US is one of the few countries where net neutrality has become a contentious debate, with far-reaching implications for global internet freedom.

images.alt_text: If the United States loses the fight over Net neutrality with the Internet service providers, the consequences in some cases will be immediate but in all long-run scenarios, dire. Streaming giants such as Netflix could struggle to provide the same level of service at the prices users appreciate.

site_title: Blumont expects Q1 loss on adjustments to financial assets
summary: Blumont Group expects to report a Q1 net loss due to fair value readjustments of investments in financial assets, caused by recent volatility in financial markets and the global economy. The company attributed the adjustments to the situation. The results are expected to be announced by May 15. As a result, Blumont shares fell to 1.2 Singapore cents before the profit warning.

site_title: US: Stocks rise at open on big biopharma merger
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, driven by a large biopharma merger between Alexion Pharmaceuticals and Synageva BioPharma, valued at $8.4 billion. This offset lackluster private-sector hiring data, with 169,000 jobs added in April. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all gained, with the Nasdaq advancing 0.35%. Investors await the US Labor Department jobs report for April on Friday.

site_title: Global private debt fund market now at US$440b: trade body
summary: The Alternative Investment Management Association reported that the global private debt fund market has reached $440 billion, with $64 billion raised in 2014. The growth is attributed to banks' reduced lending due to new regulations, prompting hedge funds and private debt funds to fill the gap. This has led to a 43% increase in deals in Europe and a doubling of funds since 2012, with 81 new funds seeking to raise $50 billion. Private debt funds have invested in sectors such as social housing, health, and renewable energy.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in the second half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rose for a 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: M1 to buy 15% stake in Oman telco for S$10.3 million
summary: M1, a Singaporean telco, plans to acquire a 15% stake in Integrated Telecommunications Oman (TeO) for S$10.3 million, subject to regulatory approvals. TeO is a niche private telco that sells mobile services under the Telecom Oman brand. The acquisition aims to help TeO become a full-service telecommunication provider in Oman. M1 will pay for the investment with internal funds and has met with Oman's Telecommunications Regulatory Authority, which sees the investment as a positive step for the sector's development.

site_title: StanChart says HQ under review amid rising UK bank tax
summary: Standard Chartered Chairman John Peace stated the bank is reviewing its domicile amid rising UK bank tax, which may lead to relocation to Asia. This follows similar comments from rival HSBC, which is conducting a formal review of its headquarters. Peace emphasized the bank will take no "knee-jerk actions" that could harm its long-term prospects.

site_title: US productivity falls for second straight quarter
summary: US nonfarm productivity declined at a 1.9% annual rate in the first quarter, marking the second consecutive quarter of decline, due to harsh winter weather and rising labour-related production costs. Productivity dropped after falling at a 2.1% pace in the fourth quarter, with unit labour costs increasing at a 5.0% rate, the fastest pace since 2014. Despite this, workers put in more hours, with hours increasing at a 1.7% rate, and compensation per hour rose at a 3.1% rate, suggesting wage inflation could be firming.

site_title: Hugo Boss posts Q1 profit fall, but expects growth to pick up
summary: Hugo Boss reported a 7% decline in Q1 net profit to 75.6 million euros, missing analyst forecasts. Despite lower-than-expected sales, the company expects sales and profit growth to pick up in the second half of the year. Sales rose 9% to 668 million euros, driven by a 3% increase in China and outperformance in Britain and Germany. The company plans to continue investing in its brand and retail network, and expects a medium single-digit percentage sales rise and a 5-7% increase in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization.

site_title: IATA says global air travel demand may soften in Q2
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) predicts a potential softening of global air travel demand in the second quarter of 2015, citing slowing trade in Asia and European economic weakness. Despite a 7.4% increase in air travel demand in March, driven by leisure travel from the Chinese New Year, IATA Director General Tony Tyler warned of a possible decline in the second quarter. The prediction may impact airline profits in 2015, which IATA will discuss at its annual meeting in June.

site_title: Indonesia's biodiesel levy for palm exports due by 3rd week of May: minister
summary: Indonesia's Chief Economic Minister, Sofyan Djalil, announced a new regulation requiring exporters to pay a levy of US$50 per tonne of crude palm oil and US$30 for processed palm oil shipments. The levy, effective by the third week of May, aims to fund biodiesel subsidies and support palm prices if demand increases. The regulation was signed by Indonesian President Joko Widodo and aims to stabilize the palm oil market.

site_title: US private sector adds 169,000 jobs in April: ADP
summary: US private sector added 169,000 jobs in April, the fewest since January 2014, below economists' expectations of 200,000. The ADP National Employment Report, jointly developed with Moody's Analytics, also revised March's private payrolls to 175,000 jobs. The US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report, set to be released Friday, is expected to show a gain of 224,000 jobs, with the unemployment rate predicted to drop to 5.4%.

site_title: Societe Generale net profit rises five-fold in first quarter
summary: Societe Generale reported a five-fold increase in first-quarter net profit to 868 million euros, surpassing analysts' 837 million euro average forecast. The bank's core business activity improved due to an improving European economic outlook, lower risk provisions, and cost-cutting measures. However, the bank's Russian affiliate posted first-quarter net losses of 91 million euros due to economic upheaval. Despite this, the bank maintained overall group financial targets for 2015, with chairman Frederic Oudea citing a strong growth in commercial revenues and Group net income.

site_title: Singapore: STI suffers third straight loss
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore suffered its third consecutive loss, falling 11.4 points to 3,459.79. The decline was attributed to overnight weakness on Wall Street due to escalating Greece's financial problems. Despite a spike in turnover, banks had a mixed performance, with DBS rising while OCBC and UOB fell.

site_title: GlaxoSmithKline targets growth across units, scraps ViiV IPO
summary: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) has set growth targets for its biggest businesses, focusing on consumer health and vaccines to drive long-term growth. The company scrapped plans to float its HIV drug business ViiV Healthcare, citing a strong outlook. GSK expects group sales to rise by a low-to-mid single digit percentage rate annually to 2020, with pharmaceuticals and vaccines increasing by low single digits and mid-to-high single digits, respectively. The company will pay a special dividend of 1 billion pounds to protect its dividend, following a disappointing first-quarter earnings report.

site_title: EU regulators launches cross-border e-commerce investigation
summary: EU antitrust regulators launched an investigation into cross-border e-commerce, aiming to remove borders to online sales and overhaul the bloc's digital market. The probe focuses on barriers to online sales in electronics, clothing, and shoes, as well as digital content. This move follows European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager's intention to open the sector inquiry in March.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Wednesday
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans a 'comply or explain' regime for sustainability reporting, seeking public feedback. COE premiums stabilized, while UOB will offer an onshore loan in Myanmar. OCBC plans to remodel its unprofitable China consumer banking unit. The Straits Times Index (STI) suffered its third consecutive loss, falling 11.4 points to 3,459.79. Meanwhile, international news includes Vietnam's reaction to the US tariff announcement, a Malaysian agency's plan to seize Daim Zainuddin's assets, and a mid-2026 target for Citigroup's global equity index.

site_title: China eyes export fillip in modern Silk Road
summary: China's cabinet has proposed using the "One Belt, One Road" project to boost exports of rail, energy, construction, and telecommunication equipment. The plan aims to increase overseas demand and employment, driving China's equipment exports to $2.5 trillion in about a decade. The government will also simplify regulations for overseas investment, build a yuan payments system, and utilize $3.7 trillion foreign exchange reserves. To support domestic businesses, red-tape will be cut for 200 government-approved procedures, and tax rebates will be offered for private health insurance premiums.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropped 6.45 points to 1,820.97 on Wednesday, with losers outnumbering gainers 454 to 353. The index saw 1.9 billion lots valued at RM1.8 billion traded.

site_title: Kingboard Copper Foil Q1 net profit more than doubles to HK$6 million
summary: Kingboard Copper Foil Holdings reported a net profit of HK$6 million in Q1 2015, more than doubling from the previous year, driven by a 41.7% increase in revenue to HK$164.5 million. Licence fees contributed HK$30 million and resin sales accounted for HK$134 million. The company plans to upgrade its production capabilities and product mix in anticipation of higher demand. Distribution costs rose 44% due to larger sales volumes.

site_title: Japan's Daiwa keen on minority stake in Malaysia's Affin Hwang Investment Bank
summary: Japan's Daiwa Securities Group Inc is considering a minority stake purchase in Malaysia's Affin Hwang Investment Bank Bhd, the smallest lender in Malaysia by market value. Bank Negara Malaysia, the central bank, has given its approval in principle for the negotiations. Affin Holdings Bhd, the parent company, will require prior approval from Bank Negara Malaysia before entering into any agreement. The deal aims to strengthen Daiwa's presence in the Malaysian market and expand its financial services offerings. Details of the proposed deal are yet to be disclosed.

site_title: COE premiums stable
summary: COE premiums remain stable, with a 41% increase in supply for the next three months. COE categories except small cars saw significant price drops, with Cat A rising to S$68,589, Cat B falling to S$77,600, and Cat C dropping to S$50,098. Cat D, for motorcycles, decreased to S$6,512. The stable premiums follow a recent increase, with Cat A reaching above S$100,000.

site_title: Britain's closest election in a generation goes down to the wire
summary: Britain's general election, considered its most unpredictable in a generation, enters its final day with the Conservative party and Labour level in most polls. Neither party has a clear lead, and a majority is unlikely. The outcome could impact Britain's future in the European Union and national cohesion. The stakes are high, with a potentially messy result possible. The election will be closely watched, and its outcome will have significant implications for the country's future.

site_title: SGX plans 'comply or explain' regime for sustainability reporting; seeks public feedback
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to implement a "comply or explain" regime for sustainability reporting, requiring listed companies to follow guidelines or explain their non-compliance by the end of 2015. The goal is to enhance disclosure and transparency to investors. The exchange expects to submit changes to listing rules and reviewed sustainability guidelines by the end of 2015, with implementation targeted for the financial year 2017. This move aims to provide investors with a comprehensive view of companies' long-term value, including environmental and social aspects.

site_title: Gold down as strong shares, US yields offset weaker dollar
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,190.53 an ounce, amid stronger European shares and higher US real yields, which offset the weaker dollar and expectations of a June Federal Reserve rate hike. US gold futures lost $3.20 an ounce. Higher US Treasury yields, a two-month high, and disappointing US trade data also weighed on gold prices. A report on US private-sector employment later in the day may influence expectations for the June rate hike.

site_title: ARA Asset Management posts 6% increase in 1Q2015 net profit
summary: ARA Asset Management reported a 6% increase in 1Q2015 net profit to S$18.97 million, driven by a fourfold increase in associate profits. Revenue slipped 1% to S$37.70 million, mainly due to lower finance income. Earnings per share rose to 2.24 Singapore cents. The company's asset under management (AUM) increased to S$27.2 billion.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Winters said to seek more direct oversight at StanChart
summary: Standard Chartered's new CEO, Bill Winters, plans to supervise the bank's regional units more directly than his predecessor, Peter Sands. Winters will report to him directly, rather than through regional leaders, when he takes over on June 10. The bank is eliminating 4,000 jobs to save $1.8 billion in costs through 2017. Winters' first tasks include forging a new management team after the departure of senior executives, and he will "decide the appropriate structure" for the regions. The changes aim to improve oversight and efficiency at the bank.

site_title: JPMorgan gets SEC subpoenas over mutual fund sales
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has received subpoenas from the US Securities and Exchange Commission over how it sells its mutual funds, amid investigations into the bank's wealth-management business. The SEC's enforcement division is looking into whether senior asset-management executives improperly steered clients into investments for the bank's own financial gain. JPMorgan is cooperating with the relevant authorities and is in advanced stages of settlement talks with the US Department of Justice and Federal Reserve. The bank is also facing investigations from French authorities and is addressing other government and self-regulatory organization inquiries.

site_title: China to start building 3rd generation nuclear reactor: company
summary: China is set to start building its first "third generation" nuclear reactor, the ACP1000, at the Fuqing nuclear power plant in Fujian province. The reactor, developed by China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC), aims to extract more energy from uranium fuel than previous technologies in a safer manner. This project is part of China's nuclear "going-global" strategy, with the country exporting nuclear technology to over 20 countries, including Pakistan and Argentina. The move is seen as a key element in tackling China's chronic pollution issues.

site_title: EU to review behaviour of web giants in digital market overhaul
summary: The European Commission will conduct a review of web giants such as Google, Facebook, and Amazon to determine if they should be regulated more tightly. The review will focus on transparency of search results, pricing policies, data use, relationships with other businesses, and promotional practices. This is part of the Digital Single Market Strategy, which aims to boost economic growth in Europe by removing national barriers for online services. The review is expected to provide a comprehensive assessment of the role of web giants in the digital market.

site_title: Prudential Q1 new business profit falls 11%
summary: UK-based insurer Prudential plc reported a 11% fall in new business profit for the first quarter of 2015 to £496 million, despite its thriving Asian business. Asia's new business profit rose 22% year-on-year, while US and UK new business profits declined 28% and 11% respectively. The group's annual premium equivalent sales increased 1% to £1.25 billion.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: Bollywood star Salman Khan sentenced to 5 years for hit-and-run
summary: Bollywood star Salman Khan was sentenced to 5 years in prison for culpable homicide in a 2002 hit-and-run accident that killed a homeless man and injured four others. Khan, 49, was found guilty of driving under the influence of alcohol and losing control of his car, which rammed into a bakery. The sentence may derail several of Khan's big movie projects.

site_title: UK services rebound, easing fears of slowdown on eve of election: PMI
summary: The UK services sector rebounded in April, with a PMI index rising to an eight-month high of 59.5, easing fears of a slowdown ahead of the national election. The sector's growth was driven by consumer spending, while manufacturing and construction sectors slowed. The rebound suggests the economy is on track to bounce back in the second quarter. The strong services sector data will be highlighted by Prime Minister David Cameron in his final election campaign, and may reduce the likelihood of the Bank of England raising interest rates this year.

site_title: Greece makes 200m euro IMF payment due Wednesday: source
summary: Greece made a 200-million-euro interest payment to the International Monetary Fund on Wednesday, averting a potential issue. The payment is part of the country's efforts to secure further aid amid a cash crisis. A larger 750-million-euro payment due on May 12 is expected to pose a bigger challenge.

site_title: Indonesia hires four banks to lead global sukuk
summary: Indonesia has mandated four banks - CIMB, Dubai Islamic Bank, HSBC, and JP Morgan - to lead a potential offering of US dollar-denominated 144A/Reg S sukuk bonds. The sovereign plans to embark on investor meetings in Asia, Europe, and the Middle East, pending market conditions. This move follows Malaysia's successful US$1.5bn global sukuk offering in April, which removed a premium previously paid by sukuk issues. Indonesia's plans aim to attract investors and potentially materialize an offering in the coming weeks.

site_title: China pulls out stops to avoid lay-offs as economy cools
summary: China is taking measures to avoid mass layoffs amid slowing economic growth, with state firms encouraged to keep idle workers employed and given subsidies and tax breaks. Subsidies and tax breaks are given to companies that do not fire their workers, and some businesses are even incentivized to hire despite the economic slowdown. Officials are more concerned with financial and debt risks, and measures appear to be working, with no major problem in employment reported.

site_title: French private-sector growth slows in April: PMI
summary: French private-sector growth slowed in April, with the composite Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) dipping to 50.6 from 51.5 in March, marking a third consecutive month above the 50 line separating expansion from contraction. The services sector's expansion weakened, while manufacturing activity continued to shrink. Despite this, business expectations improved to the highest level in over three years, and employment rose slightly, suggesting a cautious optimism for an improving economic situation. The slowdown in growth may hinder President Francois Hollande's efforts to reduce France's stubbornly high jobless rate of around 10%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares erase gains, follow mainland markets lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.4% to 27,640.91 on Wednesday, following mainland markets lower, despite earlier gains. Infrastructure and industrial stocks led the decline. Notably, Chinese automaker Dongfeng Motor Group rose 1.1% after its parent company's new chairman appointment amid a potential merger with China FAW Group Corp. Total trading volume was 2.3 billion shares.

site_title: Thailand April tourist arrivals up 18.3% y-o-y: govt spokesman
summary: Thailand reported a 18.3% increase in tourist arrivals in April, with 2.28 million visitors, mostly from China and Malaysia. This marks the seventh consecutive month of growth, offering a boost to the economy. Tourism revenue reached 104.1 billion baht, a 21.9% increase from last year. The steady recovery in tourism is attributed to the end of months of political unrest in Thailand since the army seized power last May.

site_title: IHH, Sime Darby said to submit bids for HMI's Malaysian hospital
summary: IHH Healthcare and Sime Darby Bhd have submitted first-round bids for Malaysia's Mahkota Medical Centre, valued at around US$250 million. The hospital, which attracts over 287,000 patients, is part of Health Management International Ltd's portfolio. The bidders aim to boost growth by acquiring a hospital offering specialist services. The sale process is private, with Health Management working with Credit Suisse Group to sell the hospital.

site_title: Gold extends gains on sluggish US data, safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,195.60 an ounce, extending gains for a third session, due to weakness in the US dollar and mixed economic data. The US trade deficit jumped 43.1% to $51.4 billion in March, and services sector activity accelerated to a five-month high in April, fueling speculation that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates soon. Higher oil prices also boosted demand for safe-haven bullion, with Brent hitting a 2015 high. The next major catalyst is expected to be the nonfarm payrolls report on Friday.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest daily loss in 4 months; won down
summary: South Korean shares experienced their largest daily loss in nearly four months, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) falling 1.3% to 2,014.58 points. This decline was attributed to weakness in global shares and profit-taking, particularly in brokerage shares. The market had closed on Tuesday for the Children's Day holiday.

site_title: India not interested in high sales tax rate: finance minister
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley stated that the federal and state governments are not interested in imposing higher goods and services tax (GST) rates. A proposed GST rate of 27% was suggested by a government think-tank, but Jaitley emphasized that rates would not be increased to hurt people. The GST aims to harmonize state and central levies, boost manufacturing, and reduce corruption.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit by selloff in financials, CBA slumps
summary: Australian shares plummeted 2.3% to a three-month low, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,692.2. Commonwealth Bank shares slid 5.85%, their largest daily percentage drop in over six years, after reporting flat quarterly cash earnings due to higher regulatory costs. The decline was attributed to growth worries, with investors dumping bank stocks.

site_title: Eurozone business activity starts Q2 on solid footing
summary: Eurozone businesses started Q2 with healthy growth, driven by a buoyant order book and hiring. The Markit final composite Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 53.9 in April, above 50, indicating growth. However, firms cut prices again, with the composite output price index below 50 for three years. Quarterly growth is forecasted at 0.4%, matching first-quarter growth, despite the mixed signals. The European Central Bank may welcome these signs of recovery as it embarks on a trillion-euro bond buying stimulus program.

site_title: UOB to offer onshore loan in Myanmar to finance hotel project
summary: UOB will offer an onshore loan in Myanmar to finance the refurbishment of a former colonial building into a five-storey hotel. The loan, undisclosed in size, is for the Rangoon Excelsior Company, a French-Myanmar joint venture. This is the first onshore loan by a foreign bank operating in Yangon. UOB's Ian Wong sees the hospitality sector as a key industry for the bank, supporting Myanmar's tourism growth, which is expected to create new jobs over the next decade.

site_title: Oil market's bounce masks persistent risk in Malaysian debt
summary: Malaysia's economy experienced a boost in April, with oil prices rising and foreign reserves increasing, but underlying risks persist. The country's high foreign debt and low commodity prices pose threats to its stability. Fitch is expected to downgrade Malaysia's debt, and a large-scale exodus of foreign investors could destabilize the economy and hinder growth. The decline in foreign holders of Malaysian debt is comparable to the global financial crisis, according to Fitch. This raises concerns about the country's economic prospects and the potential for a broader market downturn.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: European stock markets were mixed at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dipping 0.03% due to concerns over Britain's general election. In contrast, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gained 0.44% and Paris's CAC 40 slipped 0.12%. The eurozone's mixed performance followed a decline on Tuesday due to fears of the European Central Bank's QE stimulus programme ending and tensions over the Greek crisis. Asian stocks also retreated after US indices slumped on concerns about oil prices and the Greek debt crisis.

site_title: Bollywood star Salman Khan guilty in hit-and-run case
summary: Indian judge convicts Bollywood star Salman Khan of culpable homicide for killing a homeless man in a 2002 hit-and-run incident in Mumbai. Khan, 49, was found guilty despite claiming his driver was responsible for the crash. He faces up to 10 years in prison and is expected to be taken into custody.

site_title: French businesses boost investment plans: INSEE
summary: French businesses plan to boost investment by 7% this year, more than double the initial 3% increase planned, according to a survey by the INSEE statistics office. This follows the government's announcement of bigger tax rebates on investments in April. Finance Minister Michel Sapin welcomed the news, calling it a long-term driver of the recovery. The boost in investment is seen as a positive sign for France's economy, which is expected to grow to 1.5% in 2016, potentially creating employment if supported by economic reforms.

site_title: BMW Q1 profits beat as SUV sales take off
summary: BMW's Q1 profits rose 20.6% to 2.52 billion euros, beating forecasts, driven by strong demand for luxury SUVs in Europe and the US. Brand sales increased 5.4% to 451,576 cars, with a 30% jump in X5 deliveries. The company's automotive EBIT margin remained at 9.5%, above its target range. This contrasts with rivals Mercedes-Benz (9.2% from 7%) and Audi (9.7% from 10.1%).

site_title: Oil prices hit fresh 2015 high on weaker dollar, Libya supply woes
summary: Oil prices rose to fresh 2015 highs on Wednesday, reaching $68.53 per barrel for Brent crude and $61.69 for US crude, driven by a weaker dollar and disruptions to Libyan crude exports. The rally, supported by bullish hedge funds, continues a month-long surge despite OPEC's potential production stability. Oil prices have jumped 20% for Brent and 25% for US crude in April, with analysts attributing the optimism to record-high oil reserves and reduced supply concerns.

site_title: China to allow central govt-owned firms to trade overseas derivatives without approvals: sources
summary: China has announced that central government-owned firms will be allowed to trade overseas derivatives without prior approval from the state assets regulator, a significant shift from years of strict controls. This move aims to encourage more Chinese companies to participate in global derivatives markets. The regulator will also support these companies in obtaining foreign exchange quotas needed to conduct such business. The change is seen as a step forward for China's financial liberalization efforts.

site_title: Shipping industry points to more Asian economic weakness
summary: Shipping industry experts warn of further economic weakness in Asia due to declining export orders and rates. Container ship rates have dropped 30% this year, nearing record lows, while bulk carrier rates are also near historic lows. Analysts attribute the decline to Asia's weak export performance, with China's factories experiencing their fastest drop in activity in a year in April. The Shanghai Containerized Freight Index and Baltic Dry Index have both declined, signaling a slowdown in global trade. Experts expect no turnaround soon, citing low export orders and a lack of momentum in key economies.

site_title: Australian banks' golden run over as growth plateaus
summary: Australia's major banks are facing a slowdown in earnings growth due to tougher capital requirements and a sluggish economy. Record profits and lush dividends are coming to an end, with banks expected to post low single-digit growth in 2015. Net interest margins will hit unprecedented lows, and bad debts are likely to rise. The banks are responding by slowing dividend growth, bolstering capital, and selling low-returning businesses. Despite this, some fund managers believe bank shares are undervalued and poised for a rebound.

site_title: Broker's Take: How much higher can The Stratech Group go?
summary: The Stratech Group's shares rose 9.68% to S$0.034, making them the second-most actively traded after Noble Group, with over 29 million shares changing hands. The company attributed the surge to new contract wins for its iFerret surveillance system, which includes installations at Hong Kong International Airport and Singapore Changi Airport. Analysts predict the iFerret's adoption could drive the stock value to 4-6.9 cents based on P/B valuation methodology, contingent on global adoption.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Indonesian central bank says will use mix of policies to revive growth
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Agus Martowardojo, announced plans to use a mix of economic policies to revive the country's sluggish growth, which slowed to its weakest since 2009 in the first quarter. The economy grew 4.71% in January-March, below expectations, due to a collapse in commodities and weak government spending. Martowardojo stated that the central bank will coordinate with the government and use policies on exchange rates, interest rates, and reserves to stimulate growth. The goal is to address the economic slowdown and promote growth.

site_title: China: Stocks rise after biggest rout in three months on insurers
summary: China's stocks rose, halting their biggest drop in three months, with financial and technology companies leading gains. The Shanghai Composite Index added 0.1% to 4,303.35, while the CSI 300 Index gained 0.8%. Despite concerns over high valuations and slowing liquidity, regulators suggested the market could enter a "slow bull" mode. The bull market, which began in December 2012, is now 883 days old and has rallied 112% over the past year.

site_title: Commodities advance to highest this year as oil to gold rally
summary: Commodities have surged to their highest point this year, driven by oil's gain above $60 a barrel and gold's rise as investors expect US inflation to pick up. The Bloomberg Commodity Index rose 0.4% to 105.1778, its highest since December 31. Oil prices have rebounded 9% since hitting a 12-year low in March, while gold has gained 1.6% in the past two sessions. Speculation of China's stimulus plan and a weakening US dollar are also contributing to the gains, with some analysts predicting the dollar will weaken dramatically in the next two quarters.

site_title: Broker's Take: Tigerair making progress but no turnaround yet
summary: Tiger Airways narrowed its fourth-quarter net loss by 80.3% to S$18.8 million, driven by 5% revenue growth and improved yields and load factor. However, the airline's restructuring efforts continued to incur one-off charges, resulting in a FY2015 net loss of 18.5% to S$264.2 million. Despite progress, OCBC Investment Research believes Tigerair's turnaround is still needed, expecting a slow recovery over the next two years. The firm maintains a SELL rating and slightly increases its fair value marginally to S$0.30.

site_title: Ringgit leads gains in Asian currencies as crude extends rally
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 1.1% to 3.5710 a dollar, leading gains in Asian currencies, as crude prices extended their rally. The 2.7% weekly gain in Brent crude eased concerns about the impact of falling oil revenue on the oil-exporting nation. Despite this, Fitch Ratings is more likely to cut Malaysia's rating due to a worsening trade surplus and concerns over debt repayment. Malaysian government bonds fell, pushing yields up to 3.86%. The ringgit remains Asia's second-worst performer over six months.

site_title: Growing demand for dual-qualified, bilingual Singapore lawyers: Hays
summary: Singapore-qualified lawyers with dual qualifications and bilingual skills are in high demand, according to recruitment experts Hays. Top sought-after qualifications include Singapore/US, Singapore/UK, and Singapore/Australia. Mandarin and Bahasa Indonesia are also in high demand, particularly in the Indonesian market. The rise of "new age" lawyers, who prioritize entrepreneurial roles and hands-on experience, is also on the rise. Employers are offering attractive packages, including relocation costs, to attract these candidates, particularly from the US.

site_title: Broker's Take: Osim downgraded from 'buy' to 'neutral'
summary: RHB Research downgraded Osim International from 'buy' to 'neutral' with a target price of S$2 due to the company's 53% year-on-year decline in first-quarter net profit to S$13.5 million. Consumer sentiment remains weak, leading to negative operating leverage, and the analyst expects a negative market reaction. RHB considers S$1.60 an excellent entry price.

images.alt_text: RHB Research on Wednesday downgraded its "buy" call on Osim International to "neutral" with a target price of S$2.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks slip 0.29% in early trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.29% in early trade on May 6, 2015, following US stocks that slumped due to worries about higher oil prices and the Greek debt crisis. In contrast, Chinese shares rose, with the Shanghai Composite Index increasing 0.87% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gaining 1.01%.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks slipped 0.29 per cent in early trade on Wednesday, tracking US stocks which slumped on worries about higher oil prices and worsening tensions over the Greek debt crisis.

site_title: New Zealand jobless rate steady, wages subdued
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate remains steady at 5.8% despite a 16,000 job growth in the first quarter, led by the technical, services, and construction sectors. The participation rate reached a record 69.6%. Subdued wage pressures suggest the central bank may consider cutting interest rates.

site_title: Kaisa default forensics yield clues in accounting footnotes
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings Ltd, a Chinese property developer, has been accused of misclassifying $2.36 billion in advance deposits as current liabilities, potentially making its debt situation appear stronger than it is. The deposits, which were made by third parties for property projects, may be interest-bearing debt, according to analysts. This could have delayed the restructuring of Kaisa's $10.5 billion debt and a potential takeover by rival Sunac China Holdings Ltd. The company's debt doubled in six months, sparking concerns about its financial health, with some analysts estimating its debt ratio could have been as high as 115.4% if the deposits were included as debt.

site_title: Broker's Take: Solid start to the year for Noble
summary: Noble Group has reported a "clean net income" of US$118 million in its first-quarter earnings, exceeding Macquarie's estimate of US$100 million. The earnings represent 24% of the research house's full-year estimate. Despite a 37% year-on-year decline, Noble's annualized return on equity has returned to 9% from 1% in Q4 2014. Macquarie maintains its price target of S$1.35, citing the potential for Noble to return to a premium-to-book value if its cash conversion improves.

site_title: Singapore: STI down 0.56% at market's opening
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 0.56% at market opening on May 6, 2015, due to US trade deficit widening in March. Trading volume was 67.9 million shares worth S$137.5 million.

site_title: Hot stock: Healthway Medical shares up 9.6% in early trade
summary: Healthway Medical Corp's shares rose 9.6% in early trade on Wednesday, following the release of its first-quarter net profit, which more than doubled to S$3.5 million, or 0.15 Singapore cent per share. The increase was driven by gains from selling financial assets, despite a modest 7.6% increase in revenue to S$23.7 million.

site_title: Hot stock: Osim International fell 13.7%
summary: Osim International's shares fell 13.7% to S$1.665 following the release of its first quarter earnings, which showed a 13% revenue decline to S$149.8 million and a 53% net profit drop to S$13.5 million.

site_title: Rabobank moves to new office at South Beach Tower (Amended)
summary: Rabobank has opened a new office in Singapore at the South Beach Tower, serving as a regional hub for Singapore, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam. The bank, which has grown from two employees 30 years ago to over 200, aims to support its expanding presence in the region. This new office marks a significant milestone in the bank's growth and expansion efforts.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wed
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Wednesday, down 6 points to 1821.42, with a trading volume of 106.3 million lots worth RM29.5 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 96 to 80.

site_title: China tests yuan gold fix process amid pricing ambitions: sources
summary: China conducted trial runs for a yuan-denominated gold fix, moving closer to launching a benchmark price, according to three sources. The Shanghai Gold Exchange (SGE) tested the process with major Chinese banks and a few foreign banks, with participation expected to be open to its international board members. The launch is seen as a challenge to the century-old London gold fix, which is under scrutiny due to alleged price-manipulation. China aims to create a price-setter for bullion, feeling its market weight should entitle it to do so.

site_title: Hot stock: Noble shares most active in morning trade
summary: Noble Group's shares were the most active on Singapore Exchange in morning trade, with 33.8 million shares changing hands. The counter fell 1.5 Singapore cents or 1.7% to S$0.875 after the company reported a 30% plunge in net profit to US$106.6 million for the first quarter, citing lower commodity prices and poor performance of operational associates. Revenue fell 7.33% to US$16.64 billion during the same period.

site_title: McDonald's joins companies irking bondholders for equity's sake
summary: McDonald's plans to return up to $9 billion to shareholders this year, which may increase its debt burden and reduce its credit rating. The move, which includes dividend increases and stock buybacks, has drawn criticism from bondholders and ratings companies. The company's credit rating was cut to A- from A by Standard & Poor's, and Moody's Investors Service put its A2 rating on review for a potential cut.
