This trend of companies prioritizing shareholder rewards over debt repayment has raised concerns about credit quality and the impact on bondholders.

site_title: Greece's 500 richest families may face special levy
summary: Greece's 500 richest families may face a special levy to help unlock bailout aid. The Greek government has submitted a list of reforms, including increasing taxes on high-income earners and luxury items, and introducing a tax on luxury trips. The proposed reforms aim to improve honesty in tax matters by limiting bank debit card usage for large transactions. The move is part of Greece's efforts to secure aid from the EU and IMF amid a looming financial crisis.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Devastation a 'wake-up call' for vulnerable region
summary: A devastating earthquake struck Nepal on April 25, killing thousands and leaving many homeless. Experts warn that neighboring countries, including Bangladesh and India, are vulnerable to similar disasters due to shoddy construction, rapid urbanization, and corruption. The region is prone to quakes due to its location on a seismic faultline, and previous disasters in the area have resulted in tens of thousands of deaths. Experts urge governments to learn from past mistakes and invest in disaster preparedness and infrastructure to prevent further devastation.

images.alt_text: Nepal's earthquake should act as a wake-up call to neighbouring countries which have failed to learn lessons from their own disasters and where shoddy construction and rapid urbanisation could lead to death on an even greater scale next time round, experts say.

site_title: Asia: Shares lose steam as Wall Street sags
summary: Asian stocks declined, mirroring Wall Street's drop, amid concerns over surging oil prices and the Greek debt crisis. Markets, including Sydney, Seoul, and Hong Kong, retreated, while Chinese shares rose 0.87% to recover from a previous session's decline. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.79% due to rising oil prices and a widening trade deficit. Analysts cited a market "semi-bubble" and investors' growing skepticism about growth, with some predicting a potential interest rate hike delay.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall on global bonds selloff
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.38% on Wednesday, mirroring global bourses, amid a selloff in sovereign bonds. The main TAIEX index dropped 37.71 points to 9,785.73, with most subindexes falling. Transport stocks, led by China Airlines, dropped 2.67%, while rubber and glass/ceramics indices fell 0.93% and 2.33%, respectively. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$30.678 to the US dollar. The global selloff in bonds and commodities suggests a potential turn towards inflation, following longstanding concerns about deflation.

site_title: AVJennings says on track to hit A$40m profit before tax for FY2015
summary: AVJennings, an Australian residential-property development company, expects to deliver a profit before tax of A$40 million or higher for FY2015, driven by strong market conditions and increased production levels. Despite adverse weather affecting settlements in early FY2016, the company attributes its strong performance to its strategy to boost production and favorable market conditions. This marks a significant increase from FY2014's profit before tax of A$27 million.

site_title: Australians still shopping, but need to spend more
summary: Australian retail sales grew 0.3% in March, meeting a 10-month streak, but fell short of forecasts, with annual growth at 4.5% still below the long-term average. Demand for household goods lifted spending, with sales up 9.5% for the year, but the Reserve Bank of Australia cited the need for sustained consumer spending to offset weak export prices and a mining downturn. Interest rates remain at a record low of 2.0%.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble, Q&M, OCBC
summary: Noble Group's net profit for the first quarter of 2015 fell 30% to US$106.6 million due to lower commodity prices and poor performance from its operational associates. Revenues declined 7.33% to US$16.64 billion.

site_title: Microsoft is said to evaluate possible bid for Salesforce
summary: Microsoft is evaluating a potential bid for Salesforce, a cloud software provider with a market value of nearly $50 billion. The company is working with investment banks to consider a sale, which could include rebuffing any buyer or working out a deal. Microsoft has long anticipated competing for Salesforce if it were for sale, and the move comes after another company was in talks with Salesforce in April. Salesforce offers a leading position in customer relationship management and cloud computing, which could be a major draw for a buyer.

site_title: China April HSBC services PMI hits 2015 high, stock rally boosts business for some
summary: China's services sector grew at its fastest pace this year in April, with the HSBC/Markit China Services Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) reaching a four-month high of 52.9. However, final prices of services hit a 15-month low due to firms cutting prices to lift sales. The rally in the stock market boosted consumer confidence and spending, but the economy still faces strong headwinds, with GDP growth set to slow.

site_title: CapitaLand changes names of three trusts and their managers
summary: CapitaLand Limited, a Singapore-listed real estate company, has changed the names of its three trusts and their managers, effective Wednesday. The changes include renaming CapitaCommercial Trust to CapitaLand Commercial Trust, CapitaMall Trust to CapitaLand Mall Trust, and CapitaRetail China Trust to CapitaLand Retail China Trust. The managers of the trusts have also undergone name changes. The Singapore Exchange has notified the new security names, which will take effect on Friday before trading starts.

site_title: US penalises developer of virtual currency XRP
summary: The US Justice Department fined San Francisco-based Ripple Labs $700,000 for running a market for XRP, the world's second-largest virtual currency, outside of US financial regulations. Ripple agreed to pay the penalty and bring its XRP exchange within existing regulations for money exchanges. The company failed to follow rules governing money services businesses and establish an anti-money laundering program, according to the Justice Department. The agreement resolves a criminal investigation into Ripple's subsidiary XRP II LLC.

site_title: Global real estate investors plan to increase acquisitions in 2015: CBRE survey
summary: Global real estate investors plan to increase acquisitions in 2015, with 53% of respondents aiming to boost purchases this year. Investor appetite for cross-regional acquisitions rose to 38%, with Western Europe and Asia being top destinations. London remains the top city for investment, while second-tier cities like Madrid and Seattle gained interest. Investors are shifting towards value-add and opportunistic investments, with office and industrial assets being the preferred asset classes. Asset pricing is the top obstacle to acquiring real estate assets, with tight availability and competition also being significant challenges.

images.alt_text: More than half of the global real estate investors surveyed are planning to increase their acquisitions in 2015, says commercial real estate services and investment firm CBRE.

site_title: OCBC seeks to energise unprofitable China consumer banking unit
summary: OCBC Bank, Southeast Asia's second-largest lender, plans to remodel its unprofitable consumer-banking unit in China and focus on corporate banking to boost profits. The bank aims to add new customer segments and products, training staff over the next six to nine months. OCBC's China unit saw a 231% surge in net income last year, driven by corporate loans and fees, while the consumer-banking segment posted an operating loss. The bank plans to expand its branch network and services to Chinese companies expanding outside of the mainland.

site_title: Groupon's full-year revenue forecast below views, hit by dollar
summary: Groupon Inc. forecasted full-year revenue below analyst expectations, hurt by a stronger dollar and weaker-than-expected billings. The company aims to double deals in the next year and sustain low to mid double-digit growth in its North America local business. Revenue rose to $750.4 million in the first quarter, beating analyst estimates, but the company's stock fell 2% to $6.70. Groupon's CEO, Eric Lefkofsky, said the company will evaluate alternatives to unlock shareholder value in countries where it questions its long-term strategic positioning.

site_title: US seen joining world's biggest oil exporters if ban is lifted
summary: The US is poised to become one of the world's largest oil exporters if the federal ban on most crude exports is lifted, according to a government-sponsored study. If domestic production continues to surge, the US could send as much as 2.4 million barrels a day overseas in 2025, making it the fourth-largest oil exporter. The study assumes a 7.2 million barrel daily increase in domestic output, and its findings support lifting the ban, which has been in place for four decades.

site_title: Labour and Conservatives tied again ahead of UK election
summary: The UK parliamentary election is expected to be the tightest in decades, with Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives and the opposition Labour Party tied at 34% according to a YouGov opinion poll. Neither party is likely to win an overall majority, with opinion polls consistently showing a three-point margin of error. The election is set to take place on Thursday, with the two main parties having been neck and neck since the start of the year.

site_title: Never mind oil, Iran's about to shake the world pistachio market
summary: Iran is poised to re-enter the global pistachio market, potentially disrupting prices and benefiting US pistachio farmers who have seen a surge in production over the past decade. The country is expected to flood the market with fresh supplies, despite contamination concerns and Western sanctions limiting sales to the US and Europe. The move could lead to lower prices, but California pistachio farmers are unconcerned, citing the industry's profitability and the challenges Iran faces in selling into Western markets.

site_title: Uber ceases Kansas operations in face of stricter oversight
summary: Uber ceased operations in Kansas after the state legislature overrode Governor Sam Brownback's veto of a bill imposing stricter regulations on ride-hailing services. Uber claims it already conducts its own background checks and provides commercial auto insurance. site_title: Blackstone said to sell US apartments for about US$650 million

site_title: Asean corporate governance: Yoma ranked 18th among Singapore companies
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings, a Singapore-based company, has been ranked 18th among the 100 largest Singapore-listed companies in the Asean Corporate Governance Scorecard 2014. site_title: Sky? Skype? EU court backs Murdoch over Microsoft in name battle
summary: The European Union's General Court has ruled in favor of Rupert Murdoch's Sky, dismissing a trademark complaint filed by Microsoft over the similarity between the names "Sky" and "Skype". site_title: US Republicans pass US$3.8t 2016 budget
summary: US Republicans passed a $3.871 trillion 2016 budget, balancing federal spending and slashing $5 trillion in social programs over the next decade. The budget, which passed the Senate 51-48 and House of Representatives, eliminates the public deficit by 2024 without raising taxes and increases Pentagon spending. It sets up a fast-track vote on repealing the Affordable Care Act and trims public health care programs for the poor and elderly.

site_title: Leaders prepare final push in tight UK election
summary: Britain's general election is expected to result in a hung parliament, with the Conservative and Labour parties unlikely to win a clear majority. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Ed Miliband are gearing up for negotiations with smaller parties, including the Scottish National Party, to form a minority government. The outcome will determine the fate of the UK's welfare system, economy, and foreign policy, with potential implications for Brexit and the European Union.

site_title: Van Gogh Lovers' Lane scene sells for US$66.3 million at Sotheby's
summary: Vincent Van Gogh's "L'Allee Des Alyscamps" sold for US$66.3 million at Sotheby's in New York to a private collector from Asia, shattering the auction record of US$82.5 million set in 2000. The 1888 painting, depicting a tree-lined lovers' lane in Arles, had at least three bidders chasing it. The sale marks the highest recent price achieved at Sotheby's, surpassing the US$61.8 million paid for an 1890 still life in November.

site_title: Google sees automated flight going 'all the way' to airliners
summary: Google's Project Wing aims to extend automated flight technology from drones to commercial air travel, making it safer without human pilots. According to Dave Vos, the program's lead, automation can remove tedious work from aircraft design, leading to a safer future. This move could potentially revolutionize the aviation industry, similar to how automation has transformed factories.

site_title: Malaysian ruling coalition wins by-election by lower margin
summary: Malaysia's ruling coalition, Barisan Nasional, won a parliamentary by-election in the eastern state of Pahang by a reduced margin of 61% of the vote. The coalition held the seat, considered a stronghold, after the death of its previous holder. The victory is seen as a test of support for embattled Prime Minister Najib Razak, whose reputation has been tarnished by reports of his family's wealth and alleged fraudulent financial transactions. A second by-election in Penang is scheduled for Thursday, where opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's wife is among the candidates.

site_title: Western Union in talks to buy smaller rival MoneyGram
summary: Western Union Co is in early-stage talks to acquire MoneyGram International Inc, a smaller rival, in a deal potentially worth billions. MoneyGram's shares rose 32% after the news, while Western Union has a market value of about $11 billion. However, regulators may block the deal on antitrust grounds, and talks could still fall apart. A MoneyGram spokeswoman declined to comment on rumors, while Western Union was unresponsive.

site_title: Tea to tech: China's cybersecurity push sparks a 'gold rush'
summary: China's cybersecurity push has sparked a "gold rush" in the tech industry, as state-affiliated software firms and investors rush to capitalize on the country's $450 billion-a-year enterprise computing market. Unlikely entrepreneurs, like Zhang Long, who has no technology background, are pitching their own Linux-based operating systems, such as SPGnux, to replace Microsoft's Windows. The government's backing of the sector has made Chinese start-ups more attractive to international venture capitalists, but experts warn it will take years for local technology to mature and gain widespread adoption.

site_title: Oil analysts practice cautious capitulation as crude surprises
summary: Oil prices have surged above $68, a six-year high, as analysts initially predicted a decline in crude prices. Despite this, many banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, and Goldman Sachs, have revised their forecasts to reflect accelerating demand and slowing supply growth. Analysts predict Brent crude will average around $58-$62 in 2015, with some forecasting a "double-dip" to $50 in the third quarter. The rebound is attributed to tightening balances, particularly in the US, where supply is no longer greater than demand.

site_title: How serious is Delhi about acquiring land for industry?
summary: A suicide by an Indian farmer at an opposition rally protesting the government's ordinance to change the Land Acquisition Act 2013 has put the Narendra Modi-led government in a tight spot. The opposition claims the ordinance is a prelude to a massive land grab by people close to Mr. Modi, and the government's case is weakened by its lack of transparency and specificity.

site_title: Japan pushes big companies to pass yen benefits on to suppliers
summary: Japan's government plans to push large exporters to pass on benefits from the weaker yen to suppliers hurt by higher costs for imported raw materials. Deputy Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura stated that while the weak yen has boosted the Japanese economy, there are negative effects, including higher costs for suppliers. The government aims to secure an agreement with the Keidanren business lobby to pass on benefits to suppliers by increasing prices.

site_title: How 3-D printing is saving the Italian artisan
summary: In northeastern Italy, 3D printing is helping small-scale manufacturers compete with global competitors. After the region's industrial sector was severely impacted by China's rise, innovators like Ignazio Pomini and Selvaggia Armani teamed up to create unique, custom-made products. This collaboration led to the creation of a thriving innovation hub, with growth in exports and research and development. The use of 3D printing and other technologies is expected to boost revenue by 15% for Italy's small-scale manufacturers, offering a new path forward for the region's economy.

site_title: Vietnam banks say 'I do' as government forces arranged marriages
summary: Vietnam's banking sector is undergoing significant consolidation as the government enforces stricter rules on cross-ownership. The move is aimed at addressing the country's overbanking issue and improving financial stability. Investors are seeing a rebound in confidence, with shares of larger banks rising 28-42% this year. The government has also taken steps to absorb weak lenders and force bankruptcies, with a state-backed asset company buying troubled loans and non-performing loans dropping to 3.25%.

site_title: 26m Americans lack credit history, US consumer watchdog says
summary: A US survey reveals 26 million Americans lack a credit history, and 8% are considered "unscorable" by major credit reporting agencies. Blacks, Hispanics, and low-income residents are disproportionately affected. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau attributes this to limited access to credit reporting agencies, potentially limiting financial opportunities for economically vulnerable consumers. The CFPB plans to use the data to devise initiatives addressing the issue, while those without a credit history may rely on alternative lenders like pawnshops and payday lenders.

site_title: Brazil regulator says former Petrobras board misled investors
summary: Brazil's securities regulator, CVM, accused the former board of state-run oil producer Petrobras of misleading investors by setting a fuel pricing policy that failed to meet debt targets, resulting in significant losses and financial strain. summary: The US dollar dropped against the euro after US trade data showed a sharp rise in the trade deficit, reaching $51.4 billion in March, the largest gap since 2008. The large deficit raises questions about the timing of the Federal Reserve's plan to raise interest rates.

Analysts attributed the rise to Libya's protests and concerns over Middle East stability, but noted that price rallies are often driven by market sentiment rather than genuine risk of market tightness. site_title: Germanwings co-pilot practiced descent on outbound flight before crash
summary: Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crashed a plane in the French Alps in March, killing all 150 people on board. Torn-up sick notes and internet research on suicide were found in his home, and a computer showed he researched ways of committing suicide in the days leading up to the crash. An interim report by France's BEA crash investigation agency will confirm the findings, citing a "controlled descent with no aeronautical justification".

summary: Brazil is considering easing its ban on land acquisition by foreigners to boost investment in agriculture and forestry, as the country's economy contracts due to a commodity slump. Agriculture Minister Katia Abreu says the restriction limits investment and needs to be revisited. Authorities are softening their stance on resource nationalism amid a corruption scandal and credit tightening, which may lead to a 1.2% contraction this year. Lawmakers are pushing to change legislation restricting foreign investment in land and oil, with some states and ruralist congressmen opposing the ban on international firms buying land.

site_title: Running, fashion power strong Adidas sales in Q1
summary: Adidas reported strong first-quarter sales growth of 17% to 4.083 billion euros, exceeding analyst forecasts. The company's running and fashion businesses performed well, with double-digit sales growth, while its North America arm recovered from a 4% decline in 2014. Adidas attributed the growth to increased marketing efforts and expects a medium single-digit percentage increase in sales and a 7-10% rise in net profit from continuing operations in 2015.

site_title: India to sign port deal with Iran, ignoring US warning against haste
summary: India is set to sign a port deal with Iran this week, despite US warnings against haste. The deal, worth billions, aims to develop the Chabahar port in Iran, which would cut transport costs and freight time to Central Asia and the Gulf by a third. India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is keen to develop trade ties with Central Asia and is prepared to ignore US pressure. The deal is seen as a strategic move to circumvent Pakistan and open up a route to landlocked Afghanistan, where India has developed close security ties and economic interests.

site_title: Property data
summary: A low-profile property trust is betting on data centres, with its asking rents for office and industrial space, and sales caveats, being showcased. The trust's data centre gambit is seen as a move to diversify its portfolio and attract investors. This development comes as Chinese property shares surge on unverified reports of a meeting to revive the sector. The meeting is seen as a potential solution to China's economic woes amid trade tensions with the US. The move may also influence other countries in the region, including Malaysia, which has expressed concerns about the impact of US tariffs on the economy.

site_title: Telling stories
summary: Paperplane, a Singapore story studio, creates original playbooks and learning games, differing from typical tech startups. This article is not directly related to the provided news articles, but is instead a snippet from Thevar 2.0, a magazine published by SME Magazine in May/June 2015.

site_title: UK poll campaign enters last leg with no clear winner
summary: The UK is heading into its final 48 hours of campaigning ahead of the general election on Thursday, with polls showing the Conservative and Labour parties neck-and-neck. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Ed Miliband are urging voters to back their parties, warning of "instability" and a clash of two visions. The outcome is uncertain, with smaller parties such as the SNP and Liberal Democrats potentially holding the key to forming a government.

site_title: Singapore, Malaysia to build on deep ties
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are strengthening their bilateral ties, celebrating 50 years of diplomatic relations. The two leaders emphasized the importance of economic cooperation, with Singapore being Malaysia's second-largest trading partner globally. They also discussed cooperation on water, including the Johor River Barrage project, and the Trans-Pacific Partnership. The leaders acknowledged areas for improvement, including enhancing economic links through Asean and promoting investments.

site_title: Prices weaken in low volume
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) declined 11.51 points to 3,471.19, its lowest close in at least three months, amidst low liquidity and a large sell-off in Hong Kong. The decline was attributed to caution ahead of US jobs data release on Friday. Penny stocks made a modest comeback, with the average unit traded value at S$0.60. Shares of Keppel Corp slipped S$0.01 to S$8.79, while SMRT ended S$0.005 higher at S$1.65. Credit Suisse downgraded SMRT to "underperform", while OCBC Investment Research maintained a "buy" call due to "compelling longer-term catalysts".

site_title: Trade deficit explodes to 6-year high
summary: The US trade deficit widened to a 6-year high in March, reaching $51.4 billion, driven by a record surge in imports and a decline in exports. Imports rose 7.7% to $239.2 billion, fueled by a backlog at West Coast ports, while exports increased 0.9% to $187.8 billion. The widening trade gap likely contributed to the US economy's contraction in the first quarter, with a 0.2% annualized growth rate. A stronger dollar and rising wages may also be contributing to increased demand for foreign goods.

site_title: Indian retail chains merge to cut costs, raise capital
summary: Indian retail chains Future Retail and Bharti Retail are merging to cut costs and raise capital. The two companies will form two new entities, with Future Retail handling store operations and Future Enterprises owning infrastructure and investment assets. The merger aims to capitalize on the growing Indian grocery market, despite challenges faced by the industry. The combined entity plans to open 500 small stores in Mumbai and Delhi, and Bharti will hold a 15% stake in each of the two entities.

site_title: Turnaround bid slashes Tiger Airways' Q4 loss
summary: Tiger Airways has reported a Q4 FY2015 net loss of S$18.82 million, raising its full-year net loss to S$264.23 million. The budget carrier's turnaround efforts, including exiting loss-making operations and rationalizing its fleet, have led to a 5% increase in Q4 revenue to S$172.21 million. The company has also hedged 40% of its fuel requirements and is studying opportunities to collaborate with Scoot and other SIA Group airlines. Despite a 7.2% decline in shares, analysts remain optimistic, citing a "revitalised balanced sheet" and recovery in earnings and cash flow.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Pimco Total Return loses title as world's biggest bond mutual fund
summary: The Pimco Total Return Fund, once the world's largest bond mutual fund, has lost its title following two years of withdrawals. Investors pulled $5.6 billion from the fund in April, reducing its assets to $110.4 billion. Vanguard's Total Bond Market Index Fund now leads with $117.3 billion, according to Vanguard. The loss marks the fund's 24th consecutive month of net outflows, despite improving performance. The withdrawals have totaled $130 billion since Bill Gross's departure last September.

site_title: Space station's new drink: Out-of-this-world coffee
summary: Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti became the first person to drink an authentic serving of espresso in space on Sunday, using a special machine designed by Argotec and Lavazza. The experience was part of a scientific study on fluid physics in microgravity conditions. Cristoforetti posted on social media that she enjoyed her first espresso in over five months, and the machine was designed to emit a small waft of freshly brewed coffee when the straw was inserted. The experiment aimed to understand how fluids react under high pressure in space.

site_title: China says its exports hurt by foreign currency devaluations
summary: China's exports are being hurt by foreign currency devaluations, with the yuan's effective exchange rate rising 6.4% in 2014 and 4.2% in the first three months of this year. The Commerce Ministry attributed the devaluation to some countries using their exchange rates to boost exports and stimulate their economies. This has led to a sharp appreciation in the yuan, affecting the international competitiveness of China's export products. China has vowed to keep the yuan at a "basically stable" level.

site_title: Tesla's giant new battery plant set to shake up energy industry
summary: Tesla is set to revolutionize the energy industry with its new battery plant, which will enable large-scale energy storage and separation of generation and use. The company's gigafactory, expected to produce 50 GWh of annual battery capacity, will significantly reduce production costs, benefiting not only Tesla but also other firms in the industry. Economies of scale will lead to lower costs for battery inputs, driving demand from consumers and businesses. The company's battery technology has the potential to be astronomically profitable, with estimated annual revenue of $20 billion from battery output.

site_title: MGM Resorts hits the jackpot with mega-fight
summary: MGM Resorts International reported a significant revenue boost from the Mayweather-Pacquiao boxing match, with hotel room sales increasing 30% and companywide room sales rising 1% for the second quarter. The event drove record-breaking bets, with ticket sales reaching $70 million and closed-circuit TV sales generating $9 million. The company's Las Vegas Strip properties saw a 30% rise in hotel revenue, but its overall revenue fell 11% to $2.33 billion, missing analyst estimates.

site_title: Buffett sees end to bond market rally
summary: Warren Buffett and Bill Gross signal the end of the bond market rally, citing overvaluation of long-term bonds. The 30-year bond yield rose to a four-month high, and German 10-year yields hit the highest level since January. Both investors believe the bull market "supercycle" for bonds and stocks is ending, with Buffett predicting the value of long-term bonds to fall. The US payrolls report on May 8 is forecast to show a smaller-than-expected job increase, and economists predict the US central bank will wait until at least September before raising rates.

site_title: More buys than sells by funds, but just barely
summary: Global mutual funds slightly favored buying over selling in the three months to April 30, with S$1.37 billion in net buys versus S$1.34 billion in net sells. Finance stocks excluding Reits saw net sells worth S$485.3 million, outnumbering buys worth S$396.6 million.

site_title: On the road to asset recovery
summary: Asset recovery experts emphasize the need for a strategic approach to cross-border asset tracing to maximize returns with minimal disruption. This involves understanding the nuances of asset recovery in different jurisdictions and being aware of local regulations. Effective asset recovery can significantly benefit businesses and individuals involved in international transactions.

site_title: New York party of the year kowtows to China
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art Ball in New York has chosen China as its theme for 2015, showcasing the country's influence on Western fashion. The event, attended by A-list celebrities and fashion designers, aims to promote Chinese culture and highlights the growing luxury market for designer clothes in China. Actress Li Bingbing, a Chinese celebrity, expressed excitement about the theme, stating that Western attitudes towards China are changing and that people are increasingly curious about Chinese culture. The ball is part of the exhibition "China: Through the Looking Glass," which explores Chinese influences on Western fashion.

site_title: Yellen's name on list given to investigators probing Fed leaks
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen confirmed her name is on a list given to the House Financial Services Committee investigating potential leaks of information by central bank officials. Yellen denied any involvement in the leaks, stating she conveyed no confidential information. The investigation, which is part of the Fed's ongoing transparency efforts, is also being conducted by the Fed's inspector general and the Justice Department.

site_title: New recommendations on US air traffic control process
summary: US safety experts say five aircraft landed at the wrong airports between 2012 and 2014 due to preventable air traffic control errors. No injuries were reported, but the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) recommended changes to US air traffic control procedures to avoid similar incidents in the future. The errors involved aircraft landing on shorter-than-expected runways, sometimes at night.

site_title: Q&M plans to list China, Malaysia dental businesses
summary: Q&M Dental Group plans to list its China and Malaysia dental businesses, Q&M Dental Holdings (China) and Q&M Dental Group (Malaysia), on a reputable stock exchange. The move aims to "better reflect" the value of the business and provide an additional source of funding. This is part of the company's broader strategy to list its China manufacturing business, Q&M Aidite International. The listings are expected to provide Q&M with additional funding options, allowing the company to expand its dental healthcare services.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary: A listing of newly registered companies in Singapore shows 14 companies with issued capital between S$200,000 and S$5 million. The SME Magazine provides a list of these companies, but no further details are given.

site_title: US airlines rattled by Qatar Airways' new US routes
summary: Qatar Airways has announced its first direct flights to Los Angeles, Boston, and Atlanta, sparking concerns among US airlines that the Gulf carrier's expansion is unfair due to alleged state subsidies. US airlines, including Delta, United, and American, have accused Qatar Airways of driving down ticket prices and pushing competitors out of key markets. The move comes as the Obama administration reviews comments on subsidy claims, with Emirates also adding new flights to Orlando, Boston, and Seattle. The expansion is seen as a competitive threat to US airlines.

site_title: Big names, money vie for Indian tech startups
summary: Indian tech startups are experiencing high valuations due to intense interest from prominent investors, including venture capital firms and business executives, in the rapidly growing e-commerce market. Despite no e-commerce player being profitable yet, companies are securing market share, driving up valuations. This competition is driven by the growing number of aspiring middle-class consumers in India.

site_title: China's Meitu sets up regional HQ in S'pore
summary: Meitu, a Chinese smartphone maker, has set up a regional headquarters in Singapore, Meitu Mobile, to serve as the sales, strategic planning, and R&D hub for its smartphones. The company aims to tap into the growing Southeast Asian market, particularly in Singapore, where it plans to retail its smartphones designed for devoted selfie-takers. Meitu is also looking to partner Singapore startups to create technologies for its smartphones and apps, such as photo-editing app Meitu XiuXiu. The company's chairman, Cai Wensheng, advises Singapore entrepreneurs to be more "disruptive" and look to the Southeast Asian market from the start.

site_title: Indonesian GDP down 0.18% in Q1, missing estimates
summary: Indonesia's economy unexpectedly shrank 0.18% in Q1, missing estimates, as exports slumped. The country's GDP growth rate was 4.71% from a year earlier, below most forecasts. President Joko Widodo's efforts to boost investment and achieve 7% expansion by 2017 are being complicated by a slowdown in key commodity exports and softening consumer spending. The government plans to accelerate infrastructure spending to combat the slowdown and meet its goal of spending 290 trillion rupiah on infrastructure this year.

site_title: Noble tells more but critics left unconvinced
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, has made certain disclosures in its first-quarter results, including net fair value gains and losses by segment and region, and adopted new earnings disclosure methods. However, critics remain unconvinced about the group's overall transparency, despite the move towards greater disclosure. The disclosures include splitting its business into separate reporting segments, including energy coal and oil liquids, and power and gas. The move comes amid criticisms of Noble's accounting practices.

site_title: Will Europe retreat on the Internet front?
summary: European policymakers face a decisive choice on the Internet front, with the European Commission set to announce its new digital strategy on May 6. The continent's leaders must decide between a forward-looking, market-driven approach or a defensive, backward-looking retreat. To close the digital gap with the US and Asia, Europe should remove barriers, update regulation, and encourage more use of the Internet. However, ominous signs point to a retreat, with France and Germany pushing for regulatory rollbacks and net neutrality. If Europe continues on this path, it risks missing out on the potential of the online economy and harming small businesses and innovators.

site_title: Centropod project's completion boosts Roxy's Q1 profit
summary: Roxy-Pacific's Q1 net earnings tripled to S$46.45 million following the completion of the Centropod@Changi project, which received its Temporary Occupation Permit in January. The fully-sold office and retail project generated revenue and profit in the first quarter. This marks a significant boost to the company's earnings.

site_title: RBA cuts interest rates for second time this year
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut interest rates for the second time this year, lowering the cash rate to a fresh all-time trough of 2.0% to bolster the economy against sliding mining investment and a rising local dollar. The move was seen as a positive statement, with RBA governor Glenn Stevens indicating that recent economic trends were encouraging and that the easing cycle might be nearing its end. The local dollar initially dropped but then rallied, and investors are now speculating that the cash rate may not go below 2%.

site_title: VW board will take "some time" to find Piech successor: Huber
summary: Volkswagen's supervisory board will take time to find a successor to Ferdinand Piech, who quit as chairman after a public dispute with CEO Martin Winterkorn. Interim chairman Berthold Huber stated the board will address the succession with "diligence and calm," which will "take some time." Meanwhile, Winterkorn stated the company is "well-positioned" with its 12 brands and has no current M&A projects.

site_title: Minimum trading price seen working against share issuers, investors
summary: Singapore Exchange's new minimum trading price (MTP) rule may prove detrimental to both issuers and investors, with firms facing distraction and costly compliance, and retail investors potentially left with odd lots or cancelled share fractions. The rule could also hinder share consolidation efforts, as firms are uncertain about its effectiveness. Analysts warn that meeting the MTP requirement could be distracting and costly for firms, while retail investors may not receive payment for cancelled share fractions. This could lead to a negative impact on the market.

site_title: HSBC Q1 earnings top analyst estimates as provisions fall
summary: HSBC reported a 4.4% increase in first-quarter profit, beating analyst estimates, as provisions for bad loans fell 29%. The bank's investment arm saw strong revenue growth, while operating expenses rose 6%. HSBC's CEO, Stuart Gulliver, attributed the recovery to a "strong start to the year" and lower loan impairment charges. The bank's shares fell 1.7% despite a 4.4% year-to-date increase, as investors await the bank's June 9 strategy update.

site_title: Choice of Jurong East for rail terminal sparks immediate buzz
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has identified Jurong East as the likely location for the country's high-speed rail terminal with Malaysia, sparking excitement among consultants and economists. A 1.02 million square-foot reserve site near Jurong East MRT station is seen as the ideal spot, offering proximity to a commercial hub and transport node. The location is expected to boost the economy, with increased commercial and retail activity, and higher property values. Consultants predict a "multiplier effect" on the area, with more companies setting up office and higher residential rental demand.

site_title: Lufthansa narrows operating loss in Q1
summary: Lufthansa reported a narrower first-quarter operating loss, despite a 2.8% increase in unit costs, due to cheaper fuel. The airline confirmed its target for 2015 adjusted earnings before interest and tax of over 1.5 billion euros. However, it needs to take further action to lower costs, particularly due to rising pension burdens and staff-related expenses. The airline's pilot dispute remains unresolved, with a new mediation proposal recently made. Lufthansa's parent company, Deutsche Lufthansa, reported a first-quarter adjusted loss of 167 million euros, slightly better than forecast.

site_title: Noble Q1 profit down 30%
summary: Noble Group's net profit for the first quarter ended March 31 dropped 30% to US$106.6 million due to lower commodity prices and underperformance of two major operational associates, Yancoal and Noble Agri. Revenue fell 7% year-on-year to US$16.64 billion, with net profit margin decreasing to 0.64%. The company attributed the decline to lower commodity prices and significant headwinds in traditional China-related commodities, while investments in its oil, power & gas, and metals franchise drove growth in its bottom line.

site_title: US trade deficit largest since 2008 as imports surge
summary: The US trade deficit surged to its highest level in nearly 6-1/2 years in March, jumping 43.1% to $51.4 billion, as imports rebounded strongly after a labor dispute at West Coast ports. This surge in imports, combined with a 0.9% increase in exports, suggests the US economy contracted in the first quarter. The revised February deficit also increased, and the wider inflation-adjusted deficit of $67.2 billion is the largest in eight years.

site_title: EU raises growth outlook; GDP forecast to rise 1.5%
summary: The European Commission has raised its euro-area growth forecast to 1.5% for 2015, up from 1.3% in February, citing the impact of a weaker euro and unprecedented monetary stimulus. The forecast also indicates that Greece will grow 0.5% in 2015, down from 2.5% previously, and France's growth forecast has been downgraded to 1.1% for 2015. The commission notes that while the economy is slowly recovering, there are still concerns about inflation, unemployment, and the impact of the Greek crisis.

site_title: US: Stocks dip as trade deficit swells
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 8.07 points (0.04%) at 18,062.33. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.45% and 0.26%, respectively, amid a 40% surge in the US trade deficit to a six-year high of $51.4 billion in March. The strong dollar and surge in imports after a West Coast port strike contributed to the increase. Analysts expect the weak trade data to lower the estimate for first-quarter gross domestic product, possibly into negative territory.

site_title: FAA under pressure as US firms persist with drone trials
summary: US companies, including American International Group and Chevron, are conducting drone flight trials despite proposed FAA regulations that restrict commercial drone use. The trials aim to speed up the process and win concessions on proposed restrictions. Amazon.com has criticized the FAA for impeding the rapid deployment of drone technology, which could reshape industries like industrial inspections and farmland management. The FAA is assessing 4,500 public comments before finalizing regulations, which may take over a year.

site_title: Vietnam, South Korea seal FTA
summary: Vietnam and South Korea signed a free trade agreement (FTA) on May 5, 2015, aiming to boost exports and double bilateral trade to $70 billion by 2020. The pact covers goods, services, customs, and trade protection, with expected increases in Vietnam's agricultural exports and South Korean materials imported for Vietnamese electronics factories. The agreement follows a two-year negotiation process and is part of Vietnam's efforts to become a regional manufacturing dynamo and lure investment.

site_title: Vanity Fair reveals Star Wars baddie
summary: Vanity Fair has unveiled the first photo of Adam Driver as Kylo Ren, the new villain from the upcoming Star Wars film "The Force Awakens." The character, set to be released in December, was previously only featured in a teaser trailer with his face hidden. The photos also include Oscar-winning actress Lupita Nyong'o as the CGI character Maz Kanata. This marks the return of the Star Wars franchise, which has attracted generations of fans since its release nearly 40 years ago, following a hiatus after the prequel trilogy concluded in 2005.

site_title: GIC said to seek up to US$980m stake in Brazil's Rede D'Or
summary: GIC Pte, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, is in talks to acquire a stake worth up to 3 billion reais (S$1.3 billion) in Brazilian medical-care provider Rede D'Or Sao Luiz SA. GIC may acquire up to 14% of the hospital operator, equal shares from the company's founding Moll family and Grupo BTG Pactual. This deal could be announced within a month, following Carlyle Group LP's purchase of 8.3% of Rede D'Or for 1.75 billion reais. The move is part of a growing trend of foreign investment in Brazil's healthcare sector.

site_title: Warren Buffett to auction another charity lunch
summary: Warren Buffett to auction a charity lunch benefiting Glide, a San Francisco charity that provides food and services to the poor and homeless. The 16th annual auction will be held on eBay from May 31 to June 5. Past auctions have raised approximately US$17.8 million, with last year's winner bidding US$2,166,766.

site_title: Working hard to make a difference
summary: Unilever aims to positively impact one billion people globally by 2020 through its Sustainable Living Plan, which focuses on reducing environmental footprint and increasing social impact. The company has already delivered cost savings and profitable growth through its sustainability efforts, and has become a top employer in the world. Unilever's president for South-east Asia & Australasia, Peter ter Kulve, believes that sustainability is integral to the company's business strategy, driving growth and reducing risks. The company will continue to work with partners to achieve its ambitious sustainability goals, particularly in areas such as deforestation, sustainable agriculture, and universal access to safe drinking water.

site_title: QT Vascular seeks EU clearance for Silk balloon catheter device
summary: QT Vascular has filed an application to the European Union for a CE mark for its Silk balloon catheter device, used to treat blocked coronary arteries. The device, which uses high-strength polymer fibers, is designed to reduce stress on blood vessels during inflation. The CE mark clearance would conform the device to European standards. This announcement comes amidst a patent dispute with AngrioScore, scheduled for trial in the US in September 2015.

site_title: Sinarmas unit obtains preliminary approval for Jakarta IPO
summary: Sinarmas Land's subsidiary, PT Puradelta Lestari, has received preliminary approval for an initial public offering on the Indonesia Stock Exchange, with plans to offer up to 10.8 billion new shares. The offering, led by Macquarie Capital, Sinarmas Sekuritas, and CLSA Indonesia, is expected to close by the end of the month. Pricing has not been set, and the company will use the funds for various purposes.

site_title: Oil hits 2015 highs above US$67 as Libyan output slows
summary: Oil prices surged to 2015 highs above $67 a barrel, driven by protests in Libya that halted oil exports and a strong US dollar. Libyan oil output has dropped to below 500,000 barrels per day, a third of its pre-2010 levels. Hedge funds also increased bets on rising Brent prices, fueling the rally. The oil market is well supplied, with producers pumping more than demand, and OPEC's upcoming meeting is unlikely to restrain output.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close down on Greek fears
summary: Europe's main stock markets closed down on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.84% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index tumbling 2.51%. The CAC 40 in Paris also fell 2.2%. The decline was attributed to concerns over Greece's economic situation.

site_title: Malaysia's Barisan Nasional retains by-election seat with reduced majority
summary: Malaysia's ruling coalition, Barisan Nasional, won a by-election in Rompin, Pahang, with a reduced majority. Hasan Arifin defeated Parti Islam se-Malaysia's Nazri Ahmad by 8,895 votes, with a voter turnout of 73%. The win comes amid dissatisfaction over a new consumption tax and rising living costs, which has led to Prime Minister Najib Razak's declining approval rating. The by-election was triggered by the death of parliamentarian Jamaluddin Jarjis and marks the first of two by-elections this week.

site_title: Greece expects 'no final agreement' at May 11 Eurogroup: Varoufakis
summary: Greek Finance Minister Yanis Varoufakis stated that Greece expects no final agreement at Eurogroup talks on May 11, but considers it a step towards a final deal. Varoufakis visited Brussels and Paris to push for a desperately needed bailout deal. This follows a series of diplomatic efforts by Greek officials to secure a deal, with talks with EU officials to be held on May 11.

site_title: Noble's Q1 profit down 30% to US$106.6m
summary: Noble Group's first-quarter net profit fell 30% to US$106.6 million due to lower commodity prices and underperforming operational associates. Revenues decreased 7.33% to US$16.64 billion, while net fair value on commodity contracts dropped to US$4.2 billion. The company has adopted new disclosure protocols and secured a US$2.25 billion revolving loan facility to refinance debts and fund corporate purposes. Despite a 4.09% increase in stock price before results, Noble has declined 26.1% since February due to accounting criticism.

site_title: Healthway Q1 net profit more than doubles to S$3.5m on disposal gains
summary: Healthway Medical Corp's first-quarter net profit more than doubled to S$3.5 million, driven by gains from selling financial assets. Revenue increased 7.6% to S$23.7 million, while other operating income rose 57% to S$3.1 million. The company expects government programs to boost patient load, preparing to add joint clinics. Shares closed at 5.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Latest earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned that its second-quarter revenue may be below target and operating loss similar to the first half. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. site_title: MM2 Asia FY15 net profit surges 85% with all-round growth
summary: MM2 Asia's FY15 net profit surged 85% to S$5.1 million, driven by 51% revenue growth to S$24.3 million. Production revenue more than doubled to S$15 million, while distribution revenue rose 20%. The company plans to undertake 2-3 projects in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and China in the coming year, with plans to expand its business in Malaysia.

site_title: Gold down on stronger dollar; focus on US jobs data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,187.03 an ounce on Tuesday, amid a stronger US dollar and European shares rising ahead of US nonfarm payrolls data. The Federal Reserve's indication of a recent US economy slowdown as transitory has kept markets uncertain, with speculation over interest rate hikes prolonging gold prices. Analysts predict a rate hike in September, potentially delaying a decline in gold prices.

site_title: EU eyes McDonald's tax probe: official
summary: The European Union is considering a probe into McDonald's alleged sweetheart tax deals with Luxembourg, following information from unions. EU Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said the Commission is looking into the matter, which could be extended beyond its original June deadline. This probe is part of a larger investigation into tax deals between various multinational companies, including Apple, Starbucks, and Amazon. Vestager also mentioned ongoing probes into tax arrangements in Belgium and Poland, citing concerns over state aid and unfair subsidies.

images.alt_text: The EU may probe sweetheart tax deals that US fast food icon McDonald's allegedly agreed with Luxembourg, the bloc's competition chief said Tuesday, adding to a growing list of suspects.

site_title: Head of Coutts Intl set to exit following UBP deal: source
summary: Alexander Classen, head of Coutts International, is set to step down within two to three weeks following a sale to Union Bancaire Privee (UBP), a Geneva-based private bank. Classen, 52, had declined the offer to lead the integration of the two private banks. The sale follows the departure of two regional heads and comes amid increasing regulatory requirements. RBS is keeping Coutts' UK business, which serves the royal family. The purchase is part of UBP's aggressive expansion strategy, but retaining key private bankers is crucial for its success.

images.alt_text: Alexander Classen, chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland's overseas private banking arm, is set to step down shortly following a sale to Union Bancaire Privee (UBP), according to a person familiar with his thinking.

site_title: EU demands concessions as Greece hurtles toward IMF deadline
summary: The European Union is urging Greece to accept concessions to release aid and avoid a cash crunch, with Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras facing pressure to drop opposition to cutting pensions and firing workers. EU finance chiefs warn of a possible breakdown in talks if no deal is reached by May 11, with Greece's liquidity situation becoming increasingly complicated. The IMF has warned of a $1 billion payment deadline looming, and the euro fell for a third day as tensions rise.

site_title: Greek debt only to be discussed after reforms plan: Moscovici
summary: EU Economic and Monetary Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici stated that Greece's debt can only be discussed after Athens agrees on a reforms program with its creditors. The Commission forecasts Greece's public debt to peak at 180.2% this year due to lower-than-expected economic growth caused by political uncertainty. Moscovici emphasized the need for a sustainable and detailed reform program to reduce the debt and aid Greece's economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore Wrap Tuesday
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have pushed back the initial deadline for the completion of a high-speed rail link to 2025, citing the complexity of the project. Noble Group reported a 30% fall in quarterly profit and provided more disclosures related to its fair value contracts. Osim International's first-quarter revenue slid 13% to S$149.8 million due to weakness in massage products. The Straits Times Index (STI) lost 11.51 points, with turnover at its lowest in at least three months, amid weakening prices in line with Hong Kong.

site_title: Osim Q1 net profit down 53% to S$13.5m on massage products weakness
summary: Osim International recorded a 53% decline in Q1 net profit to S$13.5m, due to weakness in its massage products segment. Revenue fell 13% to S$149.8m, with earnings per share down to 1.8 cents. Despite this, the company's GNC health supplements business and TWG Tea segment are stable. A one-cent-per-share interim dividend was declared, unchanged from last year. The decline is attributed to a broad-based slowdown in the massage products segment, with the launch of new products expected to drive momentum in the future.

site_title: US service sector picks up speed in April: ISM
summary: The US service sector experienced a surge in April, with the Institute for Supply Management's (ISM) purchasing managers index for services rising to 57.8 from 56.5 in March, indicating expansion. Business activity, new orders, and hiring also increased, with the ISM's service sector index rising to 61.6, up 4.1 points from March. This improvement in the service sector follows a first-quarter slowdown, suggesting a possible rebound in the US economy.

site_title: Plunging China trade loans test Singapore banks
summary: Singapore banks, which have increased their China credit exposure, were hit by a decline in China trade financing deals as mainland borrowing conditions became easier and offshore interest rates grew more expensive. DBS Group reported a $7 billion decline in first-quarter trade loans, with the majority linked to China. Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp and United Overseas Bank also experienced quarter-on-quarter drops in trade loans, primarily due to China. The outlook for China trade loans is weighed down by the country's slowing economy and weak commodity trade, with loan growth expected to be in the mid-single digit range this year.

site_title: FAST transaction limit to increase to S$50,000 from S$10,000
summary: Singapore banks will increase the Fast And Secure Transfers (FAST) limit to S$50,000 starting May 8. The service, introduced in March 2014, allows for fast and secure transfers of Singapore dollar funds between banks. The increase is part of a growing trend in digital banking services.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q1 net profit trebles to S$46.45m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a net profit of S$46.45 million for Q1 2015, tripling the S$14.97 million net profit in the same period last year. Revenue jumped 149% to S$198.19 million, driven by growth in property development and property investment. The company's earnings per share rose to 3.89 cents and net asset value per share increased to 37.33 cents. The stock closed unchanged at 52.5 cents.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: France, Saudi discuss multi-billion-euro projects
summary: France and Saudi Arabia are discussing multi-billion-euro economic projects, including armament, energy, and infrastructure deals, worth tens of billions of euros. French Foreign Minister Laurent Fabius stated that agreements are being finalized in the coming months, with prospects for nuclear power cooperation and health services also being discussed. French President Francois Hollande is attending a Gulf leaders' summit in Saudi Arabia, following the signing of a 6.3 billion euro warplanes deal with Qatar.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby shelves US$500m motor business IPO plan
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Bhd, the world's largest listed palm oil firm, has indefinitely postponed an initial public offering of its automotive business that could raise up to US$500 million. The company had initially deferred the IPO to the second half of 2015 but now plans to delay it further until the market is more conducive for the exercise. Sime Darby hired several major banks to work on the IPO last year.

site_title: HSBC says HQ review is an objective look at facts, not a threat
summary: HSBC's CEO Stuart Gulliver said a review of the bank's headquarters in Britain was an objective look at economics, not a threat. The review was prompted by investors' concerns about a rise in Britain's bank levy, which would affect HSBC's commitment to making its dividend progressive. Gulliver stated that the review was about examining facts, not making a threat, as investors sought the best place for its headquarters.

site_title: Morgan Stanley warns it could lose US$292m in sub-prime suit
summary: Morgan Stanley has warned it could lose approximately US$292 million in a lawsuit filed by Deutsche Bank over sub-prime mortgages. Deutsche Bank claims Morgan Stanley knowingly passed on toxic mortgages with an original principal balance of US$735 million. A New York court has rejected Morgan Stanley's attempts to dismiss the suit, and the bank may incur additional costs, interest, and fees. The lawsuit could result in significant losses for Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Spain records biggest fall in April jobless claims in almost 20 years
summary: Spain's jobless claims declined by 118,923 to 4.33 million in April, the largest drop in almost 20 years, according to government data. This is the third consecutive month of falling unemployment. On a seasonally adjusted basis, the number of registered unemployed fell by 50,160. The decline represents a 7.5% decrease from April 2014, the strongest in 19 years. This positive trend in unemployment is consolidating, according to Deputy Labour Minister Engracia Hidalgo, as Spain's economy continues to recover from recession.

site_title: Noble Group Q1 profit falls 30%; offers more disclosures
summary: Noble Group reported a 30% decline in Q1 profit to $393 million due to the roll-off of short-term contracts in its oil liquids division. The company provided more disclosures on fair value contracts, integrating previously only included in its annual report. Noble rejected claims of improper accounting from Iceberg Research, with which it has a history, and has started legal action against the researcher. The company's shares have lost 32% since Iceberg's reports were issued in mid-February.

site_title: Swiber confirms plans to call perpetual bonds
summary: Swiber Holdings confirmed plans to call its 9.75% perpetual bonds due on September 25, despite concerns over its ability to meet debt obligations. The company has repurchased and cancelled $750,000 in principal amount, leaving $79.25 million outstanding. This move aims to demonstrate commitment to calling the bonds, which could reduce investor concerns. The company has sufficient financial resources to fulfill its debt obligations this year, according to Swiber.

site_title: BBR Q1 net profit drops 83.2% on slower general construction sales
summary: BBR Holdings reported a 83.2% drop in Q1 net profit to S$848,000 due to a 35.7% decline in revenue to S$91.8 million. General construction sales and margins decreased, while specialized engineering revenue increased. The company's gross profit margin fell to 7.1% from 7.9%. BBR's order book is approximately S$555 million, with most projects in Singapore and Malaysia. The industry outlook remains challenging, and the company's shares closed at 26 Singapore cents.

site_title: Update: Singapore, Malaysia push back deadline for high-speed rail link
summary: Singapore and Malaysia have pushed back the initial 2020 deadline for the high-speed rail link between the two cities, citing the project's complexity. Both prime ministers hope to reach a new agreement by the end of 2015 on a revised timeline, which aims to cut travel time between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur to 90 minutes. The project, initially set to be completed by 2020, now faces a five-year construction timeline, with design and tendering processes taking an additional year each.

site_title: MDR and Pixio expand in Myanmar with new large-format printing business
summary: MDR Limited and its subsidiary Pixio have expanded into Myanmar's large-format printing business. Pixio Myanmar Co will provide graphic design solutions and large-format digital inkjet production for advertisements and promotional signages. The company sees opportunities in Myanmar's growing market, driven by international brands entering the country. This marks Pixio's first expansion beyond Malaysia and MDR's second entry into Myanmar, following its 2013 introduction for Nokia products.

images.alt_text: Fiona Lam

site_title: IS claims Texas shooting, first attack on US soil
summary: The Islamic State (IS) claimed responsibility for the first attack on US soil, a shooting in Texas that left two gunmen dead after they opened fire on a security guard at a cartoon contest mocking the Prophet Mohammed. The event, organized by the American Freedom Defense Initiative, was attended by Dutch far-right politician Geert Wilders and AFDI co-founder Pamela Geller. The White House condemned the attack, stating there is no form of expression that justifies violence. The incident drew parallels to the January mass shooting at Charlie Hebdo in Paris, but commentators noted the difference in motivations and context.

site_title: Eurozone raises growth outlook for 2015 to 1.5 per cent
summary: The European Union raised its growth outlook for the eurozone in 2015 to 1.5%, citing cheap oil and a weak euro as factors. Consumer prices are expected to rise by 0.1% in 2015, avoiding deflation. The European Central Bank's unprecedented stimulus appears to be having an effect.

site_title: Greece economy in sharp downturn over past 3 months: EU
summary: Greece's economy experienced a sharp downturn over the past three months, according to the European Commission's Spring forecasts. The EU slashed its 2015 growth forecast for Greece to 0.5%, a significant reduction from its earlier prediction of 2.5%. This development raises concerns as Athens continues to negotiate with EU-IMF creditors.

site_title: EU energy boss seeks a deal on new Ukraine gas supply package before summer
summary: European Commission Vice President Maros Sefcovic aims to conclude talks with Ukraine and Russia by summer to ensure gas supply security for next winter. The talks, brokered by the European Commission, aim to extend a temporary deal until arbitration can agree a permanent solution, expected in late 2016. Ukraine is seeking to reform its energy infrastructure as part of EU conditions for support. Sefcovic hopes to conclude by the summer, after a temporary deal secured by the Commission last year expired.

site_title: China's exports face growing pressure: trade ministry
summary: China's exports face growing pressure due to sharp gains in the yuan following currency devaluations by some countries. The Ministry of Commerce stated that China's economy still faces challenges this year, with trade flows, especially exports, under increased pressure. The ministry vowed to keep the yuan at a "basically stable" level.

site_title: Greece willing to move ahead on key asset sales to appease lenders: source
summary: Greece is willing to move ahead with key asset sales, including a 1.2 billion-euro deal with Fraport to run regional airports and a majority stake in Piraeus port. The government aims to secure aid from EU and IMF lenders by making concessions. Athens plans to announce the regional airports deal by May 15 and invite shortlisted investors to submit binding offers for a 51% stake in Piraeus port by July. China's Cosco Group is among the preferred bidders for the port stake, with the option to raise their stake to 67% over five years.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says sees stronger growth in Q2
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects stronger economic growth in the second quarter after a slowdown in the first quarter. The bank attributes the improvement to government spending and infrastructure projects, which are expected to rise in the April-June period. The bank maintains its full-year growth forecast at 5.4-5.8 per cent, citing the influence of infrastructure projects on achieving this rate. The country's GDP rose 4.71 per cent in the first quarter, its weakest annual pace since 2009.

site_title: China sets rules to lure private investment in infrastructure
summary: China has introduced rules to protect private investors and expand opportunities in infrastructure projects, aiming to revitalize its stuttering economy. The National Development and Reform Commission has opened up major infrastructure projects, including energy, transportation, and water management, through franchises. Private investors can participate in build-operate-transfer models, with contracts based on up to 30-year loans and access to private equity, strategic investment, and bonds. The move aims to alleviate local governments' heavy debts and boost economic growth, as China's GDP growth slowed to a six-year low of 7% in the first quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong March retail sales fall 2.9% as tourism takes hit
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales fell 2.9% in March from a year earlier, driven by a decline in mainland Chinese tourists and tighter visa rules. The drop in tourism, combined with reduced import taxes on certain goods, has constrained retail sales performance. Jewelry, watches, and clocks sales also declined 18.6% in March, with some retailers scaling back operations due to sluggish business. The decline in tourism has been attributed to political tension in Hong Kong, including democracy demonstrations and harassment of mainland shoppers.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong retail sales fell 2.9 per cent by value in March from a year earlier, underscoring the impact of a drop in mainland Chinese tourists and tighter visa rules on residents from Shenzhen who visit the Asia financial centre.

site_title: HSBC profits up 4% as investment bank revenues bounce back
summary: HSBC reported a 4% increase in profits to $7.1 billion in the first quarter, driven by a 4% rise in underlying revenues and an 8% increase in markets income. Investment banking revenues bounced back, offsetting a rise in compliance and regulation costs. Underlying operating costs rose 6% from a year ago, partly due to an increase in compliance staff. This surpasses the average forecast from analysts polled by the company.

site_title: India to sign port deal with Iran, ignoring US warning against haste
summary: India is set to sign a port deal with Iran, despite US warnings against haste, as Prime Minister Narendra Modi pushes to develop trade ties with Central Asia. The deal, worth billions of dollars, aims to build a port at Chabahar, near Iran's border with Pakistan, to cut transport costs and freight time. India has already spent $100 million on a road in western Afghanistan to link up with the port. The move is seen as a strategic effort to circumvent Pakistan and open up a route to landlocked Afghanistan, with potential benefits for Indian exporters and investors.

images.alt_text: India will push ahead this week with plans to build a port in southeast Iran, two sources said, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi keen to develop trade ties with Central Asia and prepared to fend off US pressure not to rush into any deals with Iran.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 9.15 points higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market ended 9.15 points higher, closing at 1,827.42 on the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index. The index saw 1.8 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.93 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 434 to 362.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to reach most new targets by 2018, JPMorgan says
summary: Deutsche Bank is expected to reach most of its targets by 2018, according to JPMorgan analysts. The bank aims to achieve a return on tangible equity and reduce leverage, with analysts predicting these goals will be met by the end of 2018. However, Deutsche Bank still needs to provide more details on its cost-cutting plans to meet its goal of 3.5 billion euros in annual gross savings.

site_title: Fed cooperating with probe on leak: Yellen
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen said the central bank is cooperating with the Justice Department's probe into alleged leaks of confidential information in 2012 ahead of a crucial monetary policy meeting. The leaks, carried out by Medley Global Advisory, a Financial Times unit, revealed the Fed's plans to stimulate US economic growth. Yellen denied she revealed sensitive information during a meeting with Medley Global Advisors in June 2012, and asked lawmakers not to release the names of staffers targeted in the internal investigation until it's completed.

site_title: Oil near 2015 high above US$66 after Libya port shuts
summary: Oil prices rose above $66 a barrel on Tuesday, nearing 2015 highs, after the Libyan port of Zueitina was shut down, reducing oil exports. Libyan oil output is now less than 500,000 barrels per day, a third of its pre-2010 levels. A strong dollar also weighed on oil prices, while hedge funds raised their bets on rising Brent prices. The rally has led banks to raise forecasts for oil prices, citing momentum and a spot price low, amid ongoing civil war in Yemen and concerns over Middle East oil supplies.

site_title: Asset manager Aberdeen hit by heavy outflows
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management reported 11.3 billion pounds in net outflows in the first half of its financial year, largely due to investors pulling money from emerging markets amid concerns of increased market volatility. The company posted a 25% rise in underlying profit to 270.2 million pounds, despite a 1.6% increase in total assets. Aberdeen announced a share buyback and interim dividend, but shares were down 2.1% following the disappointing outflows. The company's Chief Executive, Martin Gilbert, warned that emerging markets are likely to weigh on performance in the short term.

site_title: Lufthansa narrows operating loss helped by cheaper fuel
summary: Lufthansa reported a narrower operating loss in the first quarter, primarily due to cheaper fuel. The airline's adjusted loss before interest and tax was 167 million euros, slightly better than analyst forecasts. Despite this improvement, Lufthansa's Chief Financial Officer stated that further action is needed to lower costs, particularly due to rising pension burdens and staff-related expenses. The airline confirmed its target for 2015 adjusted earnings before interest and tax of over 1.5 billion euros.

site_title: Australia's central bank cuts interest rate to 2 per cent
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia, cut the official cash rate by 25 basis points to a new record low of 2.0% on May 5, 2015, amid a soft economic outlook. The decision was the first easing since February and aims to reinforce recent encouraging trends in household demand. Governor Glenn Stevens stated that the inflation outlook provided the opportunity for monetary policy to be eased further.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat after RBA rate cut; NZ rises
summary: Australian shares ended flat after the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) cut its cash rate for the second time this year, sparking uncertainty about the easing cycle. The RBA noted some economic improvement but did not mention further action might be necessary. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% to finish the session. The RBA's decision follows a peak of 5,901.8 points earlier in the day, which was later erased.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end at two-week low on mainland sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 1.3% to a two-week low, led by Chinese enterprises, amid a sell-off in mainland markets. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 27,755.54, while the China Enterprises Index fell 2.6%. The sell-off was triggered by a fresh wave of share listings and tightened rules for margin financing in Chinese markets, which saw its biggest loss in nearly four months.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: European stock markets opened with mixed results, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.61% to 7,028.44 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index dipped 0.38% to 11,576.12 points and the CAC 40 in Paris shed 0.15% to 5,074.42 points. The divergence follows a long weekend in London.

site_title: China: Shares close down more than 4%
summary: Chinese shares closed down over 4% on Tuesday due to investors fleeing the market amid growing risk concerns and liquidity issues. The Shanghai Composite Index plummeted 4.06% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.79%. Over 20 companies plan to issue new shares this week, draining funds from the market. Analysts attributed the decline to a recent rapid market rally and state media warnings of market risks.

images.alt_text: Chinese shares closed down more than four per cent on Tuesday, as investors fled the market on worries over growing risk following a recent rally and concerns about liquidity, dealers said.

site_title: Diverging monetary policies a risk of instability: ECB's Noyer
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) governing council member Christian Noyer warned that diverging monetary policies between the euro zone and the US could lead to instability in financial markets. The ECB has committed to keeping interest rates low, while the US Federal Reserve is expected to begin withdrawing its stimulus. Noyer emphasized the need for vigilance towards financial market volatility, citing the potential for markets to react quickly to new information.

site_title: KFC to take a bite of Myanmar market
summary: KFC plans to open its first branch in downtown Yangon, Myanmar, becoming the first major US fast food retailer in the country. The move comes as Myanmar braces for an influx of international food outlets following the end of military rule in 2011. KFC has over 15,000 restaurants globally and will join US firms such as Coca Cola and Pepsi, and carmakers Chevrolet and Ford, which have already established a presence in the country. The opening is expected to happen by the end of the year, with several more restaurants planned.

site_title: Tsunami warning issued as magnitude 7.5 earthquake hits off PNG
summary: A magnitude 7.5 earthquake struck off Papua New Guinea, triggering a tsunami warning for coastal communities 137km south of Kokopo. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Center reported hazardous waves possible within 300km of the epicenter. The region is prone to earthquakes and tsunamis due to its location where three tectonic plates meet.

site_title: Indonesia: Stocks turn negative, rupiah wilts after weaker-than-expected Q1 GDP
summary: Indonesia's benchmark stock index fell 0.1% after weaker-than-expected Q1 GDP data, erasing early gains. The GDP expanded 4.71% in January-March, down from 5.01% in the previous quarter. The rupiah weakened to 13,030 per US dollar, its weakest since April 1. Analysts had expected a 4.95% growth rate.

site_title: Broker's Take: 'Buy' call on Thai Beverage
summary: OCBC Investment Research has issued a "buy" call on Thai Beverage, targeting a price of S$0.81. The company's shares rebounded off a near two-year key uptrend support and significant trading volume, with the relative strength index rebounding above its historical strong support level. This suggests the upside momentum could be picking up again, indicating potential for further gains.

site_title: Jurong East to be terminus here for Singapore-KL high speed rail
summary: Singapore's terminus for the high-speed rail link to Kuala Lumpur will be in Jurong East, part of the Jurong Lake District. The original 2020 timeline is now considered unrealistic, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

site_title: Oil prices down in Asian trade
summary: Oil prices in Asia declined on Tuesday, falling 12 cents to $58.81 for US West Texas Intermediate and 18 cents to $66.27 for Brent crude. The drop was attributed to low trading volumes, with few new developments to track. Dealers will focus on the US stockpiles report on Wednesday. Oil prices rose last week after a decline in US petroleum stocks, but remain down due to a global supply glut.

site_title: China to stop setting most medicine prices from June 1
summary: China will remove price caps for most medicines from June 1, allowing the market to set prices and encouraging "reasonable" pricing. The move aims to control costs in state medical insurance schemes and improve purchasing mechanisms for drugs.
