site_title: Euro zone factory growth eases in April
summary: Euro zone manufacturing growth eased in April, reaching 52.0 in Markit's final PMI survey, below the 10-month high of 52.2 in March. However, factories raised prices for the first time in eight months, and headcount rose at the fastest pace in nearly four years. The increase in output and employment suggests inflationary pressure, which is welcomed by the European Central Bank, particularly as it may have a marginal impact on growth. This data supports the ECB's quantitative easing programme, which has already shown dividends in restoring economic growth and combating deflation.

site_title: foodpanda raises another US$100m; total funding tops US$310m
summary: Foodpanda has raised an additional US$100 million in funding, bringing its total funding to over US$310 million. The latest round, led by Goldman Sachs, will be used to expand delivery activities and improve customer experience across 40 markets. This follows a series of recent investments, including the launch of a premium delivery service in Singapore and the acquisition of rival sites in seven markets. Foodpanda partners with over 60,000 restaurants globally and operates in over 580 cities in 40 markets, mostly emerging markets.

site_title: Seoul: Won posts sharpest daily loss in 2 month on China fears; shares up
summary: The South Korean won plummeted 0.6% against the dollar, its sharpest daily loss in two months, due to concerns over China's weakening economy and its impact on South Korea's exports. China's factories experienced their fastest drop in activity in a year, prompting worries about the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks start the day slightly higher
summary: European stock markets opened slightly higher on Monday, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rising 0.46% and Paris' CAC 40 adding 0.28%. This follows a cautious Asian market rally, as most markets were closed for public holidays. The US stock market also reached fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to new highs.

site_title: Singapore: Stocks weaken in low volume
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.69 points to 3,482.7 on the first trading day of May, following a 11-point gain on April 30. Low trading volume, with 1.5 billion units traded, contributed to the weakness. The dollar value of the index's 30 components was S$279 million, about 27% of overall business. This marks a decline from a month ago, with the advance-decline score also indicating a soft market.

site_title: ExxonMobil shuts Singapore petchem units for maintenance
summary: ExxonMobil has started maintenance at its Singapore Chemical Plant, expected to last a few weeks, without specifying which units are involved. The maintenance is part of the company's scheduled maintenance and will not impact production, with customers being informed to meet their business needs. The plant, which includes two steam crackers, produces hydrocarbon products such as ethylene and propylene, essential building blocks for plastics.

images.alt_text: ExxonMobil has started maintenance at its Singapore Chemical Plant (SCP) due to last "a few weeks", a spokeswoman said on Monday, without giving details of the units involved at the company's largest integrated petrochemical complex.

site_title: Macau April gambling revenue plunges record 39% from year ago
summary: Macau's April gambling revenue plummeted 38.8% from a year ago, marking the 11th consecutive monthly decline. The drop was attributed to a crackdown on corruption in China, targeting illicit money outflow, affecting the territory's casino industry. Revenues fell to 19.167 billion patacas ($3.2 billion) in April, down from 31.318 billion patacas in the same period last year, with analysts expecting a decline of around 38-40%. Macau's casino hub remains a significant player, with revenues still 6 times that of Las Vegas.

site_title: Emirates to introduce new first-class cabin this year
summary: Emirates plans to introduce a new first-class cabin this year, offering more privacy at "commercially viable" rates. The premium product, centered around the bedroom concept, will initially be rolled out on Airbus A380 planes, followed by Boeing 777s. The move comes after Etihad Airways unveiled the Residence cabin on its A380s last year, featuring a dedicated butler and three rooms. This new product aims to compete with the exclusive Etihad offering.

site_title: Indonesia inflation picks up to 6.79% y-o-y in April
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rose to 6.79% in April, driven by rising food prices, according to the statistics bureau. This is in line with analyst expectations of 6.80%. The consumer price index increased 0.36% from the previous month, while annual core inflation remained stable at 5.04%.

site_title: Global labour glut sinks US wages
summary: The US labor market is experiencing a global labor glut, suppressing wage growth and limiting policy makers' efforts to reduce labor-market slack. Experts suggest increasing training and education of US workers to provide skills unavailable elsewhere to employers. The Federal Reserve's accommodative monetary policies may have less influence on wages due to faster economic growth being offset by cheaper alternatives abroad. The US economy added 3.1 million workers last year, but the number of part-timers remains higher than before the recession, and those unemployed for 27 weeks or more make up a larger share of the jobless.

site_title: Facebook launches open Internet.org platform
summary: Facebook has launched an open Internet.org platform, allowing developers to create content and applications for low-income and rural areas in emerging markets. The platform, open to developers who meet certain guidelines, aims to boost efforts to get people online. Launched in nine countries, including India, the Internet.org application offers free access to basic internet services, Facebook's social network, and messaging services. This move comes after a debate in India over free access and net neutrality, and Facebook has emphasized that its platform promotes bringing people online while respecting net neutrality principles.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as hope of rate cut offsets bank woes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% on Monday as investors focused on potential interest rate cuts, outweighing concerns over the bank sector. Westpac Banking Corp's disappointing interim result sparked worries about its rivals, but a strong afternoon session lifted the S&P/ASX 200 index to 5827.5. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5%. The market's optimism was fueled by the prospect of a rate cut on Tuesday, which would boost the economy and potentially lift shares.

site_title: Indonesia's manufacturing activity shrinks for 7th straight month in April
summary: Indonesia's manufacturing sector contracted for the seventh consecutive month in April, with the purchasing manager's index (PMI) at 46.7, the lowest reading since 2011. Export orders and domestic demand remained weak, leading to a decline in output and employment, with employers shedding staff for the ninth straight month. The sector's fragility was attributed to global market pressures, including a weaker rupiah and increased costs of imported raw materials.

site_title: ANZ to sell loans worth US$6.5b in dealer finance biz
summary: ANZ Australia is selling its Esanda dealer finance business, worth A$8.3 billion (US$6.51 billion), as part of efforts to manage capital efficiently and focus on ANZ-branded products. The sale excludes other businesses and follows regulatory pressure to free capital. An information memorandum is expected to be issued to potential bidders later this month, with the bank posting first-half earnings on Tuesday.

images.alt_text: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group on Monday said it plans to sell its Esanda dealer finance business, which includes A$8.3 billion (US$6.51 billion) in loans to motor vehicle dealers.

site_title: China's leadership shuffle at Big Oil clears path for reform
summary: China is preparing to shuffle the leadership of its biggest oil companies, PetroChina, Sinopec Group, and China National Offshore Oil Corp, in a bid to accelerate market-driven reform and address corruption. The changes, which could be announced as early as this week, are part of President Xi Jinping's overhaul of the nation's state sector. New leaders will be tasked with steering the oil giants through Xi's anti-corruption campaign and a decline in global crude prices, potentially paving the way for industry-wide reform and a shift towards more market-driven decision-making.

site_title: Germany's manufacturing sector growth slows in April
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector experienced a slowdown in April, with Markit's purchasing manager's index (PMI) dropping to 52.1 from 52.8 in March. Despite this, the sector remained in good shape, with growth above the 50 line separating growth from contraction for a fifth consecutive month. The decline was attributed to a shift in momentum, with economist Oliver Kolodseike stating that the sector "shifted down a gear in April."

site_title: Greece aims for deal with lenders, IMF hard on reforms: minister
summary: Greece aims to meet its debt payments this month and reach a deal with international lenders, including the IMF, to unlock remaining bailout aid. However, the IMF insists on tough labor reforms, including pension cuts and mass layoffs, which the Greek government has resisted. The country faces a cash crunch, with nearly 1 billion euros in debt repayments due this month. Greek Labour Minister Panos Skourletis stated that the IMF is unyielding on its demands, while negotiations with lenders have made headway in recent days.

site_title: Philippines central bank says current policy settings remain appropriate
summary: The Philippine central bank's Governor Amando Tetangco stated that current policy settings remain appropriate, despite global economic adjustments. Tetangco expects market volatility to be transitory and believes inflation is near the target range, with strong demand conditions. The central bank will meet on May 14, keeping the overnight borrowing rate steady at 4% after maintaining it in March.

site_title: PUB and Suez Environnement to research smart-water technologies
summary: PUB and Suez Environnement have partnered to research smart-water technologies in Singapore, supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board. Three projects will focus on wastewater treatment, storm-water management, and automated meter reading, utilizing information and communication technologies to develop a smart-water grid. The collaboration aims to enhance water sustainability and encourage consumer behavior towards water conservation.

site_title: BOJ's Kuroda says won't hesitate to adjust policy: Jiji News
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that he will not hesitate to adjust the central bank's quantitative easing program if inflation does not meet its 2% target by the first half of fiscal 2016. The expected timeline was pushed back due to falling oil prices and lackluster consumer spending. Kuroda initially believed that inflation would start rising again due to a narrowing output gap, but two board members disagree, predicting it won't reach 2% until early 2018. Private-sector economists also speculate that the BOJ may ease policy later this year.

site_title: Taiwan's April PMI falls to 49.2; output, new orders slide
summary: Taiwan's manufacturing sector experienced a decline in output and new orders in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 49.2, its first contraction in 20 months. Output and new orders declined for the first time in four months, with reduced client demand and lower production requirements contributing to the decline. The sector may struggle to return to growth territory in the near future, according to HSBC economist John Zhu.

site_title: Indian manufacturing growth slows on weaker demand in April
summary: India's manufacturing growth slowed in April due to weaker domestic demand, despite factories cutting prices for the first time in nearly two years. The HSBC Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 51.3, marking its 18th month above the 50 level. Manufacturers reduced selling prices and staffing levels, but failed to attract new orders. The data supports expectations of a Reserve Bank of India interest rate cut soon, as inflation and manufacturing slow.

site_title: China's Xi calls for "equal" political talks with Taiwan
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping offered "equal" talks to Taiwan's ruling Nationalist Party chairman Eric Chu, but only if Taiwan accepts it is part of China. This is a concept many Taiwanese oppose. The meeting, in Beijing's Great Hall of the People, marks the first between the leaders of the old rivals in six years. China considers Taiwan a renegade province to be brought under its control by force if necessary. The talks aim to resolve their political differences, but the outcome is uncertain due to Taiwan's reluctance to accept China's sovereignty claim.

site_title: CASE issues warning on investing in overseas properties
summary: The Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) has issued a warning about investing in foreign properties, following 13 complaints from consumers who lost over S$100,000. The complaints were received in 2013 and 2014. CASE advises investors to exercise caution and thoroughly research the property market before making a decision.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open up 0.14%
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened up 0.14% on Monday, following a rally on Wall Street, with the Hang Seng Index rising 39.38 points to 28,172.38. Chinese shares also traded higher, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index increasing 0.01% and 0.40% respectively. The gains were attributed to modestly expanding manufacturing activity in China and positive Wall Street trends.

site_title: Brent falls towards US$66, China factory activity falls
summary: Brent crude fell towards US$66 a barrel on Monday as weak Chinese factory activity and near-record OPEC supplies stoked demand fears. China's factory activity dropped to 48.9 in April, indicating a contraction, while OPEC supplies reached a two-year high of 31.04 million barrels per day. This has put output above forecasts of demand for its oil in the first half of 2015. Despite a 40% recovery in Brent crude since its near six-year low in January, the market remains concerned about oversupply.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up on overseas markets, weak PMI caps gains
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, despite a weak manufacturing activity reading, marking the first contraction in 20 months. The HSBC PMI for April showed a sluggish start for the tech-driven economy in the second quarter. Financial stocks, particularly those with ties to China, drove gains, while the electronics and semiconductor sectors declined. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar, closing at T$30.681.

site_title: After record IPO year, Australian listings shrink to almost nothing
summary: Australian initial public offerings (IPOs) have significantly declined after a record year, raising only $327 million in the first quarter of 2015, down 96% from the previous year. This drop reflects investors' cautious mood amid a commodities bust and China's weakening economy. The average IPO size has decreased to $30 million, with only one large listing and numerous small ones. Investors are holding onto private businesses longer, seeking a more profitable exit, and some are selling small stakes to the public.

site_title: New guidelines on investment ads to be implemented by end-2015
summary: The Advertising Standards Authority of Singapore (ASAS) plans to implement new guidelines on investment ads by the end of 2015. The guidelines aim to enhance disclosure standards and tackle misleading advertisements. ASAS is working with media owners, the Monetary Authority of Singapore, and the Council for Estate Agencies to strengthen the existing advertising code. The proposed enhancements include raising disclosure standards and measures to deal with repeat offenders. The move aims to improve transparency and fairness in investment advertising.

site_title: ACCA names Singapore office chief as new Asia-Pacific director
summary: The Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) has appointed Leong Soo Yee, the head of its Singapore office, as the new Asia-Pacific director. Leong will support the development of the accountancy profession in nine markets, including Australia, New Zealand, and Southeast Asia, and explore partnerships to create fresh training opportunities for 163,000 ACCA members and students. This appointment aims to strengthen ACCA's presence in the region and meet growing demand for finance professionals with international skills.

site_title: Asia: Bourses cautious after mixed leads from Wall Street, China
summary: Asian markets made cautious gains on Monday after Wall Street finished last week on a positive note, with Hong Kong up 0.14%, Seoul up 0.38%, and Shanghai making marginal gains. However, Sydney fell 0.11% as the Australian dollar slipped due to expectations of another interest rate cut. The mixed news on China's economic front weighed on markets, despite official data showing a modest expansion in manufacturing activity in April.

site_title: Prudential names Mike Wells as its new CEO
summary: Prudential has named Mike Wells as its new CEO, succeeding Tidjane Thiam, effective June 1, 2015. Wells, who has served on Prudential's board since 2011, previously led its US subsidiary Jackson National Life Insurance Company. He brings 29 years of experience in life insurance, retirement services, and asset management. Wells' basic salary is £1.07 million, with a maximum bonus opportunity of 200% of base salary. The company praises Thiam for his exceptional contribution to the group's success over six years.

site_title: China says climate change threatens major projects
summary: China's top meteorologist, Zheng Guoguang, warned that climate change threatens major infrastructure projects, citing recent weather disasters such as floods, typhoons, and heatwaves. The country's rate of warming is higher than the global average, posing a threat to projects like the Three Gorges Dam and a high-altitude railway to Tibet. This warning highlights the growing concern about climate change's impact on China's infrastructure and development plans.

images.alt_text: Climate change threatens some of China's most important infrastructure projects, China's top meteorologist warned in a state newspaper, adding the country's rate of warming was higher than the global average.

site_title: Brokers' Take: 'Neutral', 'hold' calls on UOB
summary: RHB Research has maintained a "neutral" call on UOB's shares with a target price of S$25.40, citing a 6% Q1 2015 operating profit improvement and decent loan growth. KGI Fraser also maintained a "hold" call with a revised target price of S$24.18, citing UOB's high capital adequacy ratio and defensive position. Both analysts believe limited upside exists due to the stock's high valuation.

site_title: Swiber repurchases S$0.75m of senior perpetual securities
summary: Swiber Holdings repurchased S$0.75 million of its senior perpetual securities in the open market, with the settlement to be paid on Tuesday. The repurchased securities will be cancelled, reducing the outstanding principal amount to S$79.25 million. This follows the issuance of S$80 million 9.75% senior perpetual securities in September 2012.

site_title: China April HSBC PMI shows biggest drop in factory activity for a year
summary: China's factory activity plummeted in April, with the HSBC/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 48.9, the lowest level since April 2014. This marks the biggest drop in factory activity for a year, fueling concerns about a flagging economy. New orders and manufacturing employment contracted, while deflationary pressures persisted. Economists expect Beijing to roll out more stimulus measures to support the slowing economy, which has grown at a 7% annual rate in Q1.

images.alt_text: China's factories suffered their fastest drop in activity for a year as new orders fell in April, a private business survey showed on Monday, hardening the case for fresh policy stimulus to boost a flagging economy.

site_title: China's economy seen slowing to 6.8% in Q2: state think tank
summary: China's economy is expected to slow to 6.8% in Q2, a six-year low, according to a state think tank. This follows a six-year low of 7.0% in Q1 and recent data that have failed to impress. The think tank attributes the slowdown to structural reform and urges more stimulus to prevent a sharper downturn. The forecast comes after China's central bank cut the amount of cash banks must hold as reserves in an effort to boost growth.

site_title: German train drivers call week-long strike
summary: German train drivers from the GDL union announced a week-long strike starting Monday, affecting freight and passenger trains. The strike, the eighth in 10 months, aims to resolve contentious wage negotiations. The 43-hour walkout last month led to the cancellation of two-thirds of long-distance trains, costing Deutsche Bahn 150 million euros. The strike is set to end on May 10.

site_title: Japan and Malaysia: Financial markets closed Monday for public holidays
summary: Financial markets in Japan and Malaysia were closed on Monday for public holidays. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investor optimism despite tariff uncertainty. A Dutch firm made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share.

images.alt_text: Financial markets in Japan and Malaysia are closed Monday for public holidays.

site_title: South Korea March adjusted current account surplus falls vs Feb
summary: South Korea's current account surplus fell to $9.32 billion in March from a revised $10.77 billion in February, still higher than the one-year average of $7.92 billion. The financial account saw a net outflow of $11.02 billion, up from $5.54 billion in February. The decline was attributed to lower oil costs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ramba Energy, Tuan Sing Holdings
summary: Ramba Energy plans to sell 14.9% stake to Indonesian tycoon for S$18.4 million to repay debt. Developer Tuan Sing Holdings' net profit more than doubled to S$15.9 million, driven by strong performance from its property division, with revenue surging 153% to S$155.3 million in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed Ramba Energy has said it plans to sell a 14.9 per cent stake in the company to an Indonesian tycoon for S$18.4 million in gross proceeds to repay debt and for other uses.

site_title: WE Holdings requests for lifting of trading halt
summary: WE Holdings requested the Singapore Exchange to lift its trading halt, following an April 28 request, to facilitate discussions on a proposed transaction. The company had sought the halt to discuss the proposed transaction.

site_title: QT Vascular issues update on patent-claim lawsuit
summary: QT Vascular's board has reaffirmed its position on the ongoing patent-claim lawsuit against AngioScore, Inc, stating the CEO's initial public offering (IPO) document's information remains valid and won't impact the company's financial position or profitability. The probability of a permanent injunction is minimal, as AngioScore does not practice the '119 Patent. A new design of Chocolate PTA is expected to reduce patent-related risks, and the company does not face intellectual property (IP) risks. The patent claim is scheduled for trial in September 2015.

site_title: AIG is reducing its risk, says CEO
summary: AIG CEO Peter Hancock suggests the insurer is reducing its risk, potentially paving the way to exit the "systemically important financial institution" (SIFI) status. Hancock attributes the measures to strengthening the balance sheet. AIG's first-quarter profit was $1.22 a share, slightly better than predicted. Hancock expressed willingness to work with Fed regulators, finding the SIFI status less objectionable.

site_title: Australian regulator says no signs of misconduct around A$ trading
summary: The Australian Securities & Investment Commission (ASIC) found no signs of market misconduct in the recent trading of the Australian dollar ahead of Reserve Bank of Australia interest rate decisions. Preliminary findings attributed the spikes to normal market operations in an environment of lower liquidity. Most of the trading was linked to automated trading accounts for risk management, not misconduct. The ASIC stated that the reduction in liquidity providers is a usual occurrence prior to announcements in all markets. No evidence of manipulative trading was found.

site_title: Singapore: Shares open slightly lower on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 1.09 points or 0.03% to 3,486.30, following a sluggish start for Asian stocks. The weak opening follows global economic news, including the US jobs report and Australian inflation report, which suggest the Reserve Bank of Australia may implement a further rate cut. Losers outnumbered gainers 81 to 78, with 92 million shares worth S$75.4 million changing hands.

site_title: Brokers' Take: 'Buy' calls on OCBC follow its Q1 results
summary: Brokerages RHB Research and KGI Fraser have maintained their "buy" calls on OCBC shares following the bank's Q1 FY2015 earnings results. Despite loan growth and net interest margin slippage, the analysts see progress in OCBC's Greater China strategy and solid asset quality. They set target prices of S$11.70 and S$11.63, respectively, citing potential for growth from OCBC Wing Hang's China operations integration and reduced interbank assets.

site_title: South Korea April manufacturing activity contracts further, PMI falls to 6-mth low
summary: South Korea's manufacturing activity contracted for a second month in April, with the HSBC/Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) falling to a 6-month low of 48.8. New export orders also declined, marking the lowest level in six months. The economy's recovery remains at risk due to weak shipments and lower oil prices, which have led to the fourth straight monthly decline in exports. The Bank of Korea kept interest rates unchanged in April, despite policymakers expressing optimism about growth in private consumption.

site_title: China: Stocks drop with Aussie, copper on weak PMI as gold gains
summary: China's stocks dropped 1.2% as a private factory gauge showed a faster-than-estimated contraction, while copper futures slid 0.9%. The Shanghai Composite Index fell, and gold climbed 0.4%. The US dollar rebounded against major peers, with two Federal Reserve officials suggesting interest rate hikes could occur at any time. The US oil price dropped 0.6%, and the Aussie dollar lost 0.5%. The Chinese economy is expected to slow to 6.8% growth in the second quarter.

site_title: China conglomerate Fosun to merge insurer in US$1.84b deal
summary: China's Fosun International Ltd is planning a US$1.84 billion merger with Ironshore Inc, a Bermuda-based insurer. Fosun's unit Mettlesome Investment 2 will combine with Ironshore to boost its presence in the insurance business. The deal comes as Fosun, backed by Chinese billionaire Guo Guangchang, continues its acquisition spree in the US market, which it sees as "vibrant" despite recent asset price increases.

site_title: Greece cites progress in talks with EU/IMF lenders, aims for May deal
summary: Greece reported progress in talks with EU/IMF lenders, aiming for a deal by May. A government official stated that key steps were taken at the Brussels Group talks, bringing an agreement closer. Technical teams from Athens and lenders are set to resume talks on Monday. Greece's Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras met with the country's chief negotiators, and all parties aim to reach an agreement at a Brussels Group level by May.

site_title: Japan to increase investment in Asian infrastructure
summary: Japan plans to increase investment in Asian infrastructure, aiming to encourage high-quality economic growth in the region. Finance Minister Taro Aso announced the move at the Asian Development Bank's annual meetings in Baku, Azerbaijan. The plan could potentially put Japan at odds with China, which is setting up the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB). Japan has chosen not to join the AIIB, citing concerns over lending practices, while the US has also declined to participate. The exact size of Japan's investment is not disclosed.

images.alt_text: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso said on Sunday his country's government will increase investment in Asian infrastructure at a meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), according to Kyodo News.

site_title: Startups try to challenge Google, at least on mobile search
summary: Startups are challenging Google's dominance in mobile search, citing the unique way people interact with their phones and the fragmented mobile ecosystem. Companies like Vurb, Quixey, and URX are developing new search engines and features that leverage mobile-specific technologies, such as deep links and location-based queries. Venture capitalists have invested hundreds of millions of dollars in these startups, which could lead to increased funding and new entrants in the mobile search market. Google, however, remains committed to its search business and is reimagining its search engine for mobile phones, with initiatives like voice search and Google Now.

site_title: Twitter's streaming app creates piracy of year's biggest fight
summary: Twitter's Periscope streaming app enabled users to pirate the highly-anticipated fight between Floyd Mayweather and Manny Pacquiao, with many posting about watching the event for free. Executives from HBO and Showtime asked Periscope to take down the streams, but the company's CEO, Dick Costolo, praised Periscope as the night's victor. This incident highlights a potential problem with live-streaming apps and pay TV, and regulators may struggle to regulate such piracy, according to media adviser Shelly Palmer.

site_title: Who's run ahead among large caps
summary: The Singapore Institute of Directors and the National University of Singapore Business Schools's Centre for Governance, Institutions and Organisations released the full rankings of the 100 largest Singapore-listed companies, assessing them for financial years ending between April 1, 2013 and March 31, 2014. The top performers among large caps include companies such as DBS Group, OCBC Bank, and UOB, with DBS Group ranking highest overall. The assessors urged Singapore companies to improve their corporate governance practices.

site_title: Execs close to Charter reach out to Time Warner Cable on merger: WSJ
summary: Top executives at Charter Communications Inc. have reached out to Time Warner Cable Inc. to discuss a possible merger, according to the Wall Street Journal. Charter's chairman, John Malone, called Time Warner Cable's CEO, Rob Marcus, in recent days to express interest in pursuing friendly deal talks. This comes after Time Warner Cable rejected Charter's unsolicited approaches last year and after Comcast's US$45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable failed. The companies' bitter exchanges have ended, and Time Warner Cable is now open to merger discussions with Charter.

site_title: Saudi Arabia to restructure oil giant Aramco
summary: Saudi Arabia is restructuring state-owned oil giant Aramco, separating it from the oil ministry, in a move aimed at giving the company more autonomy. Analysts expect this change to pave the way for Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, a son of King Salman, to become oil minister, potentially leading to a generational shift in Saudi energy policy. The restructuring also aligns with the king's efforts to promote his son Mohammed bin Salman, deputy crown prince, as a key player in economic strategy.

site_title: Australia inflation gauge slows further in April: TDMI
summary: Australia's private inflation gauge slowed further in April, rising 0.3% from March, and annual inflation eased to 1.4%, below the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band of 2-3%. This moderation suggests the RBA may cut interest rates this week, with a 64% probability of a move, according to interbank futures. Non-tradable inflation, driven by domestic prices, also slowed to 1.8% in April, its lowest reading in a decade, and underlying inflation eased to 1.4% and 2.3% respectively.

site_title: China insuring US$16 trillion deposits means more bond risk-reward
summary: China has launched an insurance system for its over $21.3 trillion in bank deposits, aiming to shield savers from potential losses. This move is part of the government's plan to allow market forces to play a greater role in the bond market, potentially leading to interest rate liberalization. The introduction of deposit insurance is expected to increase credit defaults and lead to higher bond yields. The government aims to ensure that reforms don't worsen economic growth, which has been the weakest since 1990, following two recent debt failures.

site_title: Love-in for health service looms large in British election
summary: The National Health Service (NHS) is a top concern for British voters ahead of the May 7 election, with 47% of Britons listing it as their top priority. The NHS, launched in 1948, is cherished by nearly one million daily users who receive free care. Prime Minister David Cameron has pledged to plug the estimated £8 billion funding gap by 2020, but the opposition Labour Party has promised to spend £2.5 billion more. Despite being underfunded, the NHS is considered cost-effective, ranking among the world's top five employers.

site_title: HSBC mulls HQ move: China ties, taxes are key
summary: HSBC is considering moving its headquarters from London to China due to the bank's significant tax savings, which could reach $900 million or more per year. The decision is influenced by the UK's bank levy, which HSBC pays $1.5 billion this year, and the potential increase to over $2 billion if the Labour Party wins the upcoming general election. A move would require Beijing's backing, but could raise concerns with US regulators. The bank's Asia-based operations have been growing, with 63% of profits coming from the region in the last two years.

site_title: Americans stream away in shifting TV landscape
summary: The US streaming television market is mainstream, with over half of Americans using internet TV services. While streaming has grown, it hasn't led to a significant decline in traditional pay TV subscriptions, with only a 0.2% loss over the past two years. Streaming services like Netflix, Hulu, and Sling TV offer a range of options, including live programming, but analysts believe on-demand TV will become dominant in the next 10-20 years, potentially impacting traditional pay TV revenue.

site_title: Flat April continues market's tale; all eyes on Friday's jobs report
summary: The US stock market ended the month of April flat, with major indexes showing little change, despite market volatility. The Federal Reserve's interest-rate schedule remains uncertain, with traders interpreting its Wednesday statement as a potential delay in a rate hike. Biotech stocks and utility stocks were among the best performers last year, driven by the Fed's low-interest-rate policy, but may be vulnerable to a rate hike. The jobs report on Friday will be crucial in determining the market's direction, with a strong report potentially leading to a rate hike and a decline in these sectors.

site_title: Corporate purchases surge, buybacks plunge
summary: Corporate purchases surged in Singapore, with 12 companies making 17 purchases worth S$4.6 million in April 27-30, up sharply from the previous week. In contrast, buybacks plummeted, with only one company, Pacific Century Regional Developments, posting a single transaction. Significant shareholder purchases were recorded in Haw Par Corporation, TTJ Holdings, Keppel Corporation, and others, with some companies' share prices rising significantly after the purchases. This is the first time since February that directors abstained from making sales in the market, indicating a lack of sellers.

site_title: Tesla's announcement shows the coming revolution in energy storage
summary: Tesla announces the Tesla Powerwall, a home battery product to store energy from solar panels or back up homes against blackouts. The battery has a capacity of 7-10 kilowatt hours and costs $3,500-$3,000. Tesla also plans to produce larger batteries for businesses and utility companies. The company's massive battery-making "gigafactory" will drive down prices, and its partnership with Solar City gives access to a bigger pool of customers. Energy storage could lead to a true energy revolution and a greener planet, with benefits including improved grid reliability, reduced fossil fuel use, and increased renewable energy integration.

site_title: William and Kate: royal parents with a modern image
summary: Prince William and Kate, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, have completed their journey from student sweethearts to regal domesticity after the birth of their second child. The couple has cultivated an image as down-to-earth parents, with William's hands-on approach and Kate's battles against morning sickness gaining public respect. Their decision to keep their family life private has helped attract a new generation of royal support, with backing for the monarchy at 80%, its highest level in decades.

site_title: China, Japan, S Korea still committed to policies that support demand
summary: Asian central bankers from China, Japan, and South Korea reaffirmed their commitment to implementing policies to support demand amid moderate and uneven global growth. The joint statement noted the global economy's uncertain phase and urged caution in monetary policy settings to minimize negative spillovers. The three economies, which have historically driven global growth, are struggling to maintain momentum, with China's growth slipping to a six-year low and Japan's growth still subdued. Policymakers will continue to assess whether stimulus measures are needed, with South Korea's growth rate expected to be similar to 2014.

site_title: Hitting the spicy notes
summary: Long Chim, a new Thai restaurant, offers spicy dishes that may burn customers' stomachs but provide a masochistic pleasure. Located at #02-02, Atrium 2, Long Chim serves Thai cuisine that will leave a lasting impression.

site_title: Lawmakers, safety advocates slam new rules for US oil trains
summary: Federal regulators have unveiled new rules for transporting crude oil by trains, aiming to improve rail safety and reduce the risks of a catastrophic event. The regulations introduce a new tank car standard with better protections and mandate the use of electronically controlled brakes. However, critics argue that the rules do not go far enough, and some provisions would be costly and yield few safety benefits. The Department of Transportation has set a three-year deadline to replace the oldest, least safe tank cars with new ones, while later-generation cars will need to be retrofitted or replaced by 2020.

site_title: Taiwan ruling party 'optimistic' about joining AIIB
summary: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang party is optimistic about joining the Beijing-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB), despite China's previous rejection of Taiwan's bid as a founding member. The party's head, Eric Chu, expressed optimism during a visit to Shanghai, where he met with Chinese President Xi Jinping, and proposed that Taiwan join under the name "Chinese Taipei". China has considered Taiwan part of its sovereign territory since 1949, but relations have warmed in recent years.

site_title: BNP Paribas to pay US$8.9b in US sanctions violation case
summary: BNP Paribas was sentenced to five years probation and ordered to forfeit $8.83 billion and pay a $140 million fine for violating sanctions against Sudan, Cuba, and Iran. The settlement resolves claims of $8.9 billion.

site_title: Adidas CEO: Q1 results will show firm is 'back in full swing'
summary: Adidas CEO Herbert Hainer defended his record, stating that Q1 results will show the company is "back in full swing." Despite facing calls to step down due to profit warnings and losing ground to Nike, Hainer's contract runs until 2017. The company has launched a search for a successor, but Hainer remains in charge.

site_title: EU expects to get Turkmenistan natural gas by 2019
summary: The European Union expects to receive natural gas from Turkmenistan by 2019, as part of its efforts to lessen its dependence on Russia for energy supplies. This move comes amid Russia's annexation of Crimea and involvement in the Ukraine conflict, increasing the EU's urgency to find alternative energy sources.

site_title: US$ advances to 2-week high vs yen; euro dips
summary: The US dollar reached a two-week high against the yen, rising 0.7% to 120.24 yen, driven by mixed US economic reports that showed strong consumer sentiment but weak manufacturing and construction. Yields on long US Treasury debt hit seven-week highs, attracting investors to the greenback. The euro slipped 0.2% to $1.1196, as fears of deflation in Europe eased. The dollar index gained 0.7%, its best daily gain in a month, as investors viewed the dollar as oversold.

site_title: Markets struggling to make headway at key levels
summary: Major market indices, including the Dow Jones and S&P 500, struggle to surpass key psychological levels of 18,000 and 2,100, respectively. The Straits Times Index is also unable to convincingly pierce 3,500. Investors' hesitation is attributed to uncertainty over the US economy and interest rates, as well as the effectiveness of monetary policy in lifting economies. Despite this, liquidity has shifted to blue chips, with banks and major companies such as Keppel Corp and Singtel experiencing increased interest, while penny stocks are losing momentum.

site_title: Predictably unpredictable
summary: A study analyzing GDP forecasts over the years found that early estimates are often significantly off the mark. On average, estimates made in the last quarter of the previous year were 3.3 percentage points off the actual growth rate, with a median margin of error of 2.4 percentage points. This large margin of error is attributed to the volatility of economic conditions and the complexity of predicting both economic growth and inflation. The study concludes that early GDP growth forecasts should be taken with caution.

site_title: Britain's boring election reaches gripping finale
summary: Britain holds a general election on Thursday, with Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservatives virtually tied with Ed Miliband's Labour in opinion polls. The outcome could decide whether Britain stays in the European Union and whether Scotland remains in Britain, potentially triggering unprecedented political instability. This is the tightest election in living memory, with Professor Philip Cowley predicting the biggest change in the British party system in over 100 years.

images.alt_text: Britain's Prime Minister David Cameron (center) meets with members of the public as he arrives to deliver an election speech at the Ambleside Sports Club in Nuneaton, Britain on May 3, 2015.

site_title: Business schools: A global vision
summary: Asian business schools must position themselves as global centers of excellence, not just regional ones, to remain relevant in the rapidly changing business landscape. They should focus on developing adaptive business strategies, managing diversity and intercultural relations, and incorporating Asian business philosophies and Confucian values into their curriculum. Hands-on work experience through internships is also crucial. However, rankings systems often fail to account for the Asian context, making it difficult for local schools to compete with Western institutions. To differentiate themselves, Asian business schools should emphasize entrepreneurship education, alongside management and leadership training, to prepare students for the future.

site_title: Strategy: More than a board game
summary: A company's strategy is crucial for long-term success, yet 34% of directors lack understanding of their company's strategy. Effective boards should separate roles, identify key topics for discussion, and allocate time for strategy development. The board's role is to positively contribute to strategy, approve the plan, support management's execution, and review performance. A well-defined board position and agenda-setting are key to strategy impact. Boards should also establish a tracking mechanism to monitor progress and mitigate risks.

site_title: Quake devastates Nepal's rich cultural heritage
summary: A 7.8-magnitude earthquake struck Nepal on April 25, devastating the country's rich cultural heritage and leaving the Kathmandu Valley's three former royal squares in ruins. The squares, dating back to the division of the valley into three Hindu kingdoms, were at the heart of local life and a major tourist draw. The earthquake damaged 90% of Nepal's heritage sites, with UNESCO expressing concern over the loss and urging the government to protect the sites. Local authorities are working to salvage artifacts and rebuild monuments, with detailed drawings and architectural plans available for reconstruction.

site_title: Uncertainty persists over which party will form the next UK coalition
summary: The UK is likely to experience another coalition government after the general election on May 7, 2015, with either David Cameron leading a Conservative coalition or Ed Miliband heading a Labour coalition. Despite the Liberal Democrats' forecasted loss of seats, they are expected to be kingmakers. Polls show the Conservatives and Labour are neck and neck, with both parties falling short of a majority. A Labour-Lib Dem coalition would be a minority government, while a Conservative-Lib Dem coalition would still be short of a majority. The outcome remains uncertain, with both parties likely to seek support from minority parties post-election.

site_title: No rest for Warren Buffett even after 50 years at Berkshire
summary: Warren Buffett celebrated his 50th anniversary as CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, expressing optimism about the company's long-term prospects despite potential economic turbulence. Buffett fielded questions from shareholders, analysts, and journalists for five hours, giving no hints about his succession plans. He praised the turnaround at Burlington Northern railroad and offered ringing praise for the turnaround at Geico car insurance, but defended Berkshire's Clayton Homes unit amid criticism of predatory sales practices. Buffett also defended Berkshire's operations, stating he would not want someone with only investing experience to become CEO.

site_title: Buffett: stock prices would be high if rates were 'normal'
summary: Warren Buffett stated that if interest rates returned to "normal" levels, stock prices would appear expensive. He expressed his surprise at the prolonged low interest rate era and its potential impact on the economy. Buffett also praised China as a rising superpower, noting its population's ability to unlock its potential and its drive against corruption. He favored using the earned income tax credit to address income inequality in the US.

site_title: Prices mostly rise on weak dollar and US economy
summary: Commodity prices rose last week, driven by a weak US dollar and uncertain interest rate outlook. The US economy posted a 0.2% GDP growth, below forecasts, and the Federal Reserve left open the timing of an interest rate hike. Oil prices surged to new 2015 highs, with Brent crude rising to $66.19 a barrel, as the dollar weakened against the euro. Precious metals, including gold and silver, fell, while base metals like copper and aluminium rose. The dollar's decline made dollar-priced commodities cheaper for buyers using stronger currencies, stimulating demand.

site_title: FAA mulling over commercial drone initiatives: sources
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is discussing partnerships with drone makers and service providers to test commercial drones that can fly beyond an operator's visual line of sight. This technology, known as beyond-visual-line-of-sight (BVLOS), is currently banned due to safety concerns. The FAA is considering allowing BVLOS operations under restricted conditions, such as in remote areas, and may set out plans for partnering with industry in the coming weeks. This move aims to develop unmanned aircraft for various business applications and could lead to the acceptance of BVLOS technology in new commercial drone regulations within the next two years.

site_title: Digital, social media consultancy power Weber Shandwick growth
summary: Weber Shandwick, a global public relations firm, is relying on digital communications and social media expertise to drive growth. The company is hiring employees with digital expertise from various backgrounds to craft unique ideas and react to events in real-time. This shift is expected to boost the firm's topline growth, with digital and social media fueling two-thirds of its growth over the past few years.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Shell, Total to align trading and refining units to drive profits
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and Total are restructuring their refining and trading operations to drive profits, aligning their units as oil prices fall and independent trading houses expand. The move aims to optimize profits from fluctuating crude oil prices and products. Shell plans to move traders to Rotterdam and lay off dozens, while Total beefs up its Geneva trading hub. The restructuring has already led to improved first-quarter profits for both companies, with Shell reporting an extra $1 billion in profits last year.

site_title: Siemens healthcare unit probed by China regulator for bribery: sources
summary: China's State Administration for Industry and Commerce (SAIC) investigated Siemens' healthcare unit over alleged bribery of hospitals to buy expensive disposable products used in medical devices. The probe, which involved up to 1,000 hospitals, accuses Siemens and its dealers of violating competition law by donating medical devices in exchange for exclusive agreements to buy chemical reagents. Siemens has declined to comment on the investigation, and it is unclear if any action will be taken against the company or dealers.

site_title: Elektromotive's investment chairman quits amid restructuring review
summary: Elektromotive Group's investment chairman, Tan Choon Wee, resigned on May 1 amid a restructuring review. The decision has no impact on the company's financial reporting practices, according to the Singapore Exchange. Tan, who has been a director at Elektromotive since 2006, held significant shares in the company but cited "other commitments" as the reason for his resignation. The company is considering restructuring its business and has appointed PrimePartners Corporate Finance as its financial adviser.

site_title: Petronas offers Canada aboriginals almost US$1 billion to back LNG
summary: Petronas, a Malaysian state-owned energy producer, is offering the Lax Kw'alaams First Nation in Canada's Pacific Coast approximately US$950 million over 40 years to approve a natural gas export terminal project. The deal includes incentives from the provincial government and gas pipeline developers. The project aims to ship gas reserves from Canada's westernmost province to growing energy markets in Asia. The 3,600-person community will vote on the incentive package this month, with the deal seen as a multi-generational opportunity for the aboriginal community.

site_title: Najib in Singapore for leaders' retreat
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak is in Singapore for a two-day leaders' retreat with Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The retreat is expected to announce the location of Singapore's terminal station for the proposed high-speed rail link to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The three possible locations are Tuas West, Jurong East, and the city centre. Malaysia has already confirmed its terminal will be in Bandar Malaysia, about 5km from Kuala Lumpur's Petronas Twin Towers. The project aims to complete the 320-340km rail link by 2020, reducing travel time between Singapore and KL to 90 minutes.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Mr Najib and Mr Lee at the Singapore Sports Hub last August. Aiming to foster warmer bilateral relations, their meeting this week will be their sixth retreat since their first one back in 2007.

site_title: Hang Seng warrants: traders complain
summary: A group of professional traders in Singapore has complained to the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) about Macquarie Capital Securities' (MCS) pricing of Hang Seng Index (HSI) warrants. The traders alleged that MCS's pricing was "erratic" and "unfair," with warrants often not moving in line with the underlying index. MCS is the designated market maker for these warrants. The complaints, submitted between November 2014 and March 2015, listed dozens of instances of alleged price discrepancies, and the MAS is awaiting SGX's findings.

site_title: Crowdfunding comes to S'pore real estate
summary: Singapore's real estate market has seen the emergence of crowdfunding platforms, which "matchmake" property deals between investors and developers. Two platforms, CoAssets and DomaCom Singapore, are already available, while a third, FundPlaces, will launch by end-May. These platforms offer investors access to real estate deals, but critics argue that the high risks and lack of robust regulations pose significant challenges. Developers remain wary, preferring traditional funding sources, and consultants doubt that real estate crowdfunding will become mainstream in the near future.

site_title: Hoping to resuscitate a portion of Atlanta's heart
summary: Atlanta's Underground Atlanta complex, a 12-acre area of viaducts and storefronts, is set for a major makeover after being revitalized with a $25.8 million purchase by a South Carolina development company, WRS. Plans include adding 900 apartments, a supermarket, and renovating the below-street-level mall. The goal is to attract residents, as the city's population boom drives demand for urban living, with the BeltLine and Ponce City Market also transforming downtown Atlanta. The project aims to revitalize the area, which has been criticized for being "tacky" and "costly."

site_title: Global bank regulators seek more risk controls around algo trading
summary: Global bank regulators are urging banks to implement more stringent controls around algorithmic trading, citing concerns that risk controls may not keep pace with the increasing complexity of electronic trading. The Senior Supervisors Group, including the US Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, notes that a small error at an algorithmic trading firm could have a significant impact on the financial markets. The group recommends transparent, firm-wide risk management practices to mitigate systemic risk. This comes after high-profile errors in 2010 and 2012 that resulted in significant losses for financial institutions.

site_title: Leadership switch at top Chinese oil firms
summary: China is preparing to shuffle the leadership of its top oil companies, CNPC, Sinopec Group, and CNOOC, as part of President Xi Jinping's plan to overhaul the nation's state sector and promote market-driven reform. Current leaders Zhou Jiping and Fu Chengyu will be replaced, with new chairmen and executives taking over, aiming to accelerate reform and steer the companies through the anti-corruption crackdown and low crude prices. The changes are part of Xi's efforts to scale back the oil companies' monopoly and deepen reform of the state-owned sector.

site_title: Shell, Total align trading and refining units to drive profit growth
summary: Royal Dutch Shell and Total are merging their refining and trading operations to boost profits. The restructuring aims to optimize profits from fluctuating crude oil prices and products. Shell plans to move traders to Rotterdam, while Total is expanding its Geneva trading hub. The move is expected to increase profits, with Shell reporting $1 billion in extra earnings last year. This strategy is a response to independent trading houses expanding into their territory and the increasing unprofitability of oil companies' refining operations.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: Thousands still missing
summary: Thousands of people remain missing in Nepal following last week's earthquake, which killed 6,250. Up to 1,000 Europeans are unaccounted for, mostly in remote trekking areas. EU Ambassador Rensje Teerink expressed concern, stating that many backpackers don't register with their embassies, and it's unclear whether they're safe or have left the country. The Nepalese government is seeking information from embassies, but officials are frustrated by the lack of communication.

site_title: US on track to reach deals on forex rigging as soon as May
summary: US authorities are nearing agreements with five major banks over foreign exchange market rigging allegations, potentially exceeding a $4.3 billion fine paid by six banks last November. Talks are at an advanced stage, and the banks are likely to plead guilty to criminal charges, including antitrust violations. The settlements could be reached as early as the second half of May.

site_title: Euro's slide pays off for many European firms
summary: The euro's 22% drop against the US dollar in the past four quarters has given European companies a competitive edge, boosting profits and sales. Companies like Bayer, L'Oreal, and Sanofi have raised their forecasts due to the currency move, with L'Oreal expecting a 9.3% sales boost. The weaker euro has also helped European stock markets outperform US indexes this year, spurring acquisitions and benefiting companies outside the euro region, such as Swedish manufacturers. Investors remain optimistic about the currency's beneficial effects lasting.

images.alt_text: Bayer raised its 2015 sales and profit forecasts on Thursday because of the euro's drop; if exchange rates as of March 31 persist throughout the year, L'Oreal would get a 9.3% boost in sales, it said on April 20.

Bayer raised its 2015 sales and profit forecasts on Thursday because of the euro's drop; if exchange rates as of March 31 persist throughout the year, L'Oreal would get a 9.3% boost in sales, it said on April 20.

site_title: Buffett celebrates 50th year at Berkshire
summary: Warren Buffett celebrated his 50th year as CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, expressing optimism about the company's long-term prospects. The annual meeting featured Q&A sessions with Buffett and his deputy Charlie Munger, addressing questions on Berkshire's business practices, including those of owned firms like 3G Capital. Over 40,000 attendees celebrated the occasion, with Buffett calling it "Woodstock for Capitalists." Despite his retirement, Buffett remains confident in Berkshire's future.

site_title: It's unanimous: Mayweather defeats Pacquiao in mega-fight
summary: Floyd Mayweather defeated Manny Pacquiao in a closely contested welterweight bout, retaining his perfect record and solidifying his legacy as one of the best boxers of his generation. Mayweather's defensive skills and reach advantage allowed him to outmaneuver Pacquiao, landing 148 of his 435 punches. The Filipino boxer, 36, showed flashes of his explosive form but ultimately fell short. The highly anticipated bout, which generated massive hype and revenue, will be remembered as one of the richest fights in boxing history, with Mayweather's victory cementing his status as the sport's top star.

site_title: Are those assets . . . real?
summary: Companies may manipulate their financial statements, similar to individuals undergoing plastic surgery, to present a more favorable picture. This can occur through revenue recognition, where companies may incorrectly report revenues, and overstating receivables, which can lead to assets being overvalued. A case in point is Eratat Lifestyle, a China-based footwear and apparel designer, which was found to have overstated its receivables and engaged in "cosmetic surgery" by setting off renovation subsidies against outstanding trade receivables balances. This practice can be misleading to investors and may not be outright fraud. Investors should scrutinize financial statements to ensure accuracy and trust the numbers presented.

site_title: Nepal earthquake: No possibility of finding more quake survivors
summary: Nepal's government ruled out finding more survivors from last weekend's massive 7.8-magnitude earthquake, which killed 6,621 and injured 14,023, as rescue efforts continued without a successful pull of survivors since Thursday evening. The quake devastated Kathmandu and neighboring countries, with over 100 fatalities reported in India and China. Multiple teams from 20 countries are using sniffer dogs and heat-seeking equipment, but no one has been pulled alive from the rubble.

site_title: Ramba to sell 15% stake to Indon tycoon for S$18.4m
summary: Ramba Energy plans to sell 14.9% of its shares to Indonesian tycoon Dr. Clement Wang Kai's Wing Harvest for S$18.4m. The placement will be at 27 Singapore cents per share, a 9.1% discount to its previous volume-weighted average price. Proceeds will be used to repay debt, fund the oil and gas business, and cover working capital. The deal is seen as a vote of confidence in Ramba's strategy and management team, with the founder of Mayapada Group expressing optimism for the company's future.

site_title: Japan inflation up but spending still weak
summary: Japan's inflation rate rose to 2.2% in March, its first increase in 10 months, but household spending still fell 11% year-over-year, the worst on record. Policymakers are likely to expand monetary easing to boost prices, as the central bank's 2% target is still not met. The Bank of Japan has pushed back its inflation target timeline to the first half of 2016, citing steady price trends despite a delay.

site_title: Wilmar said to take record sugar delivery on ICE
summary: Wilmar International, a Singapore-based company, took a record 1.9 million metric tons of sugar from New York, with 37,611 contracts representing 112,000 pounds each. The majority of the sugar came from Brazil, amid a global glut that has led to a 28% decline in sugar prices over the past 12 months. Industry experts say the large delivery is not indicative of demand in the cash market, with global production expected to exceed demand by 620,000 tons in the next 12 months.

site_title: World's biggest oil company names new CEO in Saudi reshuffle
summary: Saudi Aramco, the world's largest oil company, has made significant leadership changes, including the appointment of Amin Nasser as interim CEO. King's son, Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman, leads a new 10-member supreme board, replacing the dissolved Supreme Petroleum Council. Khalid al-Falih, who replaced Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi, will oversee the board. The changes aim to enhance coordination and centralization of authority, following the death of King Abdullah. Analysts predict that the new leadership will maintain Saudi Arabia's near-record oil output.

site_title: Berkshire profit climbs 9.8% on insurance investments, railroad
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reported a 9.8% increase in first-quarter profit, driven by higher investment income at insurance operations and results from the BNSF railroad. Net income rose to $5.16 billion, beating analyst estimates. Berkshire's stable of profitable businesses and its broad exposure to the US economy are seen as positives, despite recent US economic data showing a near-halt in GDP growth. Buffett continues to invest in businesses, including a recent deal to purchase Kraft Foods Group Inc. and a planned $6 billion capital budget for the BNSF railroad.

site_title: New York Times not giving up on print just yet
summary: The New York Times is not giving up on print advertising, despite declining revenue. CEO Mark Thompson stated that while digital business is the future, the company will continue to defend print advertising due to its economic importance. Despite a 6.8% drop in Monday-Friday print circulation and 5.2% drop in Sunday circulation, the Times reported a 14.2% increase in digital circulation. Print ad sales fell 11% in the quarter, while digital ad revenue increased 10.7%. The company believes it is doing better in print advertising than competitors.

site_title: More elbow room as United shuffles jets
summary: United Airlines is shifting 10 Boeing 777-200s from international routes to the US market, increasing the percentage of aisle seats for domestic passengers. The wide-body jets offer twice as many aisle seats as narrow-body planes, a benefit for road warriors. United aims to promote cost-efficient flying while serving demand, with the possibility of consolidating flights between hubs. The move separates United from peers and marks a shift towards "up-gauging" in the industry, with some analysts predicting a return to bigger planes on US routes.

site_title: Tesla's announcement shows the coming revolution in energy storage
summary: Tesla Motors has announced a home battery product, the Powerwall, to store energy from solar panels or back up homes against blackouts. The 10 kWh and 7 kWh batteries will cost $3,500 and $3,000, respectively, and will be available for installation. The company also plans to produce larger batteries for businesses and utility companies, including projects with Oncor and Southern California Edison, to increase energy capacity and provide grid backup functionality. This marks a significant shift for Tesla, expanding its focus beyond electric cars to energy storage.

site_title: Bad news piles up for iron ore carriers as China demand seen falling
summary: China's demand for iron ore is expected to decline for the first time since 1995, according to the World Steel Association, with a drop in annual steel consumption. This decrease in demand is expected to impact iron ore carriers, with freight rates no longer covering crew costs. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in Chinese demand, which has grown the most over the past decade. The market's poor performance is expected to lead to a reduction in fleet growth, hastening demolition and idling of ships.

site_title: US orders BNP Paribas to pay US$8.9b in sanctions case
summary: A US judge ordered BNP Paribas to pay a record US$8.9 billion fine to settle US sanctions violations linked to Iran, Sudan, and Cuba. The bank pleaded guilty to criminal charges in June 2014 and agreed to the record penalty. The fine is based on US$6.4 billion in Sudan, US$1.7 billion in Cuba, and US$650 million in Iran. The bank will also pay $140 million in fines and face a five-year probation with a monitor. The Justice Department plans to compensate victims using the fine proceeds.

site_title: US: Stocks rebound from selloff as biotechs, chipmakers rally
summary: US stocks rebounded from a selloff as biotechnology and chipmakers rallied, with the S&P 500 gaining 1.1% to 2,108.29. The Nasdaq Biotechnology Index rose 2.9% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 1% to 18,024.06. Gilead Sciences and Expedia Inc led gains, with Gilead's first-quarter profit exceeding projections and Expedia's quarterly revenue exceeding estimates. The rebound came after a weak week of data, including a manufacturing report showing the weakest pace in almost two years and a drop in consumer confidence.

site_title: Technology and the insidious rise of English 2.0
summary: The article discusses how technology has altered the English language, dubbed "English 2.0." It highlights various examples of words and phrases that have undergone changes in meaning, such as "friend" (now a verb), "unlike" (used for contrast), and "blog" (originally a misspelling of "blob"). The article also touches on how technology has influenced language, with engineers and scientists playing a larger role in shaping the language. The author, a writer, expresses concern that this shift may lead to a loss of traditional English language knowledge.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:

Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, was named OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: McDonald's to reveal comeback recipe: what options are on table?
summary: McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook is set to unveil a plan to revive the chain's sales, which have slumped 2.1% in the US, its worst decline in over a decade. Investors are optimistic about Easterbrook's plan, which may include refranchising, relationship building with franchisees, and menu revamps. Options under consideration include converting to a real estate investment trust, simplifying the menu, and introducing customizable burger platforms. Easterbrook's presentation aims to address the challenges facing the company, including a declining sales slump and strained relationships with franchisees.

site_title: No sign of pick-up in China's April PMI
summary: China's manufacturing sector showed no sign of improvement in April, with the official PMI index remaining flat at 50.1, just above the 50-point mark separating contraction from expansion. Despite recent monetary policy easing, analysts expect more intervention by the government, citing weak demand and stagnant property market. Economists anticipate further reserve ratio cuts and measures to boost targeted investments, with some forecasting a 25 basis points cut to the policy rate in the coming weeks.

site_title: Itochu to boost dividend; eyes 10% rise in profit
summary: Itochu Corp, Japan's third-largest trading house, plans to boost its dividend payout and increase its profit by 10% to 330 billion yen, driven by its growing non-resource businesses. The company aims to expand its profit to 400 billion yen annually by 2017, with a focus on recycling its asset portfolio and generating positive free cash flow. Itochu's strategy to focus outside of commodities has helped expand profit, contrasting with domestic rivals such as Mitsui & Co and Sumitomo Corp, which are slashing earnings targets.

site_title: Who will succeed Armani, Lagerfeld?
summary: Iconic fashion designers Giorgio Armani, Karl Lagerfeld, and Roberto Cavalli are in their 80s, raising concerns about succession. Replacing a superstar designer is challenging, but possible, with recent examples like Nicolas Ghesquiere reviving growth at Vuitton and Hedi Slimane revitalizing Saint Laurent. Companies like Kering and LVMH are building stables of up-and-coming designers to ensure continuity. Meanwhile, Armani's private ownership and lack of clear succession plans create uncertainty, while Chanel's Lagerfeld has a strong team in place but faces the challenge of filling his shoes.

site_title: Alibaba pulls job ad for candidates who look like pornstar
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd withdrew a job advertisement that drew criticism for seeking candidates who resemble a Japanese porn actress to motivate computer programmers. The ad, which was meant to be humorous, was removed after it sparked outrage on Chinese social media for being offensive. The company apologized for any offense caused and stated it is committed to providing equal opportunity and fair treatment to all employees based on merit, without discrimination. The reference to Sora Aoi has been removed, and the job listing now emphasizes that both men and women can apply.

site_title: Ageing Japan turns to its youth as teens set to vote
summary: Japan is set to lower its voting age to 18, allowing teenagers to participate in elections for the first time. This move aims to rebalance the country's age demographics, where older citizens hold significant power. The change is expected to extend the franchise to 2.4 million 18 and 19-year-olds. Critics argue that the current system, known as "silver democracy," disproportionately favors the elderly and has led to a shrinking tax base, while politicians have been hesitant to change due to the voting power of older citizens.

site_title: UK banking sector's prospects look to be getting worse as election looms
summary: The UK banking sector's prospects are worsening ahead of the May 7 election, with lenders facing probes into alleged currency and interest rate-rigging. Despite a £1 trillion bailout in 2008-2009, public confidence in banks is at an all-time low, and banks' efforts to boost profit are being hindered by investigations and new regulations. The industry faces £19 billion in misconduct charges, and banks' profitability has declined, with some reducing their ROE targets due to increased regulation and capital requirements. The sector's problems have persisted for seven years, with investors pressing for change.

site_title: Next GE mainly about leadership renewal: PM
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized leadership renewal as the key issue for Singapore's next general election. He stressed the importance of bringing in new, committed individuals to maintain Singapore's exceptional status.

site_title: Oil producers selling more of future output
summary: Oil producers are hedging more of their future output to sell at higher prices, threatening to slow the biggest monthly price increase since 2009. Producers like Whiting Petroleum and WPX Energy are locking in sales at US$65 a barrel, which could add 500,000 barrels a day by the end of next year. This hedging activity dampens prices, with WTI for June delivery adding 10 cents to US$59.73 a barrel. Analysts warn that this could lock in US production for 2016, potentially slowing the WTI rally.

site_title: PM Lee given the all-clear on prostate cancer
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has been given the all-clear on prostate cancer after a follow-up blood test showed no signs of the disease. His doctors stated that his survival rate is 98% after 15 years, with only a 2% chance of death from the cancer in that timeframe. This news was shared at the May Day Rally, where Lee quipped about the chances, causing laughter from the audience.

site_title: Rio Tinto signals readiness to resume M&As as market bottoms
summary: Rio Tinto signals readiness to resume mergers and acquisitions, its first since 2012, as the mining sector nears the bottom of the cycle. Asset valuations have fallen, and investors may accept acquisitions as a better use of capital than buying back shares. Analysts believe the right asset at the correct valuation and investor backing could lead to a deal. Larger producers, including Argo Investments, see this as an opportunity for companies to buy tier-one assets at lower valuations.

images.alt_text: CHANGE IN ATTITUDE: As recently as February, Rio Tinto's CEO Sam Walsh said the company had no near-term plans for major acquisitions. Now, it is prepared to consider them if it can secure the right asset at the correct valuation and win investor backing.

site_title: S'pore tripartism model not easy to replicate: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country's strong tripartism model, a partnership between the government, employers, and labor unions, is a "precious legacy" that should be protected. While other countries may be able to replicate the structure, building trust among the partners cannot be done overnight, Lee emphasized. This suggests that replicating Singapore's unique approach to tripartism will be challenging.
